<H2>This is PART 1</b>: Introduction and Centers X(1) - X(1000)</H2>
<p style="color:#0000A0" class="auto-style3"> </p>
<center><table border="2">

<tr><td><a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/encyclopedia/ETCPart12.html"</a> <b>PART 12:</b></td> <td>Centers X(22001) - X(24000)</td></tr>

</table></center>
</div><p></p>
<center>
<script language="JavaScript">
document.write("<br>Last update: "+document.lastModified);
</script><br></center> <p></p>
<div class="auto-style2">
</center><br>
<b>Long ago,</b> someone drew a triangle and three segments across it. Each segment started at a vertex and stopped at the midpoint of the opposite side. The segments met in a point. The person was impressed and repeated the experiment on a different shape of triangle. Again the segments met in a point. The person drew yet a third triangle, very carefully, with the same result. He told his friends. To their surprise and delight, the coincidence worked for them, too. Word spread, and the magic of the three segments was regarded as the work of a higher power.
<p>
Centuries passed, and someone <i><b>proved</b></i> that the three medians do indeed concur in a point, now called the <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/class/centroid.html" style="font-style: italic">centroid</a>. The ancients found other points, too, now called the <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/class/incenter.html" style="font-style: italic">incenter</a>, <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/class/ccenter.html" style="font-style: italic">circumcenter</a>, and <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/class/orthocn.html" style="font-style: italic">orthocenter</a>. More centuries passed, more special points were discovered, and a definition of <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/roads.html" style="font-style: italic">triangle center</a> emerged. Like the definition of continuous function, this definition is satisfied by infinitely many objects, of which only finitely many will ever be published. The Encyclopedia of Triangle Centers (ETC) extends a list of 400 triangle centers published in the 1998 book <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/tcct.html" style= "font-style: italic">Triangle Centers and Central Triangles</a>. For subsequent developments, click Links (one of the buttons atop this page). In particular, Eric Weisstein's <a href="http://mathworld.wolfram.com/" style= "font-weight: bold">MathWorld</a>, covers much of classical and modern triangle geometry, including sketches and references.
</p><p>
A site in which triangle centers play a central role is Bernard Gibert's <a href="https://bernard-gibert.pagesperso-orange.fr/index.html" style="font-weight: bold">Cubics in the Triangle Plane</a>. Special points and properties of 4-sided plane figures are closely associated with triangle centers; see Chris van Tienhoven's <a href="https://chrisvantienhoven.nl/9-mathematics/encyclopedia-of-quadri-figures/3-encyclopedia-of-quadri-figures" style= "font-weight: bold">Encyclopedia of Quadri-Figures (EQF)</a>.
<br><br>
<h2>HOW TO USE ETC</h2>
You won't have to scroll down very far to find well known centers. Other named centers can be found using your computer's searcher - for example, search for "Apollonius" to find "Apollonius point" as X(181).
</p><p>
To determine if a possibly new center is already listed, click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page and scroll to "Search 6.9.13". If you're unsure of a term, click <b>Glossary</b>. For visual constructions of selected centers with text, click <b>Sketches</b>. To learn about the triangle geometry interest group, Hyacinthos and other resources, or to view acknowledgments or supplementary encyclopedic material, click <b>Links</b>, <b>Thanks</b>, or <b>Tables</b>.
</p></p>
Under <b>Tables</b>, you can find <b>Search_13_6_9</b> (and two other Searches), which can be used to determine whether a newly discovered point is already in ETC. For such a search, be sure to visit Ron Knott's <a href="http://www.maths.surrey.ac.uk/hosted-sites/R.Knott/Triangle/tricoords.html"> <b>Triangle Convertor for Cartesian, Trilinear and Barycentric Coordinates</b></a>.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view sketches of many of the triangle centers. These are <b>dynamic</b> sketches, meaning that you can vary the shape of the reference triangle A, B, C by dragging these vertices. (For information on Sketchpad, click <a href="http://www.dynamicgeometry.com/" style="font-weight: bold">Sketchpad</a>.) The sketches are also useful for making your own Sketchpad tools, so that you can quickly construct X-of-T for many choices of X and T. For example, starting with ABC and point P, you could efficiently construct center X of the four triangles ABC, BCP, CAP, ABP.
</p><p>
The algebraic definition of triangle center (<a href="http://mathworld.wolfram.com/TriangleCenterFunction.html">MathWorld</a>) admits points whose <i>geometric</i> interpretation for fixed numerical sidelengths a,b,c is not "central." Roger Smyth offers this example: on the domain of scalene triangles, define f(a,b,c) = 1 for a&gt;b and a&gt;c and f(a,b,c) = 0 otherwise; then f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b) is a triangle center which picks out the vertex opposite the longest side. Such centers turn out to be useful, as, for example, when distinguishing between the Fermat point and the 1st isogonic center; see the note at X(13).
</p>
<h3>NOTATION AND COORDINATES</h3>
<p class="auto-style2">The reference triangle is ABC, with sidelengths a,b,c. Each triangle
center P has homogeneous trilinear coordinates, or simply <a href= "http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/trilin.html" style="font-weight: bold">trilinears</a>, of the form x : y : z. This means that there is a nonzero function h of (a,b,c) such that
</p><p>
x = hx', y = hy', z = hz',
<br> <p class="auto-style2">where x', y', z' denote the directed distances from P to sidelines BC, CA, AB. Likewise, u : v : w are <b>barycentrics</b> if there is a function k of (a,b,c) such that
</p><p>
u = ku', v = kv', w = kw',
<br> <p class="auto-style2">where u', v', w' denote the signed areas of triangles PBC, PCA, PAB. Both coordinate systems are widely used; if trilinears for a point are x : y : z, then barycentrics are ax : by : cz.
</p><p>
In order that every center should have its own name, in cases where no particular name arises from geometrical or historical considerations, the name of a star is used instead. For example, X(770) is POINT ACAMAR. For a list of star names, visit <a href="http://www.obliquity.com/skyeye/misc/name.html">SkyEye - (Un)Common Star Names</a>.
</p><hr noshade size="8" width="100%">
<h3>Introduced on May 2, 2019: Writer</h3>
<p>
If you wish to submit one or more triangles centers for possible inclusion in ETC, please click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page, then scroll to and click <b>Search_13_6_9.</b> There, find <b>Writer</b>, to be used for proper formatting.
</p><hr noshade size="8" width="100%">
<h3>Introduced on December 28, 2016: Index of Triangles Referenced in ETC</h3>
<p>
Many triangles are defined in the plane of a reference triangle ABC. Some of them have well-established names (e.g., medial, orthic, tangential), but many more have been discovered only recently.
</p><p>
The <b>Index</b> is authored and updated by Cï¿½sar Lozada. You can access it <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/encyclopedia/IndexOfTrianglesReferencedInETC.html" <b>here</b></a>, and also from <b>Glossary</b> and <b>Tables</b>.
</p><hr noshade size="8" width="100%">
<h3>Introduced on March 21, 2015: Shinagawa coefficients for triangle centers on the Euler line</h3>
Suppose that X is a triangle center given by barycentric coordinates f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b). The Shinagawa coefficients of X are the functions G(a,b,c) and H(a,b,c) such that
</p> <p>
f(a,b,c) = G(a,b,c)*S<sup>2</sup> + H(a,b,c)*S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>.
</p> <p>
For many choices of X, G(a,b,c) and H(a,b,c) are conveniently expressed in terms of the following:
</p> <p>
E = (S<sub>B</sub> + S<sub>C</sub>)(S<sub>C</sub> + S<sub>A</sub>)(S<sub>A</sub> + S<sub>B</sub>)/S<sup>2</sup>, so that E = (abc/S)<sup>2</sup> = 4R<sup>2</sup>
<br>
F = S<sub>A</sub>S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>/S<sup>2</sup>, so that F = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/2 - 4R<sup>2</sup> = S<sub>&omega;</sub> - 4R<sup>2</sup>
</p> <p>
Examples:<br>
X(2) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, 0); i.e., X(2) = 1*S<sup>2</sup> + 0*S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub><br>
X(3) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, -1)<br>
X(4) has Shinagawa coefficients (0, 1)<br>
X(5) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, 1)<br>
X(23) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + 4F, -4E - 4F)<br>
X(1113) has Shinagawa coefficients (R - |OH|, -3R + |OH|)<br>
</p> <p>
A cyclic sum notation, $...$, is introduced here especially for use with Shinagawa coefficients. For example, $aS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$ abbreviates aS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + bS<sub>C</sub>S<sub>A</sub> + cS<sub>A</sub>S<sub>B</sub>.
</p> <p>
Example: X(21) has Shinagawa coefficients ($aS<sub>A</sub>$, abc - $aS<sub>A</sub>$)
</p> <p>
If a point X has Shinagawa coefficients (u,v) where u and v are real numbers (i.e, G(a,b,c) and H(a,b,c) are constants), then the segment joining X and X(2) is giving by |GX| = 2v|GO|/(3u + v), where |GO| = (E - 8F)<sup>1/2</sup>/6. Then the equation |GX| = 2v|GO|/(3u + v) can be used to obtain these combos:
</p> <p>
X = [(u + v)/2]*X(2) - (v/3)*X(3)<br>
X = u*X(2) + (v/3)*X(4)<br>
X = u*X(3) + [(u + v)/2]*X(4).
</p> <p>
The function F is also given by these identities: <br>
F = (4R<sup>2</sup> - 36|GO|<sup>2</sup>)/8 and F = R<sup>2</sup>( 1 - J<sup>2</sup>)/2, where J = |OH|/R.
</p><hr noshade size="8" width="100%">
<h3>Introduced on November 1, 2011: Combos </h3>
<p>
Suppose that P and U are finite points having normalized barycentric coordinates (p,q,r) and (u,v,w). (Normalized means that p + q + r = 1 and u + v + w = 1.) Suppose that f = f(a,b,c) and g = g(a,b,c) are nonzero homogeneous functions having the same degree of homogeneity. Let x = fp + gu, y = fq + gv, z = fr + gw. <b>The (f,g) combo of P and U, denoted by f*P + g*U, is introduced here as the point X = x : y : z (homogeneous barycentric coordinates);
</b>
the normalized barycentric coordinates of X are (kx,ky,kz), where k=1/(x+y+z).
</p><p>
<b>Note 1.</b> If P and U are given by normalized trilinear coordinates (instead of barycentric), then f*P + g*U has homogeneous trilinears fp+gu : fq+gv : fr+gw, which is symbolically identical to the homogenous barycentrics for f*P + g*U. The normalized trilinear coordinates for X are (hx,hy,hz), where h=2*area(ABC))/(ax + by + cz).
</p><p>
<b>Note 2.</b> The definition of combo readily extends to finite sets of finite points. In particular, the (f,g,h) combo of P = (p,q,r), U = (u,v,w), J = (j,k,m) is given by fp + gu + hj : fq + gv + hk : fr + gw + hm and denoted by f*P + g*U + h*J.
</p><p>
<b>Note 3.</b> f*P + g*U is collinear with P and U, and its {P,Q}-harmonic conjugate is fp - gu : fq - gv : fr - gw.
</p><p>
<b>Note 4.</b> Suppose that f,g,h are homogeneous symmetric functions all of the same degree of homogeneity, and suppose that X, X', X" are triangle centers. Then f*X + g*X' + h*X'' is a triangle center.
</p><p>
<b>Note 5.</b> Suppose that X, X', X'', X''' are triangle centers and X', X'', X''' are not collinear. Then there exist f,g,h as in Note 4 such that X = f*X' + g*X'' + h*X'''. That is, loosely speaking, every triangle center is a linear combination of any other three noncollinear triangle centers.
</p><p>
<b>Note 6.</b> Continuing from Note 5, examples of f,g,h are conveniently given using Conway symbols for a triangle ABC with sidelengths a,b,c. Conway symbols and certain classical symbols are
identified here:
</p><p>
S = 2*area(ABC)<br>
S<sub>A</sub> = (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)/2 = bc cos A<br>
S<sub>B</sub> = (c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)/2 = ca cos B<br>
S<sub>C</sub> = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/2 = ab cos C<br>
S<sub>&omega;</sub> = S cot &omega;<br>
s = (a + b + c)/2<br>
s<sub>a</sub> = (b + c - a)/2<br>
s<sub>b</sub> = (c + a - b)/2<br>
s<sub>c</sub> = (a + b - c)/2<br>
r = inradius = S/(a + b + c)<br>
R = circumradius = abc/(2S)<br>
cot(&omega;) = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/(2S), where &omega; is the Brocard angle
</p><p>
<b>Note 7.</b> The definition of combo along with many examples were developed by Peter Moses prior to November 1, 2011. After that combos have been further developed by Peter Moses, Randy Hutson, and Clark Kimberling.
</p><p>
Examples of two-point combos:<br><b>X(175) = 2s*X(1) - (r + 4R)*X(7)<br>X(176) = 2s*X(1) + (r + 4R)*X(7)<br>X(481) = s*X(1) - (r + 4R)*X(7)<br>X(482) = s*X(1) + (r + 4R)*X(7)
</b></p><p>
Examples of three-point combos: see below at X(1), X(2), etc.
</p><p>
<b>Note 8.</b> Suppose that T is a (central) triangle with vertices A',B',C' given by normalized barycentrics. Then T is represented by a 3x3 matrix with row sums equal to 1. Let NT denote the set of these matrices and let * denote matrix multiplication. Then NT is closed under *. Also, NT is closed under matrix inversion, so that (NT, *) is a group. Once normalized, any central T can be used to produce triangle centers as combos of the form Xcom(nT); see the preambles to X(3663) and X(3739).
</p><hr noshade size="8" width="100%"><hr noshade size="8" width="100%">
<br><br>
<h3 id="X1">X(1) = INCENTER<a id="Incenter" name="Incenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1 : 1 : 1<br>
Barycentrics a : b : c<br>
Barycentrics sin A : sin B : sin C<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[b c (b + c - a)] : :<br>
Tripolars sec A' : :, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br><b>
X(1) = 3R*X(2) + r*X(3) + s*cot(&omega;)*X(6)<br>
X(1) = X(1) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc - X(176)/Rs, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles, Rs = radius of inner Soddy circle, [A], [B], [C] are the vertices of ABC<br>
X(1) = X(1) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc - X(175)/Rs', where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles, Rs' = radius of outer Soddy circle, [A], [B], [C] are the vertices of ABC
<br>
X(1) = (sin A)*[A] + (sin B)*[B] + (sin C)*[C], where [A], [B], [C] are vertices of ABC<br>
X(1) = a*[A] + b*[B] + c*[C], where [A], [B], [C] are vertices
</b><p>
X(1) is the point of concurrence of the interior angle bisectors of ABC; the point inside ABC whose distances from sidelines BC, CA, AB are equal. This equal distance, r, is the radius of the incircle, given by r = 2*area(ABC)/(a + b + c).
</p><p>
Three more points are also equidistant from the sidelines; they are given by these names and trilinears:
</p><p>
A-excenter = -1 : 1 : 1, B-excenter = 1 : -1 : 1, C-excenter = 1 : 1 : -1.
</p><p> The radii of the excircles are 2*area(ABC)/(-a + b + c), 2*area(ABC)/(a - b + c), 2*area(ABC)/(a + b - c).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(1).gsp"><b>Incenter</b></a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(1).ggb"><b>Incenter</b></a>.
</p><p>
Writing the A-exradius as r(a,b,c), the others are r(b,c,a) and r(c,a,b). If these exradii are abbreviated as r<sub>a</sub>, r<sub>b</sub>, r<sub>c</sub>, then 1/r = 1/r<sub>a</sub> +1/r<sub>b</sub> + 1/r<sub>c</sub>. Moreover,
</p><p>
area(ABC) = sqrt(r*r<sub>a</sub>*r<sub>b</sub>*r<sub>c</sub>) and r<sub>a</sub> + r<sub>b</sub> + r<sub>c</sub> = r + 4R, where R denotes the radius of the circumcircle.
</p><p>
The incenter is the identity of the group of triangle centers under <b>trilinear multiplication</b> defined by (x : y : z)*(u : v : w) = xu : yv : zw.
</p><p> A construction for * is easily obtained from the construction for "barycentric multiplication" mentioned in connection with X(2), just below.
</p><p>
The incenter and the other classical centers are discussed in these highly recommended books:
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.math.fau.edu/yiu/GeometryNotes020402.pdf"><b>Paul Yiu,</b> Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle, 2002</a>;<br><b>Nathan Altshiller Court,</b> <i>College Geometry,</i> Barnes & Noble, 1952;
<br>
<b>Roger A. Johnson,</b> <i>Advanced Euclidean Geometry,</i> Dover, 1960.
</p><p>
Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circle tangent to side BC at its midpoint and to the circumcircle on the side of BC opposite A. Define O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the external tangent to circles O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub> that is nearest to O<sub>A</sub>. Define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub> &cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. Then triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to the medial triangle, and the center of homothety is X(1); see the reference at X(1001).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the intouch and excentral triangles; X(1) is the radical center of the circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C". (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(1) lies on all Z-cubics (e.g., Thomson, Darboux, Napoleon, Neuberg) and these lines:<br>2,8 3,35 4,33 5,11

<h3 id="X2">X(2) = CENTROID<a id="Centroid" name="Centroid"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1/a : 1/b : 1/c
<br>
Trilinears bc : ca : ab
<br>
Trilinears csc A : csc B : csc C
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos B cos C : cos B + cos C cos A : cos C + cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears sec A + sec B sec C : sec B + sec C sec A : sec C + sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos(B - C) : cos B + cos(C - A) : cos C + cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears cos B cos C - cos(B - C) : cos C cos A - cos(C - A) : cos A cos B - cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics 1 : 1 : 1
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[2(b^2 + c^2) - a^2] : :
<b><br>
X(2) = (3 + J) X(1113) + (3 - J) X(1114)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(2) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, 0).
</p><p>
X(2) is the point of concurrence of the medians of ABC, situated 1/3 of the distance from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side. More generally, if L is any line in the plane of ABC, then the distance from X(2) to L is the average of the distances from A, B, C to L. An idealized triangular sheet balances atop a pin head located at X(2) and also balances atop any knife-edge that passes through X(2). The triangles BXC, CXA, AXB have equal areas if and only if X = X(2).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(2).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Centroid</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(2).ggb"><b>Centroid</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(2) is the centroid of the set of 3 vertices, the centroid of the triangle including its interior, but not the centroid of the triangle without its interior; that centroid is X(10).
</p><p>
X(2) is the identity of the group of triangle centers under "barycentric multiplication" defined by
</p>
(x : y : z)*(u : v : w) = xu : yv : zw.
<p></p>
X(2) is the unique point X (as a function of a,b,c) for which the vector-sum XA + XB + XC is the zero vector.
<p></p>
The <b>Parry isodynamic circle</b> is here introduced as the circle centered at X(2502) that passes through the isodynamic points, X(15) and X(16). This circle is orthogonal to both the circumcircle and Parry circle. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
<p></p>
Let A' be the trilinear pole of the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. A'B'C' is also the anticomplement of the anticomplement of the midheight triangle. A'B'C' is homothetic to the midheight triangle at X(2). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
<p></p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let Oa be the A'-McCay circle of triangle A'BC, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. X(2) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
<p></p>
X(2) lies on the Parry circle, Thomson cubic, and these lines:<br>

<h3 id="X3">X(3) = CIRCUMCENTER<a id="Circumcenter" name= "Circumcenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos A : cos B : cos C
<br>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : b(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) : c(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics sin 2A : sin 2B : sin 2C
<br>
Barycentrics tan B + tan C : tan C + tan A: tan A + tan B
<br>
Barycentrics S^2 - SB SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1 - cot B cot C : :
<br>
Tripolars 1 : 1 : 1
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(3) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, -1).
</p><p>
X(3) is the point of concurrence of the perpendicular bisectors of
the sides of ABC. The lengths of segments AX, BX, CX are equal if and
only if X = X(3). This common distance is the radius of the
circumcircle, which passes through vertices A,B,C. Called the
circumradius, it is given by R = a/(2 sin A) = abc/(4*area(ABC)).
</p><p>
The tangents at vertices of excentral triangle to the McCay cubic K003 concur in X(3). Also, the tangents at A,B,C to the orthocubic K006 concur in X(3). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(4). Let A" be X(4)-of-AB'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(3). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
Let P be a point in the plane of ABC. Let P' be the isogonal conjugate of P. Let P" be the pedal antipodal perspector of P. X(3) is the unique point P for which P' = P". (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(3).gsp"><b>Circumcenter</b></a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(3).ggb"><b>Circumcenter</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(3) lies on the Thomson cubic, the Darboux cubic, the Napoleon cubic, the Neuberg cubic, the McCay cubic, then Darboux quintic, and these lines:<br>

</p><p>
X(3) is the {X(2),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(3), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page. If triangle ABC is acute, then X(3) is the incenter of the
tangential triangle and the Bevan point, X(40), of the orthic
triangle.
</p><p>

(6483,6486,6419), (6484,6485,6), (6484,6486,6433), (6485,6487,6434), (6486,6487,6), (6488,6489,6), (6490,6491,6), (6492,6493,6), (6494,6495,6), (6494,6499,6435), (6495,6498,6436), (6496,6497,6), (6496,6522,6519), (6497,6519,6522), (6498,6499,6), (6500,6501,6), (6519,6522,6), (6566,6567,1570), (6639,6640,2)
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X4">X(4) = ORTHOCENTER<a id="Orthocenter" name="Orthocenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears sec A : sec B : sec C
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin B sin C : cos B - sin C sin A : cos C - sin A sinB
<br>
Trilinears cos A - cos(B - C) : cos B - cos(C - A) : cos C - cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears sin B sin C - cos(B - C) : sin C sin A - cos(C - A) : sin A sin B - cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears csc A tan 3A - 2 sec 3A : :
<br>
Trilinears 4 cos A - cos(B - C) - 3 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos(B - C) + 5 cos B cos C - 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/SA : 1/SB : 1/SC
<br>
Barycentrics tan A : tan B : tan C
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Tripolars |cos A| : :
<br>
Tripolars |a(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)| : :
<b><br>
X(4) = (1 + J) X(1113) + (1 - J) X(1114)<br>
X(4) = (tan A)*[A] + (tan B)*[B] + (tan C)*[C], where A, B, C are the angles and [A], [B], [C] are the vertices
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(4) has Shinagawa coefficients (0, 1).
</p><p>
<p>X(4) is the point of concurrence of the altitudes of ABC.
</p><p>
The tangents at A,B,C to the McCay cubic K003 concur in X(4). Also, the tangents at A,B,C to the Lucas cubic K007 concur in X(4). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let P be a point in the plane of ABC. Let Oa be the circumcenter of BCP, and define Ob and Oc cyclically. Let Q be the circumcenter of OaObOc. P = Q only when P = X(4). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(4).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Orthocenter</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(4).ggb"><b>Orthocenter</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(4) and the vertices A,B,C comprise an orthocentric system, defined
as a set of four points, one of which is the orthocenter of the
triangle of the other three (so that each is the orthocenter of the
other three). The incenter and excenters also form an orthocentric
system. If ABC is acute, then X(4) is the incenter of the orthic
triangle.
</p><p>
Suppose P is not on a sideline of ABC. Let A'B'C' be the cevian
triangle of P. Let D,E,F be the circles having diameters AA', BB',CC'.
The radical center of D,E,F is X(4). (Floor van Lamoen, Hyacinthos
#214, Jan. 24, 2000.)
</p><p>
Let A2B2C2 be the 2nd Conway triangle. Let A' be the crosspoint of B2 and C2, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(4). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
<b>Ross Honsberger,</b> <i>Episodes in Nineteenth and Twentieth
Century Euclidean Geometry,</i> Mathematical Association of America,
1995. Chapter 2: The Orthocenter.</p>
<p>X(4) lies on the Thomson, Darboux, Napoleon, Lucas, McCay, and Neuberg cubics, and the Darboux septic, and on these lines:<br>

</p><p>
X(4) is the {X(3),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(4), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
<p>X(4) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,382),
(146,3448), (147,148), (149,153), (150,152)</p>

<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X5">X(5) = NINE-POINT CENTER<a id="NinePointCenter" name="NinePointCenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos(B - C) : cos(C - A) : cos(A - B)<br>
Trilinears cos A + 2 cos B cos C : :<br>
Trilinears cos A - 2 sin B sin C<br>
Trilinears bc[a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>] : :<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A + sec B sec C : : <br>
Trilinears cos B cos C + sin B sin C : : <br>
Trilinears cos^2(B/2 - C/2) - sin^2(B/2 - C/2) : :<br>
Trilinears cos A' : :, where A' is the angle formed by internal tangents to incircle and A-excircle<br>
Trilinears cos A" : : , where A" is the angle formed by external tangents to B- and C-excircles
<br>
Barycentrics a cos(B - C) : b cos(C - A) : c cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics S^2 + SB SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1 + cot B cot C : :
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[a^6-3 a^4 b^2+3 a^2 b^4-b^6-3 a^4 c^2+3 a^2 b^2 c^2+b^4 c^2+3 a^2 c^4+b^2 c^4-c^6] : :
<b><br>
X(5) = 3*X(2) + X(4) = 3*X(2) - X(3) = X(3) + X(4)<br>
X(5) = (2 + J) X(1113) + (2 - J) X(1114)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(5) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, 1).
</p><p>
X(5) is the center of the nine-point circle. Euler showed in that
this circle passes through the midpoints of the sides of ABC and the
feet of the altitudes of ABC, hence six of the nine points. The other
three are the midpoints of segments A-to-X(4), B-to-X(4), C-to-X(4).
The radius of the nine-point circle is one-half the circumradius.</p>
<p><b>Dan Pedoe,</b> <i>Circles: A Mathematical View,</i> Mathematical
Association of America, 1995.
</p><p>
Let Pa be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC. Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt Pa. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B' and C; cyclically. Then X(5) = X(597)-of-A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the half-altitude triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole, wrt A'B'C', of line BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the nine-point center of BCX(13), and define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the nine-point center of BCX(14), and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Euler triangle. Let A" be the centroid of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be any equilateral triangle inscribed in the circumcircle of ABC. The Simson lines of A', B', C' form an equilateral triangle with center X(5). If A'B'C' is the circumtangential triangle, the Simson lines of A', B', C' concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view these sketches:
<a href="X(5).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Nine-point center</a>,
<a href="EulerLine.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Euler Line</a>,
<a href="Roll%20Circle.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Roll Circle</a>,
<a href="MacBeath.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">MacBeath
Inconic</a></p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(5).ggb"><b>Nine-point center</b></a> and <a href="Euler line.ggb"><b>Euler line</b></a>.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Feuerbach triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B"and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung). X(5) = X(6146)-of-A'B'C'.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(5). Let A" be X(5)-of-AB'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
Let Na, Nb, Nc be the nine-point centers of BCF, CAF, ABF, resp., where F = X(13). Let Na', Nb', Nc' be the nine-point centers of BCF', CAF', ABF', resp., where F' = X(14). The lines NaNa', NbNb', NcNc' concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
Let Na, Nb, Nc be the nine-point centers of BCX, CAX, ABX, resp., where X = X(17). Let Na', Nb', Nc' be the nine-point centers of BCX', CAX', ABX', resp., where X' = X(18). The lines NaNa', NbNb', NcNc' concur in X(5). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>

X(5) is the {X(2),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(5), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.

X(5) = Ehrmann-side-to-orthic similarity image of X(4)<br>
X(5) = Johnson-to-Ehrmann-mid similarity image of X(3)<br>
X(5) = QA-P32 center (Centroid of the Circumcenter Quadrangle) of quadrangle ABCX(4) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/60-qa-p32.html)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X6">X(6) = SYMMEDIAN POINT (LEMOINE POINT, GREBE POINT)<a id="SymmedianPoint" name="SymmedianPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a : b : c<br>
Trilinears sin A : sin B : sin C<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)(1 - cos A + cos B + cos C) : :<br>
Trilinears cot B/2 + cot C/2 : :<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> : b<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics SB + SC : :<br>
Barycentrics SA - SW : :<br>
Barycentrics cot A - cot &omega; : :<br>
Barycentrics cot B + cot C - cot A + cot &omega; : :
<br>
Tripolars b c Sqrt[2(b^2 + c^2) - a^2] : :
<br><b>
X(6) = (r<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>2</sup> + 2rR)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) -2r<sup>2</sup>*X(3)<br>X(6) = (1 + sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(13) + (1 - sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(14)<br>X(6) = (1 + sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(15) + (1 - sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(16)<br>
X(6) = (3 + 5*sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(17) + (3 - 5*sqrt(3)*tan(&omega;))*X(18)<br>(The above four combos for X(6) found by Peter Moses, November, 2011)
</b><p>
X(6) is the point of concurrence of the symmedians (i.e., reflections of medians in corresponding angle bisectors). X(6) is the point which, when given by <i>actual</i> trilinear distances x,y,z, minimizes x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> + z<sup>2</sup>.
</p><p>
X(6) in Navigation: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pzDyi7ANoVA"><b>A talk about the symmedian point, by William Lionheart.</b></a>
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(6).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Symmedian point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(6).ggb"><b>Symmedian point</b></a>.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the pedal triangle of an arbitrary point X, and let S(X) be the vector sum XA' + XB' + XC'. Then
</p><p>
S(X) = (0 vector) if and only if X = X(6).
</p><p>
The "if" implication is equivalent to the well known fact that X(6) is the centroid of its pedal triangle, and the converse was proved by Barry Wolk (Hyacinthos #19, Dec. 23, 1999).
</p><p>
X(6) is the radical trace of the 1st and 2nd Lemoine circles. (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/24/03)
</p><p>
X(6) is the perspector of ABC and the medial triangle of the orthic triangle of ABC. (Randy Hutson, 8/23/2011)
</p><p>
<b>Ross Honsberger,</b> <i>Episodes in Nineteenth and Twentieth Century Euclidean Geometry,</i> Mathematical Association of America, 995. Chapter 7: The Symmedian Point.
</p><p>
Let A' be the center of the conic through the contact points of the incircle and the A-excircle with the sidelines of ABC. Define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the center of the conic through the contact points of the B- and C- excircles with the sidelines of ABC. Define B" and C" cyclically. The triangles A'B'C' and A"B"C" are perspective at X(6). See also X(25), X(218), X(222), X(940), X(1743). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
The tangents at A,B,C to the Thomson cubic K002 concur in X(6). Let Ha be the foot of the A-altitude. Let Ba, Ca be the feet of perpendiculars from Ha to CA, AB, resp. Let A' be the orthocenter of HaBaCa, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(6). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Ja, Jb, Jc be the excenters and I the incenter of ABC. Let Ka be the symmedian point of JbJcI, and define Kb and Kc cyclically. Then KaKbKc is perspective to JaJbJc at X(6). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung); then X(6) = X(6467)-of-A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(6) is the perspector of every pair of these triangles: anticevian triangle of X(3), submedial triangle, unary cofactor triangle of submedial triangle, unary cofactor triangle of the intangents triangle, unary cofactor triangle of the extangents triangle. (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the tangential triangle of the Jerabek hyperbola. Let A" be the pole wrt circumcircle of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(6). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the half-altitude (midheight) triangle. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A parallel to B'C', and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A" = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B", C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(6). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(6) is the unique point which is the centroid of its pedal triangle. (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(6) lies on the Thomson cubic and these lines:<br>1,9 2,69 3,15 4,53
5,68 7,294 8,594
10,1377 13,14 17,18
19,34 21,941 22,251

691,843 692,1438 694,1084
706,1502 717,789 750,899

911,1461 939,1802 943,1612
947,1622 959,961 963,1208
967,1790 971,990 986,1046
1073,3343 1096,1859 1112,1177

1173,1614 1174,1617 1195,1399
1201,1696 1214,1708 1327,1328
1362,1416 1398,1425 1423,1429
1718,1781 1826,1837 1836,1839
1854,1858 3342,3351 3344,3350
</p><p>
X(6) is the {X(15),X(16)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(6), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.

<h3 id="X7">X(7) = GERGONNE POINT<a id="GergonnePoint" name="GergonnePoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears bc/(b + c - a) : ca/(c + a - b) : ab/(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : sec<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : sec<sup>2</sup>(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(tan(B/2) + tan(C/2)) : 1/(tan(C/2) + tan(A/2)) : 1/(tan(A/2) + tan(B/2))
<br>
Trilinears (bc - S<sub>A</sub>)/a : (ca - S<sub>B</sub>)/b : (ab - S<sub>C</sub>)/c
<br>
Trilinears (1 - cos A)a<sup>-2</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b + c - a) : 1/(c + a - b) : 1/(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics tan A/2 : tan B/2 : tan C/2
<br>
Barycentrics bc - S<sub>A</sub> : ca - S<sub>B</sub> : ab - S<sub>C</sub>
<br>
Tripolars (b+c-a) Sqrt[a (a-b-c) (a^2+a b-2 b^2+a c+4 b c-2 c^2)] : :
<br><b>
X(7) = (2r + 4R)*X(1) + 3r*X(2) - 4r*X(3)<br>
X(7) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles
</b><p>
Let A', B', C' denote the points in which the incircle meets the sides BC, CA, AB, respectively. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(7).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(7).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Gergonne point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(7).ggb"><b>Gergonne point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(7) lies on the Lucas cubic and these lines:<br>1,20 2,9 3,943 4,273
6,294 8,65 11,658
12,1268 21,56 27,81
37,241 33,1041 34,1039
58,272 59,1275 72,443
73,1246 76,1479 80,150
92,189 100,1004 104,934
108,1013 109,675 145,1266
171,983 174,234 177,555
190,344 192,335 193,239
218,277 220,1223 225,969
238,1471 253,280 256,982
274,959 281,653 286,331
310,314 330,1432 349,1269
354,479 404,1259 452,1467
464,1214 480,1376 492,1267
513,885 517,1000 528,664
554,1082 594,599 604,1429
757,1414 840,927 857,1901
870,1431 940,1407 941,1427
944,1389 952,1159 986,1254
987,1106 1002,1362 1020,1765
1061,1870 1354,1367 1365,1366
1386,1456 1419,1449 1435,1848
1486,1602 1617,1621
</p><p>
X(7) is the {X(69),X(75)}-harmonic conjugate of X(8). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(7), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>

X(7) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j):<br>(7,269), (21,991), (75,75), (86,7), (99,7), (190,7), (290,7), (314,69), (645,344), (648,7), (662,6), (664,7), (666,7), (668,7), (670,7), (671,7), (811,264), (886,7), (889,7), (892,7), (903,7)<br>
X(7) = vertex conjugate of foci of inellipse that is isotomic conjugate of isogonal conjugate of incircle (centered at X(2886))<br>
X(7) = trilinear product of vertices of Hutson-extouch triangle<br>
X(7) = orthocenter of X(4)X(8)X(885)<br>
X(7) = trilinear cube of X(506)<br>
X(7) = barycentric product of PU(47)<br>
X(7) = trilinear product of PU(94)<br>
X(7) = vertex conjugate of PU(95)<br>
X(7) = bicentric sum of PU(120)<br>
X(7) = perspector of ABC and the reflection in X(57) of the pedal triangle of X(57)<br>
X(7) = perspector of AC-incircle<br>
X(7) = X(6)-of-extraversion triangle-of-X(8)<br>
X(7) = X(6)-of-intouch-triangle; X(7) is the only point X inside ABC Such that X(ABC) = X(A'B'C'), where A'B'C' = cevian triangle of X<br>
X(7) = {X(2),X(63)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5273)<br>
X(7) = {X(9),X(57)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1445)<br>
X(7) = {X(1371),X(1372)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(7) = {X(1373),X(1374)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(7) = trilinear pole of Gergonne line<br>
X(7) = trilinear pole, wrt intouch triangle, of Gergonne line<br>
X(7) = pole of Gergonne line wrt incircle<br>
X(7) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(281) (line X(3064)X(3700))<br>
X(7) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(281)<br>
X(7) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(9)<br>
X(7) = X(75)-isoconjugate of X(2175)<br>
X(7) = X(1101)-isoconjugate of X(4092)<br>
X(7) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(3160)<br>
X(7) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(3160)<br>
X(7) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(3160)<br>
X(7) = antigonal image of X(1156)<br>
X(7) = homothetic center of intouch triangle and anticomplement of the excentral triangle<br>
X(7) = X(6)-of-intouch-triangle; X(7) is the only point X inside ABC such that X(ABC) = X(A'B'C'), where A'B'C' = cevian triangle of X<br>
X(7) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of inner and outer Soddy triangles<br>
X(7) = perspector of excentral triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and Honsberger triangle<br>
X(7) = perspector of inverse-in-excircles triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and inverse-in-excircles triangle<br>
X(7) = perspector of inverse-in-incircle triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and inverse-in-incircle triangle<br>
X(7) = X(1843)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(7) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(943)<br>
X(7) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(942)<br>
X(7) = {X(1),X(1742)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2293)<br>
X(7) = barycentric square of X(508)<br>
X(7) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 40<br>
X(7) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 40<br>
X(7) = endo-homothetic center of Ehrmann vertex-triangle and Ehrmann mid-triangle; the homothetic center is X(3818)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X8">X(8) = NAGEL POINT<a id="NagelPoint" name="NagelPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears (b + c - a)/a : (c + a - b)/b : (a + b - c)/c
<br>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : csc<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : csc<sup>2</sup>(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears (bc + S<sub>A</sub>)/a : (ca + S<sub>B</sub>)/b : (ab + S<sub>C</sub>)/c
<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)a<sup>-2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears (r/R) - sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics b + c - a : c + a - b : a + b - c
<br>
Barycentrics cot A/2 : cot B/2 : cot C/2
<br>
Barycentrics square of semi-minor axis of A-Soddy ellipse : :
<br>
Barycentrics bc + S<sub>A</sub> : ca + S<sub>B</sub> : ab + S<sub>C</sub>
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[a (a^2-a b-2 b^2-a c+4 b c-2 c^2)] : :
<br><b>
X(8) = 2*X(1) - 3*X(2) = 3*X(2) - 4*X(10) = 4X(10) - X(145)
<br>
X(8) = [A]*Ra + [B]*Rb + [C]*Rc, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles
</b><p>
Let A'B'C' be the points in which the A-excircle meets BC, the B-excircle meets CA, and the C-excircle meets AB, respectively. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(8). Another construction of A' is to start at A and trace around ABC half its perimeter, and similarly for B' and C'. Also, X(8) is the incenter of the anticomplementary triangle.
</p><p>
X(8) = perspector of ABC and the intouch triangle of the medial triangle of ABC. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb be as in the construction of the Conway circle (http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ConwayCircle.html). Let Oa be the circumcircle of ABcCb, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. X(8) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. see also X(21) and X(274). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be Triangle T(-2,1). Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(519). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(8). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically. X(8) = X(1)-of-IaIbIc. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>28</sub>B<sub>28</sub>C<sub>28</sub> be the Gemini triangle 28. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A<sub>28</sub> parallel to BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'<sub>28</sub> = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B'<sub>28</sub>, C'<sub>28</sub> cyclically. Triangle A'<sub>28</sub>B'<sub>28</sub>C'<sub>28</sub> is homothetic to ABC at X(8). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(8).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Nagel point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(8).ggb"><b>Nagel point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(8) lies on these curves:<br>
Feuerbach hyperbola, anticomplementary Feuerbach hyperbola, Mandart hyperbola, Fuhrmann circle, K007, K013, K028, K033, K034, K154, K157, K199, K200, K201, K259, K308, K311, K338, K366, K386, K387, K455, K461, K506, K521, K623, K651, K654, K680, K692, K696, K697, K702, K744, K767, Q045
</p><p>

<h3 id="X9">X(9) = MITTENPUNKT<a id="Mittenpunkt" name="Mittenpunkt"></a></h3>
Trilinears b + c - a : c + a - b : a + b - c
<br>
Trilinears cot(A/2) : cot(B/2) : cot(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears a - s : b - s : c - s
<br>
Trilinears csc A + cot A : :
<br>
Trilinears csc A (1 + cos A) : :
<br>
Trilinears tan A' : : , where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = distance from A to the Gergonne line
<br>
Trilinears square of semi-minor axis of A-Soddy ellipse : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(b + c - a) : b(c + a - b) : c(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics 1 + cos A : 1 + cos B : 1 + cos C
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[b c (a^4-2 a^2 b^2+b^4-4 b^3 c-2 a^2 c^2+6 b^2 c^2-4 b c^3+c^4)] : :
<b><br>
X(9) = (r + 2R)*X(1) - 6*X(2) -2r*X(3) = 3*X(2) - X(7)
</b><p>
X(9) is the symmedian point of the excentral triangle.
</p><p>
X(9) = perspector of ABC and the medial triangle of the extouch triangle of ABC. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the orthocorrespondent of the A-excenter, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(9). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the antiorthic axis of AB'C', and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc. B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(9). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let E be the locus of the trilinear pole of a line that passes through X(1). The center of E is X(9). Moreover, E passes through the points X(100), X(658), X(662), X(799), X(1821), X(2580), X(2581) and the bicentric pairs PU(34), PU(75), PU(77), PU(79). Also, E is a circumellipse of ABC and an inellipse of the excentral triangle. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
The locus E also passes through the vertices of Gemini triangle 2. (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A' be the intersection of the tangents to the A-excircle at the intercepts with the circumcircle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(9). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A' be the perspector of the A-mixtilinear excircle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(9). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(9).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Mittenpunkt</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(9).ggb"><b>Mittenpunkt</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(9) lies on the Thomson cubic and these lines:<br>1,6 2,7 3,84 4,10
5,1729 11,3254 8,346 21,41
31,612 32,987 33,212
34,201 35,90 38,614

3341,3344 3343,3352 3349,3351</p>
<p>X(9) is the {X(44),X(45)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(9), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page. X(9) is the internal center of similitude of the Bevan
circle and Spieker circle; the external center is X(1706).</p>
<p>

<h3 id="X10">X(10) = SPIEKER CENTER<a id="SpiekerCenter" name="SpiekerCenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears bc(b + c) : ca(c + a) : ab(a + b)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(r cos A - s sin A) : :
<br>
Trilinears csc(A - U) : :, U as at X(572) and X(573)
<br>
Trilinears (cos B + cos C)/(1 - cos A) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 + 2 csc A/2 sin B/2 sin C/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears |AP(1)| + |AU(1)| : :
<br>
Trilinears (r/R) - 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics b + c : c + a : a + b
<br>
Barycentrics semi-major axis of A-Soddy ellipse : :
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[a^3-2 a b^2-b^3+a b c-2 a c^2-c^3] : :
<br><b>
X(10) = X(1) - 3X(2) = 3X(2) + X(8) = X(7) + X(8) + 2 X(9)
</b><p>
Let A' be the intersection of these three lines: the perpendicular from midpoint of CA to line BX(1), the perpendicular from midpoint of AB to line CX(1), the perpendicular from midpoint of AX(1) to line BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The orthocenter of A'B'C' is X(10), and X(10) is also the perspector of A'B'C' and the medial triangle. Note that A'B'C' is the complement of the excentral triangle, and the extraversion triangle of X(10). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
The Spieker circle is the incircle of the medial triangle; its center, X(10), is the centroid of the perimeter of ABC. If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href= "X(10).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Spieker center</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(10).ggb"><b>Spieker center</b></a>.
</p><p>
A construction of X(10) is given at <a href="https://beta.groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/24163"> 24163</a>.
(Antreas Hatzipolakis, August 29, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. X(10) is the radical center of the polar circles of triangles A'BC, B'CA, C'AB. (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>20</sub>B<sub>20</sub>C<sub>20</sub> be the Gemini triangle 20. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A<sub>20</sub> parallel to BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'<sub>20</sub> = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B'<sub>20</sub> and C'<sub>20</sub> cyclically. Triangle A'<sub>20</sub>B'<sub>20</sub>C'<sub>20</sub> is homothetic to ABC at X(10). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(10) lies on the Kiepert hyperbola and these lines:<br>1,2 3,197 4,9 5,517
6,1377 11,121 12,65
20,165 21,35 28,1891
29,1794 31,964 33,406
34,475 36,404 37,594
38,596 39,730 44,752
46,63 55,405 56,474
57,388 58,171 69,969
75,76 81,1224 82,83
86,319 87,979 92,1838
98,101 106,1222 116,120
117,123 119,124 140,214
141,142 150,1282 153,1768
158,318 182,1678 190,671
191,267 201,225 219,965
227,1214 235,1902 255,1771
257,1581 261,1326 274,291
307,1254 321,756 348,1323
391,1743 407,1867 427,1829
429,1824 480,954 485,1686
486,1685 497,1697 514,764
535,1155 537,1086 626,760
631,944 632,1483 750,1150
774,1736 775,801 846,1247
894,1046 908,994 962,1695
1018,1334 1074,1735 1146,1212
1482,1656 1587,1703 1588,1702
1762,1782 1828,1883 1900,1904</p>
<p>X(10) is the {X(1),X(2)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1125). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(10), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page. X(10) is the internal center of similitude of the
Apollonius and nine-points circles.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd extouch triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(10). Also, let A''B''C'' be the 1st circumperp triangle. The Simson lines of A'', B'', C'' concur in X(10). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015) </p><p>
X(10) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,8), (3,355), (4,40), (6,3416), (10,3421), (55,3419), (65,72), (80,100), (2948,3448)<br>
X(10) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1125), (551,2), (946,5), (1385,140)<br>
X(10) = isogonal conjugate of X(58)<br>
X(10) = isotomic conjugate of X(86)<br>

<h3 id="X11">X(11) = FEUERBACH POINT<a id="FeuerbachPoint" name= "FeuerbachPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1 - cos(B - C) : 1 - cos(C - A) : 1 - cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears sin<sup>2</sup>(B/2 - C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears bc(b + c - a)(b - c)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 - cos A - 2 cos B cos C : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos A - 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(1 - cos(B - C)) : b(1 - cos(C - A)) : c(1 - cos(A -B))
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c - a)(b - c)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[(a-b-c) (a^4-2 a^2 b^2+b^4+a^2 b c+a b^2 c-2 b^3 c-2 a^2 c^2+a b c^2+2 b^2 c^2-2 b c^3+c^4)] : :
<b><br>
X(11) = R*X(1) - 3rX(2) + r*X(3)
</b><p>
X(11) is the point of tangency of the nine-point circle and the incircle. The nine-point circle is the circumcenter of the medial triangle, as well as the orthic triangle. Feuerbach's famous theorem states that the nine-point circle is tangent to the incircle and the three excircles.
</p><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A parallel to X(1)X(3), and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let M<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of BC in L<sub>A</sub>, and define M<sub>B</sub> and M<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = M<sub>B</sub>&cap;M<sub>C</sub>, and define cyclically B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in line X(1)X(3). The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(11); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
The circumcircle of the incentral triangle intersects the incircle at 2 points, X(11) and X(3024), and the nine-point circle at 2 points, X(11) and X(115). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
X(11) lies on the bicevian conic of X(1) and X(2), which is also QA-Co1 (Nine-point Conic) of quadrangle ABCX(1) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/other-quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/76-qa-co1.html) (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Na = X(5) of BCX(1), Nb = X(5) of CAX(1), Nc = X(5) of ABX(1). Then X(11) = X(186) of NaNbNc. (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let JaJbJc be the excentral triangle and FaFbFc be the Feuerbach triangle. Let Fa' = {X(5),Ja}-harmonic conjugate of Fa, and define Fb', Fc' cyclically. The lines AFa', BFb', CFc' concur in X(11).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the antiorthic axis of AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(9), and X(11) = X(55)-of-A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let Na be the Nagel line of AB'C', and define Nb and Nc cyclically. Let A" = Nb&cap;Nc, and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, and X(11) = X(36)-of-A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. The lines IO of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(11). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. The lines IO of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(11). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(11).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Feuerbach point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(11).ggb"><b>Feuerbach point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(11) is the {X(1),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(12) and also the {X(5),X(12)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3614) . For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(11), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(11) lies on the incentral circle, Mandart circle, cevian circle of every point on the Feuerbach hyperbola, and these lines:<br>
1,5 2,55 3,499 4,56
7,658 8,1320 9,3254 10,121

486,1335 498,1656 515,1319
516,1155 517,1737 518,908
523,1090 613,1352 650,1566
774,1393 944,1388 962,1788
971,1538 1012,1470 1040,1368
1111,1358 1146,1639 1193,1834
1427,1856 1428,1503 1455,1877
1500,1506 1697,1698
</p><p>
X(11) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,80), (4,104), (5,1484), (9,3254), (100,149)<br>
X(11) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1387), (119,5), (214,1125), (1145,10), (1317,1), (1537,946)<br>

X(11) = X(100) of Mandart-incircle triangle<br>
X(11) = X(3659) of orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(11) = homothetic center of intangents triangle and reflection of extangents triangle in X(100)<br>
X(11) = homothetic center of 3rd Euler triangle and intouch triangle<br>
X(11) = QA-P2 (Euler-Poncelet Point) of quadrangle ABCX(1) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/10-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/12-qa-p2.html)<br>
X(11) = intersection of tangents to Steiner inellipse at X(1086) and X(1146)<br>
X(11) = crosspoint wrt medial triangle of X(1086) and X(1146)<br>

<h3 id="X12">X(12) = {X(1),X(5)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(11)</h3>
Trilinears&nbsp ; 1 + cos(B - C) : 1 + cos(C - A) : 1 + cos(A -B) : :
<br>
Trilinears&nbsp ; cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2 - C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears&nbsp ; 1 + cos A + 2 cos B cos C : :
<br>
Trilinears&nbsp ; 1 - cos A + 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears&nbsp ; bc(b + c)<sup>2</sup>/(b + c - a) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(1 + cos(B - C)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c)<sup>2</sup>/(b + c - a) : :
<br>
Tripolars (a-b-c) Sqrt[(a^3+a^2 b-a b^2-b^3+a^2 c+3 a b c+b^2 c-a c^2+b c^2-c^3) (a^4-2 a^2 b^2+b^4+a^2 b c-a b^2 c-2 b^3 c-2 a^2 c^2-a b c^2+2 b^2 c^2-2 b c^3+c^4)] : :
<br> <b>
X(12) = R*X(1) + 3r*X(2) - r*X(3)
</b><p>
Let A'B'C' be the touch points of the nine-point circle with the A-, B-, C- excircles, respectively. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(12).
</p> <p>
X(12) lies on these lines:<br>1,5 2,56 3,498 4,55 7,1268 10,65 17,203
18,202 30,35 33,235
34,427 36,140 37,225
38,1393 40,1836 42,1834
54,215 57,1224 63,1454
71,1901 79,484 85,120
108,451 115,1500 116,1362
117,1364 121,1357 123,1359
124,1361 125,1425 141,1469
171,1399 172,230 201,756
208,1360 221,1853 228,407
281,1118 313,349 354,1210
377,1259 381,1479 431,1824
443,1466 474,1470 485,1124
486,1124 499,999 603,750
611,1352 908,960 942,1209
946,1532 968,1904 1015,1506
1038,1368 1091,1109 1125,1319
1213,1400 1452,1892 1594,1870
1697,1699 1861,1887 1877,1883
</p><p>
X(12) is the {X(1),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(11). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(12), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(12).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(12)</a>.

</p><p>
X(12) = isogonal conjugate of X(60)<br>
X(12) = isotomic conjugate of X(261)<br>

X(12) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32753)<br>
X(12) = X(10)-Ceva conjugate of X(201)<br>
X(12) = crosssum of X(58) and X(1437)<br>
X(12) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (10,12), (1089,1089)<br>
X(12) = insimilicenter of incircle and nine-point circle<br>
X(12) = X(1594)-of-Fuhrmann triangle<br>
