X(12) = homothetic center of Euler triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Johnson-Yff triangle<br>
X(12) = homothetic center of ABC and triangular hull of circumcircles of BCX(4), CAX(4), and ABX(4); i.e., the outer Johnson triangle<br>
X(12) = centroid of curvatures of nine-point circle and excircles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X13">X(13) = 1st ISOGONIC CENTER (FERMAT POINT, TORRICELLI POINT)<a id="FirstIsogonicCenter" name="FirstIsogonicCenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears csc(A + &pi;/3) : csc(B + &pi;/3) : csc(C + &pi;/3)
<br>
Trilinears sec(A - &pi;/6) : sec(B - &pi;/6) : sec(C - &pi;/6)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>4</sup> - 2(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + 4*sqrt(3)*Area(ABC)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (SA + Sqrt[3] S) (SB + SC) + 4 SB SC : :
<br>
Tripolars 1/(a^4+a^2 b^2-2 b^4+a^2 c^2+4 b^2 c^2-2 c^4+2 Sqrt[3] a^2 S) : :
<b><br>
X(13) = 3<sup>1/2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6r(3<sup>1/2</sup>R - 2s)*X(2) - 2r(3<sup>1/2</sup>r + 3s)*X(3)<br> (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Construct the equilateral triangle BA'C having base BC and vertex A' on the negative side of BC; similarly construct equilateral triangles CB'A and AC'B based on the other two sides. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(13). If each of the angles A, B, C is &lt; 2&pi;/3, then X(13) is the only center X for which the angles BXC, CXA, AXB are equal, and X(13) minimizes the sum |AX| + |BX| + |CX|. The antipedal triangle of X(13) is equilateral.
</p><p>
If, however, A&gt; 2&pi;/3, then the Fermat point, defined geometrically as the minimizer of |AX| + |BX| + |CX|, is not the 1st isogonic center (which is defined by the above trilinears). Trilinears for the Fermat point when A&gt; 2&pi;/3 are simply 1:0:0. To represent the Fermat point in the form f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), one must use Boolean variables, as shown at <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_point">Fermat point.</a>
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view these sketches:
<br>
<a href="FermatDynamic.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Fermat Dynamic</a>
<br>
<a href="X(13).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">1st isogonic center</a>
<br>
<a href="KiepertHyperbola.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Kiepert Hyperbola</a>, showing X(13) and X(14) on the hyperbola, with midpoint X(115)
<br>
<a href="EvansConic.gsp"><b>Evans Conic</b>, passing through X(13), X(14), X(15), X(16), X(17), X(18), X(3070), X(3071).</a>
<br>
<a href="X(3054).gsp"><b>X(3054)</b>, center of the Evans Conic and 19 other triangle centers.</a>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(13).ggb"><b>1st isogonic center</b></a>.
</p><p>
The Evans conic is introduced in <b>Evans, Lawrence S.,</b> "A Conic Through Six Triangle Centers," <a href="http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2002volume2/FG200211index.html"> <b style="font-style: italic">Forum Geometricorum</b></a> 2 (2002) 89-92.
</p><p>
Let NaNbNc, Na'Nb'Nc' be the outer and inner Napoleon triangles, respectively. Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of Na', wrt NaNbNc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines NaA', NbB', NcC' concur in X(13). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p><p>
Let P be a point inside triangle ABC such that the line AP bisects angle BPC, and NBP bisets CPA, and CP bisects APB. Then P = X(13). The locus of P such that AP bisects BPC is the circumcubic given by the barycentric equation
c<sup>2</sup>xy<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>xz<sup>2</sup> + (a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)y<sup>2</sup>z - (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)yz<sup>2</sup> = 0,
and the other two cubics are given cyclically. Bernard Gibert discusses these cubics as K053A, K053B, K053C; see
<a href="https://bernard-gibert.pagesperso-orange.fr/Exemples/k053.html"> <b>Apollonian strophoids.</b></a> (Paul Hanna and Peter Moses, August 6, 2017)
</p><p>
The line X(13)X(15) is parallel to the Euler line, and the distance between the two lines is (SB - SC)(SC - SA)(SA - SB)/|(cot(&omega;) + 3<sup>1/2</sup>)|*((E - 8F)S<sup>2</sup>)<sup>1/2</sup>. (Kiminari Shinagawa, February 20, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the outer Napoleon triangle and A"B"C" the inner Napoleon triangle. Let A* be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A'B'C', of A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A'A*, B'B*, C'C* concur in X(13). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let F be X(13) or X(14). Let L and L' be lines through F such that the angle between them is &pi;/3; if you have GeoGebra, see <a href="Figure 13A.ggb" style="font-weight: bold">Figure 13A</a>. Let L<sub>BC</sub> = L&cap;BC, and define L<sub>CA</sub> and L<sub>AB</sub> cyclically. Let L'<sub>BC</sub> = L'&cap;BC, and define L'<sub>CA</sub> and L'<sub>AB</sub> cyclically. The lines L<sub>BC</sub>L'<sub>CA</sub>, L<sub>CA</sub>L'<sub>AB</sub>, L<sub>AB</sub>L'<sub>BC</sub> concur. (Dao Thanh Oai, 2014)
</p><p>
Let F be X(13) or X(14). Let A<sub>0</sub>, B<sub>0</sub>, C<sub>0</sub> be points on BC, CA, AB, respectively, such that the directed angles FA<sub>0</sub>-to-FC<sub>0</sub> = &pi;/3 and FC<sub>0</sub>-to-FB<sub>0</sub> = &pi;/3; if you have GeoGebra, see <a href="Figure 13B.ggb" style="font-weight: bold">Figure 13B</a>. The points A<sub>0</sub>, B<sub>0</sub>, C<sub>0</sub> are collinear. (Dao Thanh Oai, 2014)
</p><p>
X(13) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines:<br>
2,16 3,17 4,61 5,18
6,14 11,202 15,30
76,299 80,1251 98,1080
99,303 148,617 203,1478
226,1081 262,383 275,472
298,532 484,1277 531,671
533,621 634,635</p>
<p>X(13) is the {X(6),X(381)}-harmonic conjugate of X(14). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(13), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(13) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (14,115), (15,396), (99,619), (298,623), (616,618)<br>
X(13) = isogonal conjugate of X(15)<br>
X(13) = isotomic conjugate of X(298)<br>
X(13) = circumcircle-inverse of X(6104)<br>
X(13) = orthocentroidal-circle inverse of X(14)<br>
X(13) = complement of X(616)<br>
X(13) = anticomplement of X(618)<br>
X(13) = cevapoint of X(15) and X(62)<br>
X(13) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (15,18), (30,14), (396,2)<br>
X(13) = trilinear pole of line X(395)X(523) (polar of X(470) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(13) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(470)<br>
X(13) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(470)<br>
X(13) = antigonal image of X(14)<br>
X(13) = reflection of X(14) in line X(115)X(125)<br>
X(13) = X(15)-of-4th-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(13) = X(15)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(13) = orthocorrespondent of X(13)<br>
X(13) = homothetic center of outer Napoleon triangle and antipedal triangle of X(13)<br>
X(13) = inner-Napoleon-to-outer-Napoleon similarity image of X(15)<br>
X(13) = outer-Napoleon-isogonal conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(13) = outer-Napoleon-to-inner-Napoleon similarity image of X(14)<br>
X(13) = orthocenter of X(14)X(98)X(2394)<br>
X(13) = X(15)-of-pedal-triangle of X(13)<br>
X(13) = {X(265),X(1989)}-harmonic Conjugate of X(14)<br>
X(13) = homothetic center of (equilateral) antipedal triangle of X(13) and triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(13), CAX(13), ABX(13)<br>
X(13) = homothetic center of triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(14), CAX(14), ABX(14) and triangle formed by nine-point centers of BCX(13), CAX(13), ABX(13)<br>
X(13) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(17)<br>
X(13) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(61)<br>
X(13) = Kosnita(X(13),X(1)) point<br>
X(13) = Kosnita(X(13),X(13)) point<br>
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X14">X(14) = 2nd ISOGONIC CENTER<a id= "SecondIsogonicCenter" name= "SecondIsogonicCenter"></a></h3>
Trilinears csc(A - &pi;/3) : csc(B - &pi;/3) : csc(C - &pi;/3)<br> = sec(A + &pi;/6) : sec(B + &pi;/6) : sec(C + &pi;/6)
<p>
Barycentrics f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c) = a<sup>4</sup> - 2(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 4*sqrt(3)*Area(ABC))
<br>
Barycentrics (SA - Sqrt[3] S) (SB + SC) + 4 SB SC : :
<br>
Tripolars 1/(a^4+a^2 b^2-2 b^4+a^2 c^2+4 b^2 c^2-2 c^4-2 Sqrt[3] a^2 S : :
<b><br>
X(14) = 3<sup>1/2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6r(3<sup>1/2</sup>R + 2s)*X(2) + 2r(3<sup>1/2</sup>r - 3s)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Construct the equilateral triangle BA'C having base BC and vertex A' on the positive side of BC; similarly construct equilateral triangles CB'A and AC'B based on the other two sides. The lines AA',BB',CC' concur in X(14). The antipedal triangle of X(14) is equilateral.</p>
</p><p>
Let NaNbNc, Na'Nb'Nc' be the outer and inner Napoleon triangles, resp. Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of Na, wrt Na'Nb'Nc', and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines Na'A', Nb'B', Nc'C' concur in X(14). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the outer Napoleon triangle and A"B"C" the inner Napoleon triangle. Let A* be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A"B"C", of A', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A"A*, B"B*, C"C* concur in X(14). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
The line X(14)X(16) is parallel to the Euler line, and the distance between the two lines is (SB - SC)(SC - SA)(SA - SB)/|(cot(&omega;) - 3<sup>1/2</sup>)|((E - 8F)S<sup>2</sup>)<sup>1/2</sup>. (Kiminari Shinagawa, February 20, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(14).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">2nd isogonic center</a>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(14).ggb"><b>2nd isogonic center</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(14) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines:<br>2,15 3,18 4,62 5,17 6,13 11,203 16,30 76,298 98,383 99,302 148,616 202,1478 226,554 262,1080 275,473 299,533 397,546 484,1276 530,671 532,622 633,636
</p><p>
X(14) is the {X(6),X(381)}-harmonic conjugate of X(13). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(14), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(14) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (13,115), (16,395), (99,618), (299,624), (617,619)<br>
X(14) = isogonal conjugate of X(16)<br>
X(14) = isotomic conjugate of X(299)<br>
X(14) = complement of X(617)<br>
X(14) = anticomplement of X(619)<br>
X(14) = circumcircle-inverse of X(6105)<br>
X(14) = orthocentroidal-circle-inverse of X(13)<br>
X(14) = cevapoint of X(16) and X(61)<br>
X(14) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (16,17), (30,13), (395,2)<br>
X(14) = trilinear pole of line X(396)X(523) (polar of X(471) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(14) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(471)<br>
X(14) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(471)<br>
X(14) = antigonal image of X(13)<br>
X(14) = reflection of X(13) in line X(115)X(125)<br>
X(14) = X(16)-of-4th-Brocard triangle<br>
X(14) = X(16)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(14) = orthocorrespondent of X(14)<br>
X(14) = homothetic center of inner Napoleon triangle and antipedal triangle of X(14)<br>
X(14) = inner-Napoleon-isogonal conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(14) = outer-Napoleon-to-inner-Napoleon similarity image of X(16)<br>
X(14) = inner-Napoleon-to-outer-Napoleon similarity image of X(13)<br>
X(14) = orthocenter of X(13)X(98)X(2394)<br>
X(14) = X(16)-of-pedal-triangle of X(14)<br>
X(14) = {X(265),X(1989)}-harmonic Conjugate of X(13)<br>
X(14) = homothetic center of (equilateral) antipedal triangle of X(14) and triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(14), CAX(14), ABX(14)<br>
X(14) = homothetic center of triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(13), CAX(13), ABX(13) and triangle formed by nine-point centers of BCX(14), CAX(14), ABX(14)<br>
X(14) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(18)<br>
X(14) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(62)<br>
X(14) = Kosnita(X(14),X(1)) point<br>
X(14) = Kosnita(X(14),X(14)) point<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X15">X(15) = 1st ISODYNAMIC POINT<a id="FirstIsodynamicPoint" name=
"FirstIsodynamicPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears sin(A + &pi;/3) : sin(B + &pi;/3) : sin(C + &pi;/3)
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - &pi;/6) : cos(B - &pi;/6) : cos(C - &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A + sqrt(3) sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a sin(A + &pi;/3) : b sin(B + &pi;/3) : c sin(C + &pi;/3)
<br>
Barycentrics (SB + SC) ((SA + Sqrt[3] S) (SB + SC) + 4 SB SC) : :
<br>
Tripolars b c : :<br>
<br><b>
X(15) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) - 2r(r - 3<sup>1/2</sup>s)*X(3) = sqrt(3)*X(3) + (cot &omega;)*X(6) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b> <p>
Let U and V be the points on sideline BC met by the interior and exterior bisectors of angle A. The circle having diameter UV is the A-Apollonian circle. The B- and C- Apollonian circles are similarly constructed. Each circle passes through one vertex and both isodynamic points. (This configuration, based on the cevians of X(1), generalizes to arbitrary cevians; see TCCT, p. 98, problem 8.)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 4th Brocard triangle and A"B"C" be the 4th anti-Brocard triangle. The circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C" concur in two points, X(15) and X(16). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
The line X(13)X(15) is parallel to the Euler line, and the distance between the two lines is (SB - SC)(SC - SA)(SA - SB)/|(cot(&omega;) + 3<sup>1/2</sup>)|*((E - 8F)S<sup>2</sup>)<sup>1/2</sup>. (Kiminari Shinagawa, February 20, 2018)
</p><p>
The pedal triangle of X(15) is equilateral. If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href="X(15).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">1st isodynamic point</a> and <a href="X(15)&X(16).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(15)&X(16), with Brocard axis and Lemoine axis</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(15).ggb"><b>1st isodynamic point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(15) lies on the Parry circle, Neuberg cubic, and these lines:<br>1,1251 2,14 3,6 4,17
13,30 18,140 35,1250
36,202 55,203 298,533
303,316 395,549 397,550
532,616 628,636 1337,2981
</p><p>
X(15) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(16). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(15), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(15) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (13,396), (16,187), (298,618), (316,624), (621,623)<br>
X(15) = isogonal conjugate of X(13)<br>
X(15) = isotomic conjugate of X(300)<br>
X(15) = complement of X(621)<br>
X(15) = anticomplement of X(623)<br>
X(15) = circumcircle-inverse of X(16)<br>
X(15) = Brocard-circle-inverse of X(16)<br>
X(15) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,202), (13,62), (74,16)<br>
X(15) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (13,18), (298,470)<br>
X(15) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (15,62), (532,619)<br>
X(15) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(395)X(523)<br>
X(15) = X(6)-Hirst inverse of X(16)<br>
X(15) = X(15)-of-2nd-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(15) = X(15)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(15) = {X(371),X(372)}-harmonic conjugate of X(61)<br>
X(15) = X(75)-isoconjugate of X(3457)<br>
X(15) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(5995)<br>
X(15) = outer-Napoleon-to-inner-Napoleon similarity image of X(13)<br>
X(15) = orthocentroidal-to-ABC similarity image of X(13)<br>
X(15) = 4th-Brocard-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(13)<br>
X(15) = X(2378)-of-2nd-Parry triangle<br>
X(15) = radical center of Lucas(2/sqrt(3)) circles<br>
X(15) = homothetic center of (equilateral) 1st isogonal triangle of X(13) and pedal triangle of X(15)<br>
X(15) = homothetic center of (equilateral) 1st isogonal triangle of X(14) and triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(14), CAX(14), ABX(14)<br>
X(15) = eigencenter of inner Napoleon triangle<br>
X(15) = X(13)-of-4th-anti-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(15) = X(15)-of-X(3)PU(1)<br>
X(15) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(5463)<br>
X(15) = X(10657)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(15) = {X(16),X(61)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(15) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(61)<br>
X(15) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(17)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X16">X(16) = 2nd ISODYNAMIC POINT<a id="SecondIsodynamicPoint" name="SecondIsodynamicPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears sin(A- &pi;/3) : sin(B - &pi;/3) : sin(C - &pi;/3)
<br>
Trilinears cos(A + &pi;/6) : cos(B + &pi;/6) : cos(C + &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A - sqrt(3) sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a sin(A - &pi;/3) : b sin(B - &pi;/3) : c sin(C- &pi;/3)
<br>
Barycentrics (SB + SC) ((SA - Sqrt[3] S) (SB + SC) + 4 SB SC) : :
<br>
Tripolars b c : :
<br><b>
X(16) = -(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 6rR*X(2) + 2r(r + 3<sup>1/2</sup>s)*X(3) = sqrt(3)*X(3) - (cot &omega;)*X(6) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let U and V be the points on sideline BC met by the interior and exterior bisectors of angle A. The circle having diameter UV is the A-Apollonian circle. The B- and C- Apollonian circles are similarly constructed. Each circle passes through a vertex and both isodynamic points. The pedal triangle of X(16) is equilateral. If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(16).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">2nd isodynamic point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(16).ggb"><b>2nd isodynamic point</b></a>.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 4th Brocard triangle and A"B"C" be the 4th anti-Brocard triangle. The circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C" concur in two points, X(15) and X(16). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
The line X(14)X(16) is parallel to the Euler line, and the distance between the two lines is (SB - SC)(SC - SA)(SA - SB)/|(cot(&omega;) - 3<sup>1/2</sup>)|((E - 8F)S<sup>2</sup>)<sup>1/2</sup>. (Kiminari Shinagawa, February 20, 2018)
</p><p>
X(16) lies on the Parry circle, Neuberg cubic, and these lines:<br>1,1250 2,13 3,6 4,18
14,30 17,140 36,203
55,202 299,532 302,316
358,1135 396,549 398,550
533,617 627,635 1338,3458
</p><p>
X(16) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(15). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(16), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(16) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (14,395), (15,187), (299,619), (316,623), (622,624)<br>
X(16) = isogonal conjugate of X(14)<br>
X(16) = isotomic conjugate of X(301)<br>
X(16) = complement of X(622)<br>
X(16) = anticomplement of X(624)<br>
X(16) = circumcircle-inverse of X(15)<br>
X(16) = Brocard-circle-inverse of X(15)<br>
X(16) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,203), (14,61), (74,15)<br>
X(16) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (14,17), (299,471)<br>
X(16) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (16,61), (533,618)<br>
X(16) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(396)X(523)<br>
X(16) = X(6)-Hirst inverse of X(15)<br>
X(16) = X(16) of 2nd Brocard triangle<br>
X(16) = X(16)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(16) = {X(371),X(372)}-harmonic conjugate of X(62)<br>
X(16) = X(75)-isoconjugate of X(3458)<br>
X(16) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(5994)<br>
X(16) = inner-Napoleon-to-outer-Napoleon similarity image of X(14)<br>
X(16) = orthocentroidal-to-ABC similarity image of X(14)<br>
X(16) = 4th-Brocard-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(14)<br>
X(16) = X(2379)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(16) = homothetic center of (equilateral) 1st isogonal triangle of X(14) and pedal triangle of X(16)<br>
X(16) = homothetic center of (equilateral) 1st isogonal triangle of X(13) and triangle formed by circumcenters of BCX(13), CAX(13), ABX(13)<br>
X(16) = radical center of Lucas(-2/sqrt(3)) circles<br>
X(16) = eigencenter of outer Napoleon triangle<br>
X(16) = X(14) of 4th anti-Brocard triangle<br>
X(16) = X(16)-of-X(3)PU(1)<br>
X(16) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(5464)<br>
X(16) = X(10658)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(16) = {X(15),X(62)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(16) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(62)<br>
X(16) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(18)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X17">X(17) = 1st NAPOLEON POINT<a id= "FirstNapoleonPoint" name= "FirstNapoleonPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears csc(A + &pi;/6) : csc(B + &pi;/6) : csc(C + &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears sec(A - &pi;/3) : sec(B - &pi;/3) : sec(C - &pi;/3)
<br>
Barycentrics a csc(A + &pi;/6) : b csc(B + &pi;/6) : c csc(C + &pi;/6)
<br>
Tripolars (a^2-b^2-c^2-2 Sqrt[3] S) Sqrt[(a^2-3 b^2-3 c^2-2 Sqrt[3] S)] : :
</p><p>
Let X,Y,Z be the centers of the equilateral triangles in the construction of X(13). The lines AX, BY, CZ concur in X(17).
</p><p>
<A HREF="http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2015volume15/FG201509index.html "><b>Dao Thanh Oai,</b> Equilateral Triangles and Kiepert Perspectors in Complex Numbers, <I>Forum Geometricorum</I> 15 (2015) 105-114.</A>
</p><p>
<A HREF="http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayIssue?jid=MAG&volumeId=99&seriesId=0&issueId=544
"><b>Dao Thanh Oai,</b> A family of Napoleon triangles associated with the Kiepert configuration, <I>The Mathematical Gazette</I> 99 (March 2015) 151-153.</A>
</p><p>
<b>John Rigby,</b> "Napoleon revisited," <i>Journal of Geometry,</i>33 (1988) 126-146.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(17).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">1st Napoleon point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(17).ggb"><b>1st Napoleon point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(17) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines:<br>2,62 3,13 4,15 5,14 6,18 12,203 16,140 76,303 83,624 202,499 275,471 299,635 623,633
</p><p>
X(17) is the {X(231),X(1209)}-harmonic conjugate of X(18). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(17), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(17) = reflection of X(627) in X(629)<br>
X(17) = isogonal conjugate of X(61)<br>
X(17) = isotomic conjugate of X(302)<br>
X(17) = complement of X(627)<br>
X(17) = anticomplement of X(629)<br>
X(17) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32754)<br>
X(17) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (16,14), (140,18), (397,4)<br>
X(17) = polar conjugate of X(473)<br>
X(17) = trilinear product of vertices of outer Napoleon triangle<br>
X(17) = Kosnita(X(13),X(3)) point<br>
X(17) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(13)<br>
X(17) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(15)<br>
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X18">X(18) = 2nd NAPOLEON POINT<a id="SecondNapoleonPoint" name= "SecondNapoleonPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears csc(A - &pi;/6) : csc(B - &pi;/6) : csc(C - &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears sec(A + &pi;/3) : sec(B + &pi;/3) : sec(C + &pi;/3)
<br>
Barycentrics a csc(A - &pi;/6) : b csc(B - &pi;/6) : c csc(C - &pi;/6)
<br>
Tripolars (a^2-b^2-c^2+2 Sqrt[3] S) Sqrt[(a^2-3 b^2-3 c^2+2 Sqrt[3] S)] : :
<p>
Let X,Y,Z be the centers of the equilateral triangles in the construction of X(14). The lines AX, BY, CZ concur in X(18).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(18).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">2nd Napoleon point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(18).ggb"><b>2nd Napoleon point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(18) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines: 2,61 3,14 4,16 5,13 6,17 12,202 15,140 76,302 83,623 203,499 275,470 298,636 624,634
</p><p>
X(18) is the {X(231),X(1209)}-harmonic conjugate of X(17). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(18), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.</p>
<p>
X(18) = reflection of X(628) in X(630)<br>
X(18) = isogonal conjugate of X(62)<br>
X(18) = isotomic conjugate of X(303)<br>
X(18) = complement of X(628)<br>
X(18) = anticomplement of X(630)<br>
X(18) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32755)<br>
X(18) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (15,13), (140,17), (398,4)<br>
X(18) = polar conjugate of X(472)<br>
X(18) = trilinear product of vertices of inner Napoleon triangle<br>
X(18) = Kosnita(X(14),X(3)) point<br>
X(18) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(14)<br>
X(18) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(16)<br></p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X19">X(19) = CLAWSON POINT<a id="ClawsonPoint" name="ClawsonPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears tan A : tan B : tan C
<br>
Trilinears sin 2B + sin 2C - sin 2A : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup> + S<sub>A</sub> : :
<br>
Trilinears SB*SC : :
<br> Barycentrics a tan A : b tan B : c tan C
<br> Tripolars (-a^2+b^2+c^2) Sqrt[b c (a^6-a^4 b^2-a^2 b^4+b^6-2 a^4 b c-2 b^5 c-a^4 c^2+2 a^2 b^2 c^2-b^4 c^2+4 b^3 c^3-a^2 c^4-b^2 c^4-2 b c^5+c^6)] : :
<b><br>
X(19) = (r + 2R - s)(r + 2R + s)*X(1) - 6R(r + 2R)*X(2) - 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
X(19) is the homothetic center of the orthic and extangents triangles. The Ayme triangle, constructed at X(3610), is perspective to ABC with perspector X(19).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(19).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Clawson point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(19).ggb"><b>Clawson point</b></a>.
</p><p>
Further information is available from<br>
<a href="http://www.math.fau.edu/yiu/clawson.pdf">Paul Yiu's Website.</a></p>
<p>Although <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/bstud/clawson.html">John Clawson</a> studied this point in 1925, it was studied earlier by Lemoine:
</p><p>
<b>Emile Lemoine,</b> "Quelques questions se rapportant ï¿½ l'ï¿½tude des antiparallï¿½les des cï¿½tes d'un triangle", <i>Bulletin de la S. M.
F.,</i> tome 14 (1886), p. 107-128, specifically, on page 114. This article is available online at <a href="http://www.numdam.org/">Numdam</a>.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 4th Brocard triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product of the (real or imaginary) circumcircle intercepts of line B'C'. Define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle. Let Ab = BC&cap;C'A', Ac = BC&cap;A'B', and define Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb cyclically. Then Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb lie on an ellipse. Let A" be the intersection of the tangents to the ellipse at Ba and Ca, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle of the extangents triangle, if ABC is acute. Then A'B'C' is homothetic to the anti-Ara triangle at X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(650)X(663) (the trilinear polar of X(9)), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(661)X(663) (the trilinear polar of X(19)), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(19). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(19) lies on these lines:<br>1,28 2,534 3,1871 4,9
6,34 8,1891 25,33 27,63
31,204 41,1825 44,1828
45,1900 46,579 47,921
53,1846 56,207 57,196
64,1903 81,969 91,920
101,913 102,282 112,759
158,1712 162,897 163,563
208,225 219,517 220,1902
226,1763 232,444 273,653
294,1041 318,1840 379,1441
407,1865 429,1213 560,1910
604,909 672,1851 960,965
1158,1715 1212,1593 1405,1866
1449,1870 1581,1740 1598,1872
1633,1721 1707,1719 1708,1713
1743,1783 1836,1901 1837,1852</p>
<p>X(19) is the {X(607),X(608)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(19), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(19) = isogonal conjugate of X(63)<br>
X(19) = isotomic conjugate of X(304)<br>
X(19) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32756)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,204), (4,33), (27,4), (28,25), (57,208), (92,1), (196,207), (278,34)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (25,34), (31,1)<br>
X(19) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,278), (27,28), (57,84), (92,158)<br>
X(19) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,610), (3,219), (9,40), (48,255), (71,72)<br>
X(19) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(521)X(656)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-Hirst inverse of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,240), (4,242)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,610), (92,19), (508,223), (648,163)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (9,198), (19,608), (112,604), (281,281), (648,273), (653,19)<br>
X(19) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(5179)<br>
X(19) = inverse-in-circumconic-centered-at-X(9) of X(1861)<br>
X(19) = Zosma transform of X(9<br>
X(19) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(19) (which is also the anticevian triangle of X(19))<br>
X(19) = intersection of tangents at X(9) and X(57) to Thomson cubic K002<br>
X(19) = intersection of tangents at X(40) and X(84) to Darboux cubic K004<br>
X(19) = trilinear product of PU(i) for these i: 4, 23, 157<br>
X(19) = barycentric product of PU(15)<br>
X(19) = vertex conjugate of PU(19)<br>
X(19) = bicentric sum of PU(127)<br>
X(19) = PU(127)-harmonic conjugate of X(656)<br>
X(19) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of hexyl triangle<br>
X(19) = perspector of unary cofactor triangles of 2nd and 4th extouch triangles<br>
X(19) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of extraversion triangle of X(9)<br>
X(19) = complement of X(4329)<br>
X(19) = {X(48),X(1953)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(19) = {X(92),X(1748)}-harmonic conjugate of X(63)<br>
X(19) = trilinear product X(2)*X(25)<br>
X(19) = trilinear pole of line X(661)X(663) (the polar of X(75) wrt polar circle) <br>
X(19) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(75) (line X(514)X(661))<br>
X(19) = polar conjugate of X(75)<br>
X(19) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these {i,j}: {1,63}, {6,69}, {31,304}, {48,75}, {92,255}<br>
X(19) = X(571)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(19) = perspector, wrt excentral triangle, of polar circle<br>
</p><p><br></p><p><br></p>
<p></p><center>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 20- 30,
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>2- 5, 140, 186, 199, 235, 237, 297, 376- 379,
381- 384,<br>401- 475, 546- 550, 631, 632 (and others) lie on the Euler
line.</b><br><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"><br></center>
<h3 id="X20">X(20) = DE LONGCHAMPS POINT<a id="DeLongchampsPoint" name="DeLongchampsPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos A - cos B cos C : cos B - cos C cos A : cos C - cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears sec A - sec B sec C : sec B - sec C sec A : sec C - sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears 2 cos A - sin B sin C : 2 cos B - sin C sin A : 2 cos C - sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)(tan B + tan C - tan A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan B + tan C - tan A : tan C + tan A - tan B : tan A + tan B - tan C
<br>
Barycentrics [-3a<sup>4</sup> + 2a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) + (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>] : :
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[a^6-3 a^2 b^4+2 b^6+6 a^2 b^2 c^2-2 b^4 c^2-3 a^2 c^4-2 b^2 c^4+2 c^6] : :
<br><b>
X(20) = 2(r + 2R)*X(1) - (r +4R)*X(7) = 3X(2) - 4X(3)<br>
X(20) = (1 - J) X(1113) + (1 + J) X(1114)
</b><p>
X(20) = 9 X(2) - 8 X(5) = 3 X(4) - 4 X(5) = 3 X(3) - 2 X(5) = 15 X(2) - 16 X(140) = 5 X(4) - 8 X(140) = 5 X(5) - 6 X(140) = 5 X(3) - 4 X(140) = 2 X(10) - 3 X(165) = 8 X(140) - 15 X(376) = 4 X(5) - 9 X(376) = 2 X(3) - 3 X(376) = X(4) - 3 X(376) = 10 X(5) - 9 X(381) = 5 X(4) - 6 X(381) = 5 X(2) - 4 X(381) = 5 X(3) - 3 X(381) = 4 X(140) - 3 X(381) = 5 X(376) - 2 X(381) = 12 X(140) - 5 X(382) = 9 X(381) - 5 X(382) = 9 X(2) - 4 X(382) = 3 X(4) - 2 X(382) = 9 X(376) - 2 X(382) = 3 X(3) - X(382) = 7 X(382) - 12 X(546)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(20) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, -2).
</p><p>
Let La be the polar of X(4) wrt the circle centered at A and passing through X(3), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. (Note: X(4) is the perspector of any circle centered at a vertex of ABC.) Let A" = Lb&cap;\Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to the anticomplementary triangle, and the center of homothety is X(20), which is also the orthocenter of A"B"C". Also, let La be the line through the intersections of the B- and C-Soddy ellipses, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Then La,Lb,Lc concur in X(20). Also, let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(253). Let A" be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(20). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let L be the Brocard axis of the intouch triangle. Let La be the Brocard axis of the A-extouch triangle, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. The lines L, La, Lb, Lc concur in X(20). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection in BC of the A-vertex of the anticevian triangle of X(4), and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, and C'AB concur at X(20). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection of ABC in X(3) (i.e., the circumcevian triangle of X(3)). Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", and CC" concur in X(20). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(20).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the half-altitude triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(20).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle and A"B"C" be the side-triangle of ABC and hexyl triangle. Let A* be the {B',C'}-harmonic conjugate of A", and define B*, C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(20). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(20).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">De Longchamps point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(20).ggb"><b>De Longchamps point</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(20) lies on the the following curves: Q046, Q063, Q070, Q073, Q115, K004, K007, K032, K041, K047, K071, K077, K080, K096, K099, K122, K169, K182, K236, K268, K270, K313, K329, K344, K364, K401, K425, K426, K443, K449, K462, K499, K522, K566, K609, K617, K648, K649, K650, K651, K652, K706, K753, K763, K778, K809, K814, K824, K825, K827, K850, K894. Euler-Gergonne-Soddy circle, GEOS circle, Steiner/Wallace rectangular hyperbola, anticomplement of Kiepert hyperbola, anticomplement of Feuerbach hyperbola, anticomplement of Jerabek hyperbola, and these lines:<br>

(10267,10532,10587), (10269,10531,10586), (10304,10565,10298), (10310,11500,100), (11015,11220,944), (11111,11112,2), (11291,11292,7819), (11293,11294,2), (11413,11414,7488)
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X21">X(21) = SCHIFFLER POINT<a id="SchifflerPoint" name="SchifflerPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1/(cos B + cos C) : 1/(cos C + cos A) : 1/(cos A + cos B)
<br> = f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c - a)/(b + c)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(cos B + cos C) : b/(cos C + cos A) : c/(cos A + cos B)
<b><br>
X(21) = 3R*X(2) + 2r*X(3)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(21) has Shinagawa coefficients ($aS<sub>A</sub>$, abc - $aS<sub>A</sub>$).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle of ABC, and let L<sub>A</sub>
be the reflection of line B'C' in line BC; define L<sub>B</sub> and
L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. The triangle formed by the lines
L<sub>A</sub>, L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> is perspective to ABC, and
the perspector is X(21). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)</p>
<p>Write I for the incenter; the Euler lines of the four triangles IBC,
ICA, IAB, and ABC concur in X(21). This configuration extends to
Kirikami-Schiffler points and generalizations found by Peter Moses, as
introduced just before X(3648).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd circumperp triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", and CC" concur in X(21). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Feuerbach triangle. Let La be the tangent to the nine-point circle at A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate of the trilinear pole of La, and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A*B*C* be the circumcevian triangle, wrt A"B"C", of X(1). The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(21). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd circumperp triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. Then A", B", C" are collinear on line X(36)X(238) (the trilinear polar of X(81)). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(21). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the reflection of the A-excircle in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. Then X(21) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb be as in the construction of the Conway circle (see http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ConwayCircle.html). Let Oa be the circumcircle of AAbAc, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. X(21) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc; see also X(8) and X(274). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. X(21) is the radical center of the circles O(3,4) of triangles A'BC, B'CA, C'AB. (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(21).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Schiffler point</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(21).ggb"><b>Schiffler point</b></a>.
</p><p>
<b>Lev Emelyanov and Tatiana Emelyanova,</b>
<a href="http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2003volume3/FG200312.pdf">A note on the Schiffler point</a>, <i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 3 (2003) pages 113-116.</p>
<p>The name of this point honors <a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/bstud/schiffler.html">Kurt Schiffler</a>.
</p><p>
X(21) lies on these lines:<br>

{5686, 6600}
</p><p>
X(21) is the {X(2),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(404). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(21), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(21) = midpoint of X(1) and X(191)<br>
X(21) = reflection of X(3651) in X(3)<br>
X(21) = isogonal conjugate of X(65)<br>
X(21) = isotomic conjugate of X(1441)<br>
X(21) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(1325)<br>
X(21) = anticomplement of X(442)<br>
X(21) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (86,81), (261,333)<br>
X(21) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,3), (9,55), (1805,1806)<br>
X(21) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,29), (3,283), (9,333), (55,284), (58,285), (284,81), (522,100)<br>
X(21) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {86,333}, {1805,1806}<br>
X(21) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1046), (42,1400), (1254,1425), (1402,1409)<br>
X(21) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(647)X(661)<br>
X(21) = X(i)-Hirst inverse of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,448), (3,416), (4,425)<br>
X(21) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (21,58), (99,21), (643,21), (1043,1043), (1098,21)<br>

X(21) = perspector of 2nd circumperp triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd circumperp triangle<br>

<h3 id="X22">X(22) = EXETER POINT<a id="ExeterPoint" name="ExeterPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup>) : b(c<sup>4</sup> + a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>4</sup>) : c(a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup>) : b<sup>2</sup>(c<sup>4</sup> + a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>4</sup>) : c<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics sin 2A - tan &omega; : sin 2B - tan &omega; : : (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br>
Barycentrics tan B + tan C - tan A + tan &omega; : : (R. Hutson, 10/13/15)
<b><br>
X(22) = 3 R^2 X(2) - SW X(3)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(22) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + 2F, -2E - 2F).
</p><p>
X(22) is the perspector of the circummedial triangle and the tangential triangle; also X(22) = X(55)-of-the-tangential triangle if ABC is acute. See the note just before X(1601) for a generalization.
</p><p>
Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt the A-power circle, and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to the anticomplementary triangle, and the center of homothety is X(22). (Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(22).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Exeter point</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(22).ggb"><b>Exeter point</b></a>.

1602,1626</p>

other harmonic conjugates of X(22), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X23">X(23) = FAR-OUT POINT<a id="FarOutPoint" name="FarOutPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a[b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>] : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2 sin 2A - 3 tan &omega; : 2 sin 2B - 3 tan &omega; : 2 sin 2C - 3 tan &omega; (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[2(b^2 + c^2) - a^2] : :<br>
<b><br>
X(23) = 9 R^2 X(2) - 2 SW X(3)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(23) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + 4F, -4E - 4F).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the antipedal triangle of X(3) (the tangential triangle). The circumcircles of AA'X(3), BB'X(3), CC'X(3) concur in two points: X(3) and X(23). (Randy Hutson, Octobe3r 13, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anti-orthocentroidal triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A' in line BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. Then X(23) is the centroid of A"B"C"; see X(9140), X(11002). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(23).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Far-out point</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(23).ggb"><b>Far-out point</b></a>.
<p>
X(23) lies on the Parry circle, anti-Brocard circle, anti-McCay circumcircle, and these lines:<br>2,3 6,353 51,575

1297,1804</p>

other harmonic conjugates of X(23), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>

<h3 id="X24">X(24) = PERSPECTOR OF ABC AND ORTHIC-OF-ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears sec A cos 2A : sec B cos 2B : sec C cos 2C
<br>
Tllrilinears sec A - 2 cos A : sec B - 2 cos B : sec C - 2 cos C
<br>
Barycentrics tan A cos 2A : tan B cos 2B : tan C cos 2C
<br>
Barycentrics tan A - sin 2A : tan B - sin 2B : tan C - sin 2C
<br>
Barycentrics a(sec A - 2 cos A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2)/(a^2 - b^2 - c^2) : :
<b><br>
X(24) = 6 X(2) + (J^2 - 5) X(3)<br>
X(24) = (a^2 - b^2 - c^2) (a^2 + b^2 - c^2) (a^2 - b^2 + c^2) X(3) + 2 a^2 b^2 c^2 X(4)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(24) has Shinagawa coefficients (2F, -E - 2F).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" = inverse-in-circumcircle of A', and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(24). (Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
X(24) = homothetic center of the tangential triangle and the
triangle obtained by reflecting X(4) in the sidelines of ABC.</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(24).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(24)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(24).ggb"><b>X(24)</b></a>.
<p>

</p><p>
X(24) is the {X(3),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(378). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(24), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X25">X(25) = HOMOTHETIC CENTER OF ORTHIC AND TANGENTIAL TRIANGLES</h3>
Trilinears sin A tan A : :
<br>
Trilinears a/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sec A : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan A - tan &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics sec A sin(A - &omega;) : :
<b><br>
X(25) = 6 R^2 X(2) - SW X(3)<br>
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(25) has Shinagawa coefficients (F, -E - F).
</p><p>
Constructed as indicated by the name; also X(25) is the pole of the orthic axis (the line having trilinear coefficients cos A : cos B : cos C) with respect to the circumcircle.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(25).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(25)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(25).ggb"><b>X(25)</b></a>.
<p>
Let A' be the center of the conic through the contact points of the incircle and the A-excircle with the sidelines of ABC. Define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the center of the conic through the contact points of the B- and C- excircles with the sidelines of ABC. Define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* be the midpoint of A' and A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The triangle A*B*C* is perspective to ABC at X(25). See also X(6), X(218), X(222), X(940), X(1743).
(Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the radical center of the nine-point circle and the B- and C-power circles. efine B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is homothetic with the orthic triangle, and the center of homothety is X(25). Also X(25) is the point of intersection of these two lines: isotomic conjugate of polar conjugate of van Aubel line (i.e., line X(2)X(3)), and polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of van Aubel line (i.e., line X(25)X(393)). Also, X(25) is the trilinear pole of line X(512)X(1692), this line being the isogonal conjugate of the isotomic conjugate of the orthic axis; the line X(512)X(1692) is also the polar of X(76) wrt polar circle, and the line is also the radical axis of circumcircle and 2nd Lemoine circle. (Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" be the barycentric product of the (real or imaginary) circumcircle intercepts of line B'C'. Define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(25). (Randy Hutson, October 27, 2015)
</p><p>
The 2nd Ehrmann triangle, defined in the preamble to X(8537), can be generalized as follows. Let P be a point in the plane of ABC and not on BC&cup;CA&cup;AB. Let Ab the the point of intersection of the circle {{P,B,C}} and the line AB, and define Bc and Ca cyclically. Define Ac symmetrically, and define Ba and Cb cyclically. Let A' = BcBa&cap;CaCb, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C', here introduced as the <b>P-Ehrmann triangle</b>, is homothetic to the orthic triangle. The X(1)-Ehrmann triangle is the intangents triangle, and the X(6)-Ehrmann triangle is the 2nd Ehrmann triangle. If P lies on the circumcircle, the P-Ehrmann triangle is the tangential triangle. If P is on the Brocard 2nd cubic K018 or the circumcircle, then the P-Ehrmann triangle is perspective to ABC. The homothetic center of the orthic triangle and the X(4)-Ehrmann triangle is X(25). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(25) lies on these lines:<br>1,1036 2,3 6,51 19,33
31,608 32,1184 34,56
35,1900 36,1878 40,1902
41,42 52,155 53,157
57,1473 58,967 64,1192
65,1452 76,1241 92,242
98,107 100,1862 105,108
110,1112 111,112 114,135
125,1853 132,136 143,156
182,3066 183,264 185,1498 221,1425
225,1842 226,1892 262,275
273,1447 286,1218 317,325
339,1289 343,1352 371,493
372,494 389,1181 393,1033
394,511 669,878 692,913
694,1613 842,1304 847,1179
941,1172 958,1891 999,1870
1001,1848 1073,1297 1096,1402
1235,1239 1300,1302 1324,1785
1376,1861 1470,1877 1503,1619
1604,1863 1631,1826 1726,1736
1730,1754
</p><p>
X(25) is the {X(5),X(26)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(25), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>

X(25) = homothetic center of ABC and orthocevian triangle of X(2)<br>
X(25) = homothetic center of orthocevian triangle of X(2) and Ara triangle<br>
X(25) = {X(8880),X(8881)}-harmonic conjugate of X(184)<br>
X(25) = homothetic center of medial triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and Ara triangle<br>
X(25) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and 4th Brocard triangle<br>
X(25) = harmonic center of circumcircle and circle O(PU(4))<br>
X(25) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(5656)<br>
X(25) = homothetic center of Aries and 2nd Hyacinth triangles<br>
X(25) = intersection of tangents to Hatzipolakis-Lozada hyperbola at X(4) and X(193)<br>
X(25) = crosspoint, wrt orthic triangle, of X(4) and X(193)<br>
X(25) = barycentric product of (real or nonreal) circumcircle intercepts of orthic axis<br>
X(25) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): (2,3,7484), (2,4,427), (2,5,7539), (3,4,1593), (3,5,7395), (4,5,7507), (4,24,3)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X26">X(26) = CIRCUMCENTER OF THE TANGENTIAL TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears a[b<sup>2</sup>cos 2B + c<sup>2</sup>cos 2C - a<sup>2</sup>cos 2A] : :
<br>
Trilinears (J<sup>2</sup> - 3) cos A + 4 cos B cos C : : , where J is as at X(1113)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup>cos 2B + c<sup>2</sup>cos 2C - a<sup>2</sup>cos 2A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^8 - 2 a^6 (b^2 + c^2) + 2 a^2 (b^6 + c^6) - (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^4 + c^4)) : :
<b><br>
X(26) = 6 X(2) + (J^2 - 7) X(3)<br>
X(26) = (J^2 - 3) X(3) + 2 X(4)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(26) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + 4F, -3E - 4F).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(26).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(26)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(26).ggb"><b>X(26)</b></a>.
<p>
Theorems involving X(26), published in 1889 by A. Gob, are discussed in<br><b>Roger A. Johnson,</b> <i>Advanced Euclidean Geometry,</i> Dover, 1960, 259-260.</p>
<p>X(26) lies on these lines: 2,3 6,143
52,184 68,161 98,1286
154,155 206,511 1605,1607
1606,1608</p>
<p>X(26) is the {X(154),X(155)}-harmonic conjugate of X(156). For a
list of other harmonic conjugates of X(26), click <b>Tables</b> at the
top of this page.
</p><p>
X(26) = reflection of X(155) in X(156)<br>
X(26) = isogonal conjugate of X(70)<br>
X(26) = isotomic conjugate of X(20564)<br>
X(26) = tangential isogonal conjugate of X(155)<br>
X(26) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(2072)<br>
X(26) = crosssum of X(125) and X(924)</p>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X27">X(27) = CEVAPOINT OF ORTHOCENTER AND CLAWSON CENTER</h3>
Trilinears (sec A)/(b + c) : (sec B)/(c + a) : (sec C)/(a + b)
<br>
Barycentrics (tan A)/(b + c) : (tan B)/(c + a) : (tan C)/(a + b)
<b><br>
X(27) = 3 SA SB SC X(2) - 2 S^2 s^2 X(3)<br>
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(27) has Shinagawa coefficients (F, -E - F - $bc$).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href=
"X(27).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(27)</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(27).ggb"><b>X(27)</b></a>.
<p>
X(27) lies on these lines:<br>2,3 6,1246 7,81 19,63
57,273 58,270 84,1896
86,1474 103,107 110,917
226,284 239,1829 243,1859
295,335 306,1043 393,967
579,1751 648,903 662,913
1014,1440 1088,1434 1268,1796
1719,1733 1730,1746 1770,1780</p>
<p>X(27) is the {X(2),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(469). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(27), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p> <p>
X(27) = isogonal conjugate of X(71)<br>
X(27) = isotomic conjugate of X(306)<br>
X(27) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(2073)<br>
X(27) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(469)<br>
X(27) = complement of X(3151)<br>
X(27) = anticomplement of X(440)<br>
X(27) = X(286)-Ceva conjugate of X(29)<br>
X(27) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,19), (57,278)<br>
X(27) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,286), (19,28), (57,81), (58,86)<br>

X(27) = X(i)-Hirst inverse of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,447), (4,423)<br>
X(27) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (648,27), (923,27)<br>
X(27) = trilinear pole of line X(242)X(514) (the polar of X(10) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(27) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(10) (line X(523)X(661))<br>
X(27) = polar conjugate of X(10)<br>

X(27) = X(75)-isoconjugate of X(2200)<br>

<h3 id="X28">X(28) = CEVAPOINT OF X(19) AND X(25)</h3>
Trilinears (tan A)/(b + c) : (tan B)/(c + a) : (tan C)/(a + b)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A tan A)/(b + c) : (sin B tan B)/(c + a) : (sin C tan C)/(a + b)
<b><br>
X(28) = 8 sa sb sc X(4) + a b c (3 + J^2) X(25)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(28) has Shinagawa coefficients ($a$F, -$a$(E + F) - abc).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(28).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(28)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(28).ggb"><b>X(28)</b></a>.
</p>
X(28) lies on these lines:<br>1,19 2,3 10,1891

1633,1770 1710,1725</p>

<h3 id="X29">X(29) = CEVAPOINT OF INCENTER AND ORTHOCENTER</h3>
Trilinears (sec
A)/(cos B + cos C) : (sec B)/(cos C + cos A) : (sec C)/(cos A + cos
B)<br>Barycentrics (tan A)/(cos B + cos C) : (tan B)/(cos C + cos
A) : (tan C)/(cos A + cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics (a - b - c)/((b + c) (a^2 - b^2 - c^2)) : :
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(29) has Shinagawa coefficients (F*S<sup>2</sup>, $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$ - F*S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href=
"X(29).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(29)</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(29).ggb"><b>X(29)</b></a> and <a href="X(29) Cevapoint.ggb"><b>X(29) cevapoint.</b></a>.
<p>
X(29) lies on these lines:<br>1,92 2,3 8,219 10,1794
33,78 34,77 58,162

1842,1848</p>

other harmonic conjugates of X(29), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.

X(29) = isogonal conjugate of X(73)<br>

<h3 id="X30">X(30) = EULER INFINITY POINT<a id="EulerInfinityPoint" name= "EulerInfinityPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos A - 2 cos B cos C : cos B - 2 cos C cos A : cos C - 2 cos A cosB
<br>
Trilinears bc[2a<sup>4</sup> - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A - sec B sec C : :
<br>
Trilinears sin B sin C - 3 cos B cos C : :
<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = 2a<sup>4</sup> - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics S^2 - 3 SB SC : :
<b><br>
X(30) = X(2) - X(3); if (i) and X(j) are on the Euler line, then X(30) = X(i) - X(j)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(30) has Shinagawa coefficients (1, -3).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" are parallel to the Euler line, and therefore concur in X(30). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(30) is the point of intersection of the Euler line and the line at infinity. Thus, each of the lines listed below is parallel to the Euler line.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(30).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Euler Infinity Point</a>.
</p><p>
X(30) lies on the Neuberg cubic, the Darboux quintic, and these (parallel) lines:<br>

X(30) = isogonal conjugate of X(74)<br>
X(30) = isotomic conjugate of X(1494)<br>
X(30) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(146)<br>
X(30) = complementary conjugate of X(113)<br>

X(30) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(647)<br>
X(30) = ideal point of PU(30)<br>
X(30) = vertex conjugate of PU(87)<br>
X(30) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(3163)<br>
X(30) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(3163)<br>
X(30) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(3163)<br>
X(30) = trilinear pole of line X(1636)X(1637) (the line that is the tripolar centroid of the Euler line)<br>
X(30) = X(517)-of-orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(30) = X(542)-of-1st Brocard triangle<br>

X(30) = Lucas isogonal conjugate of X(110)<br>

X(30) = X(1154)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(30) = homothetic center of Ehrmann vertex-triangle and Trinh triangle<br>

X(30) = homothetic center of Ehrmann mid-triangle and medial triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X31">X(31) = 2nd POWER POINT<a id="SecondPowerPoint"
name="SecondPowerPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup> : b<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears 1 - cos 2A : 1 - cos 2B : 1 - cos 2C
<br>
Trilinears cot B + cot C : :
<br>
Trilinears S<sub>B</sub> + S<sub>C</sub> : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = distance between A and de Longchamps line
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup> : b<sup>3</sup> : c<sup>3</sup><br></p>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(31) = (r<sup>2</sup> +
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) - 4r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter
Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circumsymmedial triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. Then A", B", C" are collinear on line X(667)X(788) (the trilinear polar of X(31)). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(31). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Apus triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(31). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Ara triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(31). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Define the <b>1st Kenmotu diagonals triangle</b> as the triangle formed by the diagonals of the squares in the Kenmotu configuration with center X(371) that do not include X(371). Define the <b>2nd Kenmotu diagonals triangle</b> as the triangle formed by the diagonals of the squares in the Kenmotu configuration with center X(372) that do not include X(372). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>1</sub>B<sub>1</sub>C<sub>1</sub> and A<sub>2</sub>B<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub> be the 1st and 2nd Kenmotu diagonals triangles. Let A' be the trilinear product A<sub>1</sub>*A<sub>2</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(31). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(31) is the Brianchon point (perspector) of the inellipse that is the trilinear square of the Lemoine axis. The center of the inellipse is X(16584). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href= "X(31).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(31) (1)</a>,
<a href= "X(31)a.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(31) (2)</a>,
<a href= "X(31)b.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(31) (3)</a>.</p>
<br>

<h3 id="X32">X(32) = 3rd POWER POINT<a id="ThirdPowerPoint" name="ThirdPowerPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a<sup>3</sup> : b<sup>3</sup> : c<sup>3</sup>
<br>
Trilinears sin(A - &omega;) : sin(B - &omega;) : sin(C - &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears sin A + sin(A - 2&omega;) : sin B + sin(B - 2&omega;) : sin C + sin(C - 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - cos(A - 2&omega;) : cos B - cos(B - 2&omega;) : cos C - cos(C -2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin A cot &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A - cos A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears a - 2R cos A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>4</sup> : b<sup>4</sup> : c<sup>4</sup>
<br><b>
X(32) = -(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR -
s<sup>2</sup>)(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) +
6rR(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(2) +
2r<sup>2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - 3s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3)
(Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(32).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(32)</a>.
</p><p>
The 5th Brocard triangle is here introduced as the vertex triangle of the circumcevian triangles of the 1st and 2nd Brocard points. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
The 5th Brocard triangle is homothetic to ABC at X(32), homothetic to the medial triangle at X(3096), homothetic to the anticomplementary triangle at X(2896), perspective to the 1st Brocard triangle at X(2896), and perspective to the 3rd Brocard triangle at X(32).(Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A", B", C" be inverse-in-circumcircle of A', B' and C' resp. AA", BB", CC" concur in X(32). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint, wrt A'B'C', of B and C, and define B", C" cyclically. A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(32). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(32) is the Brianchon point (perspector) of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of the Lemoine axis. The center of this inellipse is X(8265). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(32) lies on these lines:<br>1,172 2,83 3,6 4,98

<h3 id="X33">X(33) = PERSPECTOR OF THE ORTHIC AND INTANGENTS TRIANGLES</h3>
Trilinears 1 + sec A : 1 + sec B : 1 + sec C = tan A cot(A/2) : tan B cot(B/2) : tan C cot(C/2)<br>
=
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c -
a)/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)<br> =
g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = sec A
cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2)
<p>Barycentrics sin A + tan A : sin B + tan B : sin C + tan
C<br> =
h(A,B,C) : h(B,C,A) : h(C,A,B), where h(A,B,C) = tan A
cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2)<br></p>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(33) = (r + 2R - s)(r + 2R + s)*X(1) -
6rR*X(2) + 4rR*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013) </p>
<p>Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of line BC in the internal angle
bisector of angle A, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub>
cyclically. Let DEF be the triangle formed by L<sub>A</sub>,
L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub>. Then DEF (the intangents triangle) is
homothetic to the orthic triangle, and the homothetic center is X(33).
(Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(33).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(33)</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(33).ggb"><b>X(33)</b></a></b></a>.
<p>
X(33) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,1040 5,1062 6,204
7,1041 8,1039 9,212
10,406 11,427 12,235
19,25 20,1038 24,35
28,975 29,78 30,1060
36,378 40,201 42,393
47,90 56,963 57,103
63,1013 64,65 79,1063
80,1061 84,603 112,609
200,281 210,220 222,971 264,350</p>

other harmonic conjugates, click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.

<h3 id="X34">X(34) = X(4)-BETH CONJUGATE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears 1 - sec A : 1 - sec B : 1 - sec C
<br>
Trilinears tan A tan(A/2) : tan B tan(B/2) : tan C tan(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears 1/[(b + c - a)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Trilinears sec A sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A - tan A : sin B - tan B : sin C - tan C
<br>
Barycentrics tan A sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Tripolars (pending)
<b><br>
X(34) = (r + 2R - s)(r + 2R + s)*X(1) + 6rR*X(2) - 4rR*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
X(34) is the center of perspective of the orthic triangle and the reflection in the incenter of the intangents triangle.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X35">X(35) = {X(1),X(3)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(36)</h3>
Trilinears 1 + 2 cos A : 1 + 2 cos B : 1 + 2 cos C
<br>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin(3A/2) csc(A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A + sin 2A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc) : :
</p><p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-circumcircle of the A-excenter, and define B' and C' cyclically. Then the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(35).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let B'C'A" be the triangle similar to ABC such that segment A'A" crosses the line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. (Equivalently, A" is the reflection of A in B'C'.) Let Ia be the incenter of B'C'A", and define Ib and Ic cyclically. The lines AIa, BIb, CIc concur in X(35). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p> X(35) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 4,498 8,993 9,90
10,21 11,140 12,30
22,612 24,33 31,386
34,378 37,267 42,58
43,1011 47,212 71,284
72,191 73,74 79,226
172,187 228,846 255,991
376,388 404,1125 411,516
474,1001 495,550 496,549
497,499 500,1154 595,902
950,1006 968,975 1124,1152
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(35).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(35)</a>.</p>

this page.

X(35) = homothetic center of 2nd isogonal triangle of X(1) and cevian triangle of X(3); see X(36)<br>
X(35) = insimilicenter of circumcircle and circumcircle of reflection triangle of X(1); exsimilicenter is X(36)<br>
X(35) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(5902)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X36">X(36) = INVERSE-IN-CIRCUMCIRCLE OF INCENTER</h3>
Trilinears 1 - 2 cos A : 1 - 2 cos B : 1 - 2 cos C
<br>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - bc)
<br>
Trilinears sec(A/2) cos(3A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A - sin 2A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - bc) : :
<br>
Tripolars Sqrt[b c (b + c - a)] : :
<br>
Tripolars sec A' : :, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(36).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(36)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(36).ggb"><b>X(36)</b></a></b></a>.
</p><p>
Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of A with respect to BCX(1), and define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the circumcenter of BCX(1), and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(36). Also,
X(36) is the QA-P4 center (Isogonal Center) of quadrangle ABCX(1) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/25-qa-p4.html)
</p><p>
Let P be a point in the plane of triangle ABC, not on a sideline of ABC. Let A1 be the isogonal conjugate of A with respect to triangle BCP, and define B1, C1 cyclically. Call triangle A1B1C1 the 1st isogonal triangle of P. A1B1C1 is also the reflection triangle of the isogonal conjugate of P. A1B1C1 is perspective to ABC iff P lies on the Neuberg cubic. The perspector lies on cubic K060 (pK(X1989, X265), O(X5) orthopivotal cubic). Let A2 be the isogonal conjugate of A1 with respect to triangle B1C1P, and define B2, C2 cyclically. Call triangle A2B2C2 the 2nd isogonal triangle of P. Continuing, let An be the isogonal conjugate of A(n-1) with respect to triangle B(n-1)C(n-1)P, and define B(n), C(n) cyclically. Call triangle AnBnCn the nth isogonal triangle of P. For n >= 2, all triangles AnBnCn are perspective to A(n-1)B(n-1)C(n-1). Call the perspector, Pn, the nth isogonal perspector of P. Pn is the orthocenter of A(n-1)B(n-1)C(n-1) and either the incenter or an excenter of AnBnCn. The triangles AnBnCn are all concyclic, with P as center. Call the circle the isogonal circle of P. For P = X(1), the 2nd isogonal triangle of X(1) is homothetic to ABC at X(36); see also X(35), X(1478), X(1479), X(3583), X(3585), X(5903), X(7741), X(7951). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(36). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(36) is the {X(3),X(56)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(36), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(36) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,535 4,499 6,609
10,404 11,30 12,140
15,202 16,203 21,79
22,614 24,34 31,995
33,378 39,172 47,602

59,1110 63,997 80,104
84,90 99,350 100,519
101,672 106,901 109,953
187,1015 191,960 214,758
226,1006 238,513 255,1106
376,497 388,498 474,958
495,549 496,550 573,604
1030,1100
</p><p>
X(36) = midpoint of X(1) and X(484)<br>
X(36) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1319), (484,1155) (2077,3)<br>
X(36) = isogonal conjugate of X(80)<br>

X(36) = anticomplement of X(3814)<br>
X(36) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(1)<br>
X(36) = inverse-in-incircle of X(942)<br>

X(36) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(37)X(650)<br>

X(36) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (21,36), (100,36), (643,519)<br>
X(36) = X(2070)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(36) = X(186)-of-2nd circumperp-triangle<br>

X(36) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(354)<br>
X(36) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(35)<br>
X(36) = homothetic center of intangents and Trinh triangles<br>
X(36) = perspector of ABC and the reflection of the 2nd circumperp triangle in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(36) = X(186)-of-reflection-triangle-of-X(1)<br>
X(36) = exsimilicenter of circumcircle and circumcircle of reflection triangle of X(1); insimilicenter is X(35)<br>
X(36) = homothetic center of medial triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd isogonal triangle of X(1)<br>
X(36) = perspector of ABC and the reflection of the excentral triangle in the antiorthic axis (the reflection of the anticevian triangle of X(1) in the trilinear polar of X(1))<br>
X(36) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(5903)<br>
X(36) = homothetic center of Kosnita triangle and anti-tangential midarc triangle<br>

<h3 id="X37">X(37) = CROSSPOINT OF INCENTER AND CENTROID<a id="CrosspointOfIncenterAndCentroid" name="CrosspointOfIncenterAndCentroid"></a></h3>
Trilinears b + c : c + a : a + b
<br>
Trilinears ar - S : br - S : cr - S
<br>
Trilinears semi-major axis of A-Soddy ellipse : :<br>
<br>
Barycentrics a(b + c) : b(c + a) : c(a + b)
<br>
Tripolars (pending)
<br><b>
X(37) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) - 2r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(1). Let A" be the centroid of
triangle AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. Then the lines AA",
BB", CC" concur in X(37). (Eric Danneels, Hyacinthos 7892, 9/13/03)
</p><p>
A simple construction of X(37) as a crosspoint can be generalized as
follows: let DEF be the medial triangle of ABC and let A'B'C' be the
cevian triangle of a point U other than the centroid, X(2). The
crosspoint of X(2) and U is then the point of concurrence of lines
LD,ME,NF, where L,M,N are the respective midpoints of AA', BB', CC'. If
U=u : v : w (trilinears), then crosspoint(X(2),U) = b/w+c/v : c/u+a/w :
a/v+b/u, assuming that uvw is nonzero. In particular, if U=X(1), then
the crosspoint is X(37). (Seiichi Kirikami, July 10, 2011)
</p><p>
X(37) = perspector of ABC and the medial triangle of the incentral
triangle of ABC. (Randy Hutson, August 23, 2011)
</p><p>
X(37) = center of the Hofstadter ellipse E(1/2); see X(359). This is the incentral inellipse, which is the trilinear square of the antiorthic axis. (Randy Hutson, August 9, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A' be the trilinear pole of the tangent to the Apollonius circle where it meets the A-excircle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(37). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the A-extraversion of the Conway circle (the circle centered at the A-excenter and passing through A, with radius sqrt(r<sub>a</sub>^2 + s^2), where r<sub>a</sub> is the A-exradius). Let La be the radical axis of the circumcircle and Oa. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(37). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(37).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(37)</a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(37).ggb"><b>X(37)</b></a></b></a>.
</p><p>
X(37) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 2,75 3,975 7,241
8,941 10,594 12,225
19,25 21,172 35,267
38,354 39,596 41,584
48,205 63,940 65,71

226,440 256,694 347,948

579,942 626,746 665,900 971,991
1953,2183
</p><p>
X(37) is the {X(1),X(9)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(37), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.

<h3 id="X38">X(38) = CROSSPOINT OF X(1) AND X(75)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> : a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup><br>
= csc A sin(A + &omega;) : csc B sin(B + &omega;) : csc C sin(C +
&omega;)<br>
= S<sub>A</sub> + S<sub>&omega;</sub> : S<sub>B</sub> +
S<sub>&omega;</sub> : S<sub>C</sub> + S<sub>&omega;</sub>
<p>Barycentrics a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) :
b(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : c(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)<br> =
sin(A + &omega;) : sin(B + &omega;) : sin(C + &omega;)<br><b>X(38) = 3r<sup>2</sup> + 8rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) -
4r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013) </b></p>
<p>X(38) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 2,244 3,976 8,986
9,614 10,596 37,354
42,518 56,201 57,612
75,310 78,988 92,240
99,745 210,899 321,726
869,980 912,1064 1038,1106</p>
<p>X(38) is the {X(1),X(63)}-harmonic conjugate of X(31). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(38), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
<p>X(38) = isogonal conjugate of X(82)<br>
X(38) = isotomic conjugate of X(3112)<br>
X(38) = anticomplement of X(1215)<br>
X(38) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(75)<br>

X(38) = PU(35)-harmonic conjugate of X(661)<br>

<h3 id="X39">X(39) = BROCARD MIDPOINT<a id="BrocardMidpoint" name="BrocardMidpoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) : b(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : c(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Trilinears sin(A + &omega;) : sin(B + &omega;) : sin(C + &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears sin A + sin(A + 2&omega;) : sin B + sin(B + 2&omega;) : sin C + sin(C + 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - cos(A + 2&omega;) : cos B - cos(B + 2&omega;) : cos C - cos(C + 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears sin A + cos A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin A cot &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears a + 2R cos A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) : b<sup>2</sup>(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : c<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)
<br><b>
X(39) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)X(1) - 6rR(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(2) - 2r<sup>2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
<br>
X(39) = P(1) + U(1)
</b><p>
X(39) is the midpoint of the 1st and 2nd Brocard points, given by trilinears c/b : a/c : b/a and b/c : c/a : a/b. The third and fourth trilinear representations were given by Peter J. C. Moses (10/3/03); cf. X(511), X(32), X(182).
</p><p>
The locus of the nine-point center in a Brocard porism (triangles sharing circumcircle and Brocard inellipse with ABC) is the circle through X(5) with center X(39).
(Randy Hutson, August 29, 2018)
</p><p>
<b>Ross Honsberger,</b> <i>Episodes in Nineteenth and Twentieth Century Euclidean Geometry,</i> Mathematical Association of America, 1995. Chapter 10: The Brocard Points.
<p>
X(39) lies on the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(99) and on these lines:<br>
1,291 2,76 3,6 4,232
5,114 9,978 10,730
36,172 37,596 51,237
54,248 83,99 110,755
140,230 141,732 185,217
213,672 325,626 395,618
493,494 512,881 588,589
590,642 597,1084 615,641</p>
<p>X(39) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(32). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(39), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>

<h3 id="X40">X(40) = BEVAN POINT</h3>
Trilinears cos B + cos C - cos A - 1 : :
<br>
Trilinears b/(c + a - b) + c/(a + b - c) - a/(b + c -a) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin<sup>2</sup>(B/2) + sin<sup>2</sup>(C/2) - sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears a^3 + a^2(b + c) - a(b + c)^2 - (b + c)(b - c)^2 : :
<br>
Trilinears b(tan B/2) + c(tan C/2) - a(tan A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears (r/R) - 2 cos A : :
<b><br> X(40) = X(1) - 2X(3) = 2R*X(4) - (r + 4R)*X(9)<br>
X(40) = X[1] - 3 X[165] = 2 X[3] - 3 X[165] = 3 X[376] - X[944] = 5 X[631] - 4 X[1125] = 3 X[1] - 4 X[1385] = 9 X[165] - 4 X[1385] = 3 X[3] - 2 X[1385] = 3 X[1] - 2 X[1482] = 9 X[165] - 2 X[1482] = 3 X[3] - X[1482] = 4 X[5] - 5 X[1698] = 4 X[5] - 3 X[1699] = 5 X[1698] - 3 X[1699] = 2 X[3095] - 3 X[3097] = X[145] - 5 X[3522] = 2 X[551] - 3 X[3524] = 2 X[3244] - 7 X[3528] = 8 X[1385] - 9 X[3576] = 4 X[1482] - 9 X[3576] = 2 X[1] - 3 X[3576] = 4 X[3] - 3 X[3576] = 3 X[3576] - 8 X[3579]
</b><p>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(40).ggb"><b>X(40)</b></a></b></a>.
</p><p>
This point is mentioned in a problem proposal by Benjamin Bevan, published in Leybourn's <i>Mathematical Repository</i>, 1804, p. 18.
</p><p>
Constructions received from Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015:
<br>
(1) Let A'B'C' be the extangents triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A' in BC, and define B", C" cyclically. A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(40).
<br>
(2) Let A'B'C' be the extangents triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(40).
<br>
(3) Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle and A"B"C" be the side-triangle of ABC and hexyl triangle. Let A* be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A", and define B*, C* cyclically. The lines A'A*, B'B*, C'C* concur in X(40).
<br>
(4) Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib, Ic cyclically. X(40) = X(104)-of-IaIbIc.
<br>
(5) Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(189). Let A" be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(40).
(6) Let A'B'C' be the mixtilinear incentral triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(40).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle of the extangents triangle, if ABC is acute. Then A'B'C' is homothetic to the Aquila triangle at X(40). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A'BC, of A. Define B" and C" cyclically. (A" is also the reflection of A' in BC, and cyclically for B" and C"). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(40). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(40) lies on the following curves: Q010, Q122, K004, K033, K100, K133, K179, K199, K269, K308, K333, K338, K343, K384, K414, K619, K667, K679, K692, K710, K736, K750, K806, K807, K815, K826, the Jerabek hyhperbola of the excentral triangle, the Mandart hyperbola, and these lines:<br>

<h3 id="X41">X(41) = X(6)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(31)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>(b + c - a) : b<sup>2</sup>(c + a - b) : c<sup>2</sup>(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>cot(A/2) : b<sup>2</sup>cot(B/2) : c<sup>2</sup>cot(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>(a - s) : b<sup>2</sup>(b - s) : c<sup>2</sup>(c - s)
<br>
Trilinears a tan A' : : , where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>(b + c - a) : b<sup>3</sup>(c + a - b) : c<sup>3</sup>(a + b - c)
<br><b>
X(41) = (r + 2R)(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR(r + 4R)*X(2) -2r(<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(41).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(41)</a>.
</p><p>
X(41) lies on these lines: 1,101 3,218
6,48 9,21 25,42 31,32
37,584 55,220 58,609
65,910 219,1036 226,379
560,872 601,906 603,911 663,884</p>
<p>X(41) is the {X(32),X(213)}-harmonic conjugate of X(31). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(41), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.</p>

<h3 id="X42">X(42) CROSSPOINT OF INCENTER AND SYMMEDIAN POINT</h3>
Trilinears a(b + c) : b(c + a) : c(a + b)
<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)(cos B + cos C) : (1 + cos B)(cos C + cos A) : (1 + cos C)(cos A + cos B)
<br>
Trilinears a(ar - S) : b(br - S): c(cr - S)
<br>
Trilinears csc B + csc C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) : b<sup>2</sup>(c + a) : c<sup>2</sup>(a + b)
<br>
Tripolars (pending)
<p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href= "X(42).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(42)</a>.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extangents triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(42). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extangents triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(42).(Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb be as defined at X(3588). Let A* be the intersection of the tangents to the Myakishev conic at Ba and Ca, and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(42).(Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(42) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,967 6,31 9,941
25,41 33,393 35,58
37,210 38,518 40,581
48,197 57,1001 65,73

other harmonic conjugates of X(42), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
