<h3 id="X43">X(43) = X(6)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears ab + ac - bc : bc + ba - ca : ca + cb - ab
<br>
Trilinears csc B + csc C - csc A : csc C + csc A - csc B : csc A + csc B - csc C
<br>
Barycentrics a(ab + ac - bc) : b(bc + ba - ca) : c(ca + cb - ab)
<p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of the midpoint of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inscribed in the Apollonius circle and homothetic to the excentral triangle at X(43). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(43) lies on the Kiepert hyperbola of the excentral triangle and these lines: <br>1,2 6,87 9,256 31,100
35,1011 40,970 46,851
55,238 57,181 58,979
72,986 75,872 81,750
165,573 170,218 210,984
312,740 518,982
</p><p>
X(43) is the {X(2),X(42)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(43), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page. X(43) is the external center of similitude of the Bevan
circle and Apollonius circle; the internal center is X(1695).
</p><p>
X(43) = reflection of X(1) in X(995)<br>
X(43) = isogonal conjugate of X(87)<br>
X(43) = isotomic conjugate of X(6384)<br>
X(43) = anticomplement of X(3840)<br>
X(43) = X(6)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(43) = X(192)-cross conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(43) = crosssum of X(2) and X(330)<br>
X(43) = X(55)-Hirst inverse of X(238)<br>
X(43) = inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of X(5121)<br>
X(43) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(87)<br>
X(43) = trilinear product of extraversions of X(87)<br>
X(43) = excentral-isogonal conjugate of X(1766)<br>
X(43) = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of X(22370)<br>
X(43) = perspector of Gemini triangle 5 and cross-triangle of Gemini triangles 3 and 5<br>
X(43) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j):<br>(1,9), (6,43), (55,170), (100,1018), (174,169), (259,165), (365,1), (366,63), (507,362), (509,57)<br>

<h3 id="X44">X(44) = X(6)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears b + c - 2a
: c + a - 2b : a + b - 2c<br>Barycentrics a(b + c - 2a) : b(c + a - 2b) : c(a + b -
2c)<br><br><b>X(44) = (3r<sup>2</sup> + 6rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 18rR*X(2) -

<h3 id="X46">X(46) X(4)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>

<br>

<br>

<p>
Let Ja' be the reflection of the A-excenter in BC, and define Jb', Jc' cyclically. Let Oa be the circumcenter of AJb'Jc', and define Ob, Oc cyclically. OaObOc and ABC are perspective at X(46). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-Bevan-circle of the A-vertex of the hexyl triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(46). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let JaJbJc be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the inverse-in-Bevan-circle of A, and define B", C" cyclically. The lines JaA", JbB", JcC" concur in X(46). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X47">X(47) = X(110)-BETH CONJUGATE OF X(34)</h3>

(Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)

<h3 id="X49">X(49) = CENTER OF SINE-TRIPLE-ANGLE CIRCLE</h3>
Trilinears cos 3A : cos 3B : cos 3C
<br>
Trilinears cos(B - C) - cos(C - A) cos(A - B) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos 3A : sin B cos 3B : sin C cos 3C
<br>
Barycentrics a^4 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2) (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2 - b^2 c^2) : :
<br><b>
X(49) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6R(R + r)*X(2) - 3(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR +
R<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p></b>
<p><b>
V. Thebault,</b> "Sine-triple-angle-circle," <i>Mathesis</i> 65 (1956) 282-284.
</p><p>
X(49) lies on these lines: 1,215 3,155
4,156 5,54 24,568
52,195 93,94 381,578
</p><p>
Suppose that P and Q are distinct points in the plane of a triangle ABC . Let P<sub>A</sub> = reflection of P in line AQ, let Q<sub>A</sub> = reflection of Q in line AP, and let M<sub>A</sub> = midpoint of segment P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>. Define M<sub>B</sub> and M<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Cï¿½sar Lozada found that if Q = isogonal conjugate of P, then the locus of P for which M<sub>A</sub>M<sub>B</sub>M<sub>C</sub> is perspective to ABC is the union of a cubic and 6 circles: specifically, the McCay cubic (K003), the circles {{B,C,B',C'}}, {{C,A,C',A'}}, {{A,B,A',B'}}, and the circles {{B,C,A'}}, {{C,A,B'}}, {{A,B,C'}}, where A',B',C' are the excenters of ABC. Moreover, if P = X(3) and Q = X(4), then M<sub>A</sub>M<sub>B</sub>M<sub>C</sub> is not only perspective, but homothetic, to ABC, and the center of homothety is X(49).
See <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/23265">Hyacinthos 23265, June 1, 2015.</a>
</p><p>
X(49) is the {X(54),X(110)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(49), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(49) = isogonal conjugate of X(93)<br>
X(49) = isotomic conjugate of X(20572)<br>
X(49) = X(4)-isoconjugate of X(2962)<br>
X(49) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(2963)<br>
X(49) = eigencenter of cevian triangle of X(94)<br>
X(49) = eigencenter of anticevian triangle of X(50)<br>
X(49) = X(94)-Ceva conjugate of X(50)
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X50">X(50) = X(74)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(184)</h3>
Trilinears sin 3A : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A sin 2A + sin A cos 2A : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A + cos A cot D/2 : : , where cot D/2 = (4*area)/(6R<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>), where R = abc/(4*area) (Peter Moses, 12/19/2011; cf.
X(568))
<br>
Trilinears a(1 - 4 cos<sup>2</sup>A) : b(1 - 4 cos<sup>2</sup>B) : c(1 - 4 cos<sup>2</sup>C)
<br>
Trilinears a(1 + 2 cos 2A) : b(1 + 2 cos 2B) : c(1 + 2 cos 2C)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sin 3A : sin B sin 3B : sin C sin 3C<br>
<br>
Barycentrics a^4 ((a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2 c^2) : :
<br>
Tripolars (pending)
<b><br>
X(50) = -(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + 3R<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 6rR(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + 3R<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(2) + 2r<sup>2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + 3R<sup>2</sup> - 3s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
Let DEF be any equilateral triangle inscribed in the circumcircle of ABC. Let D' be the barycentric product E*F, and define E', F' cyclically. Then D',E',F' all line on a line passing through X(50). In the special case that DEF is the circumtangential triangle, the points D',E',F' lie on the Brocard axis, and in case DEF is the circumnormal triangle, the points D',E'F' lie on the line X(50)X(647). See also X(6149). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the (equilateral) circumcevian triangles of X(15) and X(16). Let A* be the barycentric product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(50). See also X(6149). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p><p>
Let AA<sub>1</sub>A<sub>2</sub>, BB<sub>1</sub>B<sub>2</sub>, CC<sub>1</sub>C<sub>2</sub> be the circumcircle-inscribed equilateral triangles used in the construction of the Trinh triangle. Let A' be the barycentric product A<sub>1</sub>*A<sub>2</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(50); see also X(6149). (Randy Hutson, October 13, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 and A2B2C2 be the 1st and 2nd Ehrmann circumscribing triangles. Let A' be the crossdifference of A1 and A2, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(50). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(50) lies on these lines: 3,6 67,248 112,477 115,231 230,858 338,401 647,654
</p><p>
X(50) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(566). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(40), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(50) = isogonal conjugate of X(94)<br>
X(50) = isotomic conjugate of X(20573)<br>
X(50) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32761)<br>
X(50) = Brocard-circle-inverse of X(566)<br>
X(50) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,215), (74,184), (94,49)<br>
X(50) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (93,94), (186,323)<br>
X(50) = crosssum of X(49) and X(50)<br>
X(50) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(5)X(523)<br>
X(50) = barycentric product of X(15) and X(16)<br>
X(50) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (92,265), (1577,476)<br>
X(50) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(568)<br>
X(50) = perspector of circumconic passing through X(110) and the isogonal conjugates of PU(5)<br>
X(50) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(11597)<br>

<h3 id="X51">X(51) = CENTROID OF ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a[a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>] : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A (sin 2B + sin 2C) : :
<br>
Trilinears sec A (csc 2B + csc 2C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>cos(B - C) : b<sup>3</sup>cos(C - A) : c<sup>3</sup>cos(A - B)
<br>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(51) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR +
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 6R(R - r)*X(2) - (r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR -
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplementary triangle and let Ba and Ca be the orthogonal projections of B' and C' on BC, respectively. Define Cb and Ac cyclically, and define Ab and Bc cyclically. Then X(51) is the centroid of BaCaCbAbAcBc. (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
Let L be the van Aubel line. Let U = X(6)X(25), the isogonal conjugate of polar conjugate of L; let V = X(4)X(51), the polar conjugate of the isogonal conjugate of L. Then X(51) = U&cap;V. (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let Oa be the A-McCay circle of triangle AB'C', and define Ob, Oc cyclically. X(51) is the radical center of circles Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(51) lies on these lines:<br>2,262 4,185 5,52 6,25
21,970 22,182 23,575
24,578 26,569 31,181
39,237 44,209 54,288
107,275 125,132 129,137
130,138 199,572 210,374
216,418 381,568 397,462
398,463 573,1011</p>
<p>X(51) is the {X(5),X(143)}-harmonic conjugate of X(52). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(51), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(51) = reflection of X(210) in X(375)<br>
X(51) = isogonal conjugate of X(95)<br>
X(51) = complement of X(2979)<br>
X(51) = anticomplement of X(3819)<br>

X(51) = X(217)-cross conjugate of X(216)<br>
X(51) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,6), (5,53)<br>
X(51) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,3), (6,160), (54,97)<br>

X(51) = inverse-in-orthosymmedial-circle of X(125)<br>
X(51) = X(2) of tangential triangle of Johnson circumconic<br>
X(51) = trilinear pole of polar of X(276) wrt polar circle<br>
X(51) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(276) (line X(340)X(520))<br>
X(51) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(276)<br>
X(51) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(97)<br>
X(51) = Zosma transform of X(92)<br>
X(51) = perspector of 1st & 2nd orthosymmedial triangles<br>
X(51) = bicentric sum of PU(157)<br>
X(51) = PU(157)-harmonic conjugate of X(647)<br>
X(51) = perspector of orthic-of-orthocentroidal triangle and orthocentroidal-of-orthic triangle<br>
X(51) = centroid of reflection triangle of X(125)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X52">X(52) = ORTHOCENTER OF ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears cos 2A cos(B - C) : cos 2B cos(C - A) : cos 2C cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears sec A (sec 2B + sec 2C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - 2B) + cos(A - 2C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan A (sec 2B + sec 2C) : tan B (sec 2C + sec 2A) : tan C (sec 2A + sec 2B)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2a^2b^2 - 2a^2c^2)[a^2(b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2] : :
<br>
Tripolars (pending)
<b><br>
X(52) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) - (r<sup>2</sup> - 4rR - 2R<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let Ha be the foot of the A-altitude. Let Ba be the foot of the perpendicular from Ha to CA, and define Cb and Ac cyclically. Let Ca be the foot of the perpendicular from Ha to AB, and define Ab and Bc cyclically. Let A' be the orthocenter of HaBaCa, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines HaA', HbB', HcC' concur in X(52). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(52) lies on these lines:<br>3,6 4,68 5,51 25,155
26,184 30,185 49,195
113,135 114,211 128,134 129,139</p>
<p>X(52) is the {X(5),X(143)}-harmonic conjugate of X(51). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(52), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(52) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,389), (5,143), (113,1112), (1209,973)<br>
X(52) = isogonal conjugate of X(96)<br>
X(52) = anticomplement of X(1216)<br>
X(52) = circumcircle-inverse of X(32762)<br>
X(52) = Brocard-circle-inverse of X(569)<br>
X(52) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,5), (317,467), (324,216)<br>
X(52) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(24)<br>
X(52) = crosssum of X(3) and X(68)<br>
X(52) = {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(569)<br>
X(52) = orthic isogonal conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(52) = X(20)-of-2nd Euler triangle<br>
X(52) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Euler triangle<br>
X(52) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Kosnita triangle<br>
X(52) = antipode of X(113) in Hatzipolakis-Lozada hyperbola<br>
X(52) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(571)<br>
X(52) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(5392)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X53">X(53) = SYMMEDIAN POINT OF ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears tan A cos(B - C) : tan B cos(C - A) : tan C cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics a tan A cos(B - C) : b tan B cos(C - A) : c tan C cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics (a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2)/(a^2 - b^2 - c^2) : : <p>
Let A'B'C' be the Euler triangle. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the trilinear polar of A', and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A" be L<sub>B</sub>nL<sub>C</sub>, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(53). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(53) lies on these lines:<br>4,6 5,216 25,157 30,577
45,281 115,133 128,139
137,138 141,264 232,427
273,1086 275,288 311,324
317,524 318,594 395,472 396,473</p>
<p>X(53) is the {X(4),X(393)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(53), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(53) = isogonal conjugate of X(97)<br>
X(53) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,51), (324,5)<br>
X(53) = X(51)-cross conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(53) = crosssum of X(3) and X(577)<br>
X(53) = Kosnita(X(4),X(6)) point<br>
X(53) = trilinear pole of line X(12077)X(15451) (the polar of X(95) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(53) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(95) (line X(323)X(401))<br>
X(53) = polar conjugate of X(95)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X54">X(54) = KOSNITA POINT<a id="KosnitaPoint" name="KosnitaPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears sec(B - C) : sec(C - A) : sec(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears a/(b cos B + c cos C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec(B - C) : sin B sec(C - A) : sin C sec(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2/(S^2 + SB SC) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2/(b^4 + c^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2 - 2b^2c^2) : :
<p>
<b>John Rigby,</b> "Brief notes on some forgotten geometrical
theorems," <i>Mathematics and Informatics Quarterly</i> 7 (1997)
156-158.</p>
<p>Let O be the circumcenter of triangle ABC, and O<sub>A</sub> the
circumcenter of triangle BOC. Define O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub>
cyclically. Then the lines AO<sub>A</sub>, BO<sub>B</sub>,
CO<sub>C</sub> concur in X(54). For details and generalization, see</p>
<p><b>Darij Grinberg,</b>
<a href=
"http://mathforum.org/epigone/geometry-college/kherlchogrur">A New
Circumcenter Question</a></p>
<p>The above construction of X(54) generalizes. Suppose that P and Q
are points (as functions of a,b,c). Let A' = Q-of-BCP, B' = Q-of-CAP,
C' = Q-of-ABP. If the lines AA', BB', CC' concur, the perspector is
called the Kosnita(P,Q) point, denoted by K(P,Q). (Randy Hutson,
9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let N<sub>A</sub>N<sub>B</sub>N<sub>C</sub> be the reflection triangle of X(5). Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circumcenter of AN<sub>B</sub>N<sub>C</sub>, and define O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Triangle O<sub>A</sub>O<sub>B</sub>O<sub>C</sub> is perspective to ABC at X(54), homothetic to the orthic-of-orthocentroidal triangle at X(54), and orthologic to the reflection triangle at X(54). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p>
<table align="center" border="2">
<tr>
<td>X(3) = K(X(20),X(2))</td>
<td>X(4) = K(X(20,X(20)</td>
<td>X(5) = K(X(4),X(2))</td>
</tr><tr>
<td>X(13) = K(X(13),X(1))</td>
<td>X(17) = K(X(13),X(3))</td>
<td>X(18) = K(X(14),X(3))</td>
</tr><tr>
<td>X(140) = K(X(3), X(2))</td>
<td>X(251) = K(X(6), X(6))</td>
</tr><tr>
<td>X(481) = K(X(175),X(1))</td>
<td>X(482) = K(X(176),X(1))</td>
</tr></table>
<p></p>
Let (Na) be the reflection of the nine-point circle in BC, and define (Nb) and (Nc) cyclically. X(54) is the radical center of (Na), (Nb), (Nc). The tangents at A, B, C to the Napoleon-Feuerbach cubic K005 concur in X(54). Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" be Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(54). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
<p></p>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(54).ggb"><b>X(54)</b></a></b></a>.
</p><p>
X(54) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines:<br>1,3460 2,68 3,97 4,184
5,49 6,24 12,215 36,73
39,248 51,288 64,378
69,95 71,572 72,1006
74,185 112,217 140,252
156,381 186,389 276,290
575,895 826,879 3336,3468
<p>X(54) is the {X(5),X(49)}-harmonic conjugate of X(110). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(54), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(54) = midpoint of X(3) and X(195)<br>
X(54) = reflection of X(195) in X(1493)<br>
X(54) = isogonal conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(54) = isotomic conjugate of X(311)<br>
X(54) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(1157)<br>
X(54) = complement of X(2888)<br>
X(54) = anticomplement of X(1209)<br>
X(54) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (5,2120), (95,97), (288,6)<br>
X(54) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(184)<br>
X(54) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (3,96), (6,275), (186,74), (389,4), (523,110)<br>
X(54) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {4,3459}, {95,275}<br>
X(54) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,195), (51,216), (627,628)<br>
X(54) = X(24)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(54) = trilinear pole of line X(50)X(647) (the polar of X(324) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(54) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(324)<br>
X(54) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(324)<br>
X(54) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(216)<br>
X(54) = intersection of tangents to hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),X(5)}} at X(4) and X(3459)<br>
X(54) = {X(2595),X(2596)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1087)<br>
X(54) = trilinear product of vertices of circumnormal triangle<br>
X(54) = intersection of tangents at X(3) and X(4) to Neuberg cubic K001<br>
X(54) = exsimilicenter of nine-point circle and sine-triple-angle circle<br>
X(54) = homothetic center of orthocevian triangle of X(3) and circumorthic triangle<br>
X(54) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of reflection triangle<br>
X(54) = X(3)-of-reflection-triangle-of-X(5)<br>
X(54) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and circumorthic triangle<br>
X(54) = perspector of ABC and Hatzipolakis-Moses triangle<br>
X(54) = X(191)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(54) = trilinear product of vertices of X(4)-altimedial triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X55">X(55) = INSIMILICENTER(CIRCUMCIRCLE, INCIRCLE)</h3>
Trilinears a(b + c - a) : b(c + a - b) : c(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos A : 1 + cos B : 1 + cos C
<br>
Trilinears cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2)
<br>
Trilinears tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) : tan(C/2) + tan(A/2) : tan(A/2) + tan(B/2)
<br>
Trilinears a(a - s) : b(b - s) : c(c - s)
<br>
Trilinears a(cot A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>/(1 - cos A) : :
<br>
Trilinears a(2ar - S) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b + c - a) : b<sup>2</sup>(c + a - b) : c<sup>2</sup>(a + b - c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics area(A'BC) : : , where A'B'C' = 1st circumperp triangle
<b><br>
X(55) = R*X(1) + r*X(3)<br>
X(55) = (Ra+Rb+Rc)*X(1) + r*Ja + r*Jb + r*Jc, where Ja, Jb, Jc are excenters, and Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<p></b>
X(55) = center of homothety of three triangles: tangential, intangents, and extangents. Also, X(55) is the pole-with-respect-to-the-circumcircle of the trilinear polar of X(1). These properties and others are given in
</p><p>
<b>O. Bottema and J. T. Groenman,</b> "De gemene raaklijnen van de vier raakcirkels van een driehoek, twee aan twee," <i>Nieuw Tijdschrift voor Wiskunde</i> 67 (1979-80) 177-182.
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the second points of intersection of the angle bisectors of triangle ABC with its incircle. Let Oa be the circle externally tangent to the incircle at A', and internally tangent to the circumcircle; define Ob and Oc cyclically. Then X(55) is the radical center of circles Oa, Ob, Oc. Let A" be the touchpoint of Oa and the circumcircle, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(55). Let Ba, Ca be the intersections of lines CA, AB, respectively, and the antiparallel to BC through a point P. Define Cb, Ab, Ac, Bc cyclically. Triangles ABaCa, AbBCb, AcBcC are congruent only when P = X(55) or one of its 3 extraversions. Let A*B*C* be the incentral triangle. Let La be the reflection of line BC in line AA*, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A''' = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B''' and C'''. The lines A*A''', B*B''', C*C''' concur in X(55). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extouch triangle. Let A" be the barycentric product of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(55). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
Let (Oa) be the circumcircle of BCX(1). Let Pa be the perspector of (Oa). Let La be the polar of Pa wrt (Oa). Define Lb and Lc cyclically. The lines La, Lb, Lc concur in X(55). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(55) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,11 4,12 5,498
6,31 7,2346 8,21 9,200 10,405
15,203 16,202 19,25
20,388 30,495 34,227
41,220 43,238 45,678
48,154 63,518 64,73
77,1037 78,960 81,1002
92,243 103,109 104,1000
108,196 140,496 181,573
182,613 183,350 184,215
192,385 199,1030 201,774
204,1033 219,284 223,1456 226,516
255,601 256,983 329,1005
376,1056 386,595 392,997
411,962 511,611 515,1012
519,956 574,1015 603,963
631,1058 650,884 654,926
748,899 840,901 846,984
869,893 1026,1083 1070,1076
1072,1074 2195,5452
</p><p>
X(55) is the {X(1),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(56). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(55), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(55) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1478,495), (2099,1)<br>
X(55) = isogonal conjugate of X(7)<br>
X(55) = isotomic conjugate of X(6063)<br>
X(55) = centroid of curvatures of circumcircle and excircles<br>
X(55) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(1155)<br>
X(55) = complement of X(3434)<br>
X(55) = anticomplement of X(2886)<br>
X(55) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,6), (3,198), (7,218), (8,219), (9,220), (21,9), (59,101), (104,44), (260,259), (284,41)<br>
X(55) = cevapoint of X(42) and X(228) for these (i,j)<br>
X(55) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (41,6), (42,33), (228,212)<br>
X(55) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,9), (3,268), (7,277), (8,281), (21,284), (59,101)<br>
X(55) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,57), (2,145), (4,196), (11,514), (55,218), (56,222), (63,224), (65,226), (81,229), (177,234), (241,1362), (513,1086), (905,1364), (1361,1465)<br>
X(55) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(241)X(514)<br>
X(55) = X(i)-Hirst inverse of X(j) for these (i,j): (6,672), (43,241)<br>
X(55) = X(1)-line conjugate of X(241)<br>
X(55) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (21,999), (55,31), (100,55), (200,200), (643,2), (1021,1024)<br>
X(55) = insimilicenter of the intangents and extangents circles<br>
X(55) = insimilicenter of the intangents and tangential circles<br>
X(55) = exsimilicenter of then extangents and tangential circles<br>
X(55) = X(22)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(55) = trilinear pole of line X(657)X(663) (polar of X(331) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(55) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(331)<br>
X(55) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(331)<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of ABC and Mandart-incircle triangle<br>
X(55) = inverse-in-Feuerbach-hyperbola of X(1001)<br>
X(55) = inverse-in-circumconic-centered-at-X(1) of X(1936)<br>
X(55) = {X(1),X(40)}-harmonic conjugate of X(65)<br>
X(55) = trilinear square of X(259)<br>
X(55) = Danneels point of X(100)<br>
X(55) = vertex conjugate of PU(48)<br>
X(55) = vertex conjugate of foci of Mandart inellipse<br>
X(55) = excentral isotomic conjugate of X(2942)<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of the reflections of the intangents and extangents triangles in their respective Euler lines<br>
X(55) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(56)<br>
X(55) = trilinear product of PU(104)<br>
X(55) = barycentric product of PU(112)<br>
X(55) = bicentric sum of PU(112)<br>
X(55) = PU(112)-harmonic conjugate of X(650)<br>
X(55) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of 7th mixtilinear triangle<br>
X(55) = perspector of 4th mixtilinear triangle and unary cofactor triangle of 7th mixtilinear triangle<br>
X(55) = perspector of unary cofactor triangles of 3rd, 4th and 5th extouch triangles<br>
X(55) = {X(3513),X(3514)}-harmonic conjugate of X(56)<br>
X(55) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and extangents triangle<br>
X(55) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Hutson extouch triangle<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Johnson-Yff triangle<br>
X(55) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(5657)<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of midarc triangle and 2nd-circumperp-of-1st-circumperp triangle (which is also 1st-circumperp-of-2nd-circumperp triangle)<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of 2nd midarc triangle and 1st-circumperp-of-1st-circumperp triangle (which is also 2nd-circumperp-of-2nd-circumperp triangle)<br>
X(55) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(942)<br>
X(55) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(943)<br>
X(55) = X(4)-of-1st-Johnson-Yff-triangle<br>
X(55) = homothetic center of anti-Hutson intouch triangle and anti-tangential midarc triangle<br>
X(55) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of excircles radical circle<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X56">X(56) = EXSIMILICENTER(CIRCUMCIRCLE, INCIRCLE)</h3>
Trilinears a/(b + c - a) : b/(c + a - b) : c/(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears 1 - cos A : 1 - cos B : 1 - cos C
<br>
Trilinears sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : sin<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : sin<sup>2</sup>(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears a(tan A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears Ra - r : Rb - r : Rc - r, where Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<br>
Trilinears a*Ra : b*Rb : c*Rc, where Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<br>
Trilinears a cos A - (c + a) cos B - (a + b) cos C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(b + c - a) : b<sup>2</sup>/(c + a - b) : c<sup>2</sup>/(a + b - c)</p>
<br>
Barycentrics area(A'BC) : : , where A'B'C' = 2nd circumperp triangle
<br><b>
X(56) = R*X(1) - r*X(3)
</b><p>
X(56) is the perspector of the tangential triangle and the reflection of the intangents triangle in X(1).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Fuhrmann triangle. Let La be the line through A' parallel to BC, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(56). Also, let AaBaCa be the poristic triangle (i.e., a triangle with common circumcircle and incircle as ABC) such that BaCa is parallel to BC. Define AbBbCb and AcBcCc cyclically. The lines AAa, BBb, CCc concur in X(56). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle. Let A" be the barycentric product of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(56). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have Geometer's Sketchpad, <a href="X(56).gsp"><b>X(56)</b></a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(56).ggb"><b>X(56)</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(56) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,12 4,11 5,499
6,41 7,21 8,404 10,474
19,207 20,497 22,977
25,34 28,278 30,496
31,154 32,1015 33,963
38,201 58,222 61,202
62,203 63,960 72,997
77,1036 78,480 81,959
85,870 87,238 100,145
101,218 105,279 106,109
140,495 181,386 182,611
197,227 212,939 219,579
220,672 223,937 226,405
255,602 266,289 269,738
330,385 376,1058 411,938
511,613 551,553 607,911
631,1056 667,764 946,1012
978,979 1025,1083 1070,1074
1072,1076 1345,2464
</p><p>
X(56) is the {X(1),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(55). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(56), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(56) = midpoint of X(1) and X(46)<br>
X(56) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1479,496), (2098,1)<br>
X(56) = isogonal conjugate of X(8)<br>

X(56) = X(266)-aleph conjugate of X(1050)<br>

<h3 id="X57">X(57) ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(b + c - a) : 1/(c + a - b) : 1/(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears tan(A/2) : tan(B/2) : tan(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos B + cos C - cos A
<br>
Trilinears 1 + sin(A/2)csc(B/2)csc(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2) + cos<sup>2</sup>(C/2) - cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2) ::
<br>
Trilinears S<sub>A</sub> - bc : S<sub>B</sub> - ca : S<sub>C</sub> - ab : :
<br>
Trilinears csc A - cot A : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - cos A) csc A : :
<br>
Trilinears b(cot B/2) + c(cot C/2) - a(cot A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cot A' : :, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears |AA'|/|AX(1)| : |BB'|/|BX(1)| : |CC'|/|CX(1)|, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears Ra : Rb : Rc, where Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<br>
Barycentrics: Ra - r : Rb - r : Rc - r, where Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<br>
Barycentrics a/(b + c - a) : b/(c + a - b) : c/(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics 1 - cos A : 1 - cos B : 1 - cos C
<br>
Barycentrics area(A'BC) : : , where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br><b>
X(57) = (Ra + Rb + Rc)*X(1) - r*Ja - r*Jb - r*Jc, where Ja, Jb, Jc are excenters, and Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
</b><p>
Let Ja, Jb, Jc be the excenters and I the incenter of ABC. Let Ka be the symmedian point of JbJcI, and define Kb, Kc cyclically. Then KaKbKc is perspective to ABC at X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the perspector of the circumconic centered at the A-excenter, and define B' and C'cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the mixtilinear incentral triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the perspector of the A-mixtilinear incircle, and define B' and C'cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B' and C'be the inverse-in-{circumcircle, incircle}-inverter of A, B, C. Let A"B"C" be the tangential triangle of A'B'C'. A"B"C" is perspective to the intouch triangle at X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the reflection of line B'C' in the internal angle bisector of A, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(57). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the circle passing through B and C, and tangent to the incircle. Define Ob and Oc cyclically. Let A' be the point of tangency of Oa and the incircle, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the intouch triangle at X(57). Also, X(57) is the radical center of circles Oa, Ob, Oc.
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(57). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>1</sub>B<sub>1</sub>C<sub>1</sub> be Gemini triangle 1. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>1</sub>,C<sub>1</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is the tangential of excentral triangle. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(57). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(57) is the perspector of the intouch triangle and excentral triangle.</p>
<p>X(57) lies on the Thomson cubic and these lines:<br>1,3 2,7 4,84 6,222

<h3 id="X58">X(58) ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(10)</h3>
Trilinears a/(b + c) : b/(c + a) : c/(a + b)
<br>
Trilinears (1 - cos A)/(cos B + cos C) : :
<br>
Trilinears sa<sup>2</sup> + SR : sb<sup>2</sup> + SR : sc<sup>2</sup> + SR
<br>
Trilinears r cos A - s sin A : : , where s = semiperimeter and r = inradius
<br>
Trilinears sin(A - U) : : , U as at X(572) and X(573)
<br>
Trilinears (R/r) - 1/(cos B + cos C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (r/R) - cos 2A + 1 : :
<br>
Trilinears eccentricity of A-Soddy ellipse : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(b + c) : b<sup>2</sup>/(c + a) : c<sup>2</sup>/(a + b)
<p>
X(58) is the point of concurrence of the Brocard axes of triangles BIC, CIA, AIB, ABC, (where I denotes the incenter, X(1)), as proved in <b>Antreas P. Hatzipolakis, Floor van Lamoen, Barry Wolk, and Paul Yiu,</b> <a href=
"http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2001volume1/FG200109index.html">Concurrency of Four Euler Lines,</a> <i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 1 (2001) 59-68.
</p><p>
Let (Sa) be the reflection of the Spieker circle in BC, and define (Sb), (Sc) cyclically. X(58) is the radical center of (Sa), (Sb), (Sc). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplement of the Feuerbach triangle. Let A"B"C" be the circumcevian triangle, wrt A'B'C', of X(1). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(58). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Feuerbach triangle. Let La be the tangent to the nine-point circle at A', and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate of the trilinear pole of La, and define B", C" cyclically. Let A* = BB"&cap;CC", B* = CC"&cap;AA", C* = AA"&cap;BB". The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(58). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd circumperp triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B", C" cyclically. A", B", C" are collinear on line X(36)X(238) (the trilinear polar of X(81)). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(58). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(58) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 2,540 3,6 7,272
8,996 9,975 10,171
20,387 25,967 27,270
28,34 29,162 35,42
36,60 40,601 41,609
43,979 46,998 56,222
65,109 82,596 84,990
86,238 87,978 99,727
101,172 103,112 106,110
229,244 269,1014 274,870
314,987 405,940 519,1043
942,1104 977,982 1019,1027
</p><p>
X(58) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(386). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(58), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(58) = isogonal conjugate of X(10)<br>

<h3 id="X60">X(60) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(12)</h3>

<h3 id="X61">X(61) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(17)</h3>
Trilinears sin(A + &pi;/6) : sin(B + &pi;/6) : sin(C + &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - &pi;/3) : cos(B - &pi;/3) : cos(C - &pi;/3)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sqrt(3) sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sin(A + &pi;/6) : sin B sin(B + &pi;/6) : sin C sin(C + &pi;/6)</p>
<p>X(61) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines:<br>1,203 2,18 3,6 4,13
5,14 30,397 56,202
140,395 299,636 302,629 618,627</p>
<p>X(61) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(62). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(61), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
<p>
X(61) = reflection of X(633) in X(635)<br>
X(61) = isogonal conjugate of X(17)<br>
X(61) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(62)<br>
X(61) = complement of X(633)<br>
X(61) = anticomplement of X(635)<br>
X(61) = eigencenter of cevian triangle of X(14)<br>
X(61) = eigencenter of anticevian triangle of X(16)<br>
X(61) = X(14)-Ceva conjugate of X(16)<br>
X(61) = crosspoint of X(302) and X(473)<br>

<h3 id="X62">X(62) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(18)</h3>
Trilinears sin(A - &pi;/6) : sin(B - &pi;/6) : sin(C - &pi;/6)
<br>
Trilinears cos(A + &pi;/3) : cos(B + &pi;/3) : cos(C + &pi;/3)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sqrt(3) sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sin(A - &pi;/6) : sin B sin(B - &pi;/6) : sin C sin(C - &pi;/6)
</p><p>
X(62) lies the Napoleon cubic and these lines:<br>1,202 2,17 3,6 4,14
5,13 30,398 56,203
140,396 298,635 303,630 619,628</p>
<p>X(62) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(61). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(62), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(62) = reflection of X(634) in X(636)<br>
X(62) = isogonal conjugate of X(18)<br>
X(62) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(61)<br>
X(62) = complement of X(634)<br>

<h3 id="X63">X(63) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(19)</h3>
Trilinears cot A : cot B : cot C
<br>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> : a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears S<sub>A</sub> : S<sub>B</sub> : S<sub>C</sub>
<br>
Trilinears csc A - tan(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears csc A - cot(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears tan(A/2) - cot(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = directed distance from A to the orthic axis
<br>
Trilinears 2 csc 2A - tan A : :
<br>
Barycentrics cos A : cos B : cos C
<br><b>
X(63) = (r + 2R)*X(1) - 3R*X(2) - 2r*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
<br>
X(63) = (cos A)*[A] + (cos B)*[B] + (cos C)*[C], where A, B, C denote angles and [A], [B], [C] denote vertices
</b><p>
Let Oa be the A-extraversion of the Conway circle (the circle centered at the A-excenter and passing through A, with radius sqrt(r_a^2 + s^2), where r_a is the A-exradius). Let Pa be the perspector of Oa, and La the polar of Pa wrt Oa. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the excentral triangle at X(63). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd Brocard triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(63). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(63). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the side-triangle of ABC and hexyl triangle. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(63). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the isotomic conjugate, wrt triangle A'BC, of X(1). Define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(63).
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(63) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 2,7 3,72 6,2221 8,20 10,46 19,27 33,1013
36,997 37,940 48,326
55,518 56,960 65,958
69,71 77,219 91,921
100,103 162,204 169,379
171,612 190,312 194,239
201,603 210,1004 212,1040
213,980 220,241 223,651
238,614 240,1096 244,748
304,1102 318,412 354,1001
392,999 404,936 405,942
452,938 484,535 517,956
544,1018 561,799 654,918
750,756</p>
<p>X(63) is the {X(9),X(57)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(63), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(63) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,993), (1478,10)<br>

X(63) = excentral isogonal conjugate of X(1742)<br>

<br> X(63) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j):<br>(63,222), (190,63), (333,57), (345,345), (643,63), (645,312), (662,223)<br>
X(63) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(63), which is also the anticevian triangle of X(63)<br>

<h3 id="X64">X(64) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(20)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(cos A - cos B cos C) : 1/(cos B - cos C cos A) : 1/(cos C - cos A cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(cos A - cos B cos C) : b/(cos B - cos C cos A) : c/(cos C - cos A cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2/[3a^4 - 2a^2(b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2] : :
<p>
A construction of X(64) appears in Lemoine's 1886 paper cited at X(19).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the half-altitude triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(64). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the circle with segment BC as diameter. Let A' be the perspector of Oa. Let La be the polar of A' wrt Oa. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(64). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(69). Let A" be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(64). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection of the orthic triangle in X(4). Let A''B''C'' be the trangential triangle, with respect ot the orthic triangle, of the circumconic of the orthic triangle with center X(4); i.e., the bicevian conic of X(4) and X(459). Then X(64) is the perspector of A'B'C' and A''B''C''. (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
The tangents at A, B, C to the Darboux cubic K004 concur in X(64). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(64) lies on the Darboux cubic and these lines:<br>1,3182 3,154 4,3183
6,185 20,69 24,74 30,68
33,65 40,72 54,378
55,73 71,198 84,3353
265,382 3345,3472 3346,3355
</p><p>
X(64) = reflection of X(1498) in X(3)<br>
X(64) = isogonal conjugate of X(20)<br>
X(64) = isotomic conjugate of X(14615)<br>
X(64) = complement of X(6225)<br>
X(64) = anticomplement of X(2883)<br>
X(64) = X(25)-cross conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(64) = X(1)-beth conjugate of X(207)</p>
X(64) = crosssum of X(3) and X(1498)<br>
X(64) = perspector of hexyl triangle and anticevian triangle of X(2184)<br>
X(64) = trilinear pole of line X(647)X(657)<br>
X(64) = concurrence of normals to MacBeath circumconic at A, B, C<br>
X(64) = isogonal conjugate, wrt tangential triangle of MacBeath circumconic (or anticevian triangle of X(3)), of X(1498)<br>
X(64) = orthocenter of x(3)X(6)X(2435)<br>
X(64) = orthology center of ABC and half-altitude triangle<br>
X(64) = intersection of tangents at X(3) and X(4) to Thomson cubic K002<br>
X(64) = intersection of tangents at X(20) and X(64) to Darboux cubic K004<br>
X(64) = perspector of ABC and the reflection in X(3) of the antipedal triangle of X(3) (tangential triangle)<br>
X(64) = perspector of ABC and circumcircle antipode of circumanticevian triangle of X(3)<br>
X(64) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of half-altitude triangle<br>
X(64) = X(2136)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(64) = X(8905)-of-excentral-triangle<br>

<h3 id="X65">X(65) = ORTHOCENTER OF THE INTOUCH TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears cos B + cos C : cos C + cos A : cos A + cos B
<br>
Trilinears (b + c)/(b + c - a) : (c + a)/(c + a - b) : (a + b)/(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears sin(A/2) cos(B/2 - C/2) : sin(B/2) cos(C/2 - A/2) : sin(C/2) cos(A/2 - B/2)
<br>
Trilinears Ra + r : Rb + r : Rc + r, where Ra, Rb, Rc are the exradii
<br>
Barycentrics a(b + c)/(b + c - a) : b(c + a)/(c + a - b) : c(a + b)/(a + b - c)
<p>
Let A' be the intersections of the tangents to the Yiu conic at the points where they meet the A-excircle. Define B' and C' similarly. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(65). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac be the points where the A-excircle touches lines CA and AB resp., and define Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb cyclically. Let Ta be the intersection of the tangents to the Yiu conic (defined at X(478)) at Bc and Ca, and define Tb, Tc cyclically. Let Ta' be the intersection of the tangents to the Yiu conic at Ba and Cb, and define Tb', Tc' cyclically. Let Sa = TbTc&cap;Tb'Tc', Sb = TcTa&cap;Tc'Ta', Sc = TaTb&cap;Ta'Tb'. The lines ASa, BSb, CSc concur in X(65). (See also X(1903).) (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the homothetic center of the orthic triangles of the intouch and A-extouch triangles, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the extouch triangle at X(65). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let B'C'A" be the triangle similar to ABC such that segment A'A" crosses the line B'C'. Define B" and C" cyclically. Equivalently, A" is the reflection of A in B'C', and cyclically for B" and C". Let Ia be the incenter of B'C'A", and define Ib and Ic cyclically. The circumcenter of triangle IaIbIc is X(65). Let A* be the intersection of lines A"Ia and B'C', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A'A*, B'B*, C'C* concur in X(65). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac be the points where the A-excircle touches lines CA and AB resp., and define Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb cyclically. Let IaIbIc be the intouch triangle. Let Oa be the circle through Ab, Ac, Ib, Ic, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. X(65) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle of the extangents triangle, if ABC is acute. Then A'B'C' is perspective to the intouch triangle and 4th and 5th extouch triangles at X(65). (Randy Hutson, December 2 2017)
</p><p>
X(65) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,959 4,158 6,19
7,8 10,12 11,117 29,296
31,1104 33,64 37,71
41,910 42,73 44,374
58,109 63,958 68,91
74,108 77,969 79,80
81,961 110,229 169,218
172,248 224,1004 225,407
243,412 257,894 278,387
279,1002 386,994 409,1098
474,997 497,938 516,950
519,553 604,1100 651,895
1039,1041 1061,1063
</p><p>
X(65) is the {X(1),X(40)}-harmonic conjugate of X(55). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(65), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(65) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,942), (72,10)<br>

<h3 id="X67">X(67) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(23)</h3>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<p>
Let A' be the reflection in BC of the A-vertex of the antipedal triangle of X(6), and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, C'AB concur at X(67). Also, let A' be the reflection of X(6) in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, C'AB concur in X(67). Note: the above 2 sets of circumcircles are identical.
(Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(67) lies on these lines:<br>3,542 4,338 6,125
50,248 74,935 110,141
265,511 290,340 524,858 526,879
</p><p>
X(67) = midpoint of X(69) and X(3448)<br>
X(67) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (6,125), (110,141)<br>
X(67) = isogonal conjugate of X(23)<br>
X(67) = isotomic conjugate of X(316)<br>
X(67) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(3455)<br>
X(67) = cevapoint of X(141) and X(524)<br>
X(67) = X(187)-cross conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(67) = antigonal image of X(6)<br>
X(67) = trilinear pole of line X(39)X(647)<br>
X(67) = orthocenter of X(3)X(74)X(879)<br>
X(67) = perspector of ABC and X(2)-Ehrmann triangle; see X(25)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X68">X(68) PRASOLOV POINT</h3>
Trilinears cos A sec 2A : cos B sec 2B : cos C sec 2C
<br>
Barycentrics tan 2A : tan 2B : tan 2C
<br>
Barycentrics (b^2 + c^2 - a^2)/(a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2a^2b^2 - 2a^2c^2) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd Euler triangle. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(68), as proved in <b>V. V. Prasolov,</b> <i>Zadachi po planimetrii,</i> Moscow, 4th edition, 2001.
</p><p>
Coordinates for X(68) can be obtained easily from the Ceva ratios given his Prasolov's proof of concurrence.
</p><p>
Let Oa be the circle centered at the A-vertex of the orthic triangle and passing through A; define Ob and Oc cyclically. Then X(68) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
The X(3)-Fuhrmann triangle is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(3), and perspective to ABC at X(68). (Randy Hutson, November 3, 2017)
</p><p>
X(68) lies on these lines:<br>2,54 3,343 4,52 5,6
11,1069 20,74 26,161
30,64 65,91 66,511
73,1060 136,254 290,315 568,973
</p><p>
X(68) = reflection of X(155) in X(5)<br>
X(68) = isogonal conjugate of X(24)<br>
X(68) = isotomic conjugate of X(317)<br>
X(68) = anticomplement of X(1147)<br>
X(68) = X(96)-Ceva conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(68) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,161), (125,520)<br>
X(68) = X(115)-cross conjugate of X(525)<br>
X(68) = pedal antipodal perspector of X(4)<br>
X(68) = pedal antipodal perspector of X(186)<br>
X(68) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(924)X(6753)<br>
X(68) = trilinear product of vertices of X(3)-anti-altimedial triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X69">X(69) = SYMMEDIAN POINT OF THE ANTICOMPLEMENTARY TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (cos A)/a<sup>2</sup> : (cos B)/b<sup>2</sup> : (cos C)/c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : ca(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) : ab(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) - csc<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot A : cot B : cot C
<br>
Barycentrics b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> : a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup></p>
<br>
Barycentrics cot B + cot C - cot &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot B + cot C - cot A - cot &omega; : :
<br><b>
X(69) = 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 3(r<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(2) - 4r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
<br>
X(69) = (cot A)*[A] + (cot B)*[B] + (cot C)*[C], where A, B, C denote angles and [A], [B], [C] denote vertices
<p></b>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplementary triangle. Let A" be the inverse-in-anticomplementary-circle of A, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(69). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplementary triangle. Let A" be the orthogonal projection of A' on line BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(69).
(Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the half-altitude triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* be the trilinear pole of line B"C", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(69). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A2B2C2 be the 2nd Conway triangle. Let A' be the cevapoint of B2 and C2, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(69). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(69) lies on the Lucas cubic and these lines:<br>2,6 3,332 4,76 7,8 9,344 10,969 20,64
22,159 54,95 63,71
72,304 73,77 74,99
110,206 125,895 144,190
150,668 189,309 192,742
194,695 200,269 248,287
263,308 265,328 274,443
290,670 297,393 347,664
350,497 404,1014 478,651
485,639 486,640 520,879</p>
<p>X(69) is the {X(7),X(8)}-harmonic conjugate of X(75). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(69), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(69).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(69)</a>.
</p><p>
X(69) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (2,599), (4,1352), (6,141), (20,1350), (193,6), (895,125), (1351,5), (1353,140)

<h3 id="X70">X(70) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(26)</h3>

<br><b>
X(70) = (S cot &omega;- 2R<sup>2</sup>)/(S cot &omega;-3 R<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) - X(8907) (Peter Moses, December 28, 2015)
<p></b>
X(70) lies on the Jerabek circumhyperbola and these lines: <br>
{3,8907}, {6,1594}, {54,1899}, {64,6240}, {66,6403}, {71,2158}, {74,1288}, {265,6243}, {1176,1352}, {1177,3542}, {3448,5504}, {3527,7507}, {4846,6241}, {6145,6152}

<h3 id="X72">X(72) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(28)</h3>
Trilinears (b + c) cot A : (c + a) cot B : (a + b) cot C
<br>
Trilinears (b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : (c + a)(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) : (a + b)(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c) cos A : (c + a) cos B : (a + b) cos C
<br><b>
X(72) = (r + 2R)*X(1) - 3R*X(2) - r*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically. X(72) = X(11) of IaIbIc. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
X(72) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 2,942 3,63 4,8

this page.
</p><p>
X(72) is the perspector of the 1st and 2nd extouch triangles. X(72) is also the orthocenter of the 2nd extouch triangle. (Randy Hutson, August 23, 2011)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X73">X(73) CROSSPOINT OF INCENTER AND CIRCUMCENTER</h3>
Trilinears sec B + sec C : sec C + sec A : sec A + sec B
<br>
Trilinears a(b + c)(a^2 - b^2 - c^2)/(a - b - c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (cos B + cos C) sin 2A : (cos C + cos A) sin 2B : (cos A + cos B) sin 2C
<br><b> X(73) = (r<sup>2</sup> - 4R<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) + 4rR*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
X(73) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 3,212 6,41 21,651
35,74 36,54 37,836
42,65 55,64 57,386
66,976 68,1060 69,77
72,201 102,947 228,408
284,951 290,336 1036,1037
1057,1059
</p><p>
X(73) is the {X(1064),X(1066)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1). For a
list of other harmonic conjugates of X(73), click <b>Tables</b> at the
top of this page.
</p><p>
X(73) = isogonal conjugate of X(29)<br>
X(73) = X(1)-Ceva conjugate of X(65)<br>
X(73) = X(228)-cross conjugate of X(71)<br>
X(73) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,3), (77,222), (226,307)<br>
X(73) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,4), (33,281)<br>
X(73) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(243)X(522)<br>

</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X74">X(74) ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF EULER INFINITY POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1/(cos A - 2 cos B cos C) : 1/(cos B - 2 cos C cos A) : 1/(cos C - 2 cos A cos B)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(3 cos A - 2 sin B sin C) : 1/(3 cos B - 2 sin C sin A) : 1/(3 cos C - 2 sin A sin B)
<br>
Trilinears a/[2a<sup>4</sup> - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics a/(cos A - 2 cos B cos C) : b/(cos B - 2 cos C cos A) : c/(cos C - 2 cos A cos B)
</p> <p style="font-weight: bold">X(74) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR +
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - R(6r + 9R)*X(2) + (r<sup>2</sup> + 12rR +
18R<sup>2</sup> - 3s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April
2, 2013) </p>
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of the point in which the Euler line meets the line at infinity, X(74) lies on the circumcircle.</p>
<p>Let T be the triangle formed by reflecting the orthic axis in the
sidelines of ABC; then T is perspective to ABC, and the perspector ix
X(74). Let A' be the point of intersection of the orthic axis and line
BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. Let O<sub>A</sub> be the
circumcenter of AB'C', and define Let O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub>
cyclically; then the lines AO<sub>A</sub>, BO<sub>B</sub>,
CO<sub>C</sub> concur in X(74). (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)</p>
<p>Let A'B'C' be the anticomplementary triangle. Let L be the line
through A' parallel to the Euler line, and define M and N cyclically.
Let L' be the reflection of L in sideline BC, and define M' and N'
cyclically. The lines L', M', N' concur in X(74). (Randy Hutson, August
26, 2014)</p>
<p>Let A'B'C' be the X(3)-Fuhrmann triangle. Let A'' be the reflection
of A in line B'C', and define B'' and C'' cyclically. Then A''B''C'' is
inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(265), and A''B''C''
is perspective to ABC at X(74), which is also the orthocenter of
A''B''C''. (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)</p>
<p>In Hyacinthos 8129 (10/4/03), Floor van Lamoen noted that if X(74)
is denoted by J, then each of the points A,B,C,J is J of the other
three, in analogy with the well known property of orthocentric systems
(that is, each of the points A,B,C,H is the orthocenter of the other
three).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthocentroidal triangle and A"B"C" the anti-orthocentroidal triangle. Let A* be the reflection of A" in B'C', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(74). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anti-orthocentroidal triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(74). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
The tangents at A, B, C to the Neuberg cubic K001 concur in X(74)
</p><p>
X(74) lies on the circumcircle, Jerabek hyperbola, Neuberg cubic, Darboux septic curve, and these lines:<br>1,3464 2,113 3,110
4,107 6,112 20,68 24,64
30,265 35,73 54,185
65,108 67,935 69,99
71,101 72,100 98,690
187,248 477,523 484,3465
511,691 512,842 550,930
1157,3484
</p> <p>
X(74) = midpoint of X(20) and X(3448)<br>
X(74) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,125), (110,3), (146,113), (399,1511)<br>
X(74) = isogonal conjugate of X(30)<br>
X(74) = isotomic conjugate of X(3260)<br>
X(74) = complement of X(146)<br>
X(74) = anticomplement of X(113)<br>
X(74) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (15,16), (50,184)<br>
X(74) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,399), (616),617)<br>
X(74) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (186,54), (526,110)<br>
X(74) = circumcircle-antipode of X(110)<br>
X(74) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(647)<br>
X(74) = &Psi;(X(6),X(647))<br>
X(74) = reflection of X(477) in the Euler line<br>
X(74) = reflection of X(842) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(74) = reflection of X(2687) in the line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(74) = reflection of X(1296) in the line X(3)X(351)<br>
X(74) = {X(3),X(399)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1511)<br>
X(74) = X(128)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(74) = X(137)-of-hexyl-triangle<br>
X(74) = X(1296)-of-circumsymmedial<br>
X(74) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(133)<br>
X(74) = trilinear pole wrt circumorthic triangle of van Aubel line<br>
X(74) = inverse-in-O(15,16) of X(2715), where O(15,16) is the circle having segment X(15)X(16) as diameter<br>
X(74) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(2420)<br>
X(74) = orthocentroidal-to-ABC similarity image of X(4)<br>

X(74) = orthocenter of X(3)X(67)X(879)<br>
X(74) = intersection of tangents at X(3) and X(4) to Napoleon-Feuerbach cubic, K005<br>
X(74) = X(1317)-of-tangential-triangle is ABC is acute<br>
X(74) = 2nd-Parry-to-ABC similarity image of X(110)<br>
X(74) = X(80)-of-Trinh-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(74) = Trinh-isogonal conjugate of X(2071)<br>
X(74) = trilinear product of PU(86)<br>
X(74) = perspector of ABC and the (degenerate) side-triangle of the (equilateral) circumcevian triangles of X(15) and X(16)<br>
X(74) = homothetic center of X(15)- and X(16)-Ehrmann triangles; see X(25)<br>
X(74) = perspector of ABC and X(15)-Ehrmann triangle<br>
X(74) = perspector of ABC and X(16)-Ehrmann triangle<br>
X(74) = 3rd-Parry-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(23)<br>
X(74) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of orthocentroidal triangle<br>
X(74) = endo-homothetic center of X(4)-altimedial and X(4)-anti-altimedial triangles<br>
X(74) = Thomson isogonal conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(74) = Lucas isogonal conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(74) = X(100)-of-circumorthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X75">X(75) ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF INCENTER</h3>
Trilinears 1/a<sup>2</sup> : 1/b<sup>2</sup> : 1/c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears 1/(1 - cos 2A) : 1/(1 - cos 2B) : 1/(1 - cos 2C)
<br>
Trilinears S<sub>A</sub> + S<sup>2</sup> : S<sub>B</sub> + S<sup>2</sup> : S<sub>C</sub> + S<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) + csc<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = distance from A to Lemoine axis
<br>
Trilinears h(a,b,c) : : , where h(a,b,c) = (distance from A to antiorthic axis)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics 1/a : 1/b : 1/c
<br>
Barycentrics csc A : csc B : csc C
<br><b>
X(75) = (csc A)*[A] + (csc B)*[B] + (csc C)*[C], where A, B, C denote angles and [A], [B], [C] denote vertices
<p></b>
Let A2B2C2 be the 2nd Conway triangle. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line B2C2, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(75). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A4B4C4 be the 4th Conway triangle. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line B4C4, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(75). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let AaBaCa, AbBbCb, AcBcCc be the A-, B-, and C-anti-altimedial triangles, resp. Let A' be the trilinear product Ba*Ca, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(75). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>23</sub>B<sub>23</sub>C<sub>23</sub> be Gemini triangle 23. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>23</sub>,C<sub>23</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(75). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>40</sub>B<sub>40</sub>C<sub>40</sub> be Gemini triangle 40. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>40</sub>,C<sub>40</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(75). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
If you have Geometer's Sketchpad, <a href="X(75).gsp"><b>X(75)</b></a>.
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(75).ggb"><b>X(75)</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(75) lies on these lines:<br>1,86 2,37 6,239 7,8

<h3 id="X76">X(76) = 3rd BROCARD POINT<a id="ThirdBrocardPoint" name= "ThirdBrocardPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1/a<sup>3</sup> : 1/b<sup>3</sup> : 1/c<sup>3</sup>
<br>
Trilinears csc(A - &omega;) : csc(B - &omega;) : csc(C - &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/a<sup>2</sup> : 1/b<sup>2</sup> : 1/c<sup>2</sup>
<br><b>
X(76) = 3*X(2) - 2*X(39) = 3*X(2) - P(1) - U(1)
</b><p>
Let A' be the perspector of the A-McCay circle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(76). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
X(76) is the vertex conjugate of the foci of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of the de Longchamps line. The center of the inellipse is X(626) and its Brianchon point (perspector) is X(1502). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the obverse triangle of X(1). Let A"B"C" be the N-obverse triangle of X(1). Let A* be the barycentric product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(76). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(76) lies on these lines:<br>1,350 2,39 3,98 4,69

<h3 id="X77">X(77) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(33)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(1 + sec A) : 1/(1 + sec B) : 1/(1 + sec C)<br> =
cos A sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : cos B sec<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : cos C
sec<sup>2</sup>(C/2)<br> =
(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)/(b + c - a) :
(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)/(c + a - b) :
(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/(a + b - c)<br> =
S<sub>A</sub>(S<sub>A</sub> - bc) : S<sub>B</sub>(S<sub>B</sub> - ca) :
S<sub>C</sub>(S<sub>C</sub> - ab)
<p>Barycentrics a/(1 + sec A) : b/(1 + sec B) : c/(1 + sec
C)</p>
<p>X(77) lies on these lines:<br>1,7 2,189 6,241 9,651
29,34 40,947 55,1037
56,1036 57,81 63,219
65,969 69,73 75,664
102,934 283,603 309,318
738,951 988,1106 999,1057</p>
<p>X(77) = isogonal conjugate of X(33)<br>X(77) = isotomic conjugate of X(318)<br>X(77) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (85,57), (86,7),
(348,63)<br>X(77) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,223),
(3,222)<br>X(77) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (3,63),
(73,222)</p>
<p>X(77) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j):<br>(21,990), (69,69), (86,269), (99,75), (332,326), (336,77), (662,77),
(664,77), (811,77)</p>

<h3 id="X78">X(78) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(34)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(1 -
sec A) : 1/(1 - sec B) : 1/(1 - sec C)<br> =
cos A csc<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : cos B csc<sup>2</sup>(B/2) : cos C
csc<sup>2</sup>(C/2)<br> =
(b + c - a)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : (c + a -
b)(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) : (a + b -
c)(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<br> =
S<sub>A</sub>(S<sub>A</sub> + bc) : S<sub>B</sub>(S<sub>B</sub> + ca) :
S<sub>C</sub>(S<sub>C</sub> + ab)
<p>Barycentrics a/(1 - sec A) : b/(1 - sec B) : c/(1 - sec
C)</p>

<h3 id="X79">X(79) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(35)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(1 + 2 cos A) : :
<br>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc)
<br>
Trilinears (sin A/2)(sin 3B/2)(sin 3C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin(A/2) csc(3A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b c + 2 SA) : :
</p>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(79) = (2r + 3R)*X(1) + 6r*X(2) - 6r*X(3)
(Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection of X(1) in sideline BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. Then the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(79). (Eric Danneels, Hyacinthos 7892, 9/13/03)
</p><p>
A'B'C' is also the reflection triangle of X(1). The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(79). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let P and Q be the intersections of line BC and circle {X(1),2r}. Let X = X(1). Let A' be the circumcenter of triangle PQX, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(79). (Compare to X(592), where the circle is the 1st Lemoine circle) (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>25</sub>B<sub>25</sub>C<sub>25</sub> be Gemini triangle 25. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>25</sub>,C<sub>25</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(79). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(79) lies on these lines:<br>1,30 2,3647 8,758 9,46 12,484
21,36 33,1063 34,1061
35,226 57,90 65,80
104,946 314,320 388,1000</p>
<p>X(79) = reflection of X(191) in X(442)<br>
X(79) = isogonal conjugate of X(35)<br>
X(79) = isotomic conjugate of X(319)<br>
X(79) = cevapoint of X(481) and X(482)<br>
X(79) = crosssum of X(55) and X(1030)<br>
X(79) = anticomplement of X(3647)<br>
X(79) = X(2914) of Fuhrmann triangle<br>
X(79) = antigonal image of X(3065)<br>
X(79) = trilinear pole of line X(650)X(4802)<br>
X(79) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(80)<br>
X(79) = Hofstadter -1/2 point<br>
X(79) = trilinear pole of line X(650)X(4802)<br>
X(79) = trilinear product of vertices of reflection triangle of X(1)<br>
X(79) = X(6152)-of-excentral-triangle<br>

<h3 id="X80">X(80) REFLECTION OF INCENTER IN FEUERBACH POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1/(1 - 2 cos A) : 1/(1 - 2 cos B) : 1/(1 - 2 cos C)
<br>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - bc) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A/2) sec(3A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - bc) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(bc - 2 SA) : :
<b><br> X(80) = (2r + R)*X(1)- 6r*X(2) + 2r*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let A' be the reflection in BC of the A-vertex of the excentral triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, and C'AB concur in X(80). Also, the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(80). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Fuhrmann triangle. Let La be the line through A parallel to B'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(80). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the antiorthic axis of AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc. B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(9). The incenter of triangle A"B"C" is X(80). Also, the lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(80).(Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A'BC, of A. Define B", C" cyclically. (A" is also the reflection of A' in BC, and cyclically for B" and C"). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(80). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let Oa be the A'-Johnson circle of triangle A'BC, and define Ob and Oc cyclically. X(80) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(80) lies on these lines:<br>1,5 2,214 7,150 8,149
9,528 10,21 30,484
33,1061 34,1063 36,104
40,90 46,84 65,79
313,314 497,1000 499,944
516,655 519,908 943,950
</p><p>
X(80) = midpoint of X(8) and X(149)<br>
X(80) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,11), (100,10), (1317,1387)<br>
X(80) = isogonal conjugate of X(36)<br>
X(80) = isotomic conjugate of X(320)<br>
X(80) = inverse-in-incircle of X(1387)<br>
X(80) = inverse-in-Fuhrmann-circle of X(1)<br>
X(80) = anticomplement of X(214)<br>
X(80) = cevapoint of X(10) and X(519)<br>
X(80) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (44,2), (517,1)<br>
X(80) = X(8)-beth conjugate of X(100)<br>
X(80) = antigonal image of X(1)<br>
X(80) = syngonal conjugate of X(10)<br>
X(80) = X(186)-of-Fuhrmann triangle<br>
X(80) = orthology center of ABC and Fuhrmann triangle<br>
X(80) = reflection of any vertex of ABC in the corresponding side of the Fuhrmann triangle<br>
X(80) = perspector of ABC and reflection of Fuhrmann triangle in X(11)<br>
X(80) = trilinear pole of line X(37)X(650)<br>

X(80) = inner-Garcia-to-outer-Garcia similarity image of X(1)<br>
X(80) = X(100)-of-outer-Garcia-triangle<br>

<h3 id="X81">X(81) CEVAPOINT OF INCENTER AND SYMMEDIAN POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1/(b + c)
: 1/(c + a) : 1/(a + b)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(b + c) : b/(c + a) : c/(a + b)
<br>
Barycentrics eccentricity of A-Soddy ellipse : :
<p style="font-weight: bold">
X(81) = (r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 3rR*X(2) - 2r<sup>2</sup>*X(3)
(Peter Moses, April 2, 2013) </p>
<p>Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(1). Let A" be the symmedian
point of triangle AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. Then the
lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(81). (Eric Danneels, Hyacinthos 7892,
9/13/03)</p>
<p>Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the
reflection of B'C' in the internal angle bisector of vertex angle A,
and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'' =
L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, B'' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>,
C'' = L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>. The lines AA'', BB'', CC''
concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let H* be the Stammler hyperbola. Let A'B'C' be the tangential triangle and A"B"C" be the excentral triangle. Let A* be the intersection of the tangents to H* at A' and A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd circumperp triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplement of the Feuerbach triangle. Let A" be BB'&cap;CC', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ba, Ca be the intersections of lines CA, AB, resp., and the antiparallel to BC through X(1). Define Cb, Ab, Ac, Bc cyclically. Triangles ABaCa, AbBCb, AcBcC are similar to each other and inversely similar to ABC. Let Sa be the similitude center of triangles AbBCb and AcBcC. Define Sb and Sc cyclically. The lines ASa, BSb, CSc concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>10</sub>B<sub>10</sub>C<sub>10</sub> be Gemini triangle 10. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>10</sub>,C<sub>10</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>11</sub>B<sub>11</sub>C<sub>11</sub> be Gemini triangle 11. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>11</sub>,C<sub>11</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(81). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(81).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(81)</a>.</p>
<br>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(81).ggb"><b>X(81)</b></a></b></a>.
<p>
X(81) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 2,6 7,27 8,1010
19,969 28,60 29,189
32,980 42,100 43,750
55,1002 56,959 57,77
65,961 88,662 99,739
105,110 145,1043 226,651
239,274 314,321 377,387
386,404 411,581 593,757
715,932 859,957 941,967
982,985 1019,1022 1051,1054
1098,1104</p>
<p>
X(81) = isogonal conjugate of X(37)<br>
X(81) = isotomic conjugate of X(321)<br>
X(81) = anticomplement of X(1211)<br>
X(81) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (7,229), (86,21), (286,28)<br>
X(81) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,6), (57,222), (58,284)<br>
X(81) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,86), (3,272), (6,58), (57,27), (284,21)<br>
X(81) = crosspoint of X(274) and X(286)<br>
X(81) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,846), (6,1030), (42,1334), (213,228)<br>
X(81) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(512)X(661)<br>
X(81) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (333,333), (643,81), (645,81), (648,81), (662,81), (931,81)<br>
X(81) = trilinear product of PU(31)<br>
X(81) = intersection of tangents at X(1) and X(6) to the Stammler hyperbola<br>
X(81) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(6) wrt both the excentral and tangential triangles<br>
X(81) = trilinear pole of line X(36)X(238) (the polar of X(1) wrt the circumcircle)<br>
X(81) = {X(1),X(31)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1621)<br>
X(81) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(10)<br>
X(81) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(228)<br>
X(81) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of Gemini triangles 1 and 2<br>
X(81) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 1<br>
X(81) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 2<br>
X(81) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 3<br>

X(81) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 2<br>
X(81) = perspector of Gemini triangle 24 and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 24<br>
X(81) = perspector of Gemini triangle 28 and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 28<br>

<h3 id="X82">X(82) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(38)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(a<sup>2</sup>
+ b<sup>2</sup>)<br> =
sin A csc(A + &omega;) : sin B csc(B + &omega;) : sin C csc(C +
&omega;)
<p>
Barycentrics a/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) :
b/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : c/(a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup>)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circummedial triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B", C" cyclically. A", B", C" are collinear on line X(798)X(812) (the trilinear polar of X(3112)). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(82). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(82) lies on these lines: 1,560 10,83
31,75 37,251 58,596

<h3 id="X83">X(83) CEVAPOINT OF CENTROID AND SYMMEDIAN POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup>) : ca/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) :
ab/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)<br> =
csc(A + &omega;) : csc(B + &omega;) : csc(C + &omega;)
<p>Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) :
1/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup>)
</p><p>
Let K denote the symmedian point, X(6). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of K. Let K<sub>A</sub> be K of the triangle AB'C'; let K<sub>B</sub> be K of A'BC' and let K<sub>C</sub> be K of A'B'C. The lines AK<sub>A</sub>, BK<sub>B</sub>, CK<sub>C</sub> concur in X(83). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A' in BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. AA", BB", CC" concur in X(83). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Ba, Ca be the intersections of lines CA, AB, resp., and the antiparallel to BC through X(2). Define Cb, Ab, Ac, Bc cyclically. Triangles ABaCa, AbBCb, AcBcC are similar to each other and inversely similar to ABC. Let Sa be the similitude center of triangles AbBCb and AcBcC. Define Sb and Sc cyclically. The lines ASa, BSb, CSc concur in X(83). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let (Oa) be the circle whose diameter is the orthogonal projections of PU(1) on line BC. Define (Ob) and (Oc) cyclically. X(83) is the radical center of circles (Oa), (Ob), (Oc). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circummedial triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(83). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X84">X(84) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(40)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(cos B + cos C - cos A - 1) : :
<br>
Trilinears a^2[a^2 - (b - c)^2]^2 - (b - c)^2[a^2 - (b + c)^2]^2 : :
<br><b>
X(84) = (r + 2R)*X(1) - 6R*X(2) + (4R - 2r)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let A',B',C' be the excenters. The perpendiculars from B' to AB and from C' to AC meet in a point A". Points B" and C" are determined cyclically. The hexyl triangle, A"B"C", is perspective to ABC, and X(84) is the perspector.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extouch triangle. Let A" be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(84). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 be the 1st Conway triangle. Let A' be the crosspoint of B1 and C1, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(84). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(84) lies on the Darboux cubic and these lines: 1,221
3,9 4,57 7,946 8,20
21,285 33,603 36,90
46,80 58,990 64,3353
171,989 256,988 294,580
309,314 581,941 944,1000
2130,3345 3346,3472 3347,3355
</p><p>
X(84) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (40,1158), (1490,3)<br>
X(84) = isogonal conjugate of X(40)<br>
X(84) = isotomic conjugate of X(322)<br>
X(84) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (189,282), (280,1)<br>
X(84) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (19,57), (56,1)<br>
X(84) = X(280)-aleph conjugate of X(84)<br>
X(84) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (271,3), (280,280), (285,84)<br>
X(84) = X(68)-of-the-hexyl-triangle.
X(84) = trilinear pole of line X(650)X(1459)<br>
X(84) = perspector of ABC and the reflection in X(9) of the antipedal triangle of X(9)<br>
X(84) = Danneels point of X(110)<br>
X(84) = trilinear product of vertices of hexyl triangle (i.e., the extraversions of X(40))<br>
X(84) = hexyl-isotomic conjugate of X(12717)<br>
X(84) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of extouch and Hutson-extouch triangles<br>
X(84) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(9)<br>
X(84) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(57)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X85">X(85) ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>/(b
+ c - a) : c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup>/(c + a - b) :
a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>/(a + b - c)<br> =
tan(A/2) csc<sup>2</sup>A : tan(B/2) csc<sup>2</sup>B : tan(C/2)
csc<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Barycentrics bc/(b + c - a) : ca/(c + a - b) : ab/(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics cot A' : :, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<p>
Let A<sub>38</sub>B<sub>38</sub>C<sub>38</sub> be Gemini triangle 38. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>38</sub>,C<sub>38</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(85). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>

150,355 264,309
</p><p>

X(85) = anticomplement of X(1212)<br>
X(85) = X(274)-Ceva conjugate of X(348)<br>
X(85) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,169), (2,7), (57,77), (92,342)<br>
X(85) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,75), (57,273), (92,309), (142,2), (226,7)<br>
X(85) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (76,76), (85,279), (99,1), (274,85), (668,85), (789,85), (799,85), (811,85)<br>
X(85) = trilinear pole of line X(522)X(693) (the isotomic conjugate of the circumconic centered at X(1), conic {A,B,C,X(100),X(664),X(1120),X(1320)}; also the polar of X(33) wrt polar circle)<br>
