<h3 id="X86">X(86) CEVAPOINT OF INCENTER AND CENTROID</h3>
Trilinears bc/(b + c) : ca/(c + a) : ab/(a + b)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b + c) : 1/(c + a) : 1/(a + b)
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(86) = 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR +
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 3(r<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(2) -
4r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplement of the Feuerbach triangle. Let La be the tangent to the circumcircle at A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" be the point where La is tangent to the Steiner circumellipse, and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* = BB"&cap;CC", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(86). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 be the 1st Conway triangle. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line B1C1, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(86). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A5B5C5 be the 5th Conway triangle. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line B5C5, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(86). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>3</sub>B<sub>3</sub>C<sub>3</sub> and A<sub>4</sub>B<sub>4</sub>C<sub>4</sub> be Gemini triangles 3 and 4, resp. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the tangent at A to conic {{A,B<sub>3</sub>,C<sub>3</sub>,B<sub>4</sub>,C<sub>4</sub>}}, and define L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(86). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>21</sub>B<sub>21</sub>C<sub>21</sub> be Gemini triangle 21. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>21</sub>,C<sub>21</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(86). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(86) lies on these lines:<br>1,75 2,6 7,21 10,319
29,34 37,190 58,238
60,272 99,106 110,675
142,284 239,1100 269,1088
283,307 310,350 741,789 870,871
</p><p>
X(86) = isogonal conjugate of X(42)<br>
X(86) = isotomic conjugate of X(10)<br>
X(86) = complement of X(1654)<br>
X(86) = anticomplement of X(1213)<br>
X(86) = X(274)-Ceva conjugate of X(333)<br>
X(86) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,2), (7,77), (21,81)<br>
X(86) = crosssum of X(1) and X(1045)<br>
X(86) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(512)X(798)<br>
X(86) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,81), (2,274), (7,286), (21,333), (58,27), (513,190)<br>
X(86) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (86,1014), (99,86), (261,86), (314,314), (645,86), (811,86)<br>
X(86) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(6626)<br>
X(86) = intersection of tangents at X(1) and X(2) to the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(2); see X(99)<br>
X(86) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(2) wrt both the excentral and anticomplementary triangles<br>
X(86) = trilinear pole of line X(239)X(514) (Lemoine axis of excentral triangle)<br>
X(86) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1826)<br>
X(86) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate)-of-X(1826)<br>
X(86) = perspector of Gemini triangle 1 and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 1<br>
X(86) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 23<br>
X(86) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 24<br>
X(86) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of Gemini triangles 23 and 24<br>
X(86) = perspector of ABC and Gemini triangle 25<br>
X(86) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 23<br>
X(86) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 24<br>
X(86) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 25<br>

<h3 id="X87">X(87) X(2)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(ab + ac
- bc) : 1/(bc + ba - ca) : 1/(ca + cb - ab)<br>Barycentrics a/(ab + ac - bc) : b/(bc + ba - ca) : c/(ca +
cb - ab)
<p>X(87) lies on these lines: 1,192 6,43
9,292 10,979 34,242
56,238 58,978 106,932</p>
<p>
X(87) = isogonal conjugate of X(43)<br>
X(87) = isotomic conjugate of X(6376)<br>
X(87) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(43)<br>
X(87) = trilinear product of extraversions of X(43)<br>
X(87) = cevapoint of X(2) and X(330)<br>
X(87) = X(2)-cross conjugate of X(1)<br>X(87) = X(932)-beth conjugate of X(87)</p>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X88">X(88) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(44)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(b + c - 2a) : 1/(c + a - 2b) : 1/(a + b - 2c)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(b + c - 2a) : b/(c + a - 2b) : c/(a + b - 2c)
<br><b>
X(88) = (3r<sup>2</sup> + 6rR - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 9rR*X(2) - 6r<sup>2</sup>*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let A<sub>9</sub>B<sub>9</sub>C<sub>9</sub> be Gemini triangle 9. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>9</sub>,C<sub>9</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(88). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(88) lies on these lines: 1,100 2,45
6,89 28,162 44,679
57,651 81,662 105,901
274,799 278,653 279,658 291,660
</p><p>
X(88) = isogonal conjugate of X(44)<br>
X(88) = isotomic conjugate of X(4358)<br>
X(88) = complement of X(30578)<br>
X(88) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,44), (6,36)<br>
X(88) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (44,1), (517,7)<br>
X(88) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (88,1), (679,88), (903,63), (1022,1052)<br>
X(88) = X(333)-beth conjugate of X(190)</p>
X(88) = trilinear product of PU(50)<br>
X(88) = perspector of conic {{A,B,C,PU(50)}}<br>
X(88) = trilinear pole of PU(55); the line X(1)X(513), the line through X(1) parallel to its trilinear polar; also normal to Feuerbach hyperbola at X(1)<br>
X(88) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(678)X(1635)<br>
X(88) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(519)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X89">X(89) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(45)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(2b + 2c - a) : 1/(2c + 2a - b) : 1/(2a + 2b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(2b + 2c - a) : b/(2c + 2a - b) : c/(2a + 2b - c)
<p>
Let A<sub>9</sub>B<sub>9</sub>C<sub>9</sub> be the Gemini triangle 9. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A<sub>9</sub> parallel to BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'<sub>9</sub> = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B'<sub>9</sub>, C'<sub>9</sub> cyclically. Triangle A'<sub>9</sub>B'<sub>9</sub>C'<sub>9</sub> is homothetic to ABC at X(89). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(89) lies on these lines: 1,902 2,44 6,88 649,1022
</p><p>
X(89) = isogonal conjugate of X(45)<br>
X(89) = isotomic conjugate of X(4671)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X90">X(90) = X(3)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(cos B + cos C - cos A) : 1/(cos C + cos A - cos B) : 1/(cos A + cos B - cos C)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(a^3 + a^2 (b + c) - a (b^2 + c^2) - (b - c)^2 (b + c)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a/(cos B + cos C - cos A) : b/(cos C + cos A - cos B) : c/(cos A + cos B - cos C)
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(90) = (r + R)<sup>2</sup>*X(1) - 6rR*X(2) - 2r(r - R)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</p><p>
X(90) lies on these lines: 1,155 4,46
9,35 21,224 33,47 36,84
40,80 57,79
</p><p>
X(90) = isogonal conjugate of X(46)<br>
X(90) = X(3)-cross conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(90) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(46)<br>
X(90) = trilinear product of the extraversions of X(46), which is also the cross-triangle of the orthic and excentral triangles<br>
X(90) = trilinear product of PU(125)<br>
X(90) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(90)<br>
X(90) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(46)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X91">X(91) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(47)</h3>
Trilinears sec 2A :
sec 2B : sec 2C<br>Barycentrics sin A sec 2A : sin B sec 2B : sin C sec 2C
<br>
Trilinears cot A tan 2A : :<br>
<p>X(91) lies on these lines: 19,920 31,1087
37,498 47,92 63,921
65,68 225,847 255,1109 759,925</p>
<p>
X(91) = isogonal conjugate of X(47)<br>
X(91) = X(48)-cross conjugate of X(92)<br>
X(91) = trilinear product of X(485) and X(486)<br>
X(91) = polar conjugate of X(1748)<br>
X(91) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(563)<br>
X(91) = trilinear pole of line X(661)X(2618)<br>
X(91) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(91) (which is also the anticevian triangle of X(91))<br>
X(91) = trilinear product of vertices of outer and inner Vecten triangles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X92">X(92) CEVAPOINT OF INCENTER AND CLAWSON POINT</h3>
Trilinears csc 2A : csc 2B : csc 2C
<br>
Trilinears cot A + tan A : :
<br>
Barycentrics sec A : sec B : sec C
<br><b>
X(92) = X(4) - ((r + 2R)<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>)*X(8)
<br>
X(92) = (sec A)*[A] + (sec B)*[B] + (sec C)*[C], where A, B, C denote angles and [A], [B], [C] denote vertices
</b>
<p>Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through X(4) parallel to the internal bisector of angle A, and let<br>A' = BC&cap;L<sub>A</sub>. Define B' and C' cyclically.
</p><p><b>Alexei Myakishev,</b> "The M-Configuration of a Triangle," <a href="http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2003volume3/FG200315.pdf" style="font-weight: bold"><i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 3 (2003) 135-144</a>,
</p><p>
proves that the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(92). He notes that another construction follows from Proposition 2 of the article: let A<sub>1</sub> be the midpoint of the arc BC of the circumcircle that passes through A, and let A<sub>2</sub> be the point, other than A, in which the A-altitude meets the circumcircle. Let A" = A<sub>1</sub>A<sub>2</sub>&cap;BC. Define B" and C" cyclically. Then the lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(92).
</p><p>
Suppose that T = A'B'C' is a central triangle. Let A'' be the pole with respect to the polar circle of the line B'C', and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The appearance of T in the following list means that the lines AA'', BB'', CC'' concur in X(92): Feurerbach, incentral, excentral, extangents, Apollonius, mixtilinear excentral. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(92) lies on these lines:<br>1,29 2,273 4,8 7,189
10,1838 19,27 25,242
28,2975 31,162 33,1897
34,1220 38,240 40,412
47,91 48,2167 53,4415
55,243 56,1940 57,653
81,2995 85,331 100,917
108,1311 171,1430 226,342
239,607 255,1087 257,297
264,306 304,561 345,3262
388,1118 394,1943 406,1068
427,2969 429,3948 429,3948
459,1446 497,1857 518,1859
608,894 651,2988 823,2349
938,3176 942,1148 960,1882
984,1860 994,1845 1146,1952
1172,2997 1211,1865 1309,2717
1435,3306 1585,1659 1621,4183
1707,1733 1726,1746 1731,1751
1785,4656 1842,1891 1844,3874
1870,5136 1947,2994 1954,1955
1956,2632 1973,3112 2064,3596
2331,5256 2399,4391
3064,4468 4198,4968
</p><p>
X(92) = isogonal conjugate of X(48)<br>
X(92) = isotomic conjugate of X(63)<br>
X(92) = anticomplement of X(1214)<br>
X(92) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(2897)<br>
X(92) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (85, 342), (264,318), (286,4), (331,273)<br>
X(92) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,19), (4,281), (47,48), (196,278)<br>
X(92) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,75), (4,273), (19,158), (48,91), (226,2), (281,318)<br>
X(92) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (85,309), (264,331)<br>
X(92) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(810)X(822)<br>
X(92) = X(275)-aleph conjugate of X(47)<br>
X(92) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (92,278), (312,329), (648,57)<br>
X(92) = {X(19),X(63)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1748)<br>
X(92) = barycentric product of PU(20)<br>
X(92) = trilinear product of PU(i) for these i: 21, 45<br>
X(92) = bicentric sum of PU(130)<br>
X(92) = midpoint of PU(130)<br>
X(92) = trilinear product X(2)*X(4)<br>
X(92) = trilinear pole of line X(240)X(522) (polar of X(1) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(92) = pole of antiorthic axis wrt polar circle<br>
X(92) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(3)<br>
X(92) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(1)<br>
X(92) = X(91)-isoconjugate of X(563)<br>
X(92) = inverse-in-Fuhrmann-circle of X(5174)<br>
X(92) = perspector of ABC and extraversion triangle of X(92) (which is also the anticevian triangle of X(92))<br>
X(92) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(19) wrt excentral triangle<br>
X(92) = crosspoint of X(47) and X(48) wrt excentral triangle<br>
X(92) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of Gemini triangles 37 and 38<br>
X(92) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 37<br>
X(92) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 38<br>
X(92) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 37<br>
X(92) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 38<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X93">X(93) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(49)</h3>
Trilinears sec 3A :
sec 3B : sec 3C<br>Barycentrics sin A sec 3A : sin B sec 3B : sin C sec 3C
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(a^2 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2) (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2 - b^2 c^2)) : :
<p>
Let O<sub>A</sub>O<sub>B</sub>O<sub>C</sub> be the Kosnita triangle. Let A' be the pole wrt polar circle of line O<sub>B</sub>O<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(93). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(93) lies on these lines: 4,562 49,94 186,252
</p><p>
X(93) = isogonal conjugate of X(49)<br>
X(93) = X(50)-cross conjugate of X(94)<br>
X(93) = polar conjugate of X(1994)<br>
X(93) = X(2964)-isoconjugate of X(3)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X94">X(94) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(50)</h3>
Trilinears csc 3A : csc 3B : csc 3C
<br>
Barycentrics sin A csc 3A : sin B csc 3B : sin C csc 3C
<br>
Barycentrics b^2 c^2 / ((a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2 c^2) : :
<p>
Let A1B1C1 and A2B2C2 be the 1st and 2nd Ehrmann circumscribing triangles. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line A1A2, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(94). Let A1'B1'C1' and A2'B2'C2' be the 1st and 2nd Ehrmann inscribed triangles. Then X(94) is the radical center of nine-point circles of AA1'A2', BB1'B2', CC1'C2'. (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(94) lies on the Kiepert hyperbola and these lines: 2,300 4,143
23,98 49,93 96,925 275,324
</p><p>
X(94) = isogonal conjugate of X(50)<br>
X(94) = isotomic conjugate of X(323)<br>
X(94) = cevapoint of X(49) and X(50)<br>
X(94) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (30,264), (50,93), (265,328)<br>
X(94) = X(300)-Hirst inverse of X(301)<br>
X(94) = trilinear pole of PU(5) (line X(5)X(523))<br>
X(94) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(186)<br>
X(94) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(186)<br>
X(94) = barycentric product X(476)*X(850)<br>
X(94) = trilinear pole of PU(173)<br>
X(94) = trilinear product X(74)*X(107) (circumcircle-X(4) antipodes)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X95">X(95) CEVAPOINT OF CENTROID AND CIRCUMCENTER</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>sec(B - C) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the symmedial triangle. Let La be the reflection of line B'C' in line BC, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(95). (Randy Hutson, August 19, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the intersection, other than A, of the circumcircle and the branch of the Lucas cubic that contains A, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is here introduced as the Lucas triangle (not to be confused with the Lucas central triangle). The vertices A', B', C' lie on the rectangular hyperbola {{X(2),X(20),X(54),X(69),X(110),X(2574),X(2575),X(2979)}}. (See https://bernard-gibert.pagesperso-orange.fr/Exemples/k007.html.) Also, X(95) is the trilinear product of the vertices of the Lucas triangle. (Randy Hutson, August 19, 2015)
</p><p>
X(95) lies on these lines:<br>2,97 3,264 54,69 76,96
99,311 140,340 141,287 160,327 183,305 216,648 307,320
</p><p>
X(95) = isogonal conjugate of X(51)<br>
X(95) = isotomic conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(95) = anticomplement of X(233)<br>
X(95) = X(276)-Ceva conjugate of X(275)<br>
X(95) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,3), (6,160), (54,97)<br>
X(95) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,276), (3,97), (54,275), (140,2), (340,1494)<br>
X(95) = intersection of tangents at X(2) and X(3) to bianticevian conic of X(2) and X(3)<br>
X(95) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(3) wrt both the anticomplementary triangle and anticevian triangle of X(3)<br>
X(95) = trilinear pole of line X(323)X(401) (polar of X(53) wrt polar circle, and polar of X(69) wrt de Longchamps circle)<br>
X(95) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(53)<br>
X(95) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(53)<br>
X(95) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(217)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X96">X(96) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(52)</h3>
Trilinears sec 2A sec(B - C) : sec 2B sec(C - A) : sec 2C sec(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics a sec 2A sec(B - C) : b sec 2B sec(C - A) : c sec 2C sec(A - B)
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let B<sub>A</sub> and C<sub>A</sub> be the orthogonal projections of B' and C' on line BC, resp. Let (O<sub>A</sub>) be the circle with segment B<sub>A</sub>C<sub>A</sub> as diameter. Define (O<sub>B</sub>) and (O<sub>C</sub>) cyclically. X(96) is the radical center of circles (O<sub>A</sub>), (O<sub>B</sub>), (O<sub>C</sub>). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(96) lies on these lines: 2,54 4,231 24,847 76,95 94,925
</p><p>
X(96) = isogonal conjugate of X(52)<br>
X(96) = cevapoint of X(3) and X(68)<br>
X(96) = X(3)-cross conjugate of X(54)<br>
X(96) = polar conjugate of X(467)<br>
X(96) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(5392)<br>
X(96) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(571)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X97&quot;">X(97) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(53)</h3>
Trilinears cot A
sec(B - C) : cot B sec(C - A) : cot C sec(A - B)<br>Barycentrics cos A sec(B - C) : cos B sec(C - A) : cos C sec(A - B)
<p>X(97) lies on these lines: 2,95 3,54
110,418 216,288 276,401</p>
<p>
X(97) = isogonal conjugate of X(53)<br>
X(97) = isotomic conjugate of X(324)<br>
X(97) = X(95)-Ceva conjugate of X(54)<br>
X(97) = X(3)-cross conjugate of X(95)<br>
X(97) = cevapoint of X(3) and X(577)<br>
X(97) = X(51)-isoconjugate of X(92)<br>
X(97) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(7592)<br>
<br></p><p><br></p><center>
<p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 74, 98 - 112, <img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br></b>and others lie on the circumcircle. Mappings <b>&Lambda;</b> and
<b>&Psi;</b> derived from such a point P for application to points X,
are defined here:
<p style="font-weight: bold">&Lambda;(P,X) = isogonal conjugate of the
point where line PX meets the line at infinity.</p>
<p>Let Y = &Lambda;(P,X), let Q = isogonal conjugate of P, and let Y
and Z be the points where line YQ meets the circumcircle;<br>then <b>&Psi;(P,X) = Z.</b>
<br><br> <img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"></p>
</center><br>
<h3 id="X98">X(98) = TARRY POINT<a id="TarryPoint" name="TarryPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears sec(A + &omega;) : sec(B + &omega;) : sec(C + &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
Tripolars |cos(A + &omega;)| : :
<br>
Tripolars |a (b^4 + c^4 - a^2 b^2 - a^2 c^2)| : :
<br><b>
X(98) = 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)(r<sup>2</sup> + 2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) + 3(r<sup>4</sup> + 4Rr<sup>3</sup> + 2r<sup>2</sup>s<sup>2</sup> - 4rRs<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>4</sup>)*X(2) - 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)(3r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let A' be the apex of the isosceles triangle BA'C constructed inward on BC such that &ang;A'BC = &ang;A'CB = &omega;. Define B' nad C' cyclically. Let Ha be the orthocenter of BA'C, and define Hb and Hc cyclically. The lines AHa, BHb, CHc concur in X(98). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the apex of the isosceles triangle BA'C constructed outward on BC such that &ang;A'BC = &ang;A'CB = &omega;/2. Define B' and C' cyclically. Let Oa be the circumcenter of BA'C, and define Ob and Oc cyclically. The lines AOa, BOb, COc concur in X(98). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(98).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(98)</a>.
</p><p>
<b>J. W. Clawson,</b> "Points on the circumcircle," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 32 (1925) 169-174.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. X(98) is the radical center of the circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C". (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the Lemoine axis of triangle AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similicenter X(2). The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(98), which is X(4)-of-A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on the Steiner circumellipse. Let A' be the orthocenter of BCP, and define B' and C' cyclically. Let Q be the centroid of A'B'C'. The locus of Q as P varies is an ellipse similar and orthogonal to the Steiner circumellipse, and also centered at X(2). When P = X(671), Q = X(98). See also X(6054) and X(24808). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(98) lies on these lines:<br>2,110 3,76 4,32 5,83
6,262 10,101 13,1080
14,383 20,148 22,925
23,94 25,107 30,671
100,228 109,171 111,1637 186,935
275,427 376,543 381,598
385,511 468,685 523,842
620,631 804,878
</p><p>
X(98) is the {X(2),X(147)}-harmonic conjugate of X(114). For a list of harmonic conjugates, click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(98) = midpoint between X(20) and X(148)<br>
X(98) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,115), (99,3), (147,114), (1513,230)<br>
X(98) = isogonal conjugate of X(511)<br>
X(98) = isotomic conjugate of X(325)<br>
X(98) = complement of X(147)<br>
X(98) = anticomplement of X(114)<br>
X(98) = X(290)-Ceva conjugate of X(287)<br>
X(98) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,385), (6,237)<br>
X(98) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (230,2), (237,6), (248,287), (446,511)<br>
X(98) = crosssum of X(385) and X(401)<br>
X(98) = X(2)-Hirst inverse of X(287)<br>
X(98) = perspector of ABC and triangle formed by Lemoine axis (or PU(1) or PU(2)) reflected in sides of ABC<br>
X(98) = &Lambda;(X(4), X(69)) (the line that is the isotomic conjugate of the Jerabek hyperbola)<br>
X(98) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(523) (polar of X(297) wrt polar circle, and the radical axis of circles with segments X(13)X(16) and X(14)X(15) as diameters)<br>
X(98) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(297) (line X(114)X(132))<br>
X(98) = pole wrt {circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of line X(115)X(125)<br>
X(98) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(297)<br>
X(98) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(1959)<br>
X(98) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(132)<br>
X(98) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(125)<br>
X(98) = inverse-in-circle-{{X(1687),X(1688),PU(1),PU(2)}} of X(2715)<br>
X(98) = &Psi;(X(6), X(523))<br>
X(98) = &Psi;(X(190), X(71))<br>
X(98) = Kiepert-hyperbola antipode of X(4)<br>
X(98) = reflection of X(842) in the Euler line<br>
X(98) = reflection of X(2698) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(98) = reflection of X(2699) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(98) = X(129)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(98) = X(130)-of-hexyl-triangle<br>
X(98) = X(3)-of-1st-anti-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(98) = perspector of ABC and 1st Neuberg triangle<br>
X(98) = trilinear product of vertices of 1st Neuberg triangle<br>
X(98) = orthocenter of X(13)X(14)X(2394)<br>
X(98) = 2nd-Parry-to-ABC similarity image of X(2)<br>
X(98) = trilinear product of PU(88)<br>
X(98) = X(2456) of 6th Brocard triangle<br>
X(98) = midpoint of PU(135)<br>
X(98) = bicentric sum of PU(135)<br>
X(98) = perspector of ABC and circumsymmedial triangle of Artzt triangle<br>
X(98) = McCay-to-Artzt similarity image of X(381)<br>
X(98) = circumcircle-antipode of X(99)<br>
X(98) = the point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and Kiepert hyperbola<br>
X(98) = &Psi;(X(101), X(100)<br>
X(98) = &Lambda;(X(3), X(6))<br>
X(98) = homothetic center of 5th anti-Brocard triangle and Euler triangle<br>
X(98) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(512)<br>
X(98) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(512)<br>
X(98) = X(1380)-of-circummedial-triangle<br>
X(98) = X(6233)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(98) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(76)<br>
X(98) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(32)<br>
X(98) = perspector of ABC and vertex-triangle of reflection triangles of PU(1)<br>
X(98) = the point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(3),X(25),X(32)}} (isogonal conjugate of line X(4)X(69))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X99">X(99) = STEINER POINT<a id="SteinerPoint" name="SteinerPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears bc/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : ca/(c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : ab/(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> csc(B - C) : c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup> csc(C - A) : a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> csc(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics d(A,L) : : , where d = directed distance and L = X(115)X(125)
<br>
Tripolars |a (b^2 - c^2)| : :
<br><b>
X(99) = 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR - s<sup>2</sup>)(r<sup>2</sup> +
2rR + s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 3(r<sup>4</sup> + 4Rr<sup>3</sup> +
2r<sup>2</sup>s<sup>2</sup> - 4rRs<sup>2</sup> + s<sup>4</sup>)*X(2) -
4r<sup>2</sup>(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR + 5s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3)
(Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of the line X(3)X(6) in line BC,
and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' =
L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, B' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>,
C' = L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in
X(99). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
X(99) is the only point on the circumcircle whose isotomic conjugate lies on the line at infinity. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
X(99) is the center of the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(2), which is the rectangular hyperbola H that passes through these points: X(1), X(2), X(20), X(63), X(147), X(194), X(487), X(488), X(616), X(617), X(627), X(628), X(1764), X(2896), the excenters, the vertices of the anticomplementary triangle, and the extraversions of X(63). Also, H is the anticomplementary conjugate of line X(4)X(69), the anticomplementary isotomic conjugate of line X(2)X(6), the excentral isogonal conjugate of line X(40)X(511), and the excentral isotomic conjugate of line X(1045)X(2951); also, H is tangent to line X(1)X(75) at X(1), to line X(2)X(6) at X(2), and meets the line at infinity (and the Kiepert hyperbola, other than at X(2)) at X(3413) and X(3414). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplement of the Feuerbach triangle. Let A"B"C" be the tangential triangle of A'B'C'. Let A* be the cevapoint of B" and C", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(99). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Brocard axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to ABC with similarity ratio 3. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Brocard axis. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(115) and centroid X(99). See Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B' and C' be the intersections of the de Longchamps line and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(99). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the Brocard axis and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. Let Oa, Ob, Oc be the circumcenters of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B', resp. The lines AOa, BOb, COc concur in X(99). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let La be the line through A parallel to B'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. La, Lb, Lc concur in X(99). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the trilinear pole of the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. A'B'C' is also the anticomplement of the anticomplement of the midheight triangle. X(99) is the trilinear product A'*B'*C'. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. Let A"' be the reflection of A' in line BC, and define B"', C"' cyclically. Let A* = B"B"'&cap;\C"C"', and define B*, C* cyclically. Triangle A*B*C* is homothetic to A'B'C' at X(99). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
See a construction: Ercole Suppa, <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/29064"> <b>Hyacinthos 29064</b></a>.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view the following dynamic sketches:<br><a href="X(99).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(99)</a> and <a href="SteinerEllipse.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Steiner Circum-ellipse (showing X(99) and an area-ratio property)</a>
</p><p>
For more about the Steiner circumellipse, visit <a href="http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SteinerCircumellipse.html" style="font-weight: bold">MathWorld</a>.</p>
<p>X(99) lies on these lines:<br>1,741 2,111 3,76 4,114
6,729 13,303 14,302
20,147 21,105 22,305

670,804 692,785 695,711
813,1016 889,898 935,3267
</p><p>

<h3 id="X100">X(100) ANTICOMPLEMENT OF FEUERBACH POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1/(b - c) : 1/(c - a) : 1/(a - b)
<br>
Trilinears (a - b)(a - c) : (b - c)(b - a) : (c - a)(c - b)
<br>
Barycentrics a/(b - c) : b/(c - a) : c/(a - b)
<br>
Tripolars |b - c| : :<br>
</p>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(100) = 2R*X(1) - 3R*X(2) + 2r*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013) </p><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of the line X(1)X(3) in line BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, B' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>, C' = L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(100). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically; then X(100) = X(36)-of-IaIbIc. Also, let P be a point on line X(4)X(8) other than X(4). Let A' be the reflection of P in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', and CA'B' concur at X(100). (Randy Hutson, 9/5/2015)
</p><p>
Let IaIbIc be the excentral triangle. The Euler lines of triangles BCIa, CAIb, ABIc concur in X(100). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(100) lies on these lines:<br>1,88 2,11 3,8 4,119
6,739 7,1004 9,1005
10,21 20,153 22,197
25,1862 231,43 32,713 36,519
37,111 40,78 42,81
46,224 56,145 59,521
63,103 72,74 75,675
76,767 92,917 98,228
99,668 101,644 107,823
108,653 109,651 110,643
112,162 144,480 190,659
198,346 213,729 238,899
281,1013 329,972 442,943
484,758 513,765 516,908
517,953 518,840 522,655
560,697 594,1030 645,931
649,660 650,919 658,664
667,898 693,927 731,869
733,893 753,984 756,846
789,874 976,986 2859,3267
</p><p>
X(100) is the {X(10),X(35)}-harmonic conjugate of X(21). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(100), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(100) = midpoint of X(20) and X(153)<br>

<h3 id="X101">X(101) = &Psi;(INCENTER, SYMMEDIAN POINT)</h3>
Trilinears a/(b - c) : b/(c - a) : c/(a - b)
<br>
Trilinears a(a - b)(a - c) : b(b - c)(b - a) : c(c - a)(c - b)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(b - c) : b<sup>2</sup>/(c - a) : c<sup>2</sup>/(a - b)
<br>
Tripolars |b c (b - c)| : :
<br><b>
X(101) = (r <sup>2</sup> + 6rR + 8R<sup>2</sup> +
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(1) - 6R(r + 4R)*X(2) - 2(r<sup>2</sup> + 4rR -
s<sup>2</sup>)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of the line X(1)X(7) in line BC,
and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' =
L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, B' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>,
C' = L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in
X(101). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let I<sub>a</sub>I<sub>b</sub>I<sub>c</sub> be the excentral triangle. The Brocard axes of BCI<sub>a</sub>, CAI<sub>b</sub>, ABI<sub>c</sub> concur in X(101). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on line X(4)X(9) other than X(4). Let A' be the reflection of P in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AA'B', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(101). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Q be a point on the Nagel line other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A' (or equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'), and define B" and C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(101). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the antiorthic axis and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(101). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(101) is the perspector of the anticevian triangle of X(109) and the unary cofactor triangle of the intangents triangle. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(101) lies on these lines:<br>1,41 2,116 3,103 4,118

<h3 id="X103">X(103) = ANTIPODE OF X(101)</h3>
Trilinears a/[(a - b) cot C + (a - c) cot B] : b/[(b - c) cot A + (b - a) cot C] : c/[(c - a) cot B + (c - b) cot A]
<br>

<br>

<br>
Tripolars |b c ((a - b) cot C + (a - c) cot B)| : :
</p><p>

<h3 id="X104">X(104) = ANTIPODE OF X(100)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(-1 + cos B + cos C) : 1/(-1 + cos C + cos A) : 1/(-1 + cos C + cos B)
<br>
Trilinears 1/[b^3 + c^3 - (a^2 + bc)(b + c) + 2abc] : :
<br>
Barycentrics a/(-1 + cos B + cos C) : b/(-1 + cos C + cos A) : c/(-1 + cos C + cos B)
<br>
Tripolars |-1 + cos B + cos C| : :
<b><br>
X(104) = 2R*X(1) - 3R*X(2) + (2R - 2r)*X(3) (Peter Moses, April 2, 2013)
</b><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of the line X(1)X(513) in line BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, B' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>, C' = L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(104). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the antiorthic axis and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. Let Oa, Ob, Oc be the circumcenters of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B', resp. The lines AOa, BOb, COc conucr in X(104). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle (i.e. the antiorthic triangle). Let A"B"C" be the triangle bounded by the orthic axes of A'BC, B'CA, C'AB. Then A"B"C" is perspective to ABC at X(104); c.f. X(8068). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. The de Longchamps lines of triangles A'BC, B'CA, C'AB bound a triangle perspective to ABC at X(104). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. The Hatzipolakis axes of triangles A'BC, B'CA, C'AB bound a triangle perspective to ABC at X(104). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X107">X(107) = &Psi;(SYMMEDIAN POINT, ORTHOCENTER)</h3>

<br>

X(107) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1636)X(2972)<br>
X(107) = X(134)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(107) = circumcircle intercept, other than A, B, C, of conic {{A,B,C,PU(157)}}<br>
X(107) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(6000)<br>
X(107) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(6000)<br>
</p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X108">X(108) = &Psi;(CIRCUMCENTER, INCENTER)</h3>
Trilinears a/(sec
B - sec C) : b/(sec C - sec A): c/(sec A - sec B)<br> =
g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b) where g(a,b,c) = 1/[(b - c)(b + c -
a)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)]
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(sec B - sec C) :
b<sup>2</sup>/(sec C - sec A): c<sup>2</sup>/(sec A - sec B)
<br>
Tripolars |b c (sec B - sec C)| : :
<p>
X(108) lies on these lines:<br>1,102 2,123 3,1295 4,11 7,1013
12,451 24,915 25,105
28,225 33,57 34,106
40,207 55,196 65,74
99,811 100,653 109,1020
110,162 204,223 273,675
318,404 331,767 388,406
429,961 608,739 648,931
</p><p>
X(108) = reflection of X(1295) in X(3)<br>
X(108) = isogonal conjugate of X(521)<br>
X(108) = anticomplement of X(123)<br>
X(108) = X(162)-Ceva conjugate of X(109)<br>
X(108) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (56,513), (429,523)<br>
X(108) = X(513)-cross conjugate of X(4)<br>
X(108) = crosspoint of X(107) and X(162)<br>
X(108) = crosssum of X(520) and X(656)<br>
X(108) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (21,102), (162,108)<br>
X(108) = point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,PU(18)}}<br>
X(108) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(19) (the polar of X(4391) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(108) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(4391) (line X(11)X(123))<br>
X(108) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(4391)<br>
X(108) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(2193)<br>
X(108) = concurrence of the reflections of line X(4)X(65) in the sidelines of ABC<br>
X(108) = &Psi;(X(i),Xj)) for these (i,j): (1,4), (3,1), (4,65), (6,19), (7,4), (8,4), (9,4), (29,1), (69,7), (80,4)<br>
X(108) = reflection of X(2766) in the Euler line<br>
X(108) = reflection of X(2714) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(108) = reflection of X(2720) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(108) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(11)<br>
X(108) = X(135)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(108) = barycentric product of PU(76)<br>
X(108) = trilinear product of PU(100)<br>
X(108) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(6001)<br>
X(108) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(6001)<br>
X(108) = trilinear product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(1)X(4)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X109">X(109) = &Psi;(INCENTER, CIRCUMCENTER)</h3>
Trilinears a/(cos B - cos C) : b/(cos C - cos A) : c/(cos A - cos B)
<br>
Trilinears a/[(b - c)(b + c - a)] : : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(cos B - cos C) : b<sup>2</sup>/(cos C - cos A): c<sup>2</sup>/(cos A - cos B)
<br>
Tripolars |b c (cos B - cos C)| : :
<p>
If the line X(1)X(4) is reflected in every side of triangle ABC, then the reflections concur in X(109). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on line X(1)X(4) other than X(4). Let A' be the reflection of P in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of CA'B', BC'A', and CA'B' concur in X(109). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2011)
</p><p>
Let Q be a point on line X(2)X(7) other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A' (or equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'), and define B" and C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(109). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2011)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the Fuhrmann triangle. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(109). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2011)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the Gergonne line and lines BC, CA, AB, respectively. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(109). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2011)
</p><p>
Let P and Q be the points where the line tangent to the incircle at X(11) intersects the circumcircle. Let L(P) be the line through P, other than PQ, that is tangent to the incircle; let L(Q) be the line through Q, other than PQ, that is tangent to the incircle. Then X(109) = L(P)&cap;L(Q). (Piotr Ambroszczyk, December 21, 2016)
</p><p>
X(109) lies on these lines:<br>1,104 2,124 3,102 4,117
7,675 20,151 31,57
34,46 35,73 36,953
40,255 55,103 56,106
58,65 59,901 85,767
98,171 99,643 100,651
101,654 107,162 108,1020
112,163 165,212 191,201
278,917 284,296 478,573
579,608 604,739 649,919
658,927 662,931 840,902
</p><p>
X(109) = midpoint of X(20) and X(151)<br>
X(109) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,117), (102,3)<br>
X(109) = isogonal conjugate of X(522)<br>
X(109) = anticomplement of X(124)<br>
X(109) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (59,56), (162,108)<br>
X(109) = cevapoint of X(65) and X(513)<br>
X(109) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (56,59), (513,58)<br>
X(109) = crosspoint of X(110) and X(162)<br>
X(109) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (523,656), (652,663)<br>
X(109) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(11)X(1146)<br>
X(109) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (100,1079), (162,580), (651,223)<br>
X(109) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (21,104), (59,109), (100,100), (110,109), (765,109), (901,109)<br>
X(109) = circumcircle-antipode of X(102)<br>
X(109) = trilinear product X(1381)*X(1382)<br>
X(109) = isogonal conjugate of isotomic conjugate of trilinear pole of line X(2)X(7)<br>
X(109) = the point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and hyperbola {A,B,C,PU(19)}<br>
X(109) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(41)<br>
X(109) = trilinear pole wrt 1st circumperp triangle of line X(971)X(1158)<br>
X(109) = X(925)-of-1st-circumperp-triangle<br>
X(109) = X(136)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(109) = X(131)-of-hexyl-triangle<br>
X(109) = &Psi;(X(i),X(j)) for these (i,j): (1,3), (2,7), (3,73), (4,1), (6,41), (7,20), (21,2), (69,73), (77,3)<br>
X(109) = reflection of X(2689) in the Euler line<br>
X(109) = reflection of X(2701) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(109) = reflection of X(2222) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(109) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(4391)<br>
X(109) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(652)<br>
X(109) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(284)<br>
X(109) = barycentric product of PU(57)<br>
X(109) = trilinear product of PU(102)<br>
X(109) = Thomson isogonal conjugate of X(515)<br>
X(109) = Lucas isogonal conjugate of X(515)<br>
X(109) = intersection of antipedal lines of circumcircle intercepts of line X(3)X(10)<br>
X(109) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(2)X(7)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X110">X(110) = FOCUS OF KIEPERT PARABOLA<a id="FocusOfKiepertParabola" name="FocusOfKiepertParabola"></a></h3>
Trilinears csc(B - C) : csc(C - A) : csc(A -B)
<br>
Trilinears cos(B - C) - cos(C - A)cos(A - B) : :
<br>
Trilinears a/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Tripolars |sin(B - C)| : :
<br>
Tripolars |b c (b^2 - c^2)| : :
<p>
X(110) is the center of the Stammler hyperbola, SH, which is the rectangular hyperbola that passes through X(1), X(3), X(6), X(155), X(159), X(195), X(399), X(1498), X(2916), X(2917), X(2918), X(2929), X(2930), X(2931), X(2935), X(2948), X(3511), the excenters, and the vertices of the tangential triangle. SH is the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(6) and the antipedal-anticevian conic of X(3). SH is the tangential isogonal conjugate of the Euler line, the tangential isotomic conjugate of the van Aubel line, the excentral isogonal conjugate of line X(30)X(40), and the excentral isotomic conjugate of line X(191)X(2938). SH is tangent to the Euler line at X(3) and meets the line at infinity (and the Jerabek hyperbola, other than at X(3) and X(6)) at X(2574) and X(2575). SH is the locus of a point P for which the P-Brocard triangle is perspective to ABC. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011, 1/29/2015)
</p><p>
<b>J. W. Clawson,</b> "Points on the circumcircle," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 32 (1925) 169-174.
</p><p>
<b>Roland H. Eddy and R. Fritsch,</b> "The conics of Ludwig Kiepert: a comprehensive lesson in the geometry of the triangle," <i>Mathematics Magazine</i> 67 (1994) 188-205.
</p><p>
<b>Benedetto Scimemi,</b> <a href= "http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2002volume2/FG200212.pdf">"Paper-folding and Euler's Theorem Revisited,"</a> <i>Forum Geometricorum</i>.
</p><p>
Scimemi proves that if the Euler line is reflected in every side of triangle ABC, then the three reflections concur in X(110).
</p><p>
Seven constructions from Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015:
</p><p>
(1) Let P be a point, other than X(4), on Euler line. Let A' be the reflection of P in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AA'B', BC'A', and CA'B' concur in X(110).
</p><p>
(2) Let Q be a point on line X(2)X(6) other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A' (or equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'), and define B", C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(110).
</p><p>
(3) Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Euler line. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Euler line. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(125) and centroid X(110). (See Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008.)
</p><p>
(4) Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the Lemoine axis and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(110).
</p><p>
(5) Let A', B', C' be the intersections of line X(36)X(238) and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(110).
</p><p>
(6) Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the Euler line and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. Let Oa, Ob, Oc be the circumcenters of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B', resp. The lines AOa, BOb, COc concur in X(110).
</p><p>
(7) Let Na be the reflection of X(5) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Nb, Nc cyclically. X(110) = X(2070) of NaNbNc.
</p><p>
Let A2B2C2 and A3B3C3 be the 2nd and 3rd Parry triangles. Let A' be the barycentric product A2*A3, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(110). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung). A'B'C' is homothetic to the anticomplementary triangle at X(110). The nine-point circle of A'B'C' touches the circumcircle of ABC at X(110). Also, X(110) = X(125)-of-A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, Novermber 2, 2016)
</p><p>
X(110): Let A' be the trilinear pole of the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define B', C' cyclically. A'B'C' is homothetic to the circumanticevian triangle of X(4) at X(110). X(110) is also the barycentric product A'*B'*C'. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(110) lies on the circumcircle, the Parry circle, and these lines:<br>1,60 2,98 3,74 4,113 5,49 6,111 11,215
20,146 21,104 22,154
23,323 24,155 27,917
28,915 30,477 31,593
32,729 39,755 58,106
65,229 67,141 69,206
81,105 86,675 97,418
99,690 100,643 101,163
102,283 107,648 108,162
143,195 187,352 190,835
249,512 250,520 251,694
274,767 324,436 351,526
353,574 373,575 376,541
476,523 525,935 560,715
595,849 668,839 669,805
670,689 681,823 685,850
789,799 859,953 2868,3266
</p><p>
X(110) is the {X(5),X(49)}-harmonic conjugate of X(54). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(110), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(110) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,399), (20,146), (23,323), (1495,3292)<br>
X(110) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,1511), (4,113), (23,1495), (67,141), (74,3), (265,5), (382,1539), (895,6), (1177,206)<br>

X(110) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (249,6), (250,3)<br>
X(110) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,520), (5,523), (6,512), (141,525)<br.

X(110) = Johnson-circumconic antipode of X(265)<br>
X(110) = MacBeath-circumconic antipode of X(895)<br>
X(110) = perspector of conic {A,B,C,PU(2)}<br>
X(110) = intersection of trilinear polars of P(2) and U(2)<br>

X(110) = crosspoint of X(99) and X(648)<br>

X(110) = reflection of X(691) in the Brocard axis<br>

X(110) = reflection of X(1290) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(110) = reflection of X(111) in line X(3)X(351)<br>
X(110) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(136)<br>
X(110) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(114)<br>
X(110) = inverse-in-Moses-radical-circle of X(2715)<br>
X(110) = inverse-in-O(15,16) of X(843), where O(15,16) is the circle having segment X(15)X(16) as diameter<br>

X(110) = Collings transform of X(5)<br>
X(110) = Collings transform of X(6)<br>

X(110) = SR(PU(4))<br>
X(110) = insimilicenter of nine-point circle and sine-triple-angle circle<br>

X(110) = X(7972)-of-Trinh-triangle<br>
X(110) = &Psi;(X(i), X(j)) for these (i,j): (1,21), (2,6), (3,49), (4,2), (5,51), (6,3), (19,1), (53,5), (54,3), (64,3), (66,3), (67,3), (68,3), (69,3), (73,3), (74,3), (75,1), (76,2), (115,125), (190,99)<br>
X(110) = X(110)-of-1st-Parry-triangle<br>
X(110) = X(74)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>

X(110) = endo-homothetic center of X(2)-altimedial and X(2)-anti-altimedial triangles<br>

X(110) = center of the perspeconic of these triangles: inner and outer Napoleon<br>

X(110) = X(104)-of-circumorthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(110) = perspector, wrt circumorthic triangle, of polar circle<br>
X(110) = trilinear product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(1)X(21)<br>
X(110) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(2)X(6)<br>
X(110) = barycentric product X(6)*X(99)<br>
X(110) = Feuerbach point of the tangential triangle if ABC is acute; otherwise, a vertex of the Feuerbach triangle of the tangential triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X111">X(111) = PARRY POINT<a id="ParryPoint" name="ParryPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears a/(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : b/(2b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : c/(2c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : b<sup>2</sup>/(2b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : c<sup>2</sup>/(2c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Tripolars |b c (2 a^2 - b^2 - c^2)| : :
<p>
Let L be a line tangent to the Brocard circle. Let P be the trilinear pole of L, and let P' be the isogonal conjugate of P. As L varies, P' traces a parabola with focus at X(111). The parabola meets the line at infinity at X(524). Also, X(111) is the QA-P4 center (Isogonal Center) of quadrangle X(13)X(14)X(15)X(16) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/25-qa-p4.html)
Also, let A' = BC&cap;X(115)X(125), and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(111). (Randy Hutson, October 13, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A"B"C" be the 2nd Ehrmann triangle. Let Pa be the pole of line B"C" wrt the A-Ehrmann circle, and define Pb and Pc cyclically. Let Pa' be the pole of line BC wrt the A-Ehrmann circle, and define Pb' and Pc' cyclically. The lines APaPa', BPbPb', CPcPc' concur in X(111). Also, let A* be the trilinear pole of line B"C", and define B*, C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(111). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 and A3B3C3 be the 1st and 3rd Parry triangles. Let A' be the barycentric product A1*A3, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(111). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the 4th Brocard and 4th anti-Brocard triangles, resp. Let A* be the barycentric product A'*A'', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(111). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(111) lies on the Parry circle and these lines:<br>2,99 3,1296 6,110 23,187
25,112 37,100 42,101 98,1637
107,393 182,353 230,476
251,827 308,689 352,511
385,892 468,935 512,843
647,842 694,805 931,941
</p><p>
X(111) = reflection of X(1296) in X(3)<br>
X(111) = isogonal conjugate of X(524)<br>
X(111) = isotomic conjugate of X(3266)<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(353)<br>
X(111) = anticomplement of X(126)<br>
X(111) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(187)<br>
X(111) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (23,251), (187,6), (351,110)<br>
X(111) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(351)X(690)</p>
X(111) = perspector of ABC and the triangle formed by the reflections of line PU(7) in the sides of ABC<br>
X(111) = point of intersection, other than A, B, C, of circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(2),X(6)}}<br>
X(111) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(512)<br>
X(111) = &Lambda;(X(2), X(6))<br>
X(111) = &Psi;(X(i),X(j)) for these (i,j): (6,512), (21,650), (190,10)<br>
X(111) = trilinear pole wrt circumsymmedial triangle of Brocard axis<br>
X(111) = trilinear pole wrt circummedial triangle of line X(2)X(6)<br>
X(111) = X(110)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(111) = X(23)-of-4th-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(111) = X(352)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(111) = X(138)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(111) = reflection of X(2770) in the Euler line<br>
X(111) = reflection of X(843) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(111) = reflection of X(2721) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(111) = reflection of X(110) in line X(3)X(351)<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(1560)<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(115)<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-Moses-radical-circle of X(842)<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-circle-O(15,16) of X(691)<br>
X(111) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(5467)<br>
X(111) = SR(P,U), where P and U are the circumcircle intercepts of line X(2)X(6)<br>
X(111) = one of two harmonic traces of the McCay circles; X(2) is the other<br>
X(111) = X(1296)-of-1st-Parry-triangle<br>
X(111) = X(111)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(111) = X(691)-of-3rd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(111) = center of similitude of ABC and 2nd Parry triangle<br>
X(111) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(110); see X(2)<br>
X(111) = 3rd-Parry-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(352)<br>
X(111) = center of similitude of ABC and circumsymmedial triangle of Artzt triangle<br>
X(111) = eigencenter of circumtangential triangle<br>
X(111) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of 2nd Brocard triangle<br>
X(111) = X(2)-of-4th-anti-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(111) = anti-Artzt-to-4th-anti-Brocard similarity image of X(2)<br>
X(111) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(1499)<br>
X(111) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(1499)<br>
X(111) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(14262)<br>
X(111) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(13608)<br>
X(111) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(14210)<br>
X(111) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(2)X(523)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X112">X(112) = &Psi;(ORTHOCENTER, SYMMEDIAN POINT)</h3>
Trilinears a/(sin 2B - sin 2C) : b/(sin 2C - sin 2A) : c/(sin 2A - sin 2B)
<br>
Trilinears a/[(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)]
<br>
Trilinears tan A csc(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(sin 2B - sin 2C) : b<sup>2</sup>/(sin 2C - sin 2A) : c<sup>2</sup>/(sin 2A - sin 2B)
<br>
Tripolars |cot A sin(B - C)| : :
<p>
If the line X(4)X(6) is reflected in every side of triangle ABC, then the reflections concur in X(112). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on the van Aubel line other than X(4). Let A' be the reflection of P in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AA'B', BC'A', and CA'B' concur at X(112). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Q be a point on the Euler line other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A' (or equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'), and define B" and C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(112). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the orthic axis and lines BC, CA, AB, respectively. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(112). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection of X(6) in BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(112). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circummedial triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(112). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(112) lies on these lines:<br>2,127 3,1297 4,32 6,74 19,759
25,111 27,675 28,105
33,609 50,477 54,217
58,103 99,648 100,162
102,284 104,1108 109,163
186,187 230,403 250,691
251,427 286,767 376,577
393,571 523,935 647,1304 789,811
</p><p>
X(112) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,132), (1297,3)<br>
X(112) = isogonal conjugate of X(525)<br>
X(112) = isotomic conjugate of X(3267)<br>
X(112) = anticomplement of X(127)<br>
X(112) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (249,24), (250,25)<br>
X(112) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (32,512), (427,523)<br>
X(112) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (25,250), (512,4), (523,251)<br>
X(112) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(122)X(125)<br>
X(112) = barycentric product of X(1113) and X(1114)<br>
X(112) = isogonal conjugate of isotomic conjugate of trilinear pole of Euler line<br>
X(112) = point of intersection, other than A, B, C, of circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),PU(39)}}<br>
X(112) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(25)<br>
X(112) = X(647)-cross conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(112) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(850) (line X(115)X(127))<br>
X(112) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(850)<br>
X(112) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(520)<br>
X(112) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(3)<br>
X(112) = trilinear pole wrt circumsymmedial triangle of line X(6)X(647)<br>
X(112) = reflection of X(935) in the Euler line<br>
X(112) = reflection of X(2715) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(112) = reflection of X(2722) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(112) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(115)<br>
X(112) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(1560)<br>
X(112) = inverse-in-Moses-radical-circle of X(1304)<br>
X(112) = inverse-in-[circle with diameter X(15)X(16) and center X(187)] of X(842)<br>
X(112) = inverse-in-circle-{X(1687),X(1688),PU(1),PU(2)} of X(2698)<br>
X(112) = X(139)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(112) = barycentric product of PU(74)<br>
X(112) = trilinear product of PU(108)<br>
X(112) = eigencenter of circumnormal triangle<br>
X(112) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(1503)<br>
X(112) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(1503)<br>
X(112) = perspector of circumcevian triangle of X(468) and cross-triangle of ABC and circumcevian triangle of X(25)<br>
X(112) = trilinear product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(1)X(19)<br>
X(112) = barycentric product X(3)*X(107)<br>
X(112) = barycentric product X(4)*X(110)<br>
X(112) = X(6)-of-1st-anti-orthosymmedial-triangle
X(112) = &Psi;(X(i),X(j)) for these (i,j): (1,19), (2,3), (3,6), (4,6), (5,53), (6,25), (69,2), (76,4), (125,115)<br>
</p><br><br><br>
<center>
<p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 113-139
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>lie on the nine-point circle.</b><br>
<p>Suppose that X is a point on the nine-point circle, and let X' be
the reflection of X in the orthocenter, H. Then X is the anticenter of
the cyclic quadrilateral ABCX'. Let H<sub>A</sub> be the orthocenter of
triangle BCX, Let H<sub>B</sub> be the orthocenter of CAX, and let
H<sub>C</sub> be the orthocenter of triangle ABX. Then the
quadrilateral HH<sub>A</sub>H<sub>B</sub>H<sub>C</sub> is homothetic to
and congruent to the cyclic quadrilateral ABCX', and X is the center of
homothety. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)</p>
<p><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"></p>
</center>
<h3 id="X113">X(113) = JERABEK ANTIPODE</h3>
Trilinears sin B sin C [(sin C)/(cos C - 2 cos A cos B) + (sin B)/(cos B - 2 cos A cos C)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin C)/(cos C - 2 cos A cos B) + (sin B)/(cos B - 2 cos A cos C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics b<sup>2</sup>/(b<sup>2</sup>S<sub>B</sub> - 2S<sub>A</sub>S<sub>C</sub>) + c<sup>2</sup>/(c<sup>2</sup>S<sub>C</sub> - 2S<sub>A</sub>S<sub>B</sub>) : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 3/2003)
<br>
Barycentrics (2a^4 - b^4 - c^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2 + 2b^2c^2)[a^4(b^2 + c^2) - 2a^2(b^4 - b^2c^2 + c^4) + (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2)] : :
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let L be the line through A'
parallel to the Euler line, and define M and N cyclically. Let L' be
the reflection of L in sideline BC, and define M' and N' cyclically.
The lines L', M', N' concur in X(113). (Randy Hutson, August 26,
2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let M<sub>A</sub> be the
reflection of the orthic axis in line B'C', and define Let
M<sub>B</sub> and Let M<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'' = Let
M<sub>B</sub>&cap;M<sub>C</sub>, and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The
lines A'A'', B'B'' C'C'' concur in X(113). (Randy Hutson, August 26,
2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let N<sub>A</sub> be the orthic
axis of AB'C', and define N<sub>B</sub> and N<sub>C</sub> cyclically.
Let A'' = N<sub>B</sub>&cap;N<sub>C</sub>, B'' =
N<sub>C</sub>&cap;A<sub>C</sub>, C'' = N<sub>A</sub>&cap;B<sub>C</sub>.
Then triangle A''B''C'' is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude
center X(6), and the lines A'A'', B'B'', C'C'' concur in X(113). Also,
X(113) = X(3)-of-A''B''C''. (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
X(113) lies on the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(110) and on these lines:<br>
2,74 3,122 4,110 5,125
6,13 11,942 52,135 114,690 123,960 127,141 137,546
</p><p>
X(113) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,110), (74,146), (265,399), (1553,3258)<br>
X(113) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (52,1112), (125,5)<br>
X(113) = complementary conjugate of X(30)<br>
X(113) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,30), (2,3003)<br>
X(113) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(403)<br>
X(113) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(526)X(686)<br>
X(113) = nine-point-circle-antipode of X(125)<br>
X(113) = X(74)-of-medial-triangle<br>
X(113) = X(104)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(113) = X(186)-of-X(4)-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(113) = center of rectangular circumhyperbola that passes through X(110)<br>
X(113) = center of rectangular hyperbola {{X(3),X(4),X(110),X(155),X(1351),X(1352),X(2574,X(2575)}}<br>
X(113) = perpsector of circumconic centered at X(3003)<br>X(113) = inverse-in-polar-circle-of X(1300)<br>
X(113) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(1302)<br>
X(113) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(110)<br>
X(113) = &Lambda;(X(2),X(3))-with-respect-to-orthic-triangle<br>
X(113) = barycentric product X(30)*X(3580)<br>
X(113) = complement of X(74)<br>
X(113) = reflection of X(3) in X(5972)<br>
X(113) = antipode of X(3) in the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(110)<br>
X(113) = antipode of X(52) in the Hatzipolakis-Lozada hyperbola<br>
X(113) = orthopole of line X(3)X(523)<br>
X(113) = perspector of Ehrmann mid-triangle and orthic triangle<br>
</p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X114">X(114) = KIEPERT ANTIPODE</h3>
Trilinears bc[b sec(B + &omega;) + c sec(C + &omega;)] : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(B - C) cos 2&omega; - sin &omega; sin(A + &omega;) (Peter J. C. Moses, 9/12/03)
<br>
Barycentrics b sec(B + &omega;) + c sec(C + &omega;) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b^4 + c^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2)(2a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2 - 2b^2c^2) : :
</p><p>
X(114) is the QA-P30 center (Reflection of QA-P2 in QA-P11) of quadrangle ABCX(2) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/58-qa-p30.html)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the Lemoine axis of triangle AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similicenter X(2). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(114), which is X(3)-of-A"B"C".
</p><p>
X(114) lies on the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(99), and on these lines:<br>2,98 3,127 4,99 5,39
25,135 52,211 113,690
132,684 136,427 325,511 381,543
</p><p>
X(114) = isogonal conjugate of X(2065)<br>
X(114) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,99), (98,147)<br>
X(114) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,620), (115,5)<br>
X(114) = complementary conjugate of X(511)<br>
X(114) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,230), (4,511)<br>
X(114) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(325)<br>
X(114) = orthojoin of X(230)<br>
X(114) = nine-point-circle-antipode of X(115)<br>
X(114) = X(98)-of-medial triangle<br>
X(114) = X(103)-of-orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(114) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(230)<br>
X(114) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(230)<br>
X(114) = center of rectangular hyperbola {{X(4),X(76),X(99),X(376),X(487),X(488)}}<br>
X(114) = X(1513)-of-1st-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(114) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(3563)<br>
X(114) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(110)<br>
X(114) = center of inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of Brocard circle<br>
X(114) = X(5)=of=1st=antiBrocard=triangle<br>
X(114) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(99)<br>
X(114) = &Lambda;(X(3), X(6)), wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(114) = centroid of mid-triangle of X(15)- and X(16)-Fuhrmann triangles<br>
</p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X115">X(115) = CENTER OF KIEPERT HYPERBOLA</h3>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : ca(c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : ab(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears cos A - 2 cos(B - C) + cot &omega; sin A : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 9/12/03)
<br>
Trilinears sin A sin<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : (c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : (a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics (SB - SC)^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics (SA - SW) (SB + SC) + 4 SB SC : :
<br><b>
X(115) = 2(tan &omega; sin 2&omega;)*X(5) - X(39)<br>
X(115) = X(13) + X(14) (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</b><p>
The circumcircle of the incentral triangle intersects the nine-point circle at 2 points, X(11) and X(115), and X(115) lies on the incentral circle and the cevian circle of every point on the Kiepert hyperbola. Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. The Brocard axes of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(115). Let P be a point on the Brocard circle, and let L be the line tangent to the Brocard circle at P. Let P' be the trilinear pole of L, and let P" be the isotomic conjugate of P'. As P varies, P" traces an ellipse with center at X(115). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Brocard axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Brocard axis. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(115); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008.
</p><p>
X(115) is the QA-P2 center (Euler-Poncelet Point) of quadrangle ABCX(2) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/10-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/12-qa-p2.html)
</p><p>
Let F be the Feuerbach point, X(11), and FaFbFc be the Feuerbach triangle (the extraversion triangle of X(11)). Let A' be the barycentric product F*Fa, and define B', C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(115). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="KiepertHyperbola.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Kiepert Hyperbola</a>, showing X(115).
</p><p>
<b>Roland H. Eddy and R. Fritsch,</b> "The conics of Ludwig Kiepert: a comprehensive lesson in the geometry of the triangle," <i>Mathematics Magazine</i> 67 (1994) 188-205.
</p><p>
X(115) lies on the nine-point circle, the Steiner inellipse, the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(98), and on these lines:<br>2,99 4,32 5,39 6,13
11,1015 30,187 50,231
53,133 76,626 116,1086
120,442 125,245 127,338
128,233 129,389 131,216
232,403 316,385 325,538
395,530 396,531 427,1560 593,1029
804,1084
</p><p>
X(115) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,98), (13,14), (99,148), (316,385), (2009,2010)<br>
X(115) = midpoint of PU(40)<br>
X(115) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (99,620), (114,5), (187,230), (325,625)<br>
X(115) = isogonal conjugate of X(249)<br>
X(115) = isotomic conjugate of X(4590)<br>
X(115) = complement of X(99)<br>
X(115) = anticomplement of X(620)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(6)<br>
X(115) = complementary conjugate of X(512)<br>
X(115) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,523), (4,512), (338,125)<br>
X(115) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,523), (68,525), (3413,3414)<br>
X(115) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,110), (24,112), (163,849), (1379,1380)<br>
X(115) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(110)X(351)<br>
X(115) = X(2)-Hirst inverse of X(148)<br>
X(115) = X(99)-of-medial triangle<br>
X(115) = X(101)-of-orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(115) = X(325)-of-1st-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(115) = X(187)-of-4th-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(115) = X(187)-of-orthocentroidal-triangle<br>
X(115) = X(141)-of-1st-antiBrocard-triangle<br>
X(115) = barycentric product X(11)*X(12)<br>
X(115) = {X(5),X(39)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1506)<br>
X(115) = projection from Steiner circumellipse to Steiner inellipse of X(671)<br>
X(115) = center of similitude of incentral and Feuerbach triangles<br>
X(115) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines parallel to the orthic axis (i.e. lines that pass through X(523))<br>
X(115) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(523) (parabola {{A,B,C,X(476),X(523),X(685)})<br>
X(115) = trilinear pole wrt medial triangle of line X(2)X(6)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(2079)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(112)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(111)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-Moses-radical-circle of X(3258)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-Steiner-circumellipse of X(148)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of X(5213)<br>
X(115) = {X(99),X(671)}-harmonic conjugate of X(148)<br>
X(115) = {X(6108),X(6109)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6055)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-circle-{{X(2),X(13),X(14),X(111),X(476)}} of X(1648)<br>
X(115) = orthopole of Brocard axis<br>
X(115) = orthic isogonal conjugate of X(512)<br>
X(115) = incentral isogonal conjugate of X(512)<br>
X(115) = perspector of orthic triangle and tangential triangle of hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(2),X(6)}}<br>
X(115) = similitude center of (equilateral) pedal triangles of X(15) and X(16)<br>
X(115) = exsimilicenter of Moses circle and the nine-point circle<br>
X(115) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(98)<br>
X(115) = &Lambda;(X(187), X(237))-wrt-orthic-triangle<br>
X(115) = X(1101)-isoconjugate of X(2)<br>
X(115) = harmonic center of nine-point circle and Gallatly circle<br>
X(115) = perspector of medial triangle and Schroeter triangle<br>
X(115) = trilinear pole of line X(1648)X(8029)<br>
X(115) = barycentric square of X(523)<br>
X(115) = inverse-in-Hutson-Parry-circle of X(1648)<br>
X(115) = {X(13636),X(13722)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1648)<br>
X(115) = homothetic center of medial triangle and mid-triangle of antipedal triangles of X(13) and X(14)<br>
X(115) = homothetic center of Ehrmann vertex-triangle and mid-triangle of 1st and 2nd Kenmotu diagonals triangles<br>

<h3 id="X116">X(116) = MIDPOINT OF X(4) AND X(103)</h3>
Trilinears bc[(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup> - ab - ac)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup> - ab - ac) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the Soddy line of triangle AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(116), which is X(3)-of-A"B"C".
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(116) lies on the nine-point circle and these lines: 2,101 4,103
5,118 10,120 115,1086
119,142 121,141 124,928</p>
<p>X(116) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,103), (101,150)<br>
X(116) = reflection of X(118) in X(5)<br>
X(116) = complementary conjugate of X(514)<br>
X(116) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(514)<br>
X(116) = complement of X(101)<br>
X(116) = inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of X(3034)<br>
X(116) = inverse-in-orthoptic-circle-of-Steiner-inellipse of X(675)<br>
X(116) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(103)<br>
X(116) = &Lambda;(Gergonne line), wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(116) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(6586)<br>
X(116) = X(101)-of-medial triangle.<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X117">X(117) = MIDPOINT OF X(4) AND X(109)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = g(b,c,a) + g(c,b,a), and<br> g(b,c,a)
= b<sup>2</sup>c/[c(sec B - sec C) + a(sec B - sec A)]
<p>Barycentrics h(a,b,c) : h(b,c,a) : h(c,a,b) where
h(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>
<p>X(117) lies on the nine-point circle<br>X(117) = X(102)-of-medial triangle.</p>

5,124 10,123 11,65
118,928 136,407

<h3 id="X118">X(118) = MIDPOINT OF X(4) AND X(101)</h3>
Trilinears g(b,c,a) + g(c,b,a) : : ,where g(b,c,a) = b<sup>3</sup>c/[(b - c) cot A + (b - a) cot C]
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the Gergonne line of triangle AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(118), which is X(3)-of-A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)

<h3 id="X119">X(119) = FEUERBACH ANTIPODE</h3>
Trilinears (csc A)(-1 + cos B + cos C)[sin 2B + sin 2C + 2(-1 + cos A)(sin B + sin C)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (-1 + cos B + cos C)[sin 2B + sin 2C + 2(-1 + cos A)(sin B + sin C)] : :
<p>
Let Na = X(5)-BCX(1), Nb = X(5)-of-CAX(1), Nc = X(5)-of-ABX(1). Then X(119) = X(2071)-of-NaNbNc. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the antiorthic axis of AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. Then triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similicenter X(9). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(119). Also, X(119) = X(3) of A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(119) lies on these lines:<br>1,5 2,104 3,123 4,100
10,124 116,142 125,442
135,431 136,429 214,515
381,528 517,908
</p><p>

X(119) = complement of X(104)<br>
X(119) = complementary conjugate of X(517)<br>
X(119) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(517)<br>
X(119) = nine-point-circle-antipode of X(11)<br>

X(119) = X(2072)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>

X(119) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(100)<br>
X(119) = &Lambda;(X(1), X(3)), wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(119) = &Lambda;(X(4), X(8)), wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(119) = center of rectangular circumhyperbola passing through isogonal and isotomic conjugates of X(3657)<br>

<h3 id="X121">X(121) = X(106)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= bc(b + c - 2a)[b<sup>3</sup> + c<sup>3</sup> + a(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>) - 2bc(b + c)]
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b) where
g(a,b,c) = (b + c - 2a)[b<sup>3</sup> + c<sup>3</sup> + a(b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup>) - 2bc(b + c)]</p>

<h3 id="X122">X(122) = X(107)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(cos A - cos B cos C) cot<sup>2</sup>A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(cos A - cos B cos C) cot<sup>2</sup>A : :
<p>
Barycentrics (b^2 - c^2)^2 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 (3 a^4 - 2 a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2) : :<br>
</p><p>
X(122) lies on the nine-point circle, the cevian circle of X(20), and these lines: 2,107 3,113 5,133 118,440 125,684 138,233
</p><p>

X(122) = crosspoint of X(253) and X(525)<br>
X(122) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(112)X(1301)<br>
X(122) = X(107)-of-medial triangle<br>
X(122) = center of the rectangular hyperbola that passes through A, B, C, and X(20)<br>
X(122) = X(1293)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(122) = complement of X(107)<br>

X(122) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(1301)<br>

X(122) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(6587)<br>

</p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X123">X(123) = X(108)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (csc A)(sec B - sec C)[(sec A)(sin<sup>2</sup>B - sin<sup>2</sup>C) + sin C tan C - sin B tan B] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sec B - sec C)[(sec A)(sin<sup>2</sup>B - sin<sup>2</sup>C) + sin C tan C - sin B tan B]
<br>
Barycentrics (a - b - c)(b - c)^2(a^2 - b^2 - c^2)(a^4 - b^4 - c^4 + 2a^2bc - 2ab^2c - 2abc^2 + 2b^2c^2) : :

<h3 id="X124">X(124) = X(109)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= bc(b + c - a)(b - c)<sup>2</sup>[(b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - bc) + abc]
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where<br> g(a,b,c)
= (b + c - a)(b - c)<sup>2</sup> [(b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>
- a<sup>2</sup> - bc) + abc]</p>
<p>X(124) lies on the nine-point circle<br>X(124) = X(109)-of-medial triangle<br>X(124) = center of the rectangular hyperbola that passes through A, B,
C, and X(58)</p>
<p>X(124) lies on these lines: 2,109 4,102
5,117 10,119 116,928</p>
