<h3 id="X125">X(125) = CENTER OF JERABEK HYPERBOLA<a id="CenterOfJerabekHyperbola" name="CenterOfJerabekHyperbola"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos A sin<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : cos B sin<sup>2</sup>(C - A) : cos C sin<sup>2</sup>(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears (sec A)(c cos C - b cos B)<sup>2</sup> : (sec B)(a cos A - c cos C)<sup>2</sup> : (sec C)(b cos B - a cos A)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br> Barycentrics (sin 2A)[sin(B - C)]<sup>2</sup> : (sin 2B)[sin(C - A)]<sup>2</sup> : (sin 2C)[sin(A - B)]<sup>2</sup><br>
<p>
<b>Roland H. Eddy and R. Fritsch,</b> "The conics of Ludwig Kiepert: a comprehensive lesson in the geometry of the triangle," <i>Mathematics Magazine</i> 67 (1994) 188-205.</p>
<p>
X(125) is the pole of the Fermat axis with respect to the Dao-Moses-Telv circle. (Randy Hutson, December 14, 2014)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Euler line. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Euler line. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(125); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. The Euler lines of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(125). (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(125) lies on these curves: nine-point circle, orthic inconic, symmedial circle, Johnson circumconic of the medial triangle, cevian circle of every point on the Jerabek hyperbola, and bicevian conic of X(2) and X(72). X(125) also lies on these lines:<br>
2,98 3,131 4,74 5,113
6,67 51,132 68,1092
69,895 115,245 119,442
122,684 126,141 128,140
136,338 381,541 511,858
</p><p>
X(125) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,265), (4,74), (6,67), (110,3448)<br>
X(125) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (113,5), (185,974), (1495,468), (1511,140), (1539,546)<br>
X(125) = isogonal conjugate of X(250)<br>
X(125) = isotomic conjugate of X(18020)<br>
X(125) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(184)<br>
X(125) = complement of X(110)<br>
X(125) = complementary conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(125) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,523), (66,512), (68,520), (69,525), (338,115)<br>
X(125) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,523), (69,525), (338,339)<br>
X(125) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,110), (25,112), (162,270), (1113,1114)<br>
X(125) = crossdifference of every pair of points on the line X(110)X(112)<br>
X(125) = X(115)-Hirst inverse of X(868)<br>
X(125) = X(2)-line conjugate of X(110)<br>
X(125) = orthopole of the Euler line<br>
X(125) = perspector of orthic triangle and Schroeter triangle<br>
X(125) = X(110)-of-medial triangle<br>
X(125) = X(100)-of-orthic triangle, if ABC is acute<br>
X(125) = X(858)-of-1st-Brocard triangle<br>
X(125) = anticenter of cyclic quadrilateral ABCX(74)<br>
X(125) = &Lambda;(X(230), X(231)), wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(125) = anticomplement of X(5972)<br>
X(125) = pole of Fermat axis wrt Dao-Moses-Telv circle<br>
X(125) = orthic-isogonal conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(125) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(647)<br>
X(125) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(647)<br>
X(125) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(647)<br>
X(125) = trilinear pole wrt orthic triangle of van Aubel line<br>
X(125) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(107)<br>
X(125) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(98)<br>
X(125) = inverse-in-orthosymmedial-circle of X(51)<br>
X(125) = centroid of (degenerate) pedal triangle of X(74)<br>
X(125) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these {i,j}: {4,1101}, {92,249}<br>
X(125) = inverse-in-Hutson-Parry-circle of X(868)<br>
X(125) = {X(13636),X(13722)}-harmonic conjugate of X(868)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X126">X(126) = X(111)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= bc(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)[b<sup>4</sup> +
c<sup>4</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) -
4b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>]
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b) where
g(a,b,c) = (2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup>)[b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) -
4b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>]</p>
<p>X(126) lies on the nine-point circle<br>X(126) = X(111)-of-medial triangle.
</p><p>
X(126) lies on these lines: 2,99 125,141 625,858
</p><p>
X(126) = complement of X(111)<br>
X(126) = complementary conjugate of X(524)<br>
X(126) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(524)<br>
X(126) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(3291)<br>
X(126) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(3291)<br>
X(126) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(3291)<br>
X(126) = one of two intersections (X(3258) is the other) of the nine-point circle of ABC and the Parry circle of the X(2)-Brocard triangle<br>
X(126) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(2374)<br>
X(126) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(99)<br>
X(126) = &Lambda;(X(2), X(6)), wrt orthic triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X127">X(127) = X(112)-OF-MEDIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears bc(sin 2B - sin 2C)[(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)sin 2A - b<sup>2</sup>sin 2B + c<sup>2</sup>sin 2C] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin 2B - sin 2C)[(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)sin 2A - b<sup>2</sup>sin 2B + c<sup>2</sup>sin 2C] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)(b^4 + c^4 - a^4) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the van Aubel line of triangle AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(127), which is X(3)-of-A"B"C". (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(127) lies on the nine-point circle and these lines: 2,112 3,114
5,132 113,141 115,338
133,381 125,140
</p><p>
X(127) = reflection of X(132) in X(5)<br>
X(127) = complement of X(112)<br>
X(127) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(525)<br>
X(127) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(525)<br>
X(127) = X(1292)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(127) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(2485)<br>
X(127) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(2485)<br>
X(127) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(2485)<br>
X(127) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(1289)<br>
X(127) = inverse-in-orthoptic-circle-of-Steiner-inellipse of X(2373)<br>
X(127) = X(112)-of-medial triangle<br>
X(127) = center of the rectangular hyperbola that passes through A, B, C, and X(22)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X128">X(128) = X(74)-OF-ORTHIC-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= (sec A)(cos 2B + cos 2C)(1 + 2 cos 2A)(cos 2A + 2 cos 2B cos 2C)
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B) where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A) f(A,B,C)</p>

53,139 115,233 125,140</p>

<h3 id="X129">X(129) = X(98)-OF-ORTHIC-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= (sec A)(sin 2A)(sin 2B + sin 2C) s(A,B,C) t(A,B,C),<br> s(A,B,C)
= sin<sup>4</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>4</sup>(2C) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)
sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) sin<sup>2</sup>(2C),<br> t(A,B,C)
= sin<sup>4</sup>(2A) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) u(A,B,C) + v(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= sin 2B sin 2C - sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2C),<br> v(A,B,C)
= (sin 2B sin 2C)(sin 2B - sin 2C)<sup>2</sup>
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B) where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A) f(A,B,C)</p>

<h3 id="X132">X(132) = X(2)X(107)&cap;X(4)X(32)</h3>

: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= (sec A) u(A,B,C) v(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= [sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) + (sin 2B - sin 2C)<sup>2</sup> + (sin 2A)(sin
2A - sin 2B - sin 2C)],<br> v(A,B,C)
= [sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2C) - (sin 2A sin 2B) - (sin
2A sin 2C)]
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A) f(A,B,C)</p>

<h3 id="X134">X(134) = X(107)-OF-ORTHIC-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C) = (sec A) u(A,B,C) [v(B,C,A) - v(C,B,A)],<br>
u(A,B,C) = (sin 2A)[sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2C)][sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2C) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)]<sup>2</sup>,<br>
v(B,C,A) = sin 2C [sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2B)][sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2C)]<sup>2</sup>
<p>
Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = (sin A) f(A,B,C)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X135">X(135) = INTERSECTION OF LINE X(4)X(131) AND X(25)X(114)</h3>

= (sec A)[(sin 2B)/(sec 2C - sec 2A) + (sin 2C)/(sec 2A - sec 2B)]
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where<br> &nbnbsp; g(A,B,C)
= (tan A)[(sin 2B)/(sec 2C - sec 2A) + (sin 2C)/(sec 2A - sec 2B)]</p>
<p>X(135) lies on the nine-point circle<br>X(135) = X(108)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>X(135) = center of the rectangular hyperbola that passes through A, B,
C, and X(24)</p>

<h3 id="X136">X(136) = INTERSECTION OF LINE X(4)X(110) AND X(25)X(132)</h3>
Barycentrics (b^2 - c^2)^2 (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2)/(a^2 - b^2 - c^2) : :
<br>

: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)

u(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= [sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2C) - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)]
<p>Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)</p>

<h3 id="X138">X(138) = X(111)-OF-ORTHIC-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (v
+ w) sec A : (w + u) sec B : (u + v) sec C, where<br> u
= u(A,B,C) = (sin 2A)/(2 sin<sup>2</sup>2A - sin<sup>2</sup>2B -
sin<sup>2</sup>2C), v = u(B,C,A), w = u(C,A,B)<br>
<p>Barycentrics (v + w) tan A : (w + u) tan B : (u + v) tan
C</p>

<h3 id="X139">X(139) = X(112)-OF-ORTHIC-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= (sec A)(sin 2B + sin 2C)[(sin 2B - sin
2C)<sup>2</sup>][sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2C) -
sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)] u(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= (sin 2B)<sup>4</sup> + (sin 2C)<sup>4</sup> - (sin 2A)<sup>4</sup> +
(sin 2B sin 2C)[sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) + sin<sup>2</sup>(2C) -
sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)]
<p>Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)</p>

<center>
<p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 140- 170 <img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>113- 127, 140- 143: centers of the medial triangle<br>128- 139: centers of the orthic triangle<br>144- 153: centers of the anticomplementary triangle<br>154- 157, 159- 163: centers of the tangential triangle<br>164- 170: centers of the excentral triangle</b><br>

<h3 id="X140">X(140) = MIDPOINT OF X(3) AND X(5)</h3>
Trilinears 2 cos A + cos(B - C) : 2 cos B + cos(C - A) : 2 cos C + cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + 2 sin B sin C : cos B + 2 sin C sin A : cos C + 2 sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A + 2 cos B cos C : 3 cos B + 2 cos C cos A : 3 cos C + 2 cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A + 3 sec B sec C : 2 sec B + 3 sec C sec A : 2 sec C + 3 sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears bc[b cos(C - A) + c cos(B - A)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics b cos(C - A) + c cos(B - A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 3 - cot B cot C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2a^4 - 3a^2(b^2 + c^2) + (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics 3 S^2 - SB SC : :
<br><b>
X(140) = 3*X(2) + X(3) = 3*X(2) - X(5) = 3*X(3) + X(4) = X(4) - 3*X(5)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(140) has Shinagawa coefficients (3, -1).
</p><p>
Let A' be the midpoint between A and X(3), and define B' and C' cyclically; the triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to the medial triangle, and the center of homothety is X(140). Let A'' be the centroid of the triangle BCX(3), and define B'' and C'' cyclically; then A''B''C'' is homothetic to ABC, and the center of homothety is X(140). Also, X(140) is the center of the conic consisting of the centers of all the conics which pass through A, B, C, and X(3). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
This conic is also the locus of crosssums of the intersections of the circumcircle and lines through X(4). Furthmore, this conic is the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(3). (Randy Hutson, 9/14/2016)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the circle centered at A and passing through the A-vertex of the Euler triangle; define Ob and Oc cyclically. The radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc is X(140). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Oa be the circle centered at A with radius 1/2*sqrt(b^2 + c^2), and define Ob and Oc cyclically. The radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc is X(140). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on the circumcircle. The bicevian conic of X(2) and P is a rectangular hyperbola, H. Let X be the center of H. As P varies, X traces a circle centered at X(140). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(140) is the centroid of the six circumcenters in the construction of the van Lamoen circle. (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(140) lies on these lines:<br>

X(140) is the {X(2),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(140), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.

<h3 id="X141">X(141) = COMPLEMENT OF SYMMEDIAN POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>A sin(A + &omega;) : :
<br>
Barycentrics b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot A + cot &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics SA + SW : :
<b><br>
X(141) = 3*X(2) + X(69) = 3*X(2) - X(6)
</b><p>
Let P be a point on the circumcircle, and let L be the line tangent to the circumcircle at P. Let P' be the trilinear pole of L, and let P" be the isotomic conjugate of P'. As P traces the circumcircle, P" traces an ellipse inscribed in ABC with center at X(141). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd Brocard triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(141). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(141) lies on the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(110) and on these lines:<br>2,6 3,66 5,211 10,142
37,742 39,732 45,344
53,264 67,110 75,334
76,698 95,287 99,755
113,127 116,121 125,126
140,182 239,319 241,307
308,670 311,338 317,458
320,894 384,1031 441,577
498,611 499,613 523,882
542,549 575,629 997,1060
</p><p>X(141) is the {X(2),X(69)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(141), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(141) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,3416), (6,69), (8,3242), (66,159), (67,110), (69,3313), (1843,3313) (2930, 3448)<br>
X(141) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (182,140), (597,2), (1353,575), (1386,1125)<br>
X(141) = isogonal conjugate of X(251)<br>
X(141) = isotomic conjugate of X(83)<br>
X(141) = inverse-in-nine-point-circle of X(625)<br>
X(141) = complement of X(6)<br>
X(141) = complementary conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(141) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,39), (67,524), (110,525)<br>
X(141) = X(39)-cross conjugate of X(427)<br>
X(141) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(76)<br>
X(141) = crosssum of X(6) and X(32)<br>

X(141) = X(645)-beth conjugate of X(141)<br>

X(141) = anticomplement of X(3589)<br>

X(141) = {X(2),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3589)<br>
X(141) = {X(395),X(396)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5306)<br>
X(141) = trilinear cube root of X(14125)<br>
X(141) = perspector of 2nd Brocard triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Brocard triangle<br>
X(141) = intersection, other than X(3), of the orthosymmedial circles of the 1st and 2nd Ehrmann inscribed triangles<br>

<h3 id="X142">X(142) = COMPLEMENT OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears b + c - [(b - c)<sup>2</sup>]/a : c + a - [(c - a)<sup>2</sup>]/b : a + b - [(a - b)<sup>2</sup>]/c
<br>
Barycentrics ab + ac - (b - c)<sup>2</sup> : bc + ba - (c - a)<sup>2</sup> : ca + cb - (a - b)<sup>2</sup>
<br><b>
X(142) = 3*X(2) + X(7) = 3*X(2) - X(9)
</b><p>
Let A' be the midpoint between A and X(7), and define B' and C' cyclically; the triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to the medial triangle, and the center of homothety is X(142). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the intersection of these three lines:
</p><p>
(1) through midpoint of CA perpendicular to BX(1)<br>
(2) through midpoint of AB perpendicular to CX(1)<br>
(3) through midpoint of AX(1) perpendicular to BC.<br>
</p><p>
Define B' and C' cyclically. Then X(142) = X(6)-of-A'B'C'. The triangle A'B'C' is the complement of the excentral triangle, and also the extraversion triangle of X(10). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
X(142) lies on these lines: 1,277 2,7
3,516 5,971 10,141
37,1086 86,284 116,119
214,528 269,948 354,3059 377,950 474,954
</p><p>
X(142) is the {X(2),X(7)}-harmonic conjugate of X(9). For a list of other harmonic conjugates, click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(142) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (7,9), (8,3243), (100,3254)<br>
X(142) = reflection of X(1001) in X(1125)<br>
X(142) = isogonal conjugate of X(1174)<br>
X(142) = isotomic conjugate of X(32008)<br>
X(142) = complement of X(9)<br>
X(142) = X(100)-Ceva conjugate of X(514)<br>
X(142) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(85)<br>
X(142) = crosssum of X(6) and X(41)<br>
X(142) = X(190)-beth conjugate of X(142)<br>
X(142) = X(9)-of- medial triangle<br>
X(142) = centroid of the set {X(1), X(4), X(7), X(40)}<br>
X(142) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(1212)<br>
X(142) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(1212)<br>
X(142) = centroid of ABCX(7)<br>
X(142) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(1212)<br>
X(142) = X(9969)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
</p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X143">X(143) = NINE-POINT CENTER OF ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (sec A)[cos(2C - 2A) + cos(2A - 2B)] : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - 2 cos 2A)cos(B - C)]: :
<br>
Trilinears sec A cos(3A) cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (tan A)[cos(2C - 2A) + cos(2A - 2B)] : :
<br><b>
X(143) = X[5] - 3 X[51] = 3 X[51] + X[52] = X[4] + 3 X[568] = X[3] + 3 X[3060] = 3 X[2979] - 7 X[3526] = X[3] - 5 X[3567] = 3 X[3060] + 5 X[3567] = 5 X[632] - 3 X[3917] = 3 X[140] - 2 X[5447] = X[5447] - 3 X[5462] = 3 X[5] - X[5562] = 9 X[51] - X[5562] = 3 X[52] + X[5562] = 5 X[1656] - 9 X[5640] = 3 X[381] - X[5876] = 3 X[381] + X[5889] = X[382] + 3 X[5890] = 5 X[5562] - 9 X[5891] = 5 X[5] - 3 X[5891] = 5 X[51] - X[5891] = 5 X[52] + 3 X[5891] = 2 X[3530] - 3 X[5892] = X[1216] - 3 X[5943] = 2 X[3628] - 3 X[5943] = X[3] - 3 X[5946] = 5 X[3567] - 3 X[5946] = 3 X[568] - X[6102] = 3 X[3830] + X[6241] = 3 X[2] + X[6243] = 3 X[5093] + X[6403] = X[195] + 3 X[7730] = 11 X[5070] - 7 X[7999]
</b><p>
X(143) is the third of three Spanish Points developed by Antreas P. Hatzipolakis and Javier Garcia Capitan in 2009; see X(3567).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of X(5). Let A", B", C" be the inverse-in-circumcircle of A', B', C'. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(143). Also, X(143) = intersection of the tangent to hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),X(15)}} at X(61) and the tangent to the hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),X(16)}} at X(62). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
X(143) is the QA-P13 center (Nine-point Center of the QA-Diagonal Triangle) of quadrangle ABCX(4) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/41-qa-p13.html). Also, X(143) is the QA-P22 center (Midpoint QA-P1 and QA-P20) of quadrangle ABCX(4) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/50-qa-p22.html)
/p><p>
X(143) lies on the curves K054, K416, K464, Q106, and these lines:<br> {2,6101}, {3,1173}, {4,94}, {5,51}, {6,26}, {23,1199}, {25,156}, {30,389}, {49,1493}, {54,2070}, {61,2912}, {62,2913}, {110,195}, {140,511}, {182,7525}, {185,3627}, {324,565}, {381,5876}, {382,5890}, {567,7488}, {569,7502}, {575,7555}, {576,1147}, {578,1658}, {632,3917}, {970,7508}, {1181,7530}, {1216,3628}, {1351,6642}, {1353,1843}, {1656,5640}, {1993,7506}, {2392,5885}, {2937,5012}, {2979,3526}, {3517,5093}, {3530,5892}, {3580,5576}, {3830,6241}, {3850,5907}, {3853,6000}, {5070,7999}, {5609,7545}, {6515,7528}, {7517,7592}
</p><p>
X(143) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {4, 6102}, {5, 52}, {185, 3627}, {389, 5446}, {1353, 1843}, {1493, 6152}, {3060, 5946}, {5876, 5889}, {6101, 6243}<br>
X(143) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these {i,j}: {140, 5462}, {1216, 3628}, {5907,3850}
<br>
X(143) = isogonal conjugate of X(252)<br>
X(143) = X(137)-cross conjugate of X(1510)<br>
X(143) = X(5)-of-orthic triangle<br>
X(143) = X(249)-Ceva conjugate of X(1625)<br>
X(143) = X(137)-cross conjugate of X(1510)<br>
X(143) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): (2,6243,6101), (3,3567,5946), (4,568,6102), (49,1994,1493), (51,52,5), (54,2070,5944), (381,5889,5876), (1112,6746,4), (1216,5943,3628), (1994,3518,49), (3060,3567,3)<br>
X(143) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these {i,j}: {1,252}, {54,2962}, {93,2169}, {930,2616}, {2167,2963}, {2190,3519}
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X144">X(144) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(7)</h3> Trilinears (csc A)(tan B/2 + tan C/2 - tan A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan B/2 + tan C/2 - tan A/2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(a - b - c) + 1/(a - b + c) + 1/(a + b - c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 3a^2 - 2a(b + c) - (b - c)^2 : :
</p><p>
X(144) = X(7)-of-anticomplementary triangle</p>
<p>X(144) lies on these lines:<br>2,7 8,516 20,72 21,954
69,190 75,391 100,480
145,192 219,347 220,279 320,344</p>
<p>X(144) is the {X(7),X(9)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(144), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
<p>
X(144) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (7,9), (145,390), (149,1156)<br>
X(144) = anticomplement of X(7)<br>
X(144) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(3434)<br>
X(144) = X(8)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(144) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (190,144), (645,346)<br>
X(144) = Conway-triangle-to-inner-Conway-triangle similarity image of X(7)<br>
X(144) = perspector of extouch triangle and Gemini triangle 30<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X145">X(145) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF NAGEL POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc(3a - b - c) : :
<br>
Trilinears -1 + csc A/2 sin B/2 sin C/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears 2(r/R) - sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 3a - b - c : :
<b><br>
X(145) = 4 X(1) + 3 X(2)
</b><p>
Let A' be the reflection of the midpoint of segment BC in X(1), and
define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(145).
Let A'' be the reflection of the A in X(1), and define B'' and C''
cyclically. Let A'''B'''C''' be the intouch triangle. The lines
A''A''', B''B''', C''C''' concur in X(145). (Randy Hutson,
9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circle tangent to side BC at its midpoint
and to the circumcircle on the same side of BC as A. Define
O<sub>B</sub>, O<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Then X(145) is the trilinear
pole of the line of the exsimilicenters (the Monge line) of
O<sub>A</sub>, O<sub>B</sub>, O<sub>C</sub>. See the reference at
X(1001).
</p><p>
Let Ha be the hyperbola passing through A, with foci at B and C. This is called the A-Soddy hyperbola in (Paul Yiu, Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle, 2002; 12.4 The Soddy hyperbolas, p. 143). Let La be the polar of X(2) with respect to Ha. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. The lines La, Lb, Lc concur in X(145). (Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the intouch and extouch triangles. X(145) is the radical center of the circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C". (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
X(145) is the {X(1),X(8)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(145), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(145) lies on these lines: 1,2 4,149
6,346 20,517 21,956
37,391 56,100 72,452

279,664 329,950 330,1002
377,1056 404,999 515,962
</p><p>
X(145) = midpoint of X(2) and X(3241)<br>

<h3 id="X154">X(154) = X(3)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(6)</h3>
Trilinears (cos A - cos B cos C)a<sup>2</sup> : (cos B - cos C cos A)b<sup>2</sup> : (cos C - cos A cos B)c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears a(tan B + tan C - tan A) : b(tan C + tan A - tan B) : c(tan A + tan B - tan C)
<br>
Trilinears (sec A - sec B sec C)a^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(3a^4 - b^4 - c^4 - 2a^2b^2 - 2a^2c^2 + 2b^2c^2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin<sup>2</sup> A)(tan B + tan C - tan A) : :
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung). A'B'C' is homothetic to the Ara triangle at X(154).
</p><p>
X(154) lies on these lines:</p>
<p>3,64 6,25 22,110
26,155 31,56 48,55
160,418 197,692 198,212
205,220 237,682</p>
<p>X(154) is the {X(26),X(156)}-harmonic conjugate of X(155). For a
list of harmonic conjugates of X(154), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(154) = isogonal conjugate of X(253)<br>
X(154) = X(3)-Ceva conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(154) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (64,1073), (122,525)<br>
X(154) = X(109)-beth conjugate of X(154)<br>
X(154) = X(2)-of-tangential triangle<br>
X(154) = centroid of cevian triangle of X(20)<br>
X(154) = pole wrt circumcircle of the trilinear polar of X(3)<br>
X(154) = Thomson isogonal conjugate of X(4)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X155">X(155) EIGENCENTER OF ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (cos A)[cos<sup>2</sup>B + cos<sup>2</sup>C - cos<sup>2</sup>A] : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 SA [a^2 (SA^2 - SB SC) - SA (SB^2 + SC^2)] : :
<p>
Let (A) be the pedal circle of A wrt the tangential triangle, and define (B), (C) cyclically. The radical center of (A), (B), (C) = X(155). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(155) = X(4)-of-tangential-triangle. This point is also the center
of the circle which cuts (extended) lines BC, CA, AB in pairs of points
A' and A", B' and B", C' and C", respectively, such that angles A'AA",
B'BB", C'CC" are all right angles. This is the <i>Dou circle,</i>
described in</p>
<p><b>Jordi Dou,</b> Problem 1140, <i>Crux Mathematicorum,</i> 28
(2002) 461-462.</p>
<p>Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of A with respect to the triangle
BCX(4), and define B' and C' cyclically. Let A''B''C'' be the orthic
triangle. Then the lines A'A'', B'B'', C'C'' concur in X(155). (Randy
Hutson, 9/23/2011)</p>
<p>X(155) lies on these lines:<br>1,90 3,49 4,254 5,6
20,323 24,110 25,52
26,154 30,1498 159,511
195,381 382,399 450,1075
648,1093 651,1068</p>
<p>X(155) is the {X(26),X(156)}-harmonic conjugate of X(154). For a
list of harmonic conjugates of X(155), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(155) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,1147), (26,156), (68,5)<br>
X(155) = isogonal conjugate of X(254)<br>
X(155) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(155) = crosssum of X(136) and X(523)<br>
X(155) = eigencenter of cevian triangle of X(4)<br>
X(155) = eigencenter of anticevian triangle of X(3)<br>
X(155) = X(84)-of-orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(155) = orthic-isogonal conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(155) = tangential-isogonal conjugate of X(26)<br>
X(155) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(924)X(2501)<br>
X(155) = perspector of orthic triangle and tangential triangle of the MacBeath circumconic, which is also the anticevian triangle of X(3)<br>
X(155) = perspector of orthic triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Hyacinth triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X156">X(156) = X(5)-OF-TANGENTIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a[b<sup>2</sup>y/v +
c<sup>2</sup>z/w - a<sup>2</sup>x/u],<br> u
= u(A,B,C) = sin 2A, v = u(B,C,A), w = u(C,A,B);<br> x
= x(A,B,C) = u<sup>2</sup>(v<sup>2</sup> + w<sup>2</sup>) -
(v<sup>2</sup> - w<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>, y = x(B,C,A), z = x(C,A,B)
<p>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)</p>
<p>X(156) = X(5)-of-tangential triangle</p>
<p>X(156) lies on these lines: 3,74 4,49
5,184 25,143 26,154
54,381 546,578 550,1092</p>
<p>X(156) is the {X(154),X(155)}-harmonic conjugate of X(26). For a
list of harmonic conjugates, click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.</p>
<p>X(156) = midpoint of X(26) and X(155)</p>
<p></p>

c<sup>3</sup>cos C - a<sup>3</sup>cos A]<br> =
g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where<br> g(a,b,c)
= a[a<sup>6</sup> - b<sup>6</sup> - c<sup>6</sup> -
a<sup>4</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) +
b<sup>4</sup>(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) +
c<sup>4</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)]

<h3 id="X158">X(158) = X(19)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(92)</h3>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>A
: sec<sup>2</sup>B : sec<sup>2</sup>C<br> =
1/(1 + cos 2A) : 1/(1 + cos 2B) : 1/(1 + cos 2C)
<p>Barycentrics sec A tan A : sec B tan B : sec C tan C
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the hexyl triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(158). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the Euler and anti-Euler triangles, resp. Let A* be the trilinear product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(158). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(158) lies on these lines: 1,29 3,243 4,65
10,318 37,281 46,412
47,162 75,240 107,759
225,1093 255,775 286,969
823,897 920,921 1068,3542
</p><p>
X(158) = isogonal conjugate of X(255)<br>
X(158) = isotomic conjugate of X(326)<br>
X(158) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (19,92), (225,4)<br>
X(158) = crosssum of X(520) and X(1364)<br>
X(158) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(680)X(822)<br>
X(158) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (821,158), (1105,255)<br>
X(158) = X(107)-beth conjugate of X(34)<br>
X(158) = trilinear pole of polar of X(63) wrt polar circle (line X(661)X(3064))<br>
X(158) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(63) (line X(521)X(656))<br>
X(158) = polar conjugate of X(63)<br>
X(158) = trilinear product of X(1123) and X(1336)<br>
X(158) = trilinear square of X(4)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X159">X(159) = X(9)-OF-TANGENTIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= a[(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)sin 2A +
(c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)sin 2B + (b<sup>2</sup>
- c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)sin 2C]
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)<br></p>
<p>X(159) = X(9)-of-tangential triangle if ABC is acute</p>
<p>X(159) lies on these lines: 3,66 6,25
22,69 23,193 155,511 197,200
</p> <p>
X(159) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (6,206), (66,141)<br>
X(159) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (22,3), (69,6)<br>
X(159) = crosssum of X(127) and X(523)<br>
X(159) = tangential isogonal conjugate of X(25)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X160">X(160) = X(37)-OF-TANGENTIAL-TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= a[(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)sin 2A + (c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)sin 2B + (b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)sin 2C]
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)<br></p>
<p></p>

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= a[(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)
+ (c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)sin<sup>2</sup>(2B) +
(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)sin<sup>2</sup>(2C)]

<h3 id="X162">X(162) = CEVAPOINT OF X(108) AND X(109)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(sin 2B - sin 2C) : 1/(sin 2C - sin 2A) : 1/(sin 2A - sin 2B)
<br>
Trilinears 1/[(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)]
<br>
Trilinears sec A csc(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(tan B - tan C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a/(sin 2B - sin 2C) : b/(sin 2C - sin 2A) : c/(sin 2A - sin 2B)
<p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(1)X(19), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(162).
(Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(8)X(29), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(162).
(Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>

(Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)

<h3 id="X165">X(165) = CENTROID OF THE EXCENTRAL TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) - tan(A/2) : tan(C/2) + tan(A/2) - tan(B/2) : tan(A/2) + tan(B/2) - tan(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears 3a<sup>2</sup> - 2a(b + c) - (b - c)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears (r/R) - 4 cos A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a[tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) - tan(A/2)] : :
<b><br>
X(165) = X(1) - 4 X(3)
</b><p>
If DEF is the pedal triangle of X(165), then |AE| + |AF| = |BF| + |BD| = |CD| + |CE|. (Seiichi Kirikami, October 8, 2010.)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticevian triangle, wrt intouch triangle, of X(1). Let A" be the reflection of A' in A, and define B' and C' cyclically. The centroid of A"B"C" is X(165). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. Let A" be the symmedian point of triangle A'BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(165).
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(165)A.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(165)</a>.</p>
<p>X(165) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,516 4,1698 9,910
10,20 32,1571 42,991
43,573 63,100 71,610
105,1054 108,1767 109,212
164,167 166,168 191,1079
210,971 218,1190 220,1615
227,1394 255,1103 269,1253
355,550 371,1703 372,1702
376,515 380,579 386,1695
411,936 479,1323 498,1770
572,1051 574,1572 580,601
612,990 614,902 631,946
750,968 846,1719 950,1788
958,1706 962,1125 1011,1730
1342,1701 1343,1700</p>
<p>X(165) is the {X(3),X(40)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1). For a list of
harmonic conjugates of X(165), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.
</p><p>
X(165) = isogonal conjugate of X(3062)<br>

<h3 id="X166">X(166) GERGONNE POINT OF EXCENTRAL TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= (tan A/2)/(cos B/2 + cos C/2 - cos A/2) - (tan B/2)/(cos C/2 + cos
A/2 - cos B/2) - (tan C/2)/(cos A/2 + cos B/2 - cos C/2)
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A)f(A,B,C)<br></p>
<p>X(166) = X(7)-of-excentral triangle</p>
<p>X(166) lies on these lines: 1,1488 165,168
167,188</p>
<p>X(166) = X(266)-cross conjugate of X(57)<br>X(166) = cevapoint of X(266) and X(289)</p>

<h3 id="X167">X(167) NAGEL POINT OF EXCENTRAL TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= s(B,C,A)t(B,C,A) + s(C,A,B)t(C,A,B) - s(A,B,C)t(A,B,C),<br> where
s(A,B,C) = sin(A/2) and t(A,B,C) = (cos B/2 + cos C/2 - cos A/2) sec
A/2
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A)f(A,B,C)<br></p>
<p>X(167) = X(8)-of-excentral triangle</p>
<p>X(167) lies on these lines: 1,174 164,165
166,188</p>
<p>X(167) = X(9)-aleph conjugate of X(166)

<h3 id="X173">X(173) = CONGRUENT ISOSCELIZERS POINT<a id= "CongruentIsoscelizersPoint" name="CongruentIsoscelizersPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears cos B/2 + cos C/2 - cos A/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears tan A/2 + sec A/2 : tan B/2 + sec B/2 : tan C/2 + sec C/2 (M. Iliev, 4/12/07)
<br>
Trilinears b(csc B/2) + c(csc C/2) - a(csc A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cot A'/2 : :, where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears b' + c' - a' : :, where a', b', c' are sidelengths of excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears cot A' + csc A' : :, where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears [distance from A to far side of A-excircle] : :
</p><p>
Let P<sub>B</sub> on sideline AC and Q<sub>C</sub> be equidistant from A, so that AP<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub> is an isosceles triangle. The line P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub> is called an isoscelizer. The lines P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub>, P<sub>C</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>, P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>B</sub> concur in X(173). (P. Yff, unpublished notes, 1989)
</p> <p>
The intouch triangle of the intouch triangle of triangle ABC is perspective to triangle ABC, and X(173) is the perspector. (Eric Danneels, Hyacinthos 7892, 9/13/03)
</p> <p>
Also, X(173) = X(1486)-of-the-intouch-triangle. (Darij Grinberg; see notes at X(1485) and X(1486).)
</p> <p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(173).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Congruent Isoscelizers Point</a>.
</p> <p>
X(173) lies on these lines: 1,168 9,177 57,174 164,504 180,483 503,844 505,1130
</p> <p>
X(173) = isogonal conjugate of X(258)<br>
X(173) = X(174)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(173) = SS(A->A')-of-X(9), where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
X(173) = X(19)-of-excentral triangle<br>
X(173) = X(19)-of-Yff central triangle<br>
X(173) = homothetic center of excentral triangle and Yff central triangle<br>
X(173) = homothetic center of ABC and orthic triangle of Yff central triangle<br>
X(173) = homothetic center of ABC and extangents triangle of excentral triangle<br>
X(173) = excentral isogonal conjugate of X(845)<br>
X(173) = X(i)-aleph conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,503), (2,504), (174,173), (188,845), (366,164), (507,1), (508,362), (509,361)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X174">X(174) = YFF CENTER OF CONGRUENCE<a id="YffCenterOfCongruence" name= "YffCenterOfCongruence"></a></h3>
Trilinears sec A/2 : sec B/2 : sec C/2
<br>
Trilinears [bc/(b + c - a)]<sup>1/2</sup> : [ca(c + a - b)]<sup>1/2</sup> : [ab(a + b - c)]<sup>1/2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears csc A' : csc B' : csc C', where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears |AA'| : |BB'| : |CC'|, where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears (csc A')(cos B' + cos C') : :, where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Barycentrics sin A/2 : sin B/2 : sin C/2
<p>
Let Ea be the ellipse with B and C as foci and passing through X(1), and define Eb and Ec cyclically. Let La be the line tangent to Ea at X(1), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = La&cap;BC, B' = Lb&cap;CA, C' = Lc&cap;AB. Then A', B', C' are collinear, and X(174) = trilinear pole of line A'B'C'. The line A'B'C' meets the line at infinity at the isogonal conjugate of X(3659). Alternately, let A" be the trilinear pole of line La, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB" and CC" concur at X(174); see also X(188). The points A", B", C" lie on the circumconic centered at X(9). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
<p></p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. X(174) is the trilinear pole of the Monge line of the incircles of BCA', CAB', ABC'. (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
<p></p>
In notes dated 1987, Yff raises this question concerning certain triangles lying within ABC: can isoscelizers (defined at X(173)), P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub>, P<sub>C</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>, P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>B</sub>, be constructed so that, on putting
</p><p>
R<sub>A</sub> = P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>B</sub>&cap;P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub>, R<sub>B</sub> = P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub>&cap;P<sub>C</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>, R<sub>C</sub> = P<sub>C</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>&cap;P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>B</sub>,
</p> <p>
the following four triangles are congruent:
</p> <p>
P<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>A</sub>R<sub>A</sub>, P<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>B</sub>R<sub>B</sub>,
P<sub>C</sub>Q<sub>C</sub>R<sub>C</sub>, R<sub>A</sub>R<sub>B</sub>R<sub>C</sub> ?
</p> <p>
After proving that the answer is yes, Yff moves the three isoscelizers in such a way that the three outer triangles, stay congruent and the inner triangle (called the Yff central triangle), R<sub>A</sub>R<sub>B</sub>R<sub>C</sub>, shrinks to X(174).
</p> <p>
Let D be the point on side BC such that (angle BID) = (angle DIC), and likewise for point E on side CA and point F on side AB. The lines AD, BE, CF concur in X(174). (Seiichi Kirikami, Jan. 29, 2010)
</p> <p>
Generalization: if I is replaced by an arbitrary point P = p : q : r (trilinears), then the lines AD, BE, CF concur in the point K(P) = f(p,q,r,A) : f(q,r,p,B) : f(r,p,q,C), where f(p,q,r,A) = (q<sup>2</sup> + r<sup>2</sup> + 2qr cos A)<sup>-1/2</sup>. Moreover, if P* is the inverse of P in the circumcircle, then K(P*) = K(P). (Peter Moses, Feb. 1, 2010, based on Seiichi Kirikami's construction of X(174))
</p> <p>
X(174) is the homothetic center of ABC and the extangents triangle of the intouch triangle. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p> <p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(174).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Yff Center of Congruence (1)</a> and <a href="X(174)A.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Yff Center of Congruence (2)</a> and
<a href="X(174)B.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Yff Center of Congruence (3)</a>. For access to a sketch of the Yff central triangle, see X(177).
</p> <p>
X(174) lies on these lines: 1,167 2,236 7,234 57,173 175,483 176,1143 188,266 481,1127 558,1489
</p> <p>
X(174) = isogonal conjugate of X(259)<br>
X(174) = anticomplement of X(2090)<br>
X(174) = X(508)-Ceva conjugate of X(188)<br>
X(174) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,173), (259,266)<br>
X(174) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1488), (177,7), (259,188)<br>
X(174) = crosssum of X(1) and X(503)<br>
X(174) = X(556)-beth conjugate of X(556)<br>
X(174) = SS(A->A')-of-X(2), where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
X(174) = SS(A->A')-of-X(226), where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
X(174) = isotomic conjugate of X(556)<br>
X(174) = X(55)-of-intouch triangle<br>
X(174) = X(55)-of-Yff central triangle<br>
X(174) = homothetic center of intouch triangle and Yff central triangle<br>
X(174) = homothetic center of ABC and the intangents triangle of the intouch triangle.<br>
X(174) = {X(8134),X(8136)}-harmonic conjugate of X(8123)<br>
X(174) = {X(8137),X(8139)}-harmonic conjugate of X(8124)<br>
X(174) = X(1824)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X175">X(175) = ISOPERIMETRIC POINT<a id="IsoperimetricPoint" name= "IsoperimetricPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears -1 + sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(-1 + sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics -2a + (a + b + c) tan(A/2) : :
<b><br>
X(175) = 2s*X(1) - (r + 4R)*X(7) = 3X[2]-4X[31534] <p></b>
The points X(175) and X(176) are discussed in an 1890 article by Emile Lemoine, accessible at
<a href="http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k201173h">Gallica</a>. The article begins on page 111, and the two points are considered beginning on page 128.
</p><p>
A point X is defined as an isoperimetric point of triangle ABC if |XB| + |XC| + |BC| = |XC| + |XA| + |CA| = |XA| + |XB| + |AB|. Veldkamp established that X = X(175), uniquely, for some triangles ABC, but the conditions he gives are not correct. Hajja and Yff proved that the condition tan(A/2) + tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) &lt; 2 is necessary and sufficient. See also X(176) and the 1st and 2nd Eppstein points, X(481), X(482).
</p><p>
In unpublished notes, Yff proved that X(175) is the center of the outer Soddy circle. His proof later appeared in the paper by Hajja and Yff cited below.
</p><p>
Every point on the Soddy line has barycentric coordinates of the form a + k/sa : b + k/sb : c + k/sc, where k is a symmetric function in a,b,c, and sa=(b+c-a)/2, sb=(c+a-b)/2, sc=(a+b-c)/2. Writing S for 4*area(ABC):
</p><p>
X(175) = 2a - S/sa : 2b - S/sb : 2c - S/sc<br>
X(176) = 2a + S/sa : 2b + S/sb : 2c + S/sc<br>
X(481) = a - S/sa : b - S/sb : c - S/sc<br>
X(482) = a + S/sa : b + S/sb : c + S/sc<br>
X(1371) = a + 2S/(3 sa) : b + 2S/(3 sb) : c + 2S/(3 sc)<br>
X(1372) = a - 2S/(3 sa) : b - 2S/(3 sb) : c - 2S/(3 sc)<br>
X(1373) = a + 2S/sa : b + 2S/sb : c + 2S/sc<br>
X(1374) = a - 2S/sa : b - 2S/sb : c - 2S/sc<br>
</p><p><b>Clark Kimberling and R. W. Wagner,</b> Problem E 3020 and Solution, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 93 (1986) 650-652 [proposed 1983].
</p><p>
<b>G. R. Veldkamp,</b> "The isoperimetric point and the point(s) of equal detour," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 92 (1985) 546-558.
</p><p>
Muwaffaq Hajja and Peter Yff, "The isoperimetric point and the point(s) of equal detour in a triangle," <i>Journal of Geometry</i> 87 (2007) 76-82.
</p><p>
There are exactly two points P such that the incircles of the triangles PBC, PCA, PAB are pairwise tangent to one another; the two points are X(175) and X(176). There are exactly two points P such that the radical center of the incircles of PBC, PCA, PAB is P; the two points are X(175) and X(176). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
X(175) lies on the curves K032, K199, K200, Q074, Q092, Q104 and on these lines: {1,7}, {2,13386}, {4,10905}, {8,1270}, {65,6252}, {69,10908}, {105,30385}, {144,30557}, {174,483}, {226,1131}, {329,3084}, {388,10911}, {490,664}, {651,1335}, {1336,10253}, {1463,7353}, {2082,6203}, {3062,10973}, {3083,9776}, {3297,5228}, {3298,6180}, {4000,7968}, {4644,7969}, {5222,18992}, {5226,5393}, {5261,9907}, {5405,5435}, {5932,31528}, {5933,31530}, {6405,20358}, {7090,10405}, {7585,30325}, {9778,10135}, {9789,21147}, {10580,16663}, {11293,17086}, {13387,20211}, {13389,21454}, {13459,16441}, {15913,31536}, {16214,32081}, {21453,30335}, {30347,31588}, {30413,31547}, {31544,32201}</p>
<p>
X(175) = reflection of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {176, 3160}, {10405, 7090}, {14121, 31534}, {30334, 1}<br>
X(175) = isogonal conjugate of X(30336)<br>
X(175) = anticomplement of X(14121)<br>
X(175) = X(i)-anticomplementary conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {6, 13386}, {603, 176}, {1659, 21270}, {1805, 3869}, {2067, 8}, {2362, 4}, {5414, 329}, {6502, 31552}, {13388, 69}, {30557, 3436}<br>
X(175) = X(8)-Ceva conjugate of X(176)<br>
X(175) = X(10135)-cross conjugate of X(7)<br>
X(175) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {1, 30336}, {6, 15891}<br>
X(175) = cevapoint of X(10253) and X(32058)<br>
X(175) = crosssum of X(55) and X(19037)<br>
X(175) = reflection of X(175) in the Soddy line<br>
X(175) = X(6406)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(175) = X(1152)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(175) = X(7353)-of-(inner)-tangential-mid-arc-triangle (TCCT 6.15)<br>
X(175) = X(12224)-of-first-circumperp-triangle (TCCT 6.21)<br>
X(175) = X(6400)-of-second-circumperp-triangle (TCCT 6.22)<br>
X(175) = barycentric product X(i)*X(j) for these {i,j}: {7, 30413}, {8, 16662}, {1659, 31547}<br>
X(175) = barycentric quotient X(i)/X(j) for these {i,j}: {1, 15891}, {6, 30336}, {9778, 30412}, {16662, 7}, {30413, 8}<br>
X(175) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): {1, 7, 176}, {1, 481, 7}, {1, 482, 17805}, {1, 1372, 481}, {1, 1373, 31538}, {1, 1374, 482}, {1, 17803, 31539}, {1, 30342, 11038}, {1, 31539, 17802}, {1, 31568, 8236}, {7, 176, 21169}, {7, 482, 21170}, {7, 1372, 17801}, {7, 8236, 31566}, {7, 17802, 1}, {7, 17805, 482}, {7, 31601, 1373}, {7, 31602, 481}, {20, 347, 176}, {77, 962, 176}, {176, 21169, 17804}, {176, 21170, 482}, {269, 9785, 176}, {279, 390, 176}, {481, 482, 1374}, {481, 1372, 31602}, {481, 17802, 176}, {481, 17803, 17802}, {481, 31539, 1}, {481, 31602, 17801}, {482, 1374, 7}, {482, 17805, 176}, {482, 21170, 21169}, {1323, 30332, 176}, {1372, 17803, 1}, {1372, 31539, 7}, {1373, 31538, 31601}, {1374, 17805, 21170}, {1442, 4295, 176}, {1443, 30305, 176}, {3600, 3672, 176}, {3638, 3639, 1372}, {3663, 4308, 176}, {3664, 4323, 176}, {3668, 4313, 176}, {3674, 4344, 176}, {4296, 4329, 176}, {4318, 17170, 176}, {4862, 6049, 176}, {5542, 5543, 176}, {5731, 22464, 176}, {7190, 11037, 176}, {8236, 10481, 176}, {10135, 32083, 16662}, {10481, 31568, 31566}, {13388, 13390, 2}, {14121, 31534, 2}, {17801, 17802, 21169}, {17802, 31602, 7}, {30424, 31721, 176}, {31538, 31601, 176}, {31539, 31602, 176}<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X176">X(176) = EQUAL DETOUR POINT<a id="EqualDetourPoint" name= "EqualDetourPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears 1 + sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(1 + sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2)<br>
<br>
Barycentrics 2a + (a + b + c) tan(A/2) : :
<br><b>
X(176) = 2s*X(1) + (r + 4R)*X(7) = 3X[2]-4X[31535]
</b><p>
The points X(175) and X(176) are discussed in an 1890 article by Emile Lemoine, accessible at <a href= "http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k201173h">Gallica</a>. The article begins on page 111, and the two points are considered beginning on page 128.
</p><p>
The following construction was found by Elkies: call two circles within ABC <i>companion circles</i> if they are the incircles of two triangles formed by dividing ABC into two smaller triangles by passing a line through one of the vertices and some point on the opposite side; chain of circles O(1), O(2), ... such that O(n),O(n+1) are companion incircles for every n consists of at most six distinct circles; there is a unique chain consisting of only three distinct circles; and for this chain, the three subdividing lines concur in X(176).
</p><p>
A point X is defined as a point of equal detour of triangle ABC if |XB| + |XC| - |BC| = |XC| + |XA| - |CA| = |XA| + |XB| - |AB|. Veldkamp established that X = X(176) for some triangles ABC, but the conditions he gives are not correct. Hajja and Yff proved that the condition tan(A/2) + tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) &lt; 2 is necessary and sufficient for the existence of exactly two points of equal detour and that the condition tan(A/2) + tan(B/2) + tan(C/2) = 2 is necessary and sufficient for the existence of exactly one point of equal detour. Yff found that X(176) is also is the center of the inner Soddy circle. See also X(175) and the 1st and 2nd Eppstein points, X(481), X(482).
</p><p>
<b>G. R. Veldkamp</b>, "The isoperimetric point and the point(s) of equal detour," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 92 (1985) 546-558.
</p><p>
<b>Noam D. Elkies and Jiro Fukuta</b>, Problem E 3236 and Solution, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 97 (1990) 529-531 [proposed 1987].
</p><p>
Mowaffaq Majja and Peter Yff, "The isoperimetric point and the point(s) of equal detour in a triangle," <i>Journal of Geometry</i> 87 (2007) 76-82.
</p><p>
There are exactly two points P such that the incircles of the triangles PBC, PCA, PAB are pairwise tangent to one another; the two points are X(175) and X(176). There are exactly two points P such that the radical center of the incircles of PBC, PCA, PAB is P; the two points are X(175) and X(176). For a point Q, let A' be the incenter of triangle BCQ, and define B' and C' cyclically; then X(176) is the only point Q such that Q is the incenter of A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let Ia, Ib, Ic be the centers of the Elkies companion incircles. Let A' be the trilinear product Ib*Ic, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(482). The lines IaA', IbB', IcC' concur in X(176). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(176) lies on K032, K199, K200, Q074, Q092, Q104 and these lines: {1,7}, {2,1659}, {4,10904}, {8,1271}, {65,6404}, {69,10907}, {105,30386}, {144,30556}, {174,1274}, {226,1132}, {329,3083}, {388,10910}, {489,664}, {651,1124}, {1123,10252}, {1463,7362}, {1587,8953}, {1588,8978}, {2082,6204}, {3062,10972}, {3084,9776}, {3177,31408}, {3297,6180}, {3298,5228}, {3622,8243}, {4000,7969}, {4644,7968}, {5222,18991}, {5226,5405}, {5261,9906}, {5393,5435}, {5932,31529}, {5933,31531}, {6283,20358}, {7586,30324}, {8973,23259}, {9778,10134}, {10405,14121}, {10580,16662}, {11294,17086}, {13386,20211}, {13388,21454}, {13437,16440}, {15913,31537}, {16213,32080}, {21453,30336}, {30346,31589}, {30412,31548}, {31545,32200}</p>
<p>
X(176) = reflection of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {20, 8984}, {175, 3160}, {7090, 31535}, {10405, 14121}, {30333, 1}<br>
X(176) = isogonal conjugate of X(30335)<br>
X(176) = anticomplement of X(7090)<br>
X(176) = X(i)-anticomplementary conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {6, 13387}, {603, 175}, {1806, 3869}, {2066, 329}, {2067, 31551}, {6502, 8}, {13389, 69}, {13390, 21270}, {16232, 4}, {30556, 3436}<br>
X(176) = X(8)-Ceva conjugate of X(175)<br>
X(176) = X(10134)-cross conjugate of X(7)<br>
X(176) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {1, 30335}, {6, 15892}<br>
X(176) = cevapoint of X(10252) and X(32057)<br>
X(176) = crosssum of X(55) and X(19038)<br>
X(176) = reflection of X(176) in the Soddy line<br>
X(176) = X(6291)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(176) = X(1151)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(176) = X(7362)-of-(inner)-tangential-mid-arc-triangle (TCCT 6.15)<br>
X(176) = X(12223)-of-first-circumperp-triangle (TCCT 6.21)<br>
X(176) = X(6239)-of-second-circumperp-triangle (TCCT 6.22)<br>
X(176) = barycentric product X(i)*X(j) for these {i,j}: {7, 30412}, {8, 16663}, {13390, 31548}<br>
X(176) = barycentric quotient X(i)/X(j) for these {i,j}: {1, 15892}, {6, 30335}, {174, 5451}, {9778, 30413}, {16663, 7}, {30412, 8}<br>
X(176) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): {1, 7, 175}, {1, 481, 17802}, {1, 482, 7}, {1, 1371, 482}, {1, 1373, 481}, {1, 1374, 31539}, {1, 17804, 21170}, {1, 17806, 31538}, {1, 21170, 17801}, {1, 21171, 31602}, {1, 30341, 11038}, {1, 31538, 17805}, {1, 31567, 8236}, {1, 31601, 21169}, {7, 482, 21169}, {7, 1371, 17804}, {7, 8236, 31565}, {7, 17802, 481}, {7, 17805, 1}, {7, 21169, 21170}, {7, 31601, 482}, {7, 31602, 1374}, {20, 347, 175}, {77, 962, 175}, {175, 482, 21170}, {175, 17804, 21169}, {175, 21169, 7}, {269, 9785, 175}, {279, 390, 175}, {481, 482, 1373}, {481, 1373, 7}, {481, 17802, 175}, {482, 1371, 31601}, {482, 17805, 175}, {482, 17806, 17805}, {482, 31538, 1}, {482, 31539, 21171}, {482, 31601, 17804}, {1323, 30332, 175}, {1371, 17805, 21169}, {1371, 17806, 1}, {1371, 31538, 7}, {1374, 21171, 7}, {1374, 31539, 31602}, {1442, 4295, 175}, {1443, 30305, 175}, {1659, 13389, 2}, {3600, 3672, 175}, {3638, 3639, 1371}, {3663, 4308, 175}, {3664, 4323, 175}, {3668, 4313, 175}, {3674, 4344, 175}, {4296, 4329, 175}, {4318, 17170, 175}, {4862, 6049, 175}, {5542, 5543, 175}, {5731, 22464, 175}, {7090, 31535, 2}, {7190, 11037, 175}, {8236, 10481, 175}, {10134, 32082, 16663}, {10481, 31567, 31565}, {17804, 21169, 482}, {17805, 31601, 7}, {21171, 31539, 1374}, {30424, 31721, 175}, {31538, 31601, 175}, {31539, 31602, 175}<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X177">X(177) = 1st MID-ARC POINT<a id="FirstMidArcPoint" name= "FirstMidArcPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears (cos B/2 + cos C/2) sec A/2 : (cos C/2 + cos A/2) sec B/2 : (cos A/2 + cos B/2) sec C/2
<br>
Trilinears (b' + c')/a' : :, where a', b', c' are sidelengths of excentral triangle
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(cos B/2 + cos C/2) sec A/2 : :
<p>
Let A',B',C' be the first points of intersection of the angle
bisectors of ABC with its incircle. The tangents at A', B', C' form a
triangle A"B"C", and the lines AA",BB",CC" concur in X(177). Also,
X(177) = X(1) of the intouch triangle.</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling and G. R. Veldkamp,</b> Problem 1160 and
Solution, <i>Crux Mathematicorum</i> 13 (1987) 298-299 [proposed
1986].</p>
<p>X(177) is the perspector of ABC and the Yff central triangle, and
X(177) is X(65)-of-the-Yff-central-triangle . (Darij Grinberg,
Hyacinthos #7689, 8/25/2003)</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(177).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(177)</a> and
<a href=
"YffCentralTriangle.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Yff Central
Triangle</a>.</p>
<p>X(177) lies on these lines: 1,167 7,555
8,556 9,173 57,164</p>
<p>
X(177) = isogonal conjugate of X(260)<br>
X(177) = X(7)-Ceva conjugate of X(234)<br>
X(177) = crosspoint of X(7) and X(174)<br>
X(177) = crosssum of X(55) and X(259)<br>
X(177) = SS(A->A')-of-X(10), where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
X(177) = X(4)-of-mid-arc triangle<br>
X(177) = X(1829)-of-excentral triangle<br>
X(177) = perspector of ABC and mid-triangle of 1st tangential mid-arc triangle and Yff central triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X178">X(178) = 2nd MID-ARC POINT<a id="SecondMidArcPoint" name= "SecondMidArcPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears (cos
B/2 + cos C/2) csc A : (cos C/2 + cos A/2) csc B : (cos A/2 + cos B/2)
csc C<br>Barycentrics cos B/2 + cos C/2 : cos C/2 + cos A/2 : cos A/2
+ cos B/2
<p>Let A',B',C' be the first points of intersection of the angle
bisectors of ABC with its incircle. Let A",B",C" be the midpoints of
segments BC,CA,AB, respectively. The lines A'A",B'B",C'C" concur in
X(178).</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling,</b> Problem 804, <i>Nieuw Archikef voor
Wiskunde</i> 6 (1988) 170.</p>
<p>X(178) lies on these lines: 2,188 8,236</p>
<p>X(178) = complement of X(188)<br>X(178) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(508)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X179">X(179) = 1st AJIMA-MALFATTI POINT<a id=
"FirstAjimaMalfattiPoint" name=
"FirstAjimaMalfattiPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears sec<sup>4</sup>(A/4)
: sec<sup>4</sup>(B/4) : sec<sup>4</sup>(C/4)<br>Barycentrics sin A sec<sup>4</sup>(A/4) : sin B
sec<sup>4</sup>(B/4) : sin C sec<sup>4</sup>(C/4)
<p>The famous Malfatti Problem is to construct three circles O(A),
O(B), O(C) inside ABC such that each is externally tangent to the other
two, O(A) is tangent to lines AB and AC, O(B) is tangent to BC and BA,
and O(C) is tangent to CA and CB. Let A' = O(B)&cap;O(C), B' =
O(C)&cap;O(A), C' = O(A)&cap;O(B). The lines AA',BB',CC' concur in
X(179). Trilinears are found in Yff's unpublished notes. See also the
Yff-Malfatti Point, X(400), having trilinears csc<sup>4</sup>(A/4) :
csc<sup>4</sup>(B/4) : csc<sup>4</sup>(C/4), and the references for
historical notes.</p>
<p><b>H. Fukagawa and D. Pedoe,</b> <i>Japanese Temple Geometry
Problems (San Gaku),</i> The Charles Babbage Research Centre, Winnipeg,
Canada, 1989.</p>
<p><b>Michael Goldberg,</b> "On the original Malfatti problem,"
<i>Mathematics Magazine,</i> 40 (1967) 241-247.</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling and I. G. MacDonald,</b> Problem E 3251 and
Solution, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 97 (1990) 612-613.</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(179).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(179)</a>.</p>
<p>X(179) lies on this line: 1,1142</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X180">X(180) = 2nd AJIMA-MALFATTI POINT<a id= "SecondAjimaMalfattiPoint" name= "SecondAjimaMalfattiPoint"></a></h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = 1/t(B,C,A) + 1/t(C,B,A) - 1/t(A,C,B),<br>
t(A,B,C)
= 1 + 2(sec A/4 cos B/4 cos C/4)<sup>2</sup>
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where
g(A,B,C) = (sin A)f(A,B,C)<br></p>
<p>Let A",B",C" be the excenters of ABC, and let A',B',C' be as in the
construction of X(179). The lines A'A",B'B",B'B" concur in X(180).
Trilinears are found in Yff's unpublished notes. See X(179).</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(180).gsp"><b>X(180)</b> and
<a href="X(180)%20External.gsp" style=
"font-weight: bold">X(180) External</a>.
<p>X(180) lies on this line: 173,483
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X181">X(181) = APOLLONIUS POINT</h3> <a id="ApolloniusPoint" name="ApolloniusPoint"></a>Trilinears a(b +
c)<sup>2</sup>/(b + c - a) : b(c + a)<sup>2</sup>/(c + a - b) : c(a +
b)<sup>2</sup>/(a + b - c)<br> =
a<sup>2</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2 - C/2) :
b<sup>2</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(C/2 - A/2) :
c<sup>2</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2 - B/2)
<p>
Trilinears h(a,b,c) :
h(b,c,a) : h(c,a,b), where h(a,b,c) = [r cos(A/2) + s
sin(A/2)]<sup>2</sup>, s = semiperimeter, r = inradius</p>
<p>Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2 - C/2) :
b<sup>3</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(C/2 - A/2) :
c<sup>3</sup>cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2 - B/2)</p>
<p>Let O(A),O(B),O(C) be the excircles. Apollonius's Problem includes
the construction of the circle O tangent to the three excircles and
encompassing them. (The circle is called the Apollonius circle.) Let A'
= O&cap;O(A), B'=O&cap;O(B), C'=O&cap;O(C). The lines AA',BB',CC'
concur in X(181). Yff derived trilinears in 1992.</p>
<p>X(181) is the external center of similitude (or exsimilicenter) of
the incircle and Apollonius circle. The internal center is X(1682).
(Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/2003)</p>
<p>X(181) is the isogonal conjugate of the isotomic conjugate of X(12);
also, X(181) is the {X(i) ,X(j) }-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these
(i,j,k)): (31,51,3271), (42,1400,1402), (57,1401,1357), (57,1469,1401).
(Peter J. C. Moses, 6/20/2014)</p>
<p>A proof of the the concurrence of lines AA',BB',CC' follows.<br> A =
exsimilicenter(incircle, A-excircle)<br> A' =
exsimilicenter(A-excircle, Apollonius circle)<br> Let J =
exsimilicenter(incircle, Apollonius circle).<br>By Monge's theorem, the points A, A', J are collinear. In particular, J
lies on line AA', and cyclically, J lies on lines BB' and CC'.
Therefore, J = X(181). (Darij Grinberg, Hyacinthos, 7461, 8/10/03)
</p><p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of the midpoint of BC, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inscribed in the Apollonius circle and homothetic to the intouch triangle at X(181). (Randy Hutson, March 21, 2019)
</p><p>
See also <b>Clark Kimberling, Shiko Iwata, and Hidetosi Fukagawa,</b> Problem
1091 and Solution, <i>Crux Mathematicorum</i> 13 (1987) 128-129;
217-218. [proposed 1985].</p>
<p>X(181) lies on these lines:<br>{1,970}, {6,197}, {8,959}, {10,12}, {11,2051}, {25,2175}, {31,51}, {33,3022}, {42,228}, {43,57}, {44,375}, {55,573}, {56,386}, {58,1324}, {81,5061}, {171,511}, {182,5329}, {200,3779}, {213,2333}, {373,748}, {389,3072}, {518,3687}, {553,1463}, {575,5363}, {612,3688}, {750,3917}, {756,2171}, {942,5530}, {994,1361}, {1124,1685}, {1254,1425}, {1317,3032}, {1335,1686}, {1356,5213}, {1358,3034}, {1364,5348}, {1376,4259}, {1395,1843}, {1672,1683}, {1673,1684}, {1674,1693}, {1675,1694}, {1695,1697}, {2007,2019}, {2008,2020}, {2330,5285}, {2534,2538}, {2535,2539}, {3027,3029}, {3028,3031}, {3056,5269}, {3340,4517}, {3781,5268}, {3792,3819}, {4276,5172}</p>
<p>X(181) = isogonal conjugate of X(261)<br>

<h3 id="X182">X(182) = MIDPOINT OF BROCARD DIAMETER</h3>
Trilinears cos(A- &omega;) : cos(B - &omega;) : cos(C -&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin A tan &omega; : cos B + sin B tan &omega; : cos C + sin C tan &omega;
<br>
Trilinears sin A - sin(A - 2&omega;) : sin B - sin(B - 2&omega;) : sin C - sin(C - 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos(A - 2&omega;) : cos B + cos(B - 2&omega;) : cos C + cos(C - 2&omega;) (cf., X(39))
<br>
Trilinears a + 2R cot &omega; cos A : b + 2R cot &omega; cos B: c + 2R cot &omega; cos C (cf., X(1350), X(1351))
<br>
Trilinears sin A + cos A cot &omega; : sin B + cos B cot &omega; : sin C + cos C cot &omega; (cf., X(575), X(576),,X(1350), X(1351))
<br>
Trilinears cos A + (2 - 2 cot &omega;) sin A : cos B + (2 - 2 cot &omega;) sin B : cos C + (2 - 2 cot &omega;) sin C
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(A - &omega;) : sin B cos(B - &omega;) : sin C cos(C -&omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(a^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2 - 2b^2c^2) : :
<br><b>
X(182) = X(3) + X(6)
</p></b>
X(182) is the midpoint of the Brocard diameter (the segment X(3)-to-X(6)); also the center of the 1st Lemoine circle, and the center of the Brocard circle. If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(1316).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(1316)</a>, which includes X(182).
</p> <p>
X(182) = radical center of Lucas(2 tan &omega;) circles, where 2 tan &omega; is the value of t for which the Brocard circle is the radical circle of the Lucas(t) circles. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p> <p>
X(182) lies on these lines:<br>1,983 2,98 3,6 4,83

<h3 id="X183">X(183) = TRILINEAR PRODUCT X(75)X(182)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>cos(A- &omega;) : c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup>cos(B - &omega;) : a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>cos(C - &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics csc A cos(A - &omega;) : csc B cos(B - &omega;) : csc C cos(C - &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics cot A + tan &omega; : :
<br><b>
X(183) = 3*X(2) - 2(cos &omega;)<sup>2</sup>*X(6)
</b><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circummedial triangle. Let La be the line through A parallel to B'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(183). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(183) lies on these lines:<br>2,6 3,76 5,315 22,157
25,264 55,350 95,305

of other harmonic conjugates of X(183), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>

X(183) = X(645)-beth conjugate of X(183)<br>

<h3 id="X184">X(184) = INVERSE OF X(125) IN THE BROCARD CIRCLE</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A sin 2A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>cos A : :
<p>
X(184) is the homothetic center of triangles ABC and A'B'C', the
latter defined as follows: let B<sub>1</sub> and C<sub>1</sub> be the
points where the perpendicular bisector BC meets sidelines CA and AB,
and cyclically define C<sub>2</sub>, A<sub>2</sub>; A<sub>3</sub>,
B<sub>3</sub>. Then A'B'C' is formed by the perpendicular bisectors of
segments B<sub>1</sub>C<sub>1</sub>, C<sub>2</sub>A<sub>2</sub>,
A<sub>3</sub>B<sub>3</sub>. (Fred Lang, Hyacinthos #1190)
</p> <p>
X(184) is the subject of Hyacinthos messages 5423-5441 (May, 2002).
In #5423, Alexei Myakishev notes that X(184) serves as a common vertex
of three triangles inside ABC, mutually congruent and similar to ABC.
(The triangles can be labeled XB<sub>C</sub>C<sub>B</sub>,
XC<sub>A</sub>A<sub>C</sub>, XA<sub>B</sub>B<sub>A</sub>, with
B<sub>C</sub> and C<sub>B</sub> on side BC, C<sub>A</sub> and
A<sub>C</sub> on side CA, and A<sub>B</sub> and B<sub>A</sub> on side
AB.) See <p style="font-weight: bold">Alexei Myakishev, <a href=
"http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2003volume3/FG200302.pdf" style=
"font-weight: bold">On the Procircumcenter and Related Points</a> ,
<i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 3 (2003) 29-34.</p>
<p>In #5435, Paul Yiu cites Fred Lang's construction of X(184) and
notes that the three triangles are then easily constructed from X(184).
The triangles determine three other triangles with common vertex
X(184); in #5437, Nikos Dergiades notes that the vertex angles of these
are 4A - &pi;, 4B - &pi;, 4C - &pi;, and that
</p><p>
if ABC is acute, then X(184) = X(63)-of-the-orthic-triangle = X(226)-of-the-tangential-triangle<br>
X(184) = homothetic center of the orthic triangle and the medial triangle of the tangential triangle.
</p><p>
Randy Hutson notes that X(184) is the exsimilicenter of the circumcircle and sine-triple-angle circle. (December 14, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intersections, other than X(3), of the X(3)-cevians and the Brocard circle. Let A"B"C" be the intersections, other than X(6), of the X(6)-cevians and the Brocard circle. Then A'B'C' and A"B"C" are perspective at X(184). Also, X(184) = U&cap;V, where U = isotomic conjugate of polar conjugate of Brocard axis (i.e., line X(3)X(49)), and V = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of Brocard axis (i.e., line X(6)X(25)). Let DEF be the orthic triangle. Let D' be the isotomic conjugate of X(4) wrt AEF, and define E' and F' cyclically; then the lines AD', BE', CF' concur in X(184). (Randy Hutson, June 1, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung). A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(184).
</p><p>
X(184) lies on these lines:<br>2,98 3,49 4,54 5,156
6,25 23,576 24,389
26,52 22,511 31,604
32,211 48,212 55,215
157,570 160,571 199,573
205,213 251,263 351,686
381,567 397,463 398,462
418,577 572,1011 647,878
</p><p>
X(184) is the {X(6),X(25)}-harmonic conjugate of X(51). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(184), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p> <p>
X(184) = isogonal conjugate of X(264)<br>
X(184) = isotomic conjugate of X(18022)<br>
X(184) = complement of X(11442)<br>
X(184) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(125)<br>
X(184) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (6,32), (54,6), (74,50)<br>
X(184) = X(217)-cross conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(184) = crosspoint of X(3) and X(6)<br>
X(184) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,4), (5,324), (6, 157), (92,318), (273,342), (338,523), (339,850), (427,1235), (491,492)<br>
X(184) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(297)X(525)<br>
X(184) = X(32)-Hirst inverse of X(237)<br>
X(184) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (212,212), (692,184)<br>
X(184) = X(22) of 1st Brocard triangle<br>
X(184) = trilinear product of PU(19)<br>

X(184) = vertex conjugate of PU(157) (the polar conjugates of PU(38)<br>

<h3 id="X185">X(185) = NAGEL POINT OF THE ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears (cos A)[1 - cos A cos(B - C)] : :
<br>
Trilinears (cos A)(cos^2 B + cos^2 C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)[2a^2(b^2 - c^2)^2 - a^4(b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin 2A)[1 - cos A cos(B - C)] : (sin 2B)[1 - cos B cos(C - A)] : (sin 2C)[1 - cos C cos(A - B)]
<p>
Alexei Myakishev has noted that X(185) is the Nagel point of the orthic triangle only is ABC is an acute triangle.
</p><p>
Let Ha be the foot of the A-altitude. Let Ba and Ca be the feet of perpendiculars from Ha to CA and AB, respectively. Let Ga be the centroid of HaBaCa. Define Gb and Gc cyclically. The lines HaGa, HbGb, HcGc concur in X(185). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
</p><p>
Let Ha, Hb, Hc be the orthocenters of the A-, B-, and C-altimedial triangles. X(185) is the orthocenter of HaHbHc. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let P be a point on the circumcircle. Let Pa be the orthogonal projection of P on the A-altitude, and define Pb, Pc cyclically. The locus of the orthocenter of PaPbPc as P varies is an ellipse centered at X(185). See also X(9730). (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(185) lies on these lines:<br>1,296 3,49 4,51 5,113
6,64 20,193 25,1498
30,52 39,217 54,74
72,916 287,384 378,578
382,568 411,970 648,1105
</p><p>
X(185) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,389), (125,974)<br>
X(185) = isogonal conjugate of X(1105)<br>
X(185) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (3,417), (4,235)<br>
X(185) = crosspoint of X(3) and X(4)<br>
X(185) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,4), (25,1249)<br>
X(185) = anticomplement of X(5907)<br>
X(185) = bicentric sum of PU(17)<br>
X(185) = PU(17)-harmonic conjugate of X(647)<br>
X(185) = orthology center of orthic and half-altitude triangles<br>

<h3 id="X186">X(186) = INVERSE-IN-CIRCUMCIRCLE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears 4 cos A - sec A : 4 cos B - sec B : 4 cos C - sec C
<br>
Trilinears sin 3A csc 2A : sin 3B csc 2B : sin 3C csc 2C
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(4 cos A - sec A) : (sin B)(4 cos B - sec B) : (sin C)(4 cos C - sec C)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 ((a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2 c^2) / (a^2 - b^2 - c^2) : :
<br>
Tripolars |cos A| : :
<b><br>
X(186) = 3*X(2) + (J^2 - 3)*X(3) = 2 X(3) + X(23) = (a^2 - b^2 - c^2)(a^2 + b^2 - c^2)(a^2 - b^2 + c^2)*X(3) + (a^2b^2c^2)*X(4)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(186) has Shinagawa coefficients (4F, -E - 4F).
</p><p>
X(186) lies on these lines: 2,3 54,389
93,252 98,935 107,477
112,187 249,250 2931,3580

X(186) is the {X(3),X(24)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(100), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.

<h3 id="X187">X(187) = INVERSE-IN-CIRCUMCIRCLE OF X(6) (SCHOUTE CENTER)</h3>
Trilinears a(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A - 3 cos A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears 2 sin(A - 2&omega;) - sin(A + 2&omega;) + sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A + sin A cos 2&omega; - 3 cos A sin 2&omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A + &omega;) sin 2&omega; - e^2 sin(A - &omega;) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Tripolars b c Sqrt[2(b^2 + c^2) - a^2] : :
<br><b>
X(187) = X(15) + X(16) </b><p>
Let L denote the line having trilinears of X(187) as coefficients. Then L is the line passing through X(2) perpendicular to the Euler line.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A"B"C" be the 2nd Brocard triangle. Let A* = &Lambda;((A',A"), and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(187). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let (O<sub>A</sub>) be the circumcircle of BCX(2). Let P<sub>A</sub> be the perspector of (O<sub>A</sub>). Let L<sub>A</sub> be the polar of P<sub>A</sub> wrt (O<sub>A</sub>). Define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>nL<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(187). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(1316).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(1316)</a>, which includes X(187).
</p><p>
X(187) lies on the Darboux quintic and these lines:<br>2,316 3,6 23,111 30,115
35,172 36,1015 74,248
99,385 110,352 112,186
183,1003 237,351 249,323

<h3 id="X188">X(188) = 2nd MID-ARC POINT OF ANTICOMPLEMENTARY TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears csc A/2 : csc B/2 : csc C/2
<br>
Trilinears [bc(b + c - a)]<sup>1/2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears csc A cos A/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears |AX(1)| : |BX(1)| : |CX(1)|
<br>
Trilinears sec A' : sec B', sec C', where A'B'C' = excentral triangle
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(sin(B/2) sin(C/2) + sin(A/2)) : : c.f., X(5451)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(csc(B/2) csc(C/2) + csc(A/2)) : :
: : c.f., X(5451)
<br>
Barycentrics cos A/2 : cos B/2 : cos C/2
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle of ABC, so that A' = -1 : 1 : 1 (trilinears). Let A'' be the point where the bisector of angle BA'C meets the line BC. Define B'' and C'' cyclically. The lines AA'', BB'', CC'' concur in X(188). (Seiichi Kirikami, February 14, 2010)
</p><p>
Let Ea be the ellipse with B and C as foci and passing through the A-excenter, and define Eb and Ec cyclically. Let La be the line tangent to Ea at the A-excenter, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = La&cap;BC, B' = Lb&cap;CA, C' = Lc&cap;AB. Then A', B', C' are collinear, and the trilinear pole of line A'B'C' = X(188). Note: The triangle formed by La, Lb, Lc is also the excentral triangle of the excentral triangle. Alternately, let A" be the trilinear pole of line La, and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB" and CC" concur at X(188); see also X(174). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(188) lies on these lines: 1,361 2,178
9,173 40,164 166,167 174,266
</p><p>
X(188) = isogonal conjugate of X(266)<br>
X(188) = isotomic conjugate of X(4146)<br>
X(188) = anticomplement of X(178)<br>
X(188) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(236)<br>
X(188) = cevapoint of X(1) and X(164)<br>
X(188) = X(259)-cross conjugate of X(174)<br>
X(188) = crosssum of X(1) and X(361)<br>
X(188) = X(188)-beth conjugate of X(266)<br>
X(188) = SS(A->A') of X(4), where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle<br>
X(188) = isotomic conjugate of X(4146)<br>
X(188) = X(65)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(188) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(236)<br>
X(188) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(236)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X189">X(189) = CYCLOCEVIAN CONJUGATE OF X(8)</h3>
Trilinears bc/(cos B
+ cos C - cos A - 1) : ca/(cos C + cos A - cos B - 1) : ab/(cos A + cos
B - cos C - 1)<br>Barycentrics 1/(cos B + cos C - cos A - 1) : 1/(cos C + cos
A - cos B - 1) : 1/(cos A + cos B - cos C - 1)
<p>X(189) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the pedal triangle of
X(84).</p>
<p>X(189) lies on the Lucas cubic and these lines: 2,77 7,92
8,20 29,81 69,309 222,281</p>

<h3 id="X190">X(190) = YFF PARABOLIC POINT</h3><a id="YffParabolicPoint" name="YffParabolicPoint"></a>
Trilinears bc/(b - c) : ca/(c - a) : ab/(a - b)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b - c) : 1/(c - a) : 1/(a - b)
<p>
In unpublished notes, Yff has studied the parabola tangent to sidelines BC, CA, AB and having focus X(101). If A',B',C' are the respective points of tangency, then the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(190).
</p><p>
The line X(100)X(190) is tangent to the Steiner circumellipse at X(190) and to the circumcircle at X(100). (Peter Moses, July 7, 2009)
</p><p>
Let Ha be the hyperbola passing through A, and with foci at B and C. This is called the A-Soddy hyperbola in (Paul Yiu, <I>Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle,</I> 2002; 12.4 The Soddy hyperbolas, p. 143). Let La be the polar of X(8) with respect to Ha. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to ABC, and the perspector is X(190). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically. X(190) = X(238) of IaIbIc. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>5</sub>B<sub>5</sub>C<sub>5</sub> and A<sub>6</sub>B<sub>6</sub>C<sub>6</sub> be Gemini triangles 5 and 6, resp. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the tangent at A to conic {{A,B<sub>5</sub>,C<sub>5</sub>,B<sub>6</sub>,C<sub>6</sub>}}, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(190). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(190).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(190)</a>.
</p><p>
X(190) lies on the Steiner circumellipse and these lines:<br>1,537 2,45 6,192 7,344
8,528 9,75 10,671 37,86
40,341 44,239 63,312
69,144 71,290 72,1043
99,101 100,659 110,835
162,643 191,1089 238,726
320,527 321,333 329,345
350,672 513,660 514,1016
522,666 644,651 646,668
649,889 658,1020 670,799
789,813 872,1045 1222, 3057
</p><p>
X(190) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (239,44), (335,37), (673,9), (903,2)<br>
X(190) = isogonal conjugate of X(649)<br>
X(190) = isotomic conjugate of X(514)<br>
X(190) = complement of X(4440)<br>
X(190) = anticomplement of X(1086)<br>

X(190) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,514), (9,522), (37,513), (440,525)<br>

<h3 id="X191">X(191) = X(10)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>

<b><p>
X(191) = X(1) - 2 X(21)

Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically. X(191) = X(21) of IaIbIc. (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let IaIbIc be the excentral triangle. Let Na be the nine-point center of BCIa, and define Nb and Nc cyclically. The lines IaNa, IbNb, IcNc concur in X(191); c.f. X(5506). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
