<h3 id="X192">X(192) = X(1)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(2) <br>
(CONGRUENT PARALLELIANS POINT)</h3>
Trilinears bc(ca +
ab - bc) : ca(ab + bc - ca) : ab(bc + ca - ab)
<br>
Barycentrics ca + ab - bc : ab + bc - ca : bc + ca - ab
<p>The segments through X(192) parallel to the sidelines with endpoints on
the sidelines have equal length. For references as early as 1881, see
Hyacinthos message 2929 (Paul Yiu, May 29, 2001). See also</p>
<p><b>Sabrina Bier,</b> "Equilateral Triangles Intercepted by Oriented
Parallelians," <i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 1 (2001) 25-32.</p>
<p>X(192) lies on these lines:<br>1,87 2,37 6,190 7,335
8,256 9,239 55,385
69,742 144,145 315,746 869,1045</p>
<p>
X(192) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (8,984), (75,37), (1278,75)<br>
X(192) = isogonal conjugate of X(2162)<br>
X(192) = isotomic conjugate of X(330)<br>
X(192) = complement of X(1278)<br>
X(192) = anticomplement of X(75)<br>
X(192) = X(1)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(192) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(43)<br>
X(192) = crosssum of X(1) and X(87)<br>
X(192) = X(9)-Hirst inverse of X(239)<br>
X(192) = X(646)-beth conjugate of X(192)<br>
X(192) = perspector of anticomplementary triangle and Gemini triangle 4<br>
X(192) = perspector of Gemini triangles 4 and 6<br>
X(192) = trilinear pole of line X(3835)X(4083) (the perspectrix of ABC and Gemini triangle 16)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X193">X(193) = X(4)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears (csc
A)(cot B + cot C - cot A) : (csc B)(cot C + cot A - cot B) : (csc
C)(cot A + cot B - cot C)<br>Trilinears (S<sub>A</sub> -
a<sup>2</sup>)/a : (S<sub>B</sub> - b<sup>2</sup>)/b : (S<sub>C</sub> -
c<sup>2</sup>)/c<br>Barycentrics cot B + cot C - cot A : cot C + cot A - cot B :
cot A + cot B - cot C<br> =
3a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> : 3b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> : 3c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> -
b<sup>2</sup> (Milorad Stevanovic, 5/12/2003)
<p>Let A' be the reflection of the midpoint of segment BC in X(6), and
define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(193).
(Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the trilinear pole of the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define B', C' cyclically. A'B'C' is also the anticomplement of the anticomplement of the midheight triangle. A'B'C' is perspective to the orthic and anticomplementary triangles at X(193). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(193) lies on these lines:<br>2,6 4,1351 7,239 8,894 20,185 23,159 44,344 66,895 144,145 146,148 253,287 317,393 330,959 371,488 372,487 608,651 1839,3187
</p><p>
X(193) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,1353), (4,1351), (69,6), (1352,576)<br>
X(193) = isogonal conjugate of X(8770)<br>
X(193) = isotomic conjugate of X(2996)<br>
X(193) = complement of X(20080)<br>
X(193) = anticomplement of X(69)<br>
X(193) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(1370)<br>
X(193) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(193) = X(2)-Hirst inverse of X(230)<br>
X(193) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (645,193), (662,608)<br>
X(193) = perspector of pedal and antipedal triangles of X(4) (orthic and anticomplementary triangles)<br>
X(193) = perspector, wrt orthic triangle, of polar circle<br>
X(193) = anticomplementary isotomic conjugate of X(20)<br>
X(193) = orthic-isogonal conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(193) = trilinear pole of polar, wrt complement of polar circle, of X(69)<br>
X(193) = pole of orthic axis wrt Steiner circumellipse<br>
X(193) = {X(385),X(7774)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(193) = endo-homothetic center of 3rd and 4th tri-squares central triangles<br>
X(193) = perspector, wrt anticomplementary triangle, of polar circle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X194">X(194) = X(6)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears bc[a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>] : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot<sup>2</sup>A - csc<sup>2</sup>A cos 2&omega; : : (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br><b>
X(194) = 2X(39) - X(76) - P(1) + U(1) - X(76)
</b><p>
Let Oa be the circle through A and tangent to BC at its midpoint. Define Ob and Oc cyclically. The radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc is X(194). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let AaBaCa, AbBbCb, AcBcCc be the A-, B- and C-anti-altimedial triangles. Let A' be the trilinear product Aa*Ab*Ac, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is the anticomplementary triangle of the 1st Brocard triangle, and is perspective to ABC at X(4), and to the anticomplementary triangle at X(194). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(194) lies on these lines:<br>{1,87}, {2,39}, {3,385}, {4,147}, {6,384}, {8,730}, {10,3097}, {20,185}, {32,99}, {63,239}, {69,695}, {75,1107}, {83,3734}, {183,5013}, {184,3492}, {190,2176}, {257,986}, {262,2996}, {263,3498}, {304,3797}, {315,736}, {325,5025}, {350,2275}, {401,1993}, {487,1587}, {488,1588}, {548,3793}, {574,1078}, {616,3104}, {617,3105}, {627,3106}, {628,3107}, {648,1968}, {712,4393}, {1007,2023}, {1593,1941}, {1654,4201}, {1670,2547}, {1671,2546}, {1909,2276}, {2128,2285}, {3096,4045}, {3212,3503}, {3314,3933}, {3413,3557}, {3414,3558}, {3522,5188}, {3770,4261}, {3906,5652}, {3972,5007}
</p><p>
X(194) is the {X(39),X(76)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(194), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.
</p><p>
X(194) = reflection of X(76) in X(39)<br>
X(194) = isogonal conjugate of X(3224)<br>
X(194) = isotomic conjugate of X(2998)<br>
X(194) = complement of X(20081)<br>
X(194) = anticomplement of X(76)<br>
X(194) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(315)<br>
X(194) = eigencenter of cevian triangle of X(6)<br>
X(194) = eigencenter of anticevian triangle of X(2)<br>
X(194) = radical center of the Neuberg circles.<br>
X(194) = X(6)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(194) = X(3)-Hirst inverse of X(385)<br>
X(194) = anticomplementary isotomic conjugate of X(69)<br>
X(194) = X(6374)-cross conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(194) = vertex conjugate of PU(140)<br>
X(194) = 1st-Brocard-to-6th-Brocard similarity image of X(6)<br>
X(194) = X(99)-of-6th-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(194) = perspector of 3rd Brocard triangle and 1st Brocard-reflected triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X195">X(195) = X(5)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(3)</h3>
Trilinears (cos A)(v + w - u) : : , where u = u(A,B,C) = cos A cos(B - A) cos(C - A)
<br>
Trilinears a[a^8 + b^8 + c^8 - 4a^6(b^2 + c^2) + a^4(6b^4 + 6c^4 + 5b^2c^2) - a^2(4b^6 + 4c^6 - b^4c^2 - b^2c^4) - 2b^2c^2(b^4 + c^4 - b^2c^2)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics 4 cos 2A + cot<sup>2</sup>A - cot A cot &omega; : :( (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
</p><p>
Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of the A-vertex of the outer Napoleon triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate of the A-vertex of the inner Napoleon triangle, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(195). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
The Napoleon axis and Napoleon-Feuerbach cubic K005 meet in three points: X(17), X(18), and X(195).
(Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
A construction of X(195) is given by Antreas Hatipolakis and Angel Montesdeoca at <a href="https://beta.groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/24180"> 24180</a>.
</p><p>
X(195) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines:<br>1,3467 3,54 4,399
5,3459 6,17 49,52
110,143 140,323 155,381
382,1498 2121,3462 3461,3468</p>
<p>
X(195) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,54), (54,1493), (3519,1209)<br>
X(195) = isogonal conjugate of X(3459)<br>
X(195) = complement of X(12325)<br>
X(195) = anticomplement of X(21230)<br>
X(195) = X(5)-Ceva conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(195) = crosssum of X(137) and X(523)<br>
X(195) = X(3)-of-reflection-triangle<br>
X(195) = X(79)-of-tangential-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(195) = tangential isogonal conjugate of X(2937)<br>
X(195) = 2nd isogonal perspector of X(5); see X(36)<br>
X(195) = Yiu-isogonal conjugate of X(1157)<br>
X(195) = perspector of [cross-triangle of ABC and outer Napoleon triangle] and [cross-triangle of ABC and inner-Napoleon triangle]<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X196">X(196) = X(7)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(4)</h3>

f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos B + cos C - cos A - 1) sec A
tan A/2<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= (cos B + cos C - cos A - 1) tan A tan A/2
<p>X(196) lies on these lines:<br>1,207 2,653 4,65 7,92

55,108 226,281 329,342</p>

<h3 id="X197">X(197) = X(8)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(6)</h3>
Trilinears a[-a<sup>2</sup>tan A/2 + b<sup>2</sup>tan B/2 + c<sup>2</sup>tan C/2] : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the extouch triangle. Let A" be the crosspoint of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(197). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)

<h3 id="X198">X(198) = X(9)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(6)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) :
f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = a(cos B + cos C - cos A - 1)
<br>
Trilinears a (a^3 + a^2 (b + c) - a (b + c)^2 - (b - c)^2 (b + c)) : :
<br>
Trilinears s cos A - r cot(A/2) : :
<br>
<p>X(198) lies on these lines:<br>3,9 6,41 19,25 5,1030
64,71 100,346 101,102
154,212 208,227 218,579
284,859 478,577 958,966</p>
<p>

X(198) = crosspoint of X(40) and X(223)<br>

<h3 id="X199">X(199) = X(10)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(6)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a[b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> + (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)(bc + ca + ab)]
<br>
Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(199) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + 2F + $bc$, -2E - 2F + $bc$).
</p><p>
Let I<sub>A</sub>, I<sub>B</sub>, I<sub>C</sub> be the excenters. Let (O<sub>A</sub>) be the circle tangent to the circumcircle at A and passing through I<sub>A</sub>. Let A' be the antipode of A in (O<sub>A</sub>). Let L<sub>A</sub> be the tangent to (O<sub>A</sub>) at A'. Define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let T<sub>A</sub> = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define T<sub>B</sub> and T<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Triangle T<sub>A</sub>T<sub>B</sub>T<sub>C</sub> is homothetic to the tangential triangle at X(199). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(199) lies on these lines: 2,3 42,172
51,572 55,1030 184,573</p>
<p>
X(199) = isogonal conjugate of X(8044)<br>
X(199) = X(10)-Ceva conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(199) = crosspoint of X(101) and X(250)<br>
X(199) = crosssum of X(125) and X(514)<br>
X(199) = tangential isogonal conjugate of X(8053)<br>
X(199) = orthic-to-tangential similarity image of X(430)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X200">X(200) = X(8)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears cot<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears (b + c - a)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)/(1 - cos A) : : (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
<br>
Trilinears 1 - csc^2(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears squared distance of A to Gergonne line : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(b + c - a)<sup>2</sup> : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the extouch triangle. Let A" be the trilinear product of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(200). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>Let A' be the trilinear product of the circumcircle intercepts of the A-excircle. Define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(200). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(200) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,963 9,55 33,281
40,64 46,1004 57,518
63,100 69,269 159,197

341,1043 756,968</p>

harmonic conjugates of X(200), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.
</p><p>
X(200) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,997), (57,1376)<br>
X(200) = isogonal conjugate of X(269)<br>
X(200) = isotomic conjugate of X(1088)<br>
X(200) = X(8)-Ceva conjugate of X(9)<br>
X(200) = cevapoint of X(220) and X(480)<br>
X(200) = X(220)-cross conjugate of X(9)<br>
X(200) = crosspoint of X(8) and X(346)<br>

X(200) = X(i)-beth conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (100,223), (200,55), (643,165)<br>
X(200) = {X(1),X(8)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4853)<br>
X(200) = {X(2),X(8)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4847)<br>

<h3 id="X202">X(202) = X(1)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(15)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = u(v + w - u),<br>
u = u(A,B,C) = sin(A + &pi;/3), v = u(B,C,A), w = u(C,A,B)
<p>Trilinears 1 - cos(A +
&pi;/3) : 1 - cos(B + &pi;/3) : 1 - cos(C + &pi;/3) (Joe
Goggins, Oct. 19, 2005)</p>
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>

15,36 16,55 17,499

<h3 id="X206">X(206) = X(2)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(32)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>3</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears (sin A)(sin 2A - tan &omega;) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung); then X(206) = X(6)-of-A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(206) lies on these lines:<br>2,66 5,182 6,25 26,511
69,110 157,216 160,577
219,692 237,571
</p><p>
X(206) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,159), (110,1177)<br>
X(206) = complement of X(66)<br>
X(206) = complementary conjugate of X(427)<br>
X(206) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(32)<br>
X(206) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(315)<br>
X(206) = crosssum of X(339) and X(523)<br>

X(206) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(32)<br>
X(206) = isogonal conjugate of the isotomic conjugate of X(22)<br>
X(206) = center of conic that is the locus of centers of conics passing through X(6) and the vertices of the tangential triangle<br>
X(206) = centroid of X(6) plus the vertices of the tangential triangle<br>
X(206) = crosssum of circumcircle intercepts of de Longchamps line<br>
X(206) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(32); this conic is the isogonal conjugate of the de Longchamps line<br>

<h3 id="X207">X(207) = X(1)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(34)</h3>

A - 1)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)

- c<sup>2</sup>)

<h3 id="X215">X(215) = X(1)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(50)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (sin 3A)(sin 3B + sin 3C - sin 3A)
<br>
Trilinears cos<sup>2</sup>(3A/2)
: cos<sup>2</sup>(3B/2) : cos<sup>2</sup>(3C/2) (M.
Iliev, 4/12/07)
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos 3A : 1 +
cos 3B : 1+ cos 3C (M. Iliev, 4/12/07)
<br>
Trilinears a^3 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2 + b c)^2 (a - b - c) : :

X(215) is the insimilicenter of the incircle and the sine-triple-angle circle. (Randy Hutson, December 14, 2014)
</p>
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>

<h3 id="X216">X(216) = X(5)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(51)</h3>
Trilinears sin 2A cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A (tan A + tan B + tan C) + sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin A (cot A cot B cot C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (sin 2B + sin 2C) cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A (cos 2B + cos 2C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (sin A)(1 - sin^2 B - sin^2 C) : :
<br>
Trilinears sec B sec C + csc B csc C : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A + T) : :, T as at X(389)
<br>
Barycentrics csc 2B + csc 2C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)[a^2(b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(sin 2A)cos(B - C) : :
<p>
X(216) is the perspector of triangle ABCand the tangential triangle of the Johnson circumconic. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let Ea be the ellipse with B and C as foci and passing through X(5), and define Eb, Ec cyclically. Let La be the line tangent to Ea at X(5), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line La, and define B', C' cyclically. A', B', C' lie on the circumconic centered at X(216). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(216) = intersection of isogonal conjugate of polar conjugate of Euler line (i.e., line X(3)X(6)) and the polar conjugate of isogonal conjugate of Euler line (i.e., line X(2)X(216)) (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(216) lies on hyperbola {{X(2),X(6),X(216),X(233),X(1249),X(1560),X(3162)}}, which is a circumconic of the medial triangle, as well as the locus of the perspector of circumconics centered at a point on the Euler line. Also, this hyperbola is tangent to Euler line at X(2). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(216) lies on these lines:<br>2,232 3,6 5,53 51,418
95,648 97,288 115,131
157,206 373,852 395,465
396,466 631,1075 1015,1060 2493,3054
</p><p>
X(216) = isogonal conjugate of X(275)<br>
X(216) = isotomic conjugate of X(276)<br>
X(216) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(577)<br>
X(216) = complement of X(264)<br>
X(216) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,5), (3,418), (5,51), (324,52)<br>
X(216) = cevapoint of X(217) and X(418)<br>
X(216) = X(217)-cross conjugate of X(51)<br>
X(216) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,3), (5,343)<br>
X(216) = crosssum of X(4) and X(6)<br>
X(216) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(186)X(523)<br>
X(216) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(577)<br>
X(216) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(5)<br>
X(216) = intersection of trilinear polars of any 2 points on the Johnson circumconic<br>
X(216) = perspector of cevian triangle of X(3) and tangential triangle, wrt cevian triangle of X(3), of circumconic of cevian triangle of X(3) centered at X(3)<br>
X(216) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(8795)<br>
X(216) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(8795)<br>

X(216) = X(1577)-isoconjugate of X(933)<br>

<h3 id="X218">X(218) = X(7)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(55)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= cos<sup>2</sup>(A/2) [cos<sup>4</sup>(B/2) + cos<sup>4</sup>(C/2) -
cos<sup>4</sup>(A/2)]
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - 2 a b - 2 a c) : :
</p><p>
Let A' be the center of the conic through the contact points of the B- and C- excircles with the sidelines of ABC. Define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the intouch triangle at X(218). See also X(6), X(25), X(222), X(940), X(1743). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
A'B'C' is also the unary cofactor triangle of the intangents triangle. (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(218) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 3,41 4,294 7,277
32,906 43,170 46,910
56,101 65,169 145,644
198,579 222,241 279,651
</p><p>
X(218) = isogonal conjugate of X(277)<br>
X(218) = eigencenter of cevian triangle of X(7)<br>
X(218) = eigencenter of anticevian triangle of X(55)<br>
X(218) = X(7)-Ceva conjugate of X(55)<br>
X(218) = crosssum of X(650) and X(1086)<br>
X(218) = X(644)-beth conjugate of X(218)<br>
X(218) = crossdifference of every pair of points on the de Longchamps line of the intouch triangle<br>
X(218) = perspector of 2nd mixtilinear triangle and unary cofactor triangle of 5th mixtilinear triangle<br>
X(218) = perspector of excentral triangle and unary cofactor triangle of inverse-in-incircle triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X219">X(219) = X(8)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(55)</h3>

<h3 id="X222">X(222) = X(7)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(56)</h3>
Trilinears cos A tan
A/2 : cos B tan B/2 : cos C tan C/2<br> =
1/(csc A + 2 csc 2A) : 1/(csc B + 2 csc 2B) : 1/(csc A + 2 csc 2C)<br> =
a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)/(b + c - a) :
b(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)/(c + a - b) :
c(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/(a + b - c)
<p>Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(1 + sec A) : b<sup>2</sup>/(1
+ sec B) : c<sup>2</sup>/(1 + sec C)
</p><p>
Let A' be the center of the conic through the contact points of the incircle and the A-excircle with the sidelines of ABC. Define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the intouch triangle at X(222). See also X(6), X(25), X(218), X(940), X(1743). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle. Let A" be the barycentric product of the circumcircle intercepts of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(222). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)

<h3 id="X226">X(226) = X(7)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(65)</h3>
Trilinears (csc A)(cos B + cos C) : (csc B)(cos C + cos A) : (csc C)(cos A + cos B)
<br>
Trilinears bc(b + c)/(b + c - a) : ca(c + a)/(c + a - b) : ab(a + b)/(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears cos(angle BIC) : cos(angle CIA) : cos(angle AIB)
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c)/(b + c - a) : (c + a)/(c + a - b) : (a + b)/(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics area(A'BC) : : , where A'B'C' is the 2nd extouch triangle
<br>
Barycentrics r<sub>A</sub> + r : r<sub>B</sub> + r : r<sub>C</sub> + r, where r<sub>A</sub>, r<sub>B</sub>, r<sub>C</sub> are the exradii
</p><p>
X(226) is the homothetic center of the intouch triangle and the triangle formed by the lines of the external pairs of extouch points of the excircles. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the radical center of the incircle and the B- and C-excircles; define B' and C' cyclically. A'B'C' is also the complement of the excentral triangle, and the triangle formed by the radical axes of the incircle and each excircle. Then X(226) is the homothetic center of A'B'C' and the intouch triangle. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the homothetic center of the orthic triangles of the intouch and A-extouch triangles, and define B' and C' cyclically. Let AaBaCa be the orthic triangle of the A-extouch triangle, and define AbBbCb, and AcBcCc cyclically. Let A" be the centroid of AaAbAc, and define B" and C" cyclically. Then A'B'C' and A"B"C" are homothetic to each other and to the medial triangle and the orthic triangle of the intouch triangle at X(226). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let (A') be the pedal circle of the A-vertex of the hexyl triangle, and define (B') and (C') cyclically. Then X(226) is the radical center of circles (A'), (B'), (C'). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let IaIbIc be the reflection triangle of X(1). Let A' be the trilinear pole of line IbIc, and define B', C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(226). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>13</sub>B<sub>13</sub>C<sub>13</sub> be Gemini triangle 13. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>13</sub>,C<sub>13</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(226). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>14</sub>B<sub>14</sub>C<sub>14</sub> be Gemini triangle 14. Let A' be the center of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>14</sub>,C<sub>14</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(226). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(226) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,7 5,912 10,12

<h3 id="X230">X(230) = X(2)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(114)</h3>

<h3 id="X237">X(237) = X(3)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>cos(A
+ &omega;) : b<sup>2</sup>cos(B + &omega;) : c<sup>2</sup>cos(C + &omega;)<br>
= f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) =
a<sup>3</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) (Darij Grinberg, 3/29/03)
<p>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>cos(A + &omega;) : b<sup>3</sup>cos(B + &omega;) : c<sup>3</sup>cos(C + &omega;)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(237) has Shinagawa coefficients (EF + F<sup>2</sup> + S<sup>2</sup>, -(E + F)<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(237) is the point of intersection of the Euler line and the
Lemoine axis (defined as the radical axis of the circumcircle and the
Brocard circle).</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href= "X(1316).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(1316)</a>, which includes X(237).
<p>X(237) lies on these lines: 2,3 6,160
31,904 32,184 39,51
154,682 187,351 206,571</p>
<p>X(237) is the {X(1113),X(1114)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1316). For a
list of other harmonic conjugates of X(237), click <b>Tables</b> at the
top of this page.]
</p><p>
X(237) = isogonal conjugate of X(290)<br>
X(237) = isotomic conjugate of X(18024)<br>
X(237) = X(98)-Ceva conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(237) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,98), (232,511)<br>
X(237) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,511), (98,287)<br>
X(237) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(2)X(647)<br>
X(237) = X(32)-Hirst inverse of X(184)<br>
X(237) = X(3)-line conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(237) = X(55)-beth conjugate of X(237)<br>
X(237) = crosspoint of X(3) and X(3511) wrt excentral triangle<br>
X(237) = crosspoint of X(3) and X(3511) wrt tangential triangle<br>
X(237) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(287)<br>
X(237) = trilinear pole of PU(89)<br>

<h3 id="X244">X(244) = X(1)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(100)</h3>
Trilinears (b - c)<sup>2</sup> : (c - a)<sup>2</sup> : (a - b)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears [1 - cos(B - C)]sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = (distance from A to Nagel line)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics a(b - c)<sup>2</sup> : :
<p>
Let O* be a circle with center X(3) and variable radius R*. Let La be the radical axis of O* and the A-excircle, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A'=Lb&cap;Lc, B'=Lc&cap;La, C'=La&cap;Lb. Then A'B'C' is perspective to ABC, and the locus of the perspector as R* varies is the hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(1),X(10)}}, which has center X(244).
Also, X(244) lies in the inellipse centered at X(10), as well as the Hofstadter ellpse E(1/2), which is the incentral inellipse. (Randy Hutson, Decembe 26, 2016)
</p><p>
X(244) lies on aforementioned ellipses and these lines: 1,88 2,38
11,867 31,57 34,1106
42,354 58,229 63,748
238,896 474,976 518,899
596,1089 665,866
</p><p>
X(244) = isogonal conjugate of X(765)<br>
X(244) = isotomic conjugate of X(7035)<br>
X(244) = anticomplement of X(24003)<br>
X(244) = perspector of anti-Aquila and 2nd Sharygin triangles<br>
X(244) = barycentric product of vertices of Garcia reflection triangle<br>
X(244) = trilinear pole of line X(764)X(2087)<br>
X(244) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (1,513), (75,514)<br>
X(244) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(513)<br>
X(244) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,100), (31,101), (78,1331), (109,1420), (200,644), (651,1445), (678,1023), (756,1018)<br>
X(244) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(100)X(101)<br>
X(244) = X(1)-Hirst inverse of X(1054)<br>
X(244) = X(1)-line conjugate of X(100)<br>
X(244) = complement of X(3952)<br>
X(244) = antipode of X(4738) in inellipse centered at X(10)<br>
X(244) = reflection of X(4738) in X(10)<br>
X(244) = bicentric difference of PU(34)<br>
X(244) = PU(34)-harmonic conjugate of X(1635)<br>
X(244) = tripolar centroid of X(1022)<br>
X(244) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(661)<br>
X(244) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(661)<br>
X(244) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(661)<br>
X(244) = trilinear pole wrt incentral triangle of line X(1)X(6)<br>
X(244) = intersection of tangents to Steiner inellipse at X(1015) and X(1086)<br>
X(244) = crosspoint wrt medial triangle of X(1015) and X(1086)<br>
X(244) = trilinear square of X(513)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X245">X(245) = X(1)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(110)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= csc<sup>2</sup>(C - A) + csc(C - B) [csc(C - A) -csc(B - A)] +
csc<sup>2</sup>(A - B)
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>
<p>X(245) lies on these lines: 1,60 115,125</p>
<p>X(245) = X(1)-line conjugate of X(110)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X246">X(246) = X(3)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(110)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= csc(B-A)[cos A csc(B - A) + cos C csc(B - C)] + csc(C - A)
u(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= [cos A csc(C - A) + cos B csc(C - B)]
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>
<p>X(246) lies on these lines: 3,74 115,125</p>
<p>X(246) = X(3)-line conjugate of X(110)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X247">X(247) = X(4)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(110)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= csc(B-A)[sec A csc(B - A) + sec C csc(B - C)] + csc(C - A)
u(A,B,C),<br> u(A,B,C)
= [sec A csc(C - A) + sec B csc(C - B)]
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>
<p>X(247) lies on these lines: 4,110 115,125</p>
<p>X(247) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line
X(110)X(686)<br>X(247) = X(4)-line conjugate of X(110)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

&omega;)<br>Barycentrics sin A sin 2A sec(A + &omega;) : sin B sin 2B

<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2)/(b^4 + c^4 - a^2 b^2 - a^2 c^2) : :

>

<h3 id="X249">X(249) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(115)</h3>
Trilinears (csc
A)csc<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : (csc B)csc<sup>2</sup>(C - A) : (csc
C)csc<sup>2</sup>(A - B)<br> =
a/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : b/(c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> : c/(a<sup>2</sup> -
b<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>
<p>Barycentrics csc<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : csc<sup>2</sup>(C -
A) : csc<sup>2</sup>(A - B)</p>
<p>
X(249) is the vertex conjugate of the foci of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of line X(2)X(6). The center of this inellipse is X(620), and its perspector is X(4590). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(249) is the trilinear pole of line X(110)X(351), which is the tangent to the circumcircle at X(110), and the locus of trilinear poles of tangents at P to hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(6),P}}, as P moves on the Brocard axis. (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(249) lies on these lines: 99,525 110,512
186,250 187,323 297,316
648,687 805,827 849,1110</p>
<p>
X(249) = isogonal conjugate of X(115)<br>
X(249) = isotomic conjugate of X(338)<br>
X(249) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,110), (24,112), (1379,1380)<br>
X(249) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (3,99), (6,110)<br>
X(249) = perspector of ABC and reflection of symmedial triangle in the Brocard axis<br>
X(249) = polar conjugate of X(2970)<br>
X(249) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(125)<br>
X(249) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1648)X(8029)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X250">X(250) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(125)</h3>
Trilinears (sec
A)csc<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : (sec B)csc<sup>2</sup>(C - A) : (sec
C)csc<sup>2</sup>(A - B)<br> =
(a<sup>2</sup>sec A)/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> :
(b<sup>2</sup>sec B)/(c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup> :
(c<sup>2</sup>sec C)/(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>
<p>Barycentrics (tan A)csc<sup>2</sup>(B - C) : (tan
B)csc<sup>2</sup>(C - A) : (tan C)csc<sup>2</sup>(A - B)
</p><p>
X(250) is the trilinear pole of line X(110)X(112), which is the tangent to the MacBeath circumconic at X(110), and the locus of trilinear poles of tangents at P to conic {{A,B,C,X(3),P}}, as P moves on the Brocard axis. (Randy Hutson, March 21, 2019)
</p><p>
X(250) lies on these lines: 23,232 107,687
110,520 112,691 186,249
325,340 476,933 523,648 827,935</p>

X(250) = isotomic conjugate of X(339)<br>
X(250) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,110), (25,112), (162,270), (1113,1114)<br>
X(250) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (3,110), (22,99), (24,107), (25,112), (199,101)<br>
X(250) = polar conjugate of X(338)<br>
X(250) = circumcenter of reflection triangle of X(125)<br>
X(250) = barycentric product X(99)*X(112)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X251">X(251) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(141)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>csc(A
+ &omega;) : b<sup>2</sup>csc(B + &omega;) : c<sup>2</sup>csc(C +
&omega;)<br> =
a/(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) : b/(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) :
c/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)
<p>Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>csc(A + &omega;) :
b<sup>3</sup>csc(B + &omega;) : c<sup>3</sup>csc(C + &omega;)</p>
<p>Let K be the symmedian point of ABC and let A' be the symmedian
point of the triangle BCK; define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA',
BB', CC' concur in X(251). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A5'B5'C5' be the 5th anti-Brocard triangle. The radical center of the circumcircles of BCA5', CAB5', ABC5' is X(251). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(251) lies on these lines: 2,32 6,22
37,82 110,694 112,427
184,263 308,385 609,614 689,699</p>
<p>
X(251) = isogonal conjugate of X(141)<br>
X(251) = complement of X(1369)<br>
X(251) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(32)<br>
X(251) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (6,83), (23,111), (523,112)<br>
X(251) = isotomic conjugate of X(8024)<br>
X(251) = similitude center of ABC and 1st orthosymmedial triangle<br>
X(251) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1235)<br>
X(251) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(1235)<br>
X(251) = barycentric product of vertices of circummedial triangle<br>
X(251) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and circummedial triangle<br>
X(251) = Kosnita(X(6),X(6)) point<br>
X(251) = homothetic center of 1st orthosymmedial and 1st anti-orthosymmedial triangles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X252">X(252) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(143)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= sec(B - C)/[1 - 2 cos(2A)]
<br>
Trilinears h(A,B,C) : h(B,C,A) : h(C,A,B), where<br> h(A,B,C)
= cos A sec(3A) sec(B - C) (Manol Iliev, 4/01/07)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin C) f(C,A,B)
</p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circle with center A passing through A'. Let A" be the intersection, other than A', of O<sub>A</sub> and the nine-point circle. Define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(252). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
Let H<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of X(4) in the Euler line of BCX(4), and define H<sub>B</sub> and H<sub>C</sub> cyclically. The lines AH<sub>A</sub>, BH<sub>B</sub>, CH<sub>C</sub> concur in X(252). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(252) lies on these lines: 3,930 54,140 93,186
</p><p>
X(252) = isogonal conjugate of X(143)<br>
X(252) = anticomplement of X(31376)<br>
X(252) = X(5)-isoconjugate of X(2964)<br>
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X253">X(253) = X(4)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (csc A)/(tan B + tan C - tan A)<br>
= g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) =
(csc<sup>2</sup>A)/(cos A - cos B cos C)
<br>
Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = 1/(tan B + tan C - tan A)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(3 a^4 - 2 a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2) : :<br>
</p>
<p>X(253) is the perspector of ABC and the pedal triangle of X(64).</p>
<p>X(253) lies on the Lucas cubic and these lines: 2,1073 7,280
8,307 20,64 193,287
306,329 318,342 322,341</p>
<p>
X(253) = isogonal conjugate of X(154)<br>
X(253) = isotomic conjugate of X(20)<br>
X(253) = cyclocevian conjugate of X(69)<br>
X(253) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,459), (122,525)<br>
X(253) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,2), (122,525)<br>
X(253) = anticomplement of X(1249)<br>X(253) = polar conjugate of X(1249)<br>
X(253) = perspector of ABC and the reflection in X(1073) of the pedal triangle of X(1073)<br>
X(253) = perspector of de Longchamps circle<br>
X(253) = pole, wrt de Longchamps circle, of trilinear polar of X(69) (line X(441)X(525))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (sec A)/(cos<sup>2</sup>B +

<br

<h3 id="X255">X(255) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(158)</h3>
Trilinears cos<sup>2</sup>A : cos<sup>2</sup>B : cos<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos 2A : 1 + cos 2B : 1 + cos 2C
<br>
Trilinears tan B tan C - 1 : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos<sup>2</sup>A : sin B cos<sup>2</sup>B : sin C cos<sup>2</sup>C
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the Lucas and Lucas(-1) central triangles. Let A* be the trilinear product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(255). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the Lucas and Lucas(-1) antipodal triangles. Let A* be the trilinear product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(255). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)

<h3 id="X258">X(258) = CONGRUENT INCIRCLES ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
<a id="CongruentIncirclesIsoscelizerPoint" name="CongruentIncirclesIsoscelizerPoint"></a>
Trilinears 1/(cos B/2 + cos C/2 - cos A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 + sin(B/2) + sin(C/2) - sin(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears tan(A/2) - sec(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears tan(B/2) - sec(B/2) : tan(C/2) - sec(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(b' + c' - a') : : , where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears tan A'/2 : : , where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears cot A' - csc A' : : , where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears (distance from A to A-excircle) : :
<p>In Yff's isoscelizer configuration, if X = X(258), then the isosceles triangles T<sub>A</sub>, T<sub>B</sub>, T<sub>C</sub> have congruent incircles.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(258).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(258)</a>.
</p><p>
X(258) lies on these lines: 1,164 57,173 259,289
</p><p>
X(258) = isogonal conjugate of X(173)<br>

C/2)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)

<h3 id="X262">X(262) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(182)</h3>
Trilinears sec(A - &omega;) : sec(B - &omega;) : sec(C - &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec(A - &omega;) : sin B sec(B - &omega;) : sin C sec(C - &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(a^4 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2 - 2b^2c^2) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. X(262) is the radical center of the Brocard circles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B'. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
<p></p>
Let Pa be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC. Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt Pa and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(262). Also, X(262) is also the isotomic conjugate, wrt A'B'C', of X(3).
<p></p>
Let A' be the apex of the isosceles triangle BA'C constructed outward on BC such that &ang;A'BC = &ang;A'CB = &omega;. Define B', C' cyclically. Let Ha be the orthocenter of BA'C, and define Hb, Hc cyclically. The lines AHa, BHb, CHc concur in X(262). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the apex of the isosceles triangle BA'C constructed intward on BC such that &ang;A'BC = &ang;A'CB = &omega;/2. Define B', C' cyclically. Let Oa be the circumcenter of BA'C, and define Ob, Oc cyclically. The lines AOa, BOb, COc concur in X(262). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(262) lies on these lines: 2,51 3,83
4,39 5,76 6,98 13,383
14,1080 25,275 30,598
226,982 381,671 385,576
</p><p>
X(262) = midpoint of X(4) and X(7709)<br>
X(262) = isogonal conjugate of X(182)<br>
X(262) = isotomic conjugate of X(183)<br>
X(262) = radical center of (Brocard circle reflected in BC, CA, and AB)<br>
X(262) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(458)<br>
X(262) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(458)<br>
X(262) = trilinear pole of line X(523)X(3569)<br>
X(262) = pole of Lemoine axis wrt orthoptic circle of the Steiner inellipse (a.k.a. {circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter)<br>
X(262) = perspector of orthoptic circle of the Steiner inellipse (a.k.a. {circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter)<br>
X(262) = perspector of ABC and 2nd Neuberg triangle<br>
X(262) = trilinear product of vertices of 2nd Neuberg triangle<br>
X(262) = centroid of X(4)PU(1)<br>

</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 and A2B2C2 be the pedal triangles of PU(1). Then X(263) is the radical center of the circumcircles of AA1A2, BB1B2, CC1C2.
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)

<h3 id="X264">X(264) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF CIRCUMCENTER</h3>
Trilinears csc A csc 2A : csc B csc 2B : csc C csc 2C
<br>
Trilinears sec A csc<sup>2</sup>A : sec B csc<sup>2</sup>B : sec C csc<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Trilinears tan A csc(A - &omega;) : tan B csc(B - &omega;) : tan C csc(C - &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears sec A + cot A csc A : :
<br>
Barycentrics csc 2A : csc 2B : csc 2C
<br>
Barycentrics 1/[a<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan A + cot A : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan A - cot B - cot C + cot &omega; : :
<p>
Five constructions by Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015:
</p><p>
(1) Let A'B'C' be the tangential triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(264).
</p><p>
(2) Let A'B'C' be the symmedial triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(264).
</p><p>
(3) Let A'B'C' be the circumsymmedial triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(264).
</p><p>
(4) Let A'B'C' be the Lucas(t) central triangle (for any t). Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(264).
</p><p>
(5) X(264) is the trilinear pole of the line X(297)X(525). This line is the isotomic conjugate of the MacBeath circumconic, which is the isogonal conjugate of the orthic axis. The line is also the polar of X(6) wrt the polar circle, and the radical axis of the polar and orthosymmedial circles, and the polar conjugate of the circumcircle)
</p><p>
Let A' be the trilinear product of the vertices of the A-anti-altimedial triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(264). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(264) lies on these cubics: K045, K146, K183, K184, K208, K257, K276, K342a, K342b, K494, K504, K647, K674, K675, K677, K718
</p><p>
X(264) lies on these lines:<br>

<h3 id="X265">X(265) = REFLECTION OF X(3) IN X(125)</h3>
Trilinears sin 2A csc 3A : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(4 cos A - sec A) : :
<br>
Trilinears csc(A + &pi;/3) - csc(A - &pi;/3) : :
<br>
Trilinears (cos A)/(1 - 4 cos^2 A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sin 2A csc 3A : :
<br>
Barycentrics (a^2 - b^2 - c^2)/[(a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2c^2] : :
<br>
Tripolars a^2((a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2 c^2) : :
<b><br>
X(265) = 3 X[2] - 5 X[15081],3 X[2] - 4 X[20304],3 X[3] - 4 X[6699],2 X[3] - 5 X[15027],2 X[3] - 3 X[15061],3 X[3] - 2 X[16163],5 X[3] - 8 X[20397],3 X[4] - X[146],3 X[4] - 2 X[1539],3 X[4] + X[12317],3 X[5] - 2 X[10272],4 X[5] - 3 X[14643],2 X[5] - 3 X[14644],4 X[5] - X[23236],X[20] - 4 X[20379],3 X[51] - 2 X[11557],X[67] + 2 X[32273],X[74] - 3 X[9140],3 X[74] - 2 X[14677],2 X[74] - 3 X[20126],2 X[98] - 3 X[14849],2 X[99] - 3 X[14850],3 X[110] - 4 X[10272],X[110] - 4 X[11801],2 X[110] - 3 X[14643],X[110] - 3 X[14644],2 X[113] - 3 X[381],4 X[113] - 3 X[5655],3 X[113] - 2 X[6053],3 X[125] - 2 X[6699],4 X[125] - X[12121],2 X[125] + X[12902],4 X[125] - 5 X[15027],4 X[125] - 3 X[15061],3 X[125] - X[16163],5 X[125] - 4 X[20397],4 X[140] - 3 X[15035],4 X[140] - 5 X[15059],X[146] + 3 X[3448],2 X[146] - 3 X[7728],X[146] - 6 X[10113],3 X[381] - X[399],9 X[381] - 4 X[6053],3 X[381] - 4 X[7687],X[382] + 2 X[16003],2 X[399] - 3 X[5655],3 X[399] - 4 X[6053],X[399] - 4 X[7687],X[476] - 3 X[5627],2 X[476] - 3 X[14993],2 X[477] - 3 X[14851]
</b><p>
Let P = X(74), H = X(4), H' =H-of-BCP, H'' = H-of-CAP, and H''' = H-of ABP. Then X(265) is the circumcenter of the cyclic quadrilateral HH'H''H'''. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection in line BC of the A-vertex of the tangential triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, and C'AB concur in X(265). Let A'' be the reflection in line BC of the A-vertex of the anticevian triangle of X(5), and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The circumcircles of AB''C'', BC''A'', CA''B'' concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A*B*C* be the Kosnita triangle. Let A' be the orthopole of line B*C*, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the X(3)-Fuhrmann triangle. Let A'' be the reflection of A in line B'C', and define B'' and C'' cyclically. Then A''B''C'' is inversely similar to ABC, with similtude center X(265), and A''B''C'' is perspective to ABC with persepctor X(74). (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let L be the line through A' parallel to the Euler line, and define M and N cyclically. Let L' be the reflection of L in sideline BC, and define M' and N' cyclically. The lines L',M', N' concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(5). Let A* be the trilinear pole, wrt A'B'C', of line B"C", and define B*, C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the point such that triangle A'BC is directly similar to the orthic triangle, and define B', C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(265). If 'inversely' is substituted for 'directly', the lines concur in X(3). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of A wrt the A-altimedial triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let La be the line through A parallel to the Euler line of the A-altimedial triangle, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Lines La, Lb, Lc concur in X(265). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X266">X(266) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(188)</h3>
Trilinears sin A/2 : sin B/2 : sin C/2
<br>
Trilinears [a/(b + c - a)]<sup>1/2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A sec A/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A' : :, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears |X(1)A'| : |X(1)B'| : |X(1)C'|, where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Trilinears cos(angle BIC) : cos(angle CIA) : cos(angle AIB)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sin A/2 : :
<p>
The trilinear polar of X(266) passes through X(6729). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(266) lies on these lines:1,164 56,289
174,188 259,260 361,978

X(266) = trilinear square root of X(56)<br>

<h3 id="X267">X(267) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(191)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= 1/[b<sup>3</sup> + c<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>3</sup> + (b + c - a)(bc +
ca + ab)]
<p>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)</p>

35,37</p>

<h3 id="X268">X(268) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(196)</h3>

: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos A cot A/2)/(-1 - cos A +
cos B + cos C)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)

<h3 id="X269">X(269) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(200)</h3>
Trilinears tan<sup>2</sup>A/2 : tan<sup>2</sup>B/2 : tan<sup>2</sup>C/2
<br>
Trilinears [a<sup>2</sup> - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>]<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 - sec^2(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - cos A)/(1 + cos A) : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - sec A)/(1 + sec A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A tan<sup>2</sup>A/2 : :
<p>
X(269) is the vertex conjugate of the foci of the inellipse that is the trilinear square of the Gergonne line. The center of this inellipse is X(11019), and the Brianchon point (perspector) is X(1088). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>1</sub>B<sub>1</sub>C<sub>1</sub> be Gemini triangle 1. Let A' be the center of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>1</sub>,C<sub>1</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(269). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(269) lies on these lines: 1,7 3,939
6,57 9,241 46,1103

292,1020 307,936 320,326
479,614</p>

X(269) = trilinear square of X(57)<br>

<h3 id="X274">X(274) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(213)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>/(b + c) : :
<br>
Trilinears [a csc(A - &omega;)]/(b + c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics bc/(b + c) : ca/(c + a) : ab/(a + b)
</p><p>
Let Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb be as in the construction of the Conway circle; see http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ConwayCircle.html. Let Oa be the circumcircle of ABaCa, and define Ob and Oc cyclically. Then X(274) is the radical center of Oa, Ob, Oc. see also X(8) and X(21). (Randy Hutson, April 9, 2016)
</p><p>
X(274) lies on these lines:<br>1,75 2,39 7,959 10,291

X(274) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,86), (75,310), (81,286), (333,314)<br>
X(274) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(669)X(798)<br>

<h3 id="X275">X(275) = CEVAPOINT OF ORTHOCENTER AND SYMMEDIAN POINT</h3>

<br>

<h3 id="X278">X(278) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(219)</h3>
Trilinears sec A tan A/2 : sec B tan B/2 : sec C tan C/2
<br>
Trilinears csc A - 2 csc 2A : csc B - 2 csc 2B : csc C - 2 csc 2C
<br>
Trilinears (1 - sec A)/a : (1 - sec B)/b : (1 - sec C)/c
<br>
Trilinears bc/[(b + c - a)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)]<br>
<br> Barycentrics tan A tan A/2 : tan B tan B/2 : tan C tan C/2
<br>
Barycentrics 1 - sec A : 1 - sec B : 1 - sec C
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the extouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(278). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 2nd extouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(278). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ha be the hyperbola passing through A, and with foci at B and C. This is called the A-Soddy hyperbola in (Paul Yiu, Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle, 2002; 12.4 The Soddy hyperbolas, p. 143). Let La be the polar of X(3) with respect to Ha. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC, and the center of homothety is X(278). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
X(278) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,92 7,27 19,57
25,105 28,56 65,387
88,653 109,917 219,329
240,982 241,277 242,459
274,331 354,955 393,1108
412,962 443,1038 614,1096
</p><p>
X(278) = isogonal conjugate of X(219)<br>
X(278) = isotomic conjugate of X(345)<br>
X(278) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (27,57), (92,196), (273,4), (331,7)<br>
X(278) = cevapoint of X(19) and X(34)<br>
X(278) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (19,4), (56,7), (225,273)<br>
X(278) = trilinear pole of line X(513)X(1835) (the polar of X(8) wrt polar circle, and inverse-in-polar-circle of Fuhrmann circle)<br>
X(278) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(8) (line X(522)X(650))<br>
X(278) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(8)<br>
X(278) = {X(2),X(92)}-harmonic conjugate of X(281)<br>
X(278) = vertex conjugate of foci of inconic that is the polar conjugate of the isogonal conjugate of the incircle<br>
X(278) = perspector of Gemini triangle 38 and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 38<br>
X(278) = trilinear pole of line X(513)X(1835) (the perspectrix of ABC and Gemini triangle 37)<br>
X(278) = Brianchon point (perspector) of inconic that is the polar conjugate of the isotomic conjugate of the incircle<br>

<p>

<h3 id="X281">X(281) = X(37)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears sec A cot A/2 : sec B cot B/2 : sec C cot C/2
<br>
Trilinears csc A + 2 csc 2A : csc B + 2 csc 2B : csc C + 2 csc 2C
<br>
Trilinears (1 + sec A)/a : (1 + sec B)/b : (1 + sec C)/c
<br>
Trilinears (b + c - a) sec A : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan A cot A/2 : tan B cot B/2 : tan C cot C/2
<br>
Barycentrics 1 + sec A : 1 + sec B : 1 + sec C
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c - a)/(b^2 + c^2 - a^2) : :
<p>
X(281): Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(281). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 3rd extouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(281). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 4th extouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(281). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 5th extouch triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(281). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ea be the ellipse passing through A, and with foci at B and C (the A-Soddy ellipse). Let La be the polar of X(3) with respect to Ea. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC, and the center of homothety is X(281). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)

<h3 id="X284">X(284) = X(55)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(21)</h3>
Trilinears (sin A)/(cos B + cos C) : (sin B)/(cos C + cos A) : (sin C)/(cos A + cos B)
<br>
Trilinears a (b + c - a)/(b + c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(cos B + cos C) : b<sup>2</sup>/(cos C + cos A) : c<sup>2</sup>/(cos A + cos B)
<br><b>
X(284) = s*X(3) + (r + 2R)*cot(&omega;)*X(6)
</b><p>
X(284) lies on these lines:<br>1,19 2,272 3,6 9,21
27,226 29,950 35,71
37,101 55,219 57,77
60,283 73,951 86,142
102,112 109,296 163,909

501,942 515,1065
</p><p>
X(284) = isogonal conjugate of X(226)<br>
X(284) = isotomic conjugate of X(349)<br>

<h3 id="X285">X(285) = X(58)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(21)</h3>

: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where<br> f(A,B,C)
= 1/[(cos B + cos C)(-1 - cos A + cos B + cos C)]

C)f(C,A,B)</p>

<h3 id="X291">X(291) = 2nd SHARYGIN POINT</h3>

<h3 id="X292">X(292) = X(1)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(291)</h3>
Trilinears a/(a<sup>2</sup>
- bc) : b/(b<sup>2</sup> - ca) : c/(c<sup>2</sup> - ab)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/(a<sup>2</sup> - bc) :
b<sup>2</sup>/(b<sup>2</sup> - ca) : c<sup>2</sup>/(c<sup>2</sup> - ab)
<p>

</p><p>

6,869 9,87 37,86 44,660
58,101 106,813 171,893
269,1020 659,665</p>

<h3 id="X297">X(297) = X(2)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears csc 2A cos(A + &omega;) : csc 2B cos(B + &omega;) : csc 2C cos(C + &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics sec A cos(A + &omega;) : sec B cos(B + &omega;) : sec C cos(C + &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics tan A - cot &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics SB*SC(-SA^2 + SB*SC) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b^4 + c^4 - a^2 b^2 - a^2 c^2)/(b^2 + c^2 - a^2) : :
<b><br>
X(297) = X(340) + 2X(1990)
</b>
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(297) has Shinagawa coefficients (EF + F<sup>2</sup>, - S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(297) lies on these lines:<br>
{2, 3}, {6, 317}, {53, 141}, {69, 393}, {76, 343}, {83, 275}, {92, 257}, {107, 2710}, {112, 2857}, {193, 1249}, {230, 2966}, {232, 325}, {239, 5081}, {249, 316}, {273, 3662}, {286, 1865}, {287, 685}, {290, 1987}, {315, 394}, {318, 3661}, {324, 1235}, {340, 524}, {459, 2996}, {525, 850}, {530, 6111}, {531, 6110}, {623, 6117}, {624, 6116}, {626, 3199}, {1515, 1533}, {1654, 2322}, {1785, 3912}, {1915, 1970}, {3087, 3618}, {3978, 6331}, {3981, 5254}, {5032, 5702}
</p> <p>
X(297) = midpoint of X(340) and X(648)<br>

X(300) = X(94)-Hirst inverse of X(301)<br>

<h3 id="X301">X(301) ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF 2nd ISODYNAMIC CENTER</h3>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>A
csc(A - &pi;/3) : csc<sup>2</sup>B csc(B - &pi;/3) : csc<sup>2</sup>C
csc(C - &pi;/3)<br>Barycentrics csc A csc(A - &pi;/3) : csc B csc(B - &pi;/3) :
csc C csc(C - &pi;/3)
<p>
The trilinear polar of X(301) passes through X(850). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
<p>X(301) lies on these lines: 2,94 14,76
264,303 265,622 302,311
</p><p>
X(301) = isotomic conjugate of X(16)<br>
X(301) = cevapoint of X(299) and X(302)<br>
X(301) = X(94)-Hirst inverse of X(300)<br>
X(301) = polar conjugate of X(8740)<br>

<h3 id="X304">X(304) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(19)</h3>

<h3 id="X311">X(311) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(54)</h3>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>A cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics csc A cos(B - C) : csc B cos(C - A) : csc C cos(A - B)
<p>
Let O<sub>A</sub>O<sub>B</sub>O<sub>C</sub> be the Kosnita triangle. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line O<sub>B</sub>O<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(1994). Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B"and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(311). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
<p>
X(311) lies on these lines: 2,570 4,69
22,157 53,324 95,99
141,338 290,308 300,303
301,302 305,1007

<h3 id="X312">X(312) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(57)</h3>
Trilinears (b + c - a)b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> : (c + a - b)c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup> : (a + b - c)a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)csc(A - &omega;) : (1 + cos B)csc(B - &omega;) : (1 + cos C)csc(C - &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)/(1 - cos A) : (csc B)/(1 - cos B) : (csc C)/(1 - cos C) (M. Iliev, 4/12/07)
<br>
Trilinears bc tan A' : ca tan B' : ab tan C', where A'B'C' is the excentral triangle
<br>
Barycentrics bc(b + c - a) : ca(c + a - b) : ab(a + b - c)
<p>
Let A<sub>37</sub>B<sub>37</sub>C<sub>37</sub> be Gemini triangle 37. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>37</sub>,C<sub>37</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(312). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>39</sub>B<sub>39</sub>C<sub>39</sub> be Gemini triangle 39. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>39</sub>,C<sub>39</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(312). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)

<h3 id="X314">X(314) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(65)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>(b +
c - a)/(b + c)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= bc(b + c - a)/(b + c)
<p>
Let D and E be the intersections of line X(1)X(3) with lines PU(3) and PU(6), respectively. Let D' and E' be the isogonal conjugates of D and E, respectively. Let D" and E" be the isotomic conjugates of D and E, respectively. Then X(314) = D'D" &cap;E'E". (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A4B4C4 be the 4th Conway triangle. Let A' be the cevapoint of B4 and C4, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(314). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A5B5C5 be the 5th Conway triangle. Let A' be the cevapoint of B5 and C5, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(314). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)

X(314) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (8,312), (69,75)<br>
X(314) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (8,333), (69,332), (333,274), (497,29)</p>
X(314) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(1764) wrt excentral triangle<br>

X(314) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1880)<br>

<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X316">X(316) = DROUSSENT PIVOT</h3>
<a id="DroussentPivot" name="DroussentPivot"></a>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a)
: f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> -
a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> -
b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Tripolars a^2 Sqrt[2(b^2 + c^2) - a^2] : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the antipedal triangle of X(4) (the anticomplementary triangle). The circumcircles of AA'X(4), BB'X(4), CC'X(4) concur, other than X(4), in X(316). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
See <b>Lucien Droussent,</b> "Cubiques circulaires anallagmatiques par points r&eacute;ciproques ou isogonaux," <i>Mathesis</i> 62 (1953) 204-215.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X325">X(325) = X(2)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(69)</h3>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>A : :
<br>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot A - tan &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> : :
</p><p>
Let La be the line through A parallel to the Lemoine axis, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let Ma be the reflection of BC in La, and define Mb and Mc cyclically. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Lemoine axis. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(325); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
X(325) lies on the Simson quartic Q101 and these lines: <br>
{2,6}, {3,315}, {4,1975}, {5,76}, {11,350}, {12,1909}, {20,6337}, {22,160}, {23,3447}, {25,317}, {30,99}, {32,3788}, {39,626}, {51,4121}, {74,2855}, {75,2886}, {95,1799}, {98,2065}, {100,2856}, {110,2857}, {111,2858}, {114,511}, {115,538}, {140,1078}, {147,1503}, {187,620}, {194,5025}, {232,297}, {250,340}, {253,6340}, {264,305}, {274,442}, {290,3978}, {310,3136}, {311,1238}, {320,1447}, {332,2893}, {339,1236}, {383,622}, {441,2966}, {523,684}, {532,6108}, {533,6109}, {542,5939}, {621,1080}, {623,6115}, {624,6114}, {631,3785}, {637,6289}, {638,6290}, {639,3103}, {640,3102}, {671,5503}, {672,4766}, {698,1916}, {732,2023}, {740,5988}, {758,5977}, {868,2396}, {892,1494}, {1235,1594}, {1329,6377}, {1368,6375}, {1444,4220}, {1506,3934}, {2071,5866}, {2482,3849}, {3233,6148}, {3734,5475}, {3814,6382}, {3829,4479}, {3847,4357}, {3932,4518}, {5149,5162}, {5965,6036}

<h3 id="X331">X(331) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(219)</h3>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2)

csc(2C)<br> =

C)csc(C - &omega;)
<p>Barycentrics sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) sec A :
sec<sup>2</sup>(B/2) sec B : sec<sup>2</sup>(C/2) sec C</p>
X(331) is the Brianchon point (perspector) of the inconic that is the polar conjugate of the isogonal conjugate of the incircle. (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p> <p>X(331) lies on these lines: 4,150 7,286
34,870 75,225 85,92
108,767 274,278</p>
<p>
X(331) = isotomic conjugate of X(219)<br>
X(331) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (7,278), (92,273)<br>
X(331) = X(92)-cross conjugate of X(264)<br>
X(331) = trilinear pole of polar of X(55) wrt polar circle<br>
X(331) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(55) (line X(657)X(663))<br>
X(331) = polar conjugate of X(55)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X333">X(333) CEVAPOINT OF X(8) AND X(9)</h3>

+ b - c)/(a + b)

B)

<h3 id="X347">X(347) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(280)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (-1 - cos A + cos B + cos C)
sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2)<br>Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>
Let Ha be the hyperbola passing through A, and with foci at B and C. This is called the A-Soddy hyperbola in (Paul Yiu, Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle, 2002; 12.4 The Soddy hyperbolas, p. 143). Let La be the polar of X(20) with respect to Ha. Define Lb, Lc cyclically. La, Lb, Lc concur in X(347). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(347) lies on these lines:<br>1,7 2,92 8,253 34,452
37,948 69,664 75,280
144,219 223,329 227,322
241,1108 573,1020</p>
<p>
X(347) = isogonal conjugate of X(2192)<br>
X(347) = isotomic conjugate of X(280)<br>
X(347) = anticomplement of X(281)<br>
X(347) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (75,7), (348,2)<br>
X(347) = cevapoint of X(40) and X(223)<br>
X(347) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (40,329), (221,196), (227,223)<br>
X(347) = crosspoint of X(75) and X(322)<br>
X(347) = polar conjugate of X(7003)<br>
X(347) = {X(175),X(176)}-harmonic conjugate of X(20)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X348">X(348) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(281)</h3>
Trilinears cot A sec<sup>2</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)/(1 + sec A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(1 + sec A) : 1/(1 + sec B) : 1/(1 + sec C)
<br>
Barycentrics (b^2 + c^2 - a^2)/(b + c - a) : :
<p>
X(348) is the Brianchon point (perspector) of the inconic that is the isotomic conjugate of the polar conjugate of the incircle. The center of the inconic is X(17073). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A<sub>36</sub>B<sub>36</sub>C<sub>36</sub> be Gemini triangle 36. Let A' be the perspector of conic {{A,B,C,B<sub>36</sub>,C<sub>36</sub>}}, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(348). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(348) lies on these lines: 2,85 7,21
8,664 69,73 75,280
150,944 201,337 274,278
304,345 499,1111</p>
<p>
X(348) = isogonal conjugate of X(607)<br>
X(348) = isotomic conjugate of X(281)<br>
X(348) = complement of X(30694)<br>
X(348) = X(274)-Ceva conjugate of X(85)<br>
X(348) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,347), (63,77)<br>
X(348) = X(222)-cross conjugate of X(7)</p>
X(348) = polar conjugate of X(1857)<br>
X(348) = trilinear pole of line X(4025)X(4131)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

B) csc<sup>3</sup>C<br> =

cos A)csc<sup>2</sup>B : (cos A + cos B)(csc C/2)<sup>2</sup></p>

Trilinears (a<sup>2</sup>
- bc)b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> : (b<sup>2</sup> -
ca)c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup> : (c<sup>2</sup> -
ab)a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics bc(a<sup>2</sup> - bc) : ca(b<sup>2</sup> - ca)
: ab(c<sup>2</sup> - ab)
<p>X(350) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle
of the conic that passes through A, B, C, and the pair P(10) and U(10)
