<h3 id="X351">X(351) = CENTER OF THE PARRY CIRCLE</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>)
<p>
X(351) is the center of the Parry circle introduced in TCCT (Art. 8.13) as the circle that passes through X(i) for I = 2, 15, 16, 23, 110, 111, 352, 353.
</p><p>
X(351) lies on these lines: 2,804 110,526 184,686 187,237 694,881 865,888
</p><p>
X(351) = midpoint of X(5638) and X(5639)<br>
X(351) = isogonal conjugate of X(892)<br>
X(351) = crosspoint of X(110) and X(111)<br>
X(351) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,690), (523,524), (850,1236)<br>
X(351) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(2)X(99)<br>
X(351) = Lemoine axis intercept of trilinear polar of X(512)<br>
X(351) = centroid of the triangle X(3)X(5607)X(5608)<br>
X(351) = tripolar centroid of X(6)<br>
X(351) = centroid of Lemoine axis intercepts with sidelines of ABC<br>
X(351) = X(351)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(351) = intersection of tangents to Steiner inellipse at X(1084) and X(2482)<br>
X(351) = crosspoint wrt medial triangle of X(1084) and X(2482)<br>
X(351) = vertex conjugate of PU(62)<br>
X(351) = radical center of (circumcircle, Brocard circle, McCay circumcircle)<br>
X(351) = harmonic center of circles {{X(14),X(15),X(16)}} and {{X(13),X(15),X(16)}}<br>
X(351) = bicentric difference of PU(i) for these i: 62, 63, 64, 65, 66, 67<br>
X(351) = PU(62)-harmonic conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(351) = PU(63)-harmonic conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(351) = PU(64)-harmonic conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(351) = PU(65)-harmonic conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(351) = PU(66)-harmonic conjugate of X(10)<br>
X(351) = PU(67)-harmonic conjugate of X(39)<br>
X(351) = X(3)-of-1st-Parry-triangle<br>
X(351) = X(3)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(351) = X(3)-of-3rd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(351) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(187); see X(2)<br>
X(351) = pole of Brocard axis wrt Parry isodynamic circle<br>
X(351) = bicentric sum of PU(105)<br>
X(351) = PU(105)-harmonic conjugate of X(3124)<br>
X(351) = centroid of (degenerate) cross-triangle of 1st and 3rd Parry triangles<br>
X(351) = Lemoine axis (or line PU(2)) intercept of line connecting P(2)-Ceva conjugate of U(2) and U(2)-Ceva conjugate of P(2)
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X352">X(352) = INVERSE-IN-CIRCUMCIRCLE OF X(353)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a(-a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup> - 5b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 4a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> + 4a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>
X(352) lies on the Parry circle and these lines: 2,6 3,353 23,2502 110,187 111,511
</p> <p>
X(352) = reflection of X(843) in X(187)<br>
X(352) = isogonal conjugate of X(6094)<br>
X(352) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(353)<br>
X(352) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(373)X(512)<br>
X(352) = X(23)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(352) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(3815)<br>
X(352) = orthocentroidal-to-ABC similarity image of X(111)<br>
X(352) = 4th-Brocard-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(111)<br>
X(352) = X(2709)-of-1st-Parry-triangle<br>
X(352) = X(843)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(352) = X(110)-of-3rd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(352) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(23); see X(2)<br>
X(352) = radical trace of circumcircles of Artzt and anti-Artzt triangles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X353">X(353) = INVERSE-IN-BROCARD-CIRCLE OF X(111)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a(4a<sup>4</sup> - 2b<sup>4</sup> - 2c<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - 4a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> -4a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>
Let AaBaCa, AbBbCb, AcBcCc be the A-, B- and C-anti-altimedial triangles. Let A' be the trilinear product Aa*Ab*Ac, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is the anticomplementary triangle of the 1st Brocard triangle, and is similar to the anti-orthocentroidal triangle, with similitude center X(353). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(353) lies on the Parry circle and these lines: 3,352 6,23
110,574 111,182 187,3117
</p><p>
X(353) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(352)<br>
X(353) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(111)<br>
X(353) = centroid of circumsymmedial triangle<br>
X(353) = circumcevian isogonal conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(353) = X(5640)-of-4th-anti-Brocard triangle<br>
X(353) = isogonal conjugate, wrt 2nd Brocard triangle, of X(2)<br>
X(353) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(2); see X(2)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X354">X(354) = WEILL POINT</h3> <a id="WeillPoint" name="WeillPoint"></a>
Trilinears (b - c)<sup>2</sup> - ab - ac : :
<br>
Trilinears 2 + cos B + cos C : :
<br>
Trilinears cos^2(B/2) + cos^2(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears b(cot B/2) + c(cot C/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a[(b - c)<sup>2</sup> - ab - ac] : :
<p>
X(354) is the perspector of the intangents triangle and the triangle Q<sub>A</sub>Q<sub>B</sub>Q<sub>C</sub> described at X(3598). (Peter Moses, Nov. 4, 2010)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the inverse-in-{circumcircle, incircle}-inverter of A, B, C. Let A"B"C" be the tangential triangle of A'B'C'. Then A"B"C" is perspective to ABC at X(354). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
<b>William Gallatly,</b> <i>The Modern Geometry of the Triangle, 2nd edition,</i> Hodgson, London, 1913, page 16.
</p><p>
Let Ab be the intersection, other than B, of circle {{X(1),B,C}} and line AB. Let Ac be the intersection, other than C, of circle {{X(1),B,C}} and line AC. Define Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb cyclically. X(354) is the centroid of AbAcBcBaCaCb. Note that the lines AbAc, BcBa, CaCb bound the intangents triangle. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(354) lies on these lines: 1,3 2,210
6,374 7,479 11,118
37,38 42,244 44,748
48,584 63,1001 81,105 142,3059
278,955 373,375 388,938
392,551 516,553 1418,2293
</p><p>
X(354) = isogonal conjugate of X(2346)<br>
X(354) = complement of X(3681)<br>
X(354) = anticomplement of X(3740)<br>
X(354) = inverse-in-incircle of X(1155)<br>
X(354) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (210,2), (392,551)<br>
X(354) = X(101)-Ceva conjugate of X(513)<br>
X(354) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(7)<br>
X(354) = crosssum of X(1) and X(55)<br>
X(354) = X(2)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
X(354) = homothetic center of intouch triangle and inverse-in-incircle triangle<br>
X(354) = centroid of inverse-in-incircle triangle<br>
X(354) = pole of antiorthic axis wrt incircle<br>
X(354) = {X(1),X(40)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3303)<br>
X(354) = {X(1),X(65)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3057)<br>
X(354) = {X(3513),X(3514)}-harmonic conjugate of X(65)<br>
X(354) = centroid of the six intersections of the Conway circle and the sidelines of ABC<br>
X(354) = centroid of the six intersections of the sidelines of ABC and the antiparallels to sidelines through X(1)<br>
X(354) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, incircle}-inverter of X(36)<br>
X(354) = cevian isogonal conjugate of X(7) = intouch isogonal conjugate of X(7)<br>
X(354) = bicentric sum of PU(94)<br>
X(354) = PU(94)-harmonic conjugate of X(650)<br>
X(354) = X(381)-of-incircle-circles-triangle<br>
X(354) = {X(1),X(57)}-harmonic conjugate of X(55)<br>
X(354) = centroid of the six intersections of the Adams' circle and the sidelines of ABC<br>
</p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X355">X(355) = FUHRMANN CENTER</h3>
<a id="FuhrmannCenter" name="FuhrmannCenter"></a>
Trilinears a cos A - (b + c)cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears bc(b + c)[a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>] - a<sup>3</sup>bc(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : : (Michel Garitte, 4/3/03)
<br>
Trilinears cos B + cos C - 2 cos B cos C - 1 : :
<br>
Trilinears r - R cos(B - C) : :
<p>
X(355) = the center of the Fuhrmann circle, defined as the circumcircle of the Fuhrmann triangle A"B"C", where A" is obtained as follows: let A' be the midpoint of the circumcircle-arc having endpoints B and C and not containing A; then A" is the reflection of A' in line BC. Vertices B" and C" are obtained cyclically. (Other constructions of A'', and hence the Fuhrmann triangle, follow: (1) Let I<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of X(1) in BC; then A'' is the circumcenter of I<sub>A</sub>BC. (2) Let J<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of the A-excenter in BC; then A'' is the circumcenter of J<sub>A</sub>BC.
</p><p>
X(355) is the homothetic center of the triangles formed by internal and external tangents of circumcircles of BCX(4), CAX(4), ABX(4). Equivalently, the incenter of the trianglar hull of circumcircles of BCX(4), CAX(4), ABX(4). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let Na = X(5)-of-BCX(1), Nb = X(5)-of-CAX(1), Nc = X(5)- of-ABX(1). Then X(355) = X(20)-of-NaNbNc. (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the anticomplementary triangle. Then X(355) is the radical center of the incircles of A'BC, B'CA, C'AB. (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the outer Garcia triangle and A"B"C" the inner Garcia triangle. Let A* be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A'B'C', of A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A'A*, B'B*, C'C* concur in X(355); see also X(952). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
<b>Ross Honsberger,</b> <i>Episodes in Nineteenth and Twentieth Century Euclidean Geometry,</i> Mathematical Association of America, 1995. Chapter 6: The Fuhrmann Circle.
</p><p>
X(355) lies on these lines:<br>
1,5 2,944 3,10 4,8
30,40 65,68 85,150
104,404 165,550 381,519
382,516 388,942 938,1056
</p><p>
X(355) = midpoint of X(4) and X(8)<br>
X(355) = isogonal conjugate of X(3417)<br>
X(355) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,5), (3,10), (944,1385), (1482,946)<br>
X(355) = anticomplement of X(1385)<br>
X(355) = complement of X(944)<br>
X(355) = inverse-in-Feuerbach-hyperbola of X(1837)<br>
X(355) = {X(1),X(80)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1837)<br>
X(355) = outer-Garcia-isogonal conjugate of X(40)<br>
X(355) = X(3)-of-outer-Garcia-triangle<br>
X(355) = X(6265)-of-inner-Garcia-triangle<br>
X(355) = X(6102)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(355) = inner-Garcia-to-outer-Garcia similarity image of X(3)<br>
X(355) = X(12844)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(355) = endo-homothetic center of Ehrmann side-triangle and 4th anti-Euler triangle; the homothetic center is X(12111)<br>
X(355) = reflection of X(12699) in X(4)<br>
X(355) = {X(1),X(1837)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5722)<br>
X(355) = Ursa-minor-to-Ursa-major similarity image of X(1)<br>
X(355) = {X(1),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5886)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X356">X(356) = MORLEY CENTER</h3><a id="MorleyCenter" name="MorleyCenter"></a>
Trilinears cos A/3 + 2 cos B/3 cos C/3 : :
<br>
Trilinears = cos(B/3 - C/3) + sqrt(3)sin(A/3 + &pi;/3) (M. Stevanovic, 12/25/2007)
<br><b>
X(356) = X(3276) + X(3277) - X(3)
</b><p>
<p>X(356) is the centroid of the Morley equilateral triangle. For a discussion of the theorem and extensive list of references, see
</p><p>
<b>C. O. Oakley and J. C. Baker,</b> "The Morley trisector theorem," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 85 (1978) 737-745.
</p><p>For a sketch of the Morley cubic and list of centers on it, including X(356), X(357), X(358), see
<a href="http://perso.wanadoo.fr/bernard.gibert/Exemples/morley.html">Bernard Gibert's site</a>.
</p><p>
See also Dao Thanh Oai, <a href="http://geometry-math-journal.ro/pdf/Volume7-Issue2/5.pdf" style="font-weight: bold">Some new equilateral triangles in a plane geometry.</a>
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Morley triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(356). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(356).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(356)</a>.
</p><p>
For a biographical sketch, including details about Morley's famous theorem on angle trisectors, with history and references, see
</p><p>
<a href="http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/bstud/morley.html">Frank Morley (1860-1937) geometer</a>.
</p><p>
X(356) lies on these lines: 2,5455 3,3278 357,358 1134,1135 3605,5456.
</p><p>
X(356) = isogonal conjugate of X(3605)<br>
X(356) = orthology center of 1st Morley adjunct triangle and 1st Morley triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X357">X(357) = 1st MORLEY-TAYLOR-MARR CENTER</h3>
<a id="1stMorleyTaylorMarrCenter" name= "1stMorleyTaylorMarrCenter"></a>
Trilinears sec A/3 : sec B/3 :
sec C/3<br>Barycentrics sin A sec A/3 : sin B sec B/3 : sin C sec C/3
<p>X(357) is the perspector of Morley triangle and ABC, and also the
Hofstadter 1/3 point. See</p>
<p><b>F. Glanville Taylor and W. L. Marr,</b> "The six trisectors of
each of the angles of a triangle," <i>Proceedings of the Edinburgh
Mathematical Society</i> 33 (1913-14) 119-131, especially item 9, page
127.</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href="X(357).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(357)</a>.
<p>X(357) lies on these lines: 356,358 1134,3275 3280,5454
</p><p>
X(357) = isogonal conjugate of X(358)<br>
X(357) = {X(1135),X(3272)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3603)<br>
X(357) = trilinear product of vertices of 1st Morley triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X358">X(358) = 2nd MORLEY-TAYLOR-MARR CENTER</h3>
<a id="2ndMorleyTaylorMarrCenter" name="2ndMorleyTaylorMarrCenter"></a>
Trilinears cos A/3 : cos B/3 : cos C/3
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos A/3 : sin B cos B/3 : sin C cos C/3
<p>X(358) is the perspector of the adjunct Morley triangle and ABC, and also the Hofstadter 2/3 point.</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(358).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(358)</a>.
<p>X(358) lies on these lines: 356,357 16,1135</p>
<p>X(358) = isogonal conjugate of X(357)<br>
X(358) = trilinear product of vertices of 1st Morley adjunct triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X359">X(359) = HOFSTADTER ONE POINT</h3>
<a id="HofstadterOnePoint" name="HofstadterOnePoint"></a>
Trilinears a/A : b/B : c/C
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>/A : b<sup>2</sup>/B : c<sup>2</sup>/C
<p>
This point is the limit as r approaches 1 of the Hofstadter r point. See X(360) for details.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(359)&X(360).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(359) and X(360)</a> and <a href="HofstadterTriangles.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Hofstadter Triangles</a>. These sketches include the Hofstadter ellipse (actually a family of ellipses, indexed by a parameter r) introduced (February 4, 2005) by Peter J. C. Moses. The ellipse E(r) is given for 0 &lt; r &lt; 1 by the following equation in trilinears:
</p><p>
x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> + z<sup>2</sup> + yz(D + 1/D) + zx(E + 1/E) + xy(F + 1/F) = 0, where D = cos A - sin A cot rA, E = cos B - sin B cot rB, F = cos C - sin C cot rC.
</p><p>
The Hofstadter ellipse E(1/2), given by x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> + z<sup>2</sup> - 2yz - 2xz - 2xy = 0, has center X(37) and passes through X(i) for these i: 244, 678, 2310, 2632, 2638, 2643, 3248, 4094, 4117.
</p><p>
Taking the limit of E(r) as r tends to 0 gives information about the circumellipse, E(0) (which is also E(1)):
</p><p>
Equation: ayz/A + bzx/B + cxy/C = 0<br>
Center: X(5945) = (a/A)(b<sup>2</sup>/B + c<sup>2</sup>/C - a<sup>2</sup>/A) : (b/B)(c<sup>2</sup>/C + a<sup>2</sup>/A - b<sup>2</sup>/B) : (c/C)(a<sup>2</sup>/A + b<sup>2</sup>/B - c<sup>2</sup>/C)
<br>
Intersection with circumcircle (other than A, B, C): X(3067) = a/[A(B - C)] : b/[B(C - A)] : c/[C(A - B)]
</p><p>
The Hofstadter ellipse E(1/2) is also the incentral inellipse, centered at X(37), and touching ABC at the traces of X(1). The ellipse also passes through X(4094), and is the incentral isotomic conjugate of line X(512)X(4895). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
See <a href="http://mathworld.wolfram.com/HofstadterEllipse.html" style="font-weight: bold">Hofstadter Ellipse at MathWorld</a>.
</p> <p>
X(359) lies on this line: {6,9036}
</p> <p>
X(359) = isogonal conjugate of X(360)<br>
X(359) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(5945)<br>
X(359) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {1, 360}, {2, 1049}<br>
X(359) = barycentric product X(i)*X(j) for these {i,j}: {1, 1077}, {1028, 1049}<br>
X(359) = barycentric quotient X(i)/X(j) for these {i,j}: {6, 360}, {31, 1049}, {1077, 75}<br>
X(359) = perspector of Hofstadter 0-ellipse<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X360">X(360) = HOFSTADTER ZERO POINT</h3>
<a id="HofstadterZeroPoint" name="HofstadterZeroPoint"></a>
Trilinears A/a : B/b : C/c
<br>
Barycentrics A : B : C
<b><br>
X(360) = A*[A] + B*[B] + C*[C], where A, B, C are the angles and [A], [B], [C] are the vertices
</b><p>
This point is obtained as a limit of perspectors. Let r denote a real number, but not 0 or 1. Using vertex B as a pivot, swing line BC toward vertex A through angle rB and swing line BC about C through angle rC. Let A(r) be the point in which the two swung lines meet. Obtain B(r) and C(r) cyclically. Triangle A(r)B(r)C(r) is the <i>r-Hofstadter triangle</i>; its perspector with ABC, called the Hofstadter r point, is the point given by trilinears
</p><p>
(sin rA)/sin(A - rA) : (sin rB)/sin(B - rB) : (sin rC)/sin(C - rC).
</p><p>
The limit of this point as r approaches 0 is X(360). The two Hofstadter points, X(359) and X(360) are examples of transcendental triangle centers, since they have no trilinear or barycentric representation using only algebraic functions of a,b,c (or sin A, sin B, sin C).
</p><p>
<b>Clark Kimberling,</b> "Hofstadter points," <i>Nieuw Archief voor Wiskunde</i> 12 (1994) 109-114.
</p><p>
<b>Conjecture and corollary (Randy Hutson, August 10, 2014): </b><br>
<i>If r is an integer other than 0, 1, or 2, then the inverse-in-circumcircle of the Hofstadter r point is the Hofstadter (2-r) point;<br>thus, since the isogonal conjugate of the Hofstadter r point is the Hofstadter (1-r) point, if r is not -1, 0 or 1,<br>then the antigonal image of the Hofstadter r point is the Hofstadter -r point.</i>
</p><p>
X(1) = Hofstadter 1/2 point = antigonal image of X(80)<br>
X(3) = Hofstadter 2 point = antigonal image of X(265)<br>
X(4) = Hofstadter -1 point<br>
X(35) = Hofstadter 3/2 point<br>
X(79) = Hofstadter -1/2 point = antigonal image of X(3065)<br>
X(186) = Hofstadter 3 point = antigonal image of X(5962)<br>
X(265) = Hofstadter -2 point = antigonal image of X(3)<br>
X(357) = Hofstadter 1/3 point<br>
X(358) = Hofstadter 2/3 point<br>
X(359) = Hofstadter 0 point<br>
X(360) = Hofstadter 1 point<br>
X(1127) = Hofstadter 1/4 point<br>
X(1129) = Hofstadter 3/4 point<br>
X(5457) = Hofstadter -1/3 point<br>
X(5458) = Hofstadter -2/3 point<br>
X(5961) = Hofstadter 4 point = antigonal image of X(5964)<br>
X(5962) = Hofstadter -3 point = antigonal image of X(186)<br>
X(5963) = Hofstadter 5 point<br>
X(5964) = Hofstadter -4 point = antigonal image of X(5961)
</p><p>
X(360) lies on this line: {2,1115}
</p><p>
X(360) = isogonal conjugate of X(359)<br>
X(360) = anticomplement of X(1115)<br>
X(360) = X(i)-anticomplementary conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {7021, 8}, {7041, 69}<br>
X(360) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): {1, 359}, {6, 1077}<br>
X(360) = barycentric product X(75)*X(1049)<br>
X(360) = barycentric quotient X(i)/X(j) for these {i,j}: {1, 1077}, {6, 359}, {1049, 1}, {1077, 1028}, {1085, 1049}<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X361">X(361) = X(266)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears csc B/2 +
csc C/2 - csc A/2 : csc C/2 + csc A/2 - csc B/2 : csc A/2 + csc B/2 -
csc C/2<br>Barycentrics f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C)
= (sin A)(csc B/2 + csc C/2 - csc A/2)
<p>The isoscelizer equation au(X) = bv(X) = cw(X) has solution X =
X(361).</p>
<p>X(361) lies on these lines: 1,188 164,503
266,978</p>
<p>X(361) = X(266)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X362">X(362) = CONGRUENT CIRCUMCIRCLES ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
<a id="CongruentCircumcirclesIsoscelizerPoint" name="CongruentCircumcirclesIsoscelizerPoint"></a>
Trilinears b cos B/2 + c cos C/2 - a cos A/2
<p>
The isoscelizer equations u(X)/a = v(X)/b = w(X)/c have solution X = X(362).
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href= "X(362).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(362)</a>.
</p><p>
X(362) lies on this line: 57,234
</p><p>
X(362) = X(31)-of-excentral triangle
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X363">X(363) = EQUAL PERIMETERS ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
<a id="EqualPerimetersIsoscelizerPoint" name="EqualPerimetersIsoscelizerPoint"></a>
Trilinears b/(1 + sin B/2) + c/(1 + sin C/2) - a/(1 + sin A/2) : :
<p>
If X = X(363), the isoscelizer triangles of X have equal perimeters.
</p><p>
X(363) is the homothetic center of the excentral triangle and the
inner Hutson triangle. A construction of the latter follows. The
internal bisector of angle A meets the A-excircle in two points. Let
P<sub>A</sub> be the point closer to line BC and let Q<sub>A</sub> be
the other point. Define P<sub>B</sub> and P<sub>C</sub> cyclically, and
define Q<sub>B</sub> and Q<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let L<sub>A</sub> be
the line tangent to the A-excircle at P<sub>A</sub>, and define
L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let M<sub>A</sub> be the
line tangent to the A-excircle at Q<sub>A</sub>, and define
M<sub>B</sub> and M<sub>C</sub> cyclically. The inner Hutson triangle
is the triangle A'B'C' given by A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>,
B' = L<sub>C</sub>&cap;L<sub>A</sub>, C' =
L<sub>A</sub>&cap;L<sub>B</sub>; the outer Hutson triangle is given by
A'' = M<sub>B</sub>&cap;M<sub>C</sub>, B'' =
M<sub>C</sub>&cap;M<sub>A</sub>, C' = M<sub>A</sub>&cap;M<sub>B</sub>.
(Based on a description of A'B'C' by Randy Hutson, September 23,
2011)
</p><p>
Peter Moses (November 10, 2011) found trilinears for A'B'C' and A''B''C''. As these are central triangles, trilinears for A' and A'' suffice:
</p><p>
A' = aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2bc - 2ca - 2ab) + bU<sub>B</sub>(b + c - a)(c + a - b) + cU<sub>C</sub>(b + c - a)(a + b - c)
<br>
: aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - 3c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc + 2ca - 2ab) + U<sub>B</sub>(c - a)(-a + b + c)(a - b + c) - cU<sub>C</sub>(-a + b + c)(a + b - c)
<br>
: aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> - 3b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc - 2ca + 2ab) - bU<sub>B</sub>(-a + b + c)(a - b + c) + U<sub>C</sub>(b - a)(-a + b + c)(a + b - c)
</p><p>
A'' = aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2bc - 2ca - 2ab) - bU<sub>B</sub>(b + c - a)(c + a - b) - cU<sub>C</sub>(b + c - a)(a + b - c)
<br>
: aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - 3c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc + 2ca - 2ab) - U<sub>B</sub>(c - a)(-a + b + c)(a - b + c) + cU<sub>C</sub>(-a + b + c)(a + b - c)
<br>
: aU<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> - 3b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc - 2ca + 2ab) + bU<sub>B</sub>(-a + b + c)(a - b + c) - U<sub>C</sub>(b - a)(-a + b + c)(a + b - c),
</p><p>
where U<sub>A</sub> = sqrt[bc/((a - b + c)(a + b - c)] = (1/2)csc(A/2), and U<sub>B</sub> and U<sub>C</sub> are defined cyclically.
</p><p>
A'B'C' is perspective to the following triangles: intouch, hexyl,Yff, and the 1st and 2nd circumperp triangles. A''B''C'' is perspective to these: ABC, intouch, hexyl, Yff, and the 1st and 2nd circumperp triangles. A'B'C' is homothetic to A''B''C'', which is perspective to the excentral triangle at X(168). (Peter Moses, 11/10/11)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(363).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(363)</a>.
</p><p>
Let UVW and U'V'W' be the tangential-midarc triangles introduced in the preamble to X(8075). The inner and outer Hutson triangles introduced at X(363) are the excircles-version of UVW and U'V'W'. (Randy Hutson and Cï¿½sar Lozada, August 29, 2015)
</p><p>
X(363) lies on these lines: 1,289 40,164 165,166
</p><p>
X(363) = X(57) of excentral triangle<br>
X(363) = homothetic center of ABC and orthic triangle of inner Hutson triangle
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X364">X(364) = WABASH CENTER (EQUAL AREAS ISOSCELIZER POINT)</h3>
<a id="WabashPoint" name="WabashPoint"></a>
Trilinears b<sup>1/2</sup> + c<sup>1/2</sup> -
a<sup>1/2</sup> : :
<p>
If X = X(364), the isoscelizer triangles T(X,a), T(X,b), T(X,c) have equal areas.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(364).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(364)</a>.
</p><p>
X(364) lies on these lines: 1,365 9,366</p>
<p>X(364) = X(366)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X365">X(365) = SQUARE ROOT POINT</h3>
<a id="SquareRootPoint"
name="SquareRootPoint"></a>Trilinears a<sup>1/2</sup> :
b<sup>1/2</sup> : c<sup>1/2</sup><br>Barycentrics a<sup>3/2</sup> : b<sup>3/2</sup> :
c<sup>3/2</sup>
<p>For a construction of X(365), see the note at X(2), which provides
for a construction barycentric square roots which one can easily extend
to a construction for trilinear square roots.</p>
<p>X(365) lies on these lines: 1,364 6,2118
43,2068 292,2146 2110,2119
2144,2147</p>
<p>
X(365) = isogonal conjugate of X(366)<br>
X(365) = crosssum of X(1) and X(364)<br>
X(365) = trilinear square root of X(6)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X366">X(366) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(365)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>-1/2</sup>
: b<sup>-1/2</sup> : c<sup>-1/2</sup><br>Barycentrics a<sup>1/2</sup> : b<sup>1/2</sup> :
c<sup>1/2</sup>
<p>See the note at X(365).</p>
<p>X(366) lies on these lines: 2,367 6,2068
9,364</p>
<p>
X(366) = isogonal conjugate of X(365)<br>
X(366) = cevapoint of X(1) and X(364)<br>
X(366) = X(367)-cross conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(366) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(366)<br>
X(366) = trilinear square root of X(2)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X367">X(367) = CROSSPOINT OF X(1) AND X(366)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>1/2</sup>
+ c<sup>1/2</sup> : c<sup>1/2</sup> + a<sup>1/2</sup> : a<sup>1/2</sup>
+ b<sup>1/2</sup><br>Barycentrics a(b<sup>1/2</sup> + c<sup>1/2</sup>) :
b(c<sup>1/2</sup> + a<sup>1/2</sup>) : c(a<sup>1/2</sup> +
b<sup>1/2</sup>)
<p>X(367) lies on these lines: 1,364 2,366</p>
<p>X(367) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(366)<br>X(367) = crosssum of X(1) and X(365)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X368">X(368) = EQUI-BROCARD CENTER</h3>
<a id=
"EquiBrocardCenter" name="EquiBrocardCenter"></a>Trilinears (reasonable
trilinears are sought)<br>Barycentrics (reasonable barycentrics are sought)
<p>The center X for which the triangle XBC, XCA, XAB have equal Brocard
angles. Peter Yff proved that X(368) lies on the self-isogonal
conjugate cubic with trilinear equation f(a,b,c)u + f(b,c,a)v +
f(c,a,b)w = 0, where f(a,b,c) = bc(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) and,
for variable x : y : z, the cubics u, v, w are given by u(x,y,z) =
x(y<sup>2</sup> + z<sup>2</sup>), v = u(y,z,x), w = u(z,x,y).</p>
<p>Cyril Parry proved that X(368) lies on the anticomplement of the
Kiepert hyperbola, this anticomplement being given by the trilinear
equation a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)x<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup>(c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)y<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)z<sup>2</sup> = 0.</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(368).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(368)</a> and
<a href=
"X(368)WithCurves.gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(368) With Curves</a>.
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X369">X(369) = 1st TRISECTED PERIMETER POINT</h3>
<a name="1st TrisectedPerimeterPoint"></a>Trilinears x : y : z (see
below)
<br>Barycentrics ax : by : cz
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(369).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(369)</a>.
<p>There exist points A', B', C' on segments BC, CA, AB, respectively,
such that AB' + AC' = BC' + BA' = CA' + CB' = (a + b + c)/3, and the
lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(369). Near the end of the 20th century,
Yff found trilinears for X(369) in terms of the unique real root, r, of
the cubic polynomial</p>
<p>2t<sup>3</sup> - 3(a + b + c)t<sup>2</sup> + (a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + 8bc + 8ca + 8ab)t - (cb<sup>2</sup> +
ac<sup>2</sup> + ba<sup>2</sup> + 5bc<sup>2</sup> + 5ca<sup>2</sup> +
5ab<sup>2</sup> + 9abc),</p>
<p>as follows: x = bc(r - c + a)(r - a + b). Here x(a,c,b) &ne;
x(a,b,c), so that y and z are not obtained from x by cyclically
permutating a,b,c. At the geometry conference held at Miami University
of Ohio, October 2, 2004, Yff, proved that X(369) is also given by
x<sub>1</sub> : y<sub>1</sub> : z<sub>1</sub> where y<sub>1</sub> :
z<sub>1</sub> <i>are</i> given by cyclic permutations of a,b,c, in
x<sub>1</sub>, where</p>
<p>x<sub>1</sub> = bc[r<sup>2</sup> - (2c + a)r + (- a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup> + 2c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc + 3ca + 2ab].</p>
<p>His presentation included a proof that there is only one point for
which AB' + AC' = BC' + BA' = CA' + CB' .</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X370">X(370) = EQUILATERAL CEVIAN TRIANGLE POINT</h3>
<a id="EquilateralCevianTrianglePoint" name=
"EquilateralCevianTrianglePoint"></a>Trilinears (see below)<br>Barycentrics (see below)
<p>A point P is an equilateral cevian triangle point if the cevian
triangle of P is equilateral. Jiang Huanxin introduced this notion in
1997.</p>
<p>Jean-Pierre Ehrmann notes (11/6/02) that the normalized barycentric
coordinates (x,y,z) of X(370) are the unique solution of this
system:</p>
<p>y(1 - y)S<sub>B</sub> + z(1 - z)S<sub>C</sub> = x(1 + x)F<br>z(1 - z)S<sub>C</sub> + x(1 - x)S<sub>A</sub> = y(1 + y)F<br>x(1 - x)S<sub>A</sub> + y(1 - y)S<sub>B</sub> = z(1 + z)F<br>x + y + z = 1,</p>
<p>where S<sub>A</sub> = (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)/2; S<sub>B</sub>, S<sub>C</sub> are defined cyclically,
F = [2 area(ABC)]/sqrt(3), and x&gt;0, y&gt;0, z&gt;0.</p>
<p><b>Jiang Huanxin and David Goering,</b> Problem 10358* and Solution,
"Equilateral cevian triangles," <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i>
104 (1997) 567-570 [proposed 1994].</p>
<p>X(370) lies on the Neuberg cubic.</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X371">X(371) = KENMOTU POINT (CONGRUENT SQUARES POINT)</h3>
<a id="KenmotuPoint" name="KenmotuPoint"></a>
Trilinears cos(A - &pi;/4) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears a(S<sub>A</sub> + S) : :
<br>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + 2S) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(A - &pi;/4) : :
<br><b>
X(371) = L<sub>A</sub>/R<sub>A</sub> + L<sub>B</sub>/R<sub>B</sub> + L<sub>C</sub>/R<sub>C</sub> - X(3)/R, where L<sub>A</sub>, L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> are the centers of the Lucas circles, and R<sub>A</sub>, R<sub>B</sub>, R<sub>C</sub> their radii (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
<br>
X(371) = L<sub>A</sub>/R<sub>A</sub> + L<sub>B</sub>/R<sub>B</sub> + L<sub>C</sub>/R<sub>C</sub> - L<sub>R</sub>/R<sub>R</sub>, where L<sub>R</sub> and R<sub>R</sub> are the center and radius of the Lucas radical circle (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</b><p>
There exist three congruent squares U, V, W positioned in ABC as
follows: U has opposing vertices on segments AB and AC; V has opposing
vertices on segments BC and BA; W has opposing vertices on segments CA
and CB, and there is a single point common to U, V, W. The common
point, X(371), may have first been published in Kenmotu's <i>Collection
of Sangaku Problems</i> in 1840, indicating that its first appearance
may have been anonymously inscribed on a wooden board hung up in a
Japanese shrine or temple. (The Kenmotu configuration uses only
half-squares; i.e., isosceles right triangles). Trilinears were found
by John Rigby.
</p><p>
The edgelength of the three squares is
2<sup>1/2</sup>abc/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> +
4&sigma;), where &sigma; = area(ABC). (Edward Brisse, 2/12/2000)</p>
<p>X(371) is the internal center of similitude of the circumcircle and
the 2nd Lemoine circle (cosine circle) (Peter J. C. Moses, 5/9/03).
Also, X(371) is the internal center of similitude of the Gallatly
circle (defined just before X(2007)) and the 1st Lemoine circle (Peter
J. C. Moses, 9/10/2003).
</p><p>
X(371) is the perspector of several pairs of triangles associated
with Lucas circles. Some of these triangles are defined at MathWorld;
e.g. <a href="http://mathworld.wolfram.com/LucasCentralTriangle.html" style=
"font-weight: bold">Lucas Central Triangle</a>, and others are
Lucas(L:W) configurations. The latter are generalizations of
configurations associated with Lucas circles, in which the squares are
replaced by rectangles of length-to-width ratio L:W, with length on the
corresponding sideline of ABC. A negative ratio indicates that the
rectangles are directed inward; e.g. Lucas(-1:1) indicates
inward-directed squares, whereas Lucas(1:1) indicates the classical
case of outward-directed squares. These generalizations and the
following properties of X(371) were contributed by Randy Hutson,
9/23/2011. See also X(372) and X(1084).
</p><p>
<b>Hidetoshi Fukagawa and John F. Rigby,</b> <i>Traditional Japanese
Mathematics Problems of the 18th and 19th Centuries,</i> SCT
Publishing, Singapore, 2002. Reviewed, together with the Fukagawa and
Pedoe book, <i>Japanese Tempe Geometry Problems: San Gaku,</i> by Clark
Kimberling in <i>The Mathematical Intelligencer</i> 28, no. 1 (Winter
2006) 61-63.
</p><p style="font-weight: bold">Floor van Lamoen, <a href=
"http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant3.html" style=
"font-style: italic">Vierkanten in een driehoik: 3. Congruente
vierkanten</a>
<p style="font-weight: bold">Tony Rothman, with the cooperation of
Hidetoshi Fukagawa, <a href= "http://www.sciam.com/1998/0598issue/0598rothman.html">Japanese Temple
Geometry</a> (feature article in <i>Scientific American</i>)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Lucas central triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(371). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(371).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Kenmotu Point</a>.
</p><p>
X(371) lies on these lines:<br>2,486 3,6 4,485 5,590 25,493 140,615 193,488 315,491 492,641 601,606 602,605
</p><p>
X(371) is the {X(3),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(372). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(371), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(371) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (315,640), (372,32), (637,639)<br>
X(371) = isogonal conjugate of X(485)<br>
X(371) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(372)<br>
X(371) = inverse-in-1st-Lemoine-circle of X(2461)<br>
X(371) = complement of X(637)<br>
X(371) = anticomplement of X(639)<br>
X(371) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(372)<br>
X(371) = perspector of ABC and the Lucas tangents triangle<br>
X(371) = perspector of the Lucas central triangle and the anticevian triangle of X(6)<br>
X(371) = perspector of the Lucas inner triangle and Lucas(-1:1) tangents triangle<br>
X(371) = perspector of the Lucas(4:3) central triangle and the circumcevian triangle of X(6)<br>
X(371) = perspector of the Lucas central triangle and the cevian triangle of X(588)<br>
X(371) = radical center of the Lucas(2:1) circles<br>
X(371) = X(481)-of-Lucas-central-triangle<br>
X(371) = perspector of ABC and 2nd Lucas(-1) secondary tangents triangle<br>
X(371) = perspector of tangential triangle and Lucas secondary central triangle<br>
X(371) = perspector of Lucas inner tangential triangle and Lucas(-1) central triangle<br>
X(371) = inverse-in-2nd-Brocard-circle of X(3103)<br>
X(371) = inverse-in-Lucas-radical-circle of X(2460)<br>
X(371) = exsimilicenter of circumcircle and Lucas radical circle<br>
X(371) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of outer Vecten circle<br>
X(371) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): (3,3311,6), (3,3312,1152), (6,1151,3), (6,1152,3312), (1151,3311,372), (1152,3312,372)
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X372">X(372) = {X(3),X(6)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(371)</h3>
Trilinears cos(A + &pi;/4) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears a(S<sub>A</sub> - S) : :
<br>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - 2S) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(A + &pi;/4) : :
</p><p>
X(372) is the external center of similitude of the circumcircle and the 2nd Lemoine circle (cosine circle) (Peter J. C. Moses, 5/9/03). Also, X(372) is the external center of similitude of the Gallatly circle (defined just before X(2007)) and the 1st Lemoine circle (Peter J. C. Moses, 9/10/03).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Lucas(-1) central triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(372). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(372).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">2nd Kenmotu Point</a>.
</p><p>
X(372) lies on these lines:<br>
2,485 3,6 4,486 5,615 25,494 140,590 193,487 315,492 601,605 602,606
</p><p>
X(372) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (315,639), (371,32), (638,640)<br>
X(372) = isogonal conjugate of X(486)<br>
X(372) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(371)<br>
X(372) = inverse-in-1st-Lemoine-circle of X(2462)<br>
X(372) = complement of X(638)<br>
X(372) = anticomplement of X(640)<br>
X(372) = X(4)-Ceva conjugate of X(371)<br>
X(372) = perspector of ABC and the Lucas(-1:1) tangents triangle<br>
X(372) = perspector of the tangential triangle and the Lucas(-1) central triangle<br>
X(372) = perspector of the Lucas(-1:1) inner tangential triangle and the Lucas central triangle<br>
X(372) = perspector of the Lucas(-4:3) central triangle and the circumcevian triangle of X(6)<br>
X(372) = perspector of the Lucas(-1:1) central triangle and cevian triangle of X(589)<br>
X(372) = radical center of the Lucas(-2:1) circles<br>
X(372) = perspector of ABC and 2nd Lucas secondary tangents triangle<br>
X(372) = perspector of tangential triangle and Lucas(-1) secondary central triangle<br>
X(372) = perspector of Lucas(-1) inner triangle and Lucas tangents triangle<br>
X(372) = inverse-in-2nd-Brocard-circle of X(3102)<br>
X(372) = inverse-in-Lucas(-1)-radical-circle of X(2459)<br>
X(372) = perspector of ABC and the free vertices of the Kenmotu squares (described at X(371))<br>
X(372) = insimilicenter of circumcircle and Lucas(-1) radical circle<br>
X(372) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of inner Vecten circle<br>
X(372) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): (3,3311,1151), (3,3312,6), (6,1151,3311), (6,1152,3), (1151,3311,371), (1152,3312,371)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X373">X(373) = CENTROID OF THE PEDAL TRIANGLE OF THE CENTROID</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 2bc + ac cos C + ab cos B
<br>
=
g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = a(b<sup>4</sup> +
c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>
- 6b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics h(a,b,c) : h(b,c,a) : h(c,a,b), where
h(a,b,c) = 2abc + ca<sup>2</sup>cos C + ba<sup>2</sup>cos B
<br><br>
X(373) = 2*X(2) + X(51)
</b><p>
X(373) lies on these lines: 2,51 5,113 110,575 181,748 216,852 354,375 597,2854
</p><p>
X(373) = isogonal conjugate of X(11169)<br>
X(373) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(352)X(1499)<br>
X(373) = {X(2),X(51)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3917)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X374">X(374) = CENTROID OF THE PEDAL TRIANGLE OF X(9)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) :
f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 2b + 2c - 3a + (c + a)cos C + (b
+ a)cos B
<br>
Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>
X(374) lies on these lines: 6,354 9,517 44,65 51,210 966,3740
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X375">X(375) = CENTROID OF THE PEDAL TRIANGLE OF X(10)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 2bc(b + c) + ca(c + a)cos C +
ab(a + b)cos B<br>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>X(375) lies on these lines: 44,181 51,210
354,373</p>
<p>X(375) = midpoint of X(51) and X(210)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X376">X(376) = CENTROID OF THE ANTIPEDAL TRIANGLE OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears 5 cos A - cos(B - C) : 5 cos B - cos(C - A) : 5 cos C - cos(A - B)
<br>
Trilinears 2 cos A - cos B cos C : 2 cos B - cos C cos A : 2 cos C - cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A - sin B sin C : 3 cos B - sin C sin A : 3 cos C - sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears sec A - 2 sec B sec C : sec B - 2 sec C sec A : sec C - 2 sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)(5 sin 2A - sin 2B - sin 2C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a/(b sec B + c sec C) - 2 cos A : :
<br>
Barycentrics 5 sin 2A - sin 2B - sin 2C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2*SA*a^2 - SB*SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics 5 a^4 - 4 a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(376) has Shinagawa coefficients (2, -3).
</p><p>
Let Pa be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC. Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt Pa. Define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. X(376) = X(69) of triangle A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ma be the polar of X(4) wrt the circle centered at A and passing through X(2), and define Mb, Mc cyclically. (Note: X(4) is the perspector of any circle centered at a vertex of ABC.) Let A" = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B", C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, and its orthocenter is X(376). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Aa, Ab, Ac be the centers of the inverse-in-A-excircle of lines BC, CA, AB, resp. Let A' be the point of concurrence of lines AAa, BAb, CAc. Define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the excentral triangle at X(376). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(376) lies on these lines:<br>1,553 2,3 35,388 36,497
40,519 55,1056 56,1058
69,74 98,543 103,544
104,528 110,541 112,577
165,515 316,1007 390,999
476,841 477,691 487,490
488,489 516,551 524,1350

X(376) is the {X(3),X(20)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(376), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X377">X(377) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(7)X(8)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - 2abc(a + b + c))
<br>
=
g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = cos A +(cos A + cos B
+ cos C) cos B cos C<br>Barycentrics h(a,b,c) : h(b,c,a) : h(c,a,b), where h(a,b,c)
= b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>4</sup> -
2b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - 2abc(a + b + c)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(377) has Shinagawa coefficients (abc*$a, 2S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(377) lies on these lines:<br>
{1, 224}, {2, 3}, {7, 8}, {10, 46}, {12, 1259}, {56, 2886}, {58, 1714}, {72, 5905}, {77, 5930}, {78, 226}, {79, 5692}, {81, 387}, {84, 5587}, {100, 3085}, {142, 950}, {145, 1056}, {149, 1058}, {171, 5230}, {200, 5290}, {225, 1038}, {274, 315}, {278, 4296}, {283, 1754}, {318, 1947}, {329, 3876}, {348, 3188}, {355, 1071}, {394, 3193}, {495, 5687}, {497, 2646}, {498, 3822}, {516, 5250}, {527, 3951}, {528, 3303}, {908, 936}, {938, 5175}, {940, 1834}, {942, 3419}, {958, 3925}, {960, 1836}, {962, 3877}, {965, 1901}, {966, 2245}, {993, 3841}, {1001, 6284}, {1060, 1068}, {1125, 1479}, {1155, 2551}, {1159, 3621}, {1210, 3306}, {1220, 4429}, {1329, 4413}, {1330, 5739}, {1454, 1788}, {1621, 4294}, {1698, 3585}, {1765, 5816}, {1771, 3561}, {1837, 3812}, {1935, 3215}, {2096, 5818}, {2182, 5749}, {2287, 5746}, {2327, 5747}, {2345, 5279}, {2549, 5283}, {2893, 5738}, {2975, 4293}, {3086, 5253}, {3189, 3475}, {3304, 3813}, {3361, 5231}, {3421, 3617}, {3476, 4861}, {3485, 4511}, {3583, 3624}, {3618, 5135}, {3679, 5270}, {3710, 3729}, {3767, 5277}, {3869, 4295}, {3873, 5178}, {3897, 5731}, {3916, 5791}, {4000, 5262}, {4255, 5718}, {4298, 4847}, {4302, 5248}, {4312, 5785}, {4359, 5016}, {4652, 5745}, {4999, 5204}, {5217, 6690}, {5219, 5438}, {5225, 5550}, {5254, 5275}, {5256, 5717}, {5276, 5286}, {5334, 5367}, {5335, 5362}, {5439, 5722}, {5691, 5732}, {5715, 6282}, {5927, 6259}

<h3 id="X378">X(378) = REFLECTION OF X(22) IN X(3)</h3>
Trilinears sec A + 2 cos A : sec B + 2 cos B : sec C + 2 cos C
<br>
Barycentrics tan A + sin 2A : tan B + sin 2B : tan C + sin 2C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2 + 4 b^2 c^2)/(b^2 + c^2 - a^2) : :
<b><br>
X(378) = 6 X(2) + (J^2 + 3) X(3) = 2 X(3) - X(22)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(378) has Shinagawa coefficients (2F, E - 2F).
</p><p>
X(378) lies on these lines:<br>1,1063 2,3 6,74 33,36

<h3 id="X379">X(379) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(6)X(7)</h3>

<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = a<sup>5</sup> + (b + c)(bca<sup>2</sup> - (bc + ca + ab)(b - c)<sup>2</sup>)

<h3 id="X381">X(381) = MIDPOINT OF X(2) AND X(4)</h3>
Trilinears 2 cos(B - C) - cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + 4 cos B cos C : :
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A - 4 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)(2 tan A + tan B + tan C) + 2 sec A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(cos A + 4 cos B cos C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^4 - 2b^4 - 2c^4 + a^2b^2 + a^2c^2 + 4b^2c^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics S^2 + 3 SB SC : :
<b><br>
X381) = X(2) + X(4) = X(3) + 2 X(4)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(381) has Shinagawa coefficients (1,3).
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection of X(3) in A, and define B'and C'
cyclically. Let A'' be the reflection of X(3) in BC, and define B'' and
C'' cyclically. The lines A'A'', B'B'', C'C'' concur in X(381).
</p><p>
X(381) is the point QA-P14 (Centroid of the Morley Triangle) of quadrangle ABCX(2) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/42-qa-p14.html)
</p><p>
Let Pa be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC. Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt Pa. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The symmedian point of triangle A'B'C' is X(381). Analogously, let La be the trilinear polar of A wrt BCX(3), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A'=Lb&cap;Lc, B'=Lc&cap;La, C'=La&cap;Lb. Equivalently, A'B'C' is the cevian triangle of X(3) wrt the cevian triangle of X(3). Also, let A" be the reflection of A' in BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(381). Finally, let A' be the orthocenter of BCX(6), and define B' and C' cyclically; then X(381) is the centroid of A'B'C'.
(Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Sa be the similitude center of the orthocentroidal triangle and the A-altimedial triangle. Define Sb and Sc cyclically. The lines ASa, BSb, CSc concur in X(381). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A1B1C1 and A2B2C2 be the 1st and 2nd Ehrmann circumscribing triangles. Let A' be the crosspoint of A1 and A2, and define B', C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(381). (Randy Hutson, June 27, 2018)
</p><p>
X(381) lies on the McCay circumcircle and these lines:<br>2,3 6,13 11,999 49,578
51,568 54,156 98,598
114,543 118,544 119,528
125,541 127,133 155,195
183,316 184,567 210,517
262,671 264,339 298,622
299,621 302,616 303,617
355,519 388,496 495,497
511,599 515,551
</p><p>
X(381) is the {X(4),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3) and also the {X(13),X(14)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(381), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p> <p>
X(381) = midpoint of X(2) and X(4)<br>

<h3 id="X382">X(382) = REFLECTION OF CIRCUMCENTER IN ORTHOCENTER</h3>
Trilinears cos A - 4 cos B cos C : cos B - 4 cos C cos A : cos C - 4 cos A cosB
<br>
Trilinears 5 cos A - 4 sin B sin C : 5 cos B - 4 sin C sin A : 5 cos C - 4 sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears 4 sec A - sec B sec C : :
<br>
Trilinears 4 cos A - cos B cos C - 3 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + 6 cos B cos C - 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears 4 cos B cos C - 2 sin B sin C + cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears 5 cos A - cos(B - C) + cos B cos C - 3 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(cos A - 4 cos B cos C) : b(cos B - 4 cos C cos A) : c(cos C - 4 cos A cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics 3 a^4 - a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - 2 (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<b><br>
X(382) = 6 X(2) - 5 X(3) = X(3) - 2 X(4)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(382) has Shinagawa coefficients (1,-5).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the reflection triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole, wrt A'B'C', of line BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(382). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p> <p>
X(382) lies on these lines: 2,3 64,265 155,399 185,568 195,1498 355,516 952,962
</p> <p>
X(382) is the {X(5),X(20)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(382), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.

X(382) = {X(2),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(15720)<br>

<h3 id="X383">X(383) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(14)X(98)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where
<br>
f(A,B,C) = csc(B - C) [sin 2B cos(C - &omega;) sin(C + &pi;/3) - sin 2C cos(B - &omega;) sin(B + &pi;/3)]
<p>
Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin C)f(C,A,B)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(383) has Shinagawa coefficients (S, -3<sup>1/2</sup>(E + F)).
</p><p>
X(383) lies on these lines: 2,3 13,262 14,98 183,621 299,511 325,622
</p> <p>
X(383) = reflection of X(1080) in X(1513)<br>

<h3 id="X384">X(384) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(32)X(76)</h3>
Trilinears bc(a<sup>4</sup>
+ b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : ca(b<sup>4</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup>) : ab(c<sup>4</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>)<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> :
b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>a<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>4</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(384) has Shinagawa coefficients (E + F)<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup>, 2S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
A center on the Euler line; contributed by John Horton Conway, email, 1998.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(384). (Randy Hutson, December 11, 2015)
</p><p>
Let La be the line through the 2nd Brocard circle intercepts (other than PU(1)) of lines AP(1) and AU(1); define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. The triangle A'B'C' is here introduced as the 6th Brocard triangle; A'B'C' is homothetic to the 1st Brocard triangle at X(384), homothetic to the 1st anti-Brocard triangle at X(3), and perspective to the 3rd Brocard triangle at X(384). The 2nd Brocard circle of ABC is the 1st Lemoine circle of A'B'C'. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard-reflected triangle. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate of A', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(384). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(384) lies on these lines: {1, 335}, {2, 3}, {6, 194}, {31, 17033}, {32, 76}, {37, 20136}, {39, 83}, {58, 17034}, {61, 12204}, {62, 12205}, {69, 5017}, {75, 4426}, {98, 6248}, {112, 1235}, {115, <h3 id="X385">X(385) = X(2)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(6)</h3>
Trilinears bc(a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot B + cot C - cot A - tan &omega; : :
<p>
Contributed by John Horton Conway, 1998.
</p><p>
X(385) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle
of the conic that passes through A, B, C, and the pair P(1) and U(1) of
bicentric points (see the notes just before X(1908). (Randy Hutson,
9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(385). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
Let La be the line through A parallel to the Lemoine axis, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let Ma be the reflection of BC in La, and define Mb and Mc cyclically.
Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B', C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the Lemoine axis. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(325) and centroid X(385); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
X(385) lies on the anti-Brocard circle, the anti-McCay circumcircle, and these lines: {1, 257}, {2, 6}, {3, 194}, {4, 7823}, {5, 7762}, {15, 5980}, {16, 5981}, {20, 6392}, {21, 1655}, {22, 3164}, {23, <h3 id="X386">X(386) = INVERSE-IN-BROCARD-CIRCLE OF X(58)</h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc + ca + ab) : :
<br>
Trilinears r cos A + s sin A : : , where s = semiperimeter, r = inradius
<br>
Trilinears sin(A + U) : : , where cot U = cot(A/2) cot(B/2) cot(C/2)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc + ca + ab) : :
</p><p>
X(386) is the external center of similitude of the circumcircle and Apollonius circle. The internal center is X(573). (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)
</p><p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of the midpoint of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inscribed in the Apollonius circle and homothetic to the 2nd circumperp triangle at X(386). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(386) lies on these lines: {1, 2}, {3, 6}, {4, 2051}, {5, 1834}, {9, 10467}, {11, 9555}, {12, 9552}, {20, 9535}, {21, 1724}, {22, 9571}, {24, 9570}, {31, 35}, {34, 14018}, {36, 1468}, {37, 5044}, <h3 id="X388">X(388) = X(1)X(4)&cap;X(7)X(8)</h3>
Trilinears bc[a<sup>2</sup> + (b + c)<sup>2</sup>]/(b + c - a)
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos B cos C : 1 + cos C cos A : 1 + cos A cos B
<br>
Barycentrics [a<sup>2</sup> + (b + c)<sup>2</sup>]/(b + c - a)
<br><b>
X(388) = 2(R/r)*X(1) + 3X(2) - 2X(3)
</b><p>

</p><p>

X(388) = homothetic center of anti-inverse-in-incircle triangle and anti-tangential midarc triangle<br>
X(388) = centroid of curvatures of anticomplementary circle and excircles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X389">X(389) = CENTER OF THE TAYLOR CIRCLE</h3>
Trilinears cos A - cos 2A cos(B - C) : cos B - cos 2B cos(C - A) : cos C - cos 2C cos(A - B) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin A (tan A + tan B + tan C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A (cot A cot B cot C) - sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a[cos A - cos 2A cos(B - C)] : b[cos B - cos 2B cos(C - A)] : c[cos C - cos 2C cos(A - B)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2[a^6(b^2 + c^2) - 3a^4(b^4 + c^4) + 3a^2(b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^4 + c^4)] : :
<p>
If ABC is acute then X(389) is the Spieker center of the orthic triangle. Peter Yff reports (Sept. 19, 2001) that since X(389) is on the Brocard axis, there must exist T for which X(389) is sin(A+T) : sin(B+T) : sin(C+T), and that tan(T) = - cot A cot B cot C.
</p><p>
Let H<sub>A</sub> be the A-altitude of triangle ABC, and let A' be the midpoint of segment AH<sub>A</sub>. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A' parallel to AO, where O denotes the circumcenter. Define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. The lines L<sub>A</sub>, L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> concur in X(389). (Construction by Alexei Myakishev, March 24, 2010.)
</p><p>
Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circle with center A tangent to line BC, and define O<sub>B</sub> and O<sub>C</sub> cyclically. X(389) is the radical center of the three circles. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle, let A'' be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The triangle A''B''C'' is homothetic to A'B'C', and the center of homothety is X(389). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let Oa be the circle with center A tangent to line B'C', and define Ob and Oc cyclically. The radical circle of Oa, Ob, Oc is the Taylor circle, which is also the Spieker radical circle of the orthic triangle if ABC is acute. (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. X(389) is the radical center of the polar circles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B'. (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
A construction of X(389) is given at <a href="https://beta.groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/24162"> 24162</a>.
(Antreas Hatzipolakis, August 29, 2016)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(389).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(389)</a>.
</p><p>
X(389) lies on these lines:<br>3,6 4,51 24,184 30,143
54,186 115,129 217,232 517,950
</p><p>
X(389) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,52), (4,185), (974,1112)<br>
X(389) = reflection of X(1216) in X(140)<br>
X(389) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(578)<br>
X(389) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(54)<br>
X(389) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,5), (6,418)<br>
X(389) = orthology center of half-altitude and orthic triangles<br>
X(389) = complement of X(4) wrt orthic triangle<br>
X(389) = X(20)-of-polar-triangle-of-complement-of-polar-circle<br>
X(389) = X(10)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(389) = X(4)-of-1st-Hyacinth-triangle<br>
X(389) = {X(61),X(62)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3284)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X390">X(390) REFLECTION OF GERGONNE POINT IN INCENTER</h3>
Trilinears bc(b + c - a)[3a<sup>2</sup> + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>]
<br>
Barycentrics (b + c - a)[3a<sup>2</sup> + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>]
<br><b>X(390) = 4(R/r)*X(1) - 3X(2) + 4X(3)
</b><p>
X(390) is the point in whIch the extended legs X(1)X(7) and X(8)X(9) of the trapezoid X(1)X(7)X(8)X(9) meet. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extangents-to-intangents similarity image of ABC. A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(55) and to the anticomplementary triangle at X(390). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(390) lies on these lines:<br>1,7 2,11 3,1058 4,495
8,9 30,1056 40,938
144,145 376,999 387,595
496,631 944,971 952,1000</p>
<p>
X(390) = midpoint of X(144) and X(145)<br>
X(390) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (7,1), (8,9)<br>
X(390) = anticomplement of X(2550)<br>
X(390) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(657)X(665)<br>
X(390) = inverse-in-Feuerbach-hyperbola of X(2)<br>
X(390) = {X(1),X(20)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3600)<br>
X(390) = {X(175),X(176)}-harmonic conjugate of X(279)<br>
X(390) = bicentric sum of PU(122)<br>

<h3 id="X391">X(391) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(2,6) AND X(8,9)</h3>
Trilinears bc(3a + b + c)(b + c - a) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (3a + b + c)(b + c - a) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup> : b<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>
<p>

75,144 319,344

of other harmonic conjugates of X(391), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.

<h3 id="X392">X(392) = X(1,6)&cap;X(10,11)</h3>
Trilinears (b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) + 4abc : :
<p>
X(392) lies on the Thomson-Gibert-Moses hyperbola and these lines: (pending)<br>
</p><p>
X(392) = {X(1),X(9)}-harmonic conjugate of X(956)<br>
X(392) = X(2)-of-X(1)-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(392) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(4220)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X393">X(393) = X(25)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears bc tan<sup>2</sup>A : ca tan<sup>2</sup>B : ab tan<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Trilinears sec A - csc B csc C : sec B - csc C csc A : sec C - csc A csc B
<br>
Trilinears sec A tan A : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(sin A - csc A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan<sup>2</sup>A : tan<sup>2</sup>B : tan<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Barycentrics (tan A)/(cot B + cot C - cot &omega;) : :
<br>
Barycentrics [a^4 - (b^2 - c^2)^2]^2 : :
<p>
Let Ha be the foot of the A-altitude of ABC. Let Pa be the foot of the altitude from Ha to AB, and Qa the foot of the altitude from Ha to CA. Define Hb, Hc, Pb, Pc, Qb, Qc cyclically. Let A' be the trilinear pole of line PaQa, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(393). Lines PaQa, PbQb, PcQc are the antiparallels in the construction of the Taylor circle. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the Euler and anti-Euler triangles, resp. Let A* be the barycentric product A'*A'', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(393). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" be the cevapoint of the (real or imaginary) circumcircle intercepts of line B'C'. Define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(393). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(393) is the Brianchon point (perspector) of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of the orthic axis. The center of this inellipse is X(3767). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(393) lies on these lines:<br>1,836 2,216 4,6 19,208
20,577 24,254 25,1033
27,967 33,42 37,158
69,297 107,111 193,317
230,459 278,1108 342,948
394,837 800,1093 3146,3284
</p><p>
X(393) = isogonal conjugate of X(394)<br>
X(393) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(459)<br>
X(393) = X(25)-cross conjugate of X(4)<br>
X(393) = crosssum of X(577) and X(1092)<br>
X(393) = isotomic conjugate of X(3926)<br>
X(393) = anticomplement of X(6389)<br>
X(393) = cevapoint of X(5412) and X(5413)<br>
X(393) = barycentric square of X(4)<br>
X(393) = trilinear pole of line X(460)X(512) (the polar of X(69) wrt polar circle, and radical axis of nine-point circle and orthosymmedial circle)<br>
X(393) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(69) (line X(441)X(525))<br>
X(393) = polar conjugate of X(69)<br>
X(393) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these {i,j}: {1,394}, {31,3926}, {48,69}, {92,1092}<br>

<h3 id="X394">X(394) = X(69)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(3)</h3>
Trilinears cos A cot A : cos B cot B : cos C cot C
<br>
Trilinears sin A - csc A : :
<<br>
Trilinears a cot<sup>2</sup>A : :
<br>
Barycentrics cos<sup>2</sup>A : cos<sup>2</sup>B : cos<sup>2</sup>C
<br>
Barycentrics 1 - tan B tan C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)^2 : :
<p>
Let A' be the trilinear pole of the tangent to the circumcircle at the antipode of A, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(394). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" be the crosssum of the (real or imaginary) circumcircle intercepts of line B'C'. Define B" andC" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(393).
(Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(394) lies on these lines: 2,6 3,49

<h3 id="X395">X(395) = MIDPOINT OF X(14) AND X(16)</h3>
Trilinears cos(B - C) + 2 cos(A + &pi;/3) : :
<p>
X(395) is the center of the (equilateral) pedal triangle of X(16), as well as the circumcenter of the pedal triangle of X(14).
</p><p>
Let F = X(14), the 2nd Fermat point. Let Ab be the point on CA and Ac the point on AB such that FAbAc is an equilateral triangle. Let A' be the midpoint of FAbAc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C', here named the <b>8th Fermat-Dao equilateral triangle</b>, is perspective to ABC. The circumcircle of A'B'C' is the pedal circle of X(14) and (X16), and the centroid of A'B'C' is X(395). The perspector of ABC and A'B'C' is X(2), and the centroid of A'B'C' is X(395).
See X(16247), X(16267), and X(16459). (Based on notes from Dao Thanh Dao, March 15, 2018)
</p><p>
You can view <a href="Fermat-Dao_7-8.gif"><b>7th and 8th Fermat-Dao equilateral triangles</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(395) lies on these lines:<br>2,6 3,398 5,13 14,16
15,549 39,618 53,472
61,140 115,530 187,531
202,495 216,465 466,577
532,624 533,619
</p><p>
X(395) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (14,16), (298,385)<br>
X(395) = reflection of X(396) in X(230)<br>
X(395) = isogonal conjugate of X(6151)<br>
X(395) = complement of X(299)<br>
X(395) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(14)<br>
X(395) = crosssum of X(6) and X(16)<br>
X(395) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(15)X(512)<br>
X(395) = barycentric products X(13)*X(533), X(14)*X(619)<br>
X(395) = {X(2),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(396)<br>
X(395) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(619)<br>
X(395) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(619)<br>
X(395) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(619)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X396">X(396) = MIDPOINT OF X(13) AND X(15)</h3>
Trilinears cos(B - C) + 2 cos(A - &pi;/3) : :
<p>
X(396) is the center of the (equilateral) pedal triangle of X(15), as well as the circumcenter of the pedal triangle of X(13).
</p><p>
X(396) is the centroid of the points Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb in the construction of the 3rd Fermat-Dao equilateral triangle; see X(16267). Also, X(396) is the center of the ellipse passing through these six points. (Randy Hutson, March 14, 2018)
</p><p>
Let F = X(13), the 1st Fermat point. Let Ab be the point on CA and Ac the point on AB such that FAbAc is an equilateral triangle. Let A' be the midpoint of FAbAc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C', here named the <b>7th Fermat-Dao equilateral triangle</b>, is perspective to ABC. The circumcircle of A'B'C' is the pedal circle of X(13) and (X15), and the centroid of A'B'C' is X(396). The perspector of ABC and A'B'C' is X(2), and the centroid of A'B'C' is X(396).
</p><p>
If you have GeoGebra, you can view <a href="X(396).ggb"><b>X(396)</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(396) lies on these lines:<br>2,6 3,397 5,14 13,15
16,549 39,619 53,473
62,140 115,531 187,530
203,495 216,466 465,577
532,618 533,623
</p><p>
X(396) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (13,15), (299,385)<br>
X(396) = reflection of X(395) in X(230)<br>
X(396) = isogonal conjugate of X(2981)<br>
X(396) = anticomplement of X(298)<br>
X(396) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(13)<br>
X(396) = crosssum of X(6) and X(15)<br>
X(396) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(16)X(512)<br>
X(396) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(618)<br>
X(396) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(618)<br>
X(396) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(618)<br>
X(396) = barycentric products X(14)*X(532), X(13)*X(618)<br>
X(396) = {X(2),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(395)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X397">X(397) CROSSPOINT OF X(4) AND X(17)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = cos(B - C) - 2 cos(A +
&pi;/3)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,B,A)
<p>X(397) lies on these lines: 3,396 4,6
5,13 14,546 15,550
16,17 30,61 51,462
141,634 184,463 202,496
524,633 532,635</p>
<p>X(397) is the {X(4),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(398). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(397), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.</p>
<p>X(397) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(17)<br>X(397) = crosssum of X(3) and X(61)</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X398">X(398) CROSSPOINT OF X(4) AND X(18)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = cos(B - C) - 2 cos(A - &pi;/3)<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin C)f(C,B,A)
<p>
X(398) lies on these lines:<br>3,395 4,6 5,14 13,546
15,18 16,550 30,62
51,463 141,633 184,462
203,496 524,634 533,636</p>
<p>X(398) is the {X(4),X(6)}-harmonic conjugate of X(397). For a list
of other harmonic conjugates of X(398), click <b>Tables</b> at the top
of this page.</p>
<p>&gt; X(398) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(18)<br>X(398) = crosssum of X(3) and X(62)</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X399">X(399) = PARRY REFLECTION POINT</h3> <a id= "ParryReflectionPoint" name="ParryReflectionPoint"></a>
Trilinears 5 cos A - 4 cos B cos C - 8 sin B sin C cos<sup>2</sup>A : :
<br>
Barycentrics Barycentrics a^2[a^8 - 4a^6(b^2 + c^2) + a^4(6b^4 + b^2c^2 + 6c^4) - a^2(4b^6 - b^4c^2 - b^2c^4 + 4 c^6) + (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^4 + 4b^2c^2 + c^4)] : :
</p><p>
Let L, M, N be lines through A, B, C, respectively, parallel to the Euler line. Let L' be the reflection of L in sideline BC, let M' be the reflection of M in sideline CA, and let N' be the reflection of N in sideline AB. The lines L', M', N' concur in X(399), as proved in
</p><p>
<b>Cyril Parry,</b> Problem 10637, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 105 (1998) 68.
</p><p>
In <b>Cosmin Pohoata,</b> "On the Parry reflection point," <i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 8 (2008), 43-48 <a href="http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2008volume8/FG200806.pdf" style= "font-weight: bold">here</a>, the following is proved:
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection of vertex A in line BC, and define B', C' cyclically. Let A<sub>t</sub>B<sub>t</sub>C<sub>t</sub> be the tangential triangle of ABC. The circumcircles of the triangles A<sub>t</sub>B'C', A'B<sub>t</sub>C', A'B'C<sub>t</sub> concur in X(399). Moreover, the circumcircles of triangles A'B<sub>t</sub>C<sub>t</sub>, A<sub>t</sub>B'C<sub>t</sub>, A<sub>t</sub>B<sub>t</sub>C' concur in a point Q = X8157), here named the <b>Parry-Pohoata point</b>. Barycentric coordinates for Q, of degree 22 in a,b,c, were found by J. F. Garcia Captit&aacute;n (Hyacinthos #15827, Nov. 19, 2007) and are included in Pohoata's article. Pohoata notes that the point Q lies on the circumcircle of the points X(3), X(4), X(399).
</p><p>
Let I, I<sub>A</sub>, I<sub>B</sub>, I<sub>C</sub>, denote the incenter and excenters of ABC. Lawrence Evans (Hyacinthos #6878) found that the circumcircles of the triangles IA'I<sub>A</sub>, IB'I<sub>B</sub>, IC'<sub>C</sub> concur in X(399).
</p><p>
The Pohoata article includes a proof that the circumcircles of the triangles A'I<sub>B</sub>I<sub>C</sub>, I<sub>A</sub>B'I<sub>C</sub>, I<sub>A</sub>I<sub>B</sub>C' also pass through X(399). Similar results involving the Fermat points, X(13) and X(14), are proved.
</p><p>
Pohoata reports that the following points are concyclic: X(13), X(16), X(110), X(399), X(1338), as are the points X(14), X(15), X(110), X(399), X(1337). Randy Hutson adds (Aug. 13, 2012) that the first of
these circles also passes through X(2381), and the second, through X(2380).
</p><p>
X(399) is the point P on the line X(3)X(74) for which the P-Brocard triangle is perspective to ABC. (Randy Hutson, August 26, 2014)
</p><p>
Let AaBaCa, AbBbCb, AcBcCc be the A-, B- and C-anti-altimedial triangles. Let La be the line through Aa parallel to the Euler line of AaBaCa. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. The lines La, Lb, Lc concur in X(399). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(399) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines:<br>
1,3065 3,74 4,195 6,13 30,146 155,382 394,541 1337,3441 1338,3440 3466,3483
</p><p>
X(399) = isogonal conjugate of X(1138)<br>
X(399) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,110), (74,1511), (265,113)<br>
X(399) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (30,3), (323,6)<br>
X(399) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(1511)<br>
X(399) = tangential isogonal conjugate of X(2070)<br>
X(399) = antigonal image of X(1117)<br>
X(399) = orthocentroidal-to-ABC similarity image of X(3)<br>
X(399) = 4th-Brocard-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(3)<br>
X(399) = X(80)-of-tangential-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(399) = orthologic center of these triangles: reflection to 1st Hyacinth<br>
X(399) = orthologic center of these triangles: reflection to AOA<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X400">X(400) = YFF-MALFATTI POINT</h3> <a id="YffMalfattiPoint" name="YffMalfattiPoint"></a>
Trilinears csc<sup>4</sup>(A/4) : csc<sup>4</sup>(B/4) : csc<sup>4</sup>(C/4)<br>
Barycentrics sin A csc<sup>4</sup>(A/4) : sin B csc<sup>4</sup>(B/4) : sin C csc<sup>4</sup>(C/4)
<p>
In 1997, Yff considered the configuration for the 1st Ajima-Malfatti
point, X(179). He proved that the same tangencies are possible in
another way if the circles are not required to lie inside ABC. With
tangency points labeled as before, the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in
X(400). If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href=
"X(400).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(400)</a>.
<p></p> <p><br></p> <p><br></p>
<center>
<p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 401- 475,
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>2- 4, 20- 30, 376, 379, 381- 384 (and others) lie on the Euler line.</b><br><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"><br>
</center>
<h3 id="X401">X(401) = BAILEY POINT</h3>
<a id="BaileyPoint" name="BaileyPoint"></a>
Trilinears [sin 2B sin 2C - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A)](csc A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin 2B sin 2C - sin<sup>2</sup>(2A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics tan B + tan C - tan A - cot &omega; : :
<b><br>
X(401) = 3 SA SB SC SW X(2) - S^4 X(20)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(401) has Shinagawa coefficients (EF + F<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup>, 2S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(401) lies on these lines:<br>2,3 50,338 97,276 248,290 264,577 287,511 323,525
</p><p>
X(401) = reflection of X(297) in X(441)<br>
X(401) = isogonal conjugate of X(1987)<br>
X(401) = isotomic conjugate of X(1972)<br>
X(401) = anticomplement of X(297)<br>
X(401) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (287,2), (511,385)<br>
X(401) = crosspoint of X(276) and X(290)<br>
X(401) = crosssum of X(217) and X(237)<br>
X(401) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(51)X(647)<br>
X(401) = X(2)-Hirst inverse of X(3)<br>
X(401) = inverse-in-Steiner-circumellipse of X(3)<br>
X(401) = {X(2479),X(2480)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(401) = crossdifference of PU(157)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X402">X(402) = ZEEMAN-GOSSARD PERSPECTOR</h3>
<a id= "Zeeman-GossardPerspector" name="Zeeman-GossardPerspector"></a>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= p(a,b,c)y(a,b,c)/a, polynomials p and y as given below
<p>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where<br>
g(a,b,c)
= p(a,b,c)y(a,b,c), polynomials p and y as given below
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(402) has Shinagawa coefficients (5EF - 13F<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup>, 3EF + 3F<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
In <i>A History of Mathematics,</i> Florian Cajori writes, "H. C.
Gossard of the University of Oklahoma showed in 1916 that the three
Euler lines of the triangles formed by the Euler line and the sides,
taken by twos, of a given triangle, form a triangle . . . perspective
with the given triangle and having the same Euler line." Let ABC be the
given triangle and A'B'C' the Gossard triangle - that is, the triangle
perspective with the given triangle and having the same Euler line. The
lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(402), named the Gosssard perspector by
John Conway (1998).</p>
<p>Actually, X(402) dates back to an article by Christopher Zeeman in
<i>Wiskundige Opgaven</i> 8 (1899-1902) 305. For details, see Paul
Yiu's Hyacinthos message #7536 and others with Gossard in the subject
line. (In ETC, the change of name from Gossard Perspector to
Zeeman-Gossard Perspector was made on Oct. 15, 2003.) Further details
are given by Wilson Stothers in Hyacinthos #8383, Oct. 21, 2003.</p>
<p>Barycentrics for X(402) were received from Paul Yiu (2/20/99); the
polynomials p and y referred to above are given as
follows: </p>
<p>p(a,b,c) = 2a<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - (b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup></p>
<p>y(a,b,c) = a<sup>8</sup> - a<sup>6</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>) + a<sup>4</sup>(2b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup>)(2c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>) + [(b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>][3a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>) - b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup> -
3b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>]</p>
<p>X(402) lies on this line: 2,3</p>
<p>X(402) = complement of X(1650)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X403">X(403) = X(36) OF THE ORTHIC TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (sec A)(1 + cos 2B + cos 2C)
<br>
Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = (tan A)(1 + cos 2B + cos 2C)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(403) has Shinagawa coefficients (2F, 2F - E).
</p><p>
X(403) is centroid of the triangle having vertices X(4), P(4), U(4). (Regarding the bicentric pair P(4) and U(4), see the notes just before X(1908)). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection in BC of the A-vertex of the tangential triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', and CA'B' concur at the isogonal conjugate of X(403). Also, X(403) is the perspector of ABC and the reflection of the anticevian triangle of X(4) in the orthic axis (trilinear polar of X(4)). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
X(403) lies on these lines: 2,3 112,230 115,232 847,1093
</p><p>
X(403) = midpoint of X(4) and X(186)<br>
X(403) = reflection of X(186) in X(468)<br>
X(403) = isogonal conjugate of X(5504)<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(24)<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-nine-point-circle of X(4)<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(378)<br>
X(403) = complement of X(2071)<br>
X(403) = X(113)-cross conjugate of X(4)<br>
X(403) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(577)X(647)<br>
X(403) = X(36)-of-orthic-triangle if and only if ABC is acute<br>
X(403) = X(186)-of Euler-triangle<br>
X(403) = {X(4),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1594)<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(3)<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-{{circumcircle, nine-point circle}}-inverter of X(25)<br>
X(403) = reflection of X(186) in the orthic axis<br>
X(403) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(2986)<br>
X(403) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(2986)<br>
X(403) = perspector of the orthic triangle and the reflection of the Euler triangle in the Euler line<br>
X(403) = radical trace of polar and second Droz-Farny circles<br>
X(403) = inverse-in-second-Droz-Farny-circle of X(4)<br>
X(403) = Euler line intercept, other than X(403), of circle {X(403),X(858),PU(4)}<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X404">X(404) = {X(2),X(3)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(21)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc(a + b + c) - a(b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= abc(a + b + c) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(404) has Shinagawa coefficients (abc*$a$ - 2S<sup>2</sup>, 2S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(404) lies on these lines:<br>1,88 2,3 8,56 10,36
31,978 46,997 57,78
60,662 63,936 69,1014
81,386 104,355 108,318
145,999 149,496 603,651
612,988 976,982</p>
<p>X(404) is the {X(2),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(21). For a list of
harmonic conjugates of X(404), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.
<p></p>
X(404) = complement of X(320)<br> </p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X405">X(405) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(1)X(6)</h3>
Trilinears bc(a + b + c) + abc cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears bcS + raS<sub>A</sub> : :
<br>
Barycentrics b + c + a(1 + cos A) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a*(a^3 - a*b^2 - 2*a*b*c - 2*b^2*c - a*c^2 - 2*b*c^2) : :
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(405) has Shinagawa coefficients (abc*$a$ + S<sup>2</sup>, -S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(405) lies on these lines: {1, 6}, {2, 3}, {8, 943}, {10, 55}, {11, 19755}, {12, 10198}, {31, 5711}, {32, 5275}, {34, 1214}, {35, 1376}, {36, 3624}, {38, 19729}, {39, 19758}, {40, 1730}, {46, 3812},
