<h3 id="X406">X(406) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(10)X(33)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc(a + b + c) + abc sec A<br>Barycentrics b + c + a(1 + sec A) : c + a + b(1 + sec B) : a + b + c(1 + sec C)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(406) has Shinagawa coefficients ($a$F, abc).
</p><p>
<p>X(406) lies on these lines:<br>2,3 8,1061 10,33 37,158
92,1068 108,388 208,226 261,317</p>
<p>X(406) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(475)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X407">X(407) = CROSSPOINT OF X(4) AND X(225)</h3>
Trilinears (v +
w)sec A : (w + u)sec B : (u + v)sec C, where<br> u
: v : w = X(21); e.g., u = u(A,B,C) = 1/(cos B + cos C)
<p>Barycentrics (v + w) tan A : (w + u) tan B : (u + v) tan C
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(407) has Shinagawa coefficients (FS<sup>2</sup>, -($aS<sub>A</sub>$)<sup>2</sup> - FS<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(407) lies on these lines: 2,3 12,228
65,225 117,136</p>
<p>
X(407) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(225)<br>
X(407) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,283), (21,411)<br>
X(407) = tangential-to-orthic similarity image of X(3145)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X408">X(408) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(73)X(228)</h3>
Trilinears (v + w)cos A : (w + u)cos B : (u + v)cos C, where<br> u : v : w = X(29); e.g., u = u(A,B,C) = (sec A)/(cos B + cos C)
p>Barycentrics (v + w)sin 2A : (w + u)sin 2B : (u + v)sin2C
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(408) has Shinagawa coefficients (($bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$)<sup>2</sup>, -($bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$)<sup>2</sup> + EFS<sup>4</sup>).
</p><p>
X(408) lies on these lines: 2,3 73,228
</p> <p>
X(408) = crosssum of X(29) and X(412)<br>
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X409">X(409) = EULER X(21)-1st-SUBSTITUTION POINT</h3>
Trilinears u<sup>2</sup> + vw : v<sup>2</sup> + wu : w<sup>2</sup> + uv, where u : v : w = X(21); e.g., u = u(A,B,C) = 1/(cos B + cos C)
<p>
Barycentrics a(u<sup>2</sup> + vw) : b(v<sup>2</sup> + wu) : c(w<sup>2</sup> + uv)
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(409) has Shinagawa coefficients ($aS<sub>A</sub>$[($aS<sub>A</sub>$)<sup>2</sup> - $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$] + 2abcFS<sup>2</sup>, -$aS<sub>A</sub>$[($aS<sub>A</sub>$)<sup>2</sup> - $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$] + abc[($aS<sub>A</sub>$)<sup>2</sup> + $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$ - 2FS<sup>2</sup>]).
</p><p>
<p>X(409) lies on these lines: 2,3 65,1098</p>
<p>X(409) is the {X(21),X(29)}-harmonic conjugate of X(413). For a list
of harmonic conjugates of X(409), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(409) = crosspoint of PU(80) </p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X410">X(410) = EULER X(29)-1st-SUBSTITUTION POINT</h3>
Trilinears u<sup>2</sup> + vw : v<sup>2</sup> + wu : w<sup>2</sup> + uv, where<br>
u
: v : w = X(29); e.g., u = u(A,B,C) = (sec A)/(cos B + cos C)
<p>Barycentrics a(u<sup>2</sup> + vw) : b(v<sup>2</sup> +
wu) : c(w<sup>2</sup> + uv)</p>
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(410) has Shinagawa coefficients ([S<sup>6</sup> - (2E - F)FS<sup>4</sup> + 3$bc$FS<sup>4</sup> - 3$bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$FS<sup>2</sup>]F, -[S<sup>4</sup> - 4(E - F)FS<sup>2</sup> + 3$bc$FS<sup>2</sup>]FS<sup>2</sup> + $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$[S<sup>4</sup> - 2(E - 2F)F S<sup>2</sup> + abc$aS<sub>A</sub>$F]).
<p></p>
<p>X(410) lies on these lines: 2,3 73,2659 823,2660
</p>
<p>X(410) is the {X(21),X(29)}-harmonic conjugate of X(414). For a list
of harmonic conjugates of X(410), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.
</p><p>
X(410) = crosspoint of PU(82) </p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X411">X(411) = EULER X(21)-2nd-SUBSTITUTION POINT</h3>
Trilinears (1/v)<sup>2</sup>
+ (1/w)<sup>2</sup> - (1/u)<sup>2</sup> : (1/w)<sup>2</sup> +
(1/u)<sup>2</sup> - (1/v)<sup>2</sup> : (1/u)<sup>2</sup> +
(1/v)<sup>2</sup> - (1/w)<sup>2</sup>, where<br>
u : v : w = X(21); e.g., u = u(A,B,C) = 1/(cos B + cos C)
<br>
Trilinears g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = cos B cos C - (cos A + cos B + cos C)cos A
<br>
Barycentrics a[(1/v)<sup>2</sup> + (1/w)<sup>2</sup> -
(1/u)<sup>2</sup>] : b[(1/w)<sup>2</sup> + (1/u)<sup>2</sup> -
(1/v)<sup>2</sup>] : c[(1/u)<sup>2</sup> + (1/v)<sup>2</sup> -
(1/w)<sup>2</sup>]
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(411) has Shinagawa coefficients
($aS<sub>A</sub>$, -$aS<sub>A</sub>$ - abc).
</p><p>
X(411) lies on these lines: 2,3 35,516
40,78 55,962 81,581
165,936 185,970 243,821 255,651</p>
<p>X(411) is the {X(3),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(21). For a list of
harmonic conjugates of X(411), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this
page.</p>
<p></p>
X(411) = complement of X(6895)<br>
X(411) = anticomplement of X(6831)<br>
X(411) = {X(404),X(7411)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3)<br>

- $bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$]

+3$ab$F<sup>2</sup>S<sup>2</sup>, (E-2F)[(E+F)F- S<sup>2</sup>]S<sup>2</sup>

<h3 id="X426">X(426) = EULER X(19)-4th-SUBSTITUTION POINT</h3>
Trilinears (v<sup>2</sup> + w<sup>2</sup>)cos A : (w<sup>2</sup> + u<sup>2</sup>)cos B : (u<sup>2</sup> + v<sup>2</sup>)cos C, where
<br>

<p>
Barycentrics (v<sup>2</sup> + w<sup>2</sup>)sin 2A : (w<sup>2</sup> + u<sup>2</sup>)sin 2B : (u<sup>2</sup> + v<sup>2</sup>)sin 2C
</p><p>
</p> <p>

((2E + F)F - S<sup>2</sup>,-(E + F)F + S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(426) lies on these lines: <br> {2,3}, {125,2351}, {157,1853}, {394,2972}, {577,3917}, {1073,6090}, {3964,4176
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X427">X(427) = COMPLEMENT OF X(22)</h3>
Trilinears sec A + cos(B - C)
<br>
Barycentrics tan A + tan &omega; : :
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(427) has Shinagawa coefficients (F,E + F).
</p><p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line tangent to the nine-point circle at
the midpoint of segment BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub>
cyclically. The triangle formed by the lines L<sub>A</sub>,
L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> is homothetic to the orthic triangle, and
the center of homothety is X(427). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let (O) be the circumcircle, (N) the nine-point circle, and
(I<sub>A</sub>, (I<sub>B</sub>, (I<sub>C</sub> the excircles of ABC.
Let A' and A'' be the points of intersection of (O) and (I<sub>A</sub>.
Let F<sub>A</sub> be the touchpoint of (N) and (I<sub>A</sub>, and let
(K<sub>A</sub>) be the circle through A' and A'' that is internally
tangent to (N); let L<sub>A</sub> be the touchpoint. Define
F<sub>B</sub>, F<sub>C</sub> and L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub>
cyclically. The lines F<sub>A</sub>L<sub>A</sub>,
F<sub>B</sub>L<sub>B</sub>, F<sub>C</sub>L<sub>C</sub> concur ion
X(427). (Tran Quang Hung ADGEOM #1458, August 5, 2014; see also
#1459)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the circummedial triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(427). Moreover, X(427) is the Euler line intercept of radical axis of nine-point circle and every circle with center on orthic axis that is orthogonal to nine-point circle, and X(427) is the point in which the extended trapezoid legs (P(4),P(4)-Ceva conjugate of U(4)) and (U(4),U(4)-Ceva conjugate of P(4)) meet. Also, X(427) is the QA-P38 center (Montesdeoca-Hutson Point) of quadrangle ABCX(2). (Randy Hutson, October 13, 2015)
</p><p>
X(427) lies on these lines:<br>2,3 6,66 11,33 12,34
51,125 53,232 98,275 112,251 114,136 115,1560 183,317 230,571 264,305 343,511
</p><p>
X(427) = midpoint of X(4) and X(378)<br>
X(427) = isogonal conjugate of X(1176)<br>
X(427) = isotomic conjugate of X(1799)<br>
X(427) = inverse-in-nine-point-circle of X(468)<br>
X(427) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(25)<br>
X(427) = complement of X(22)<br>
X(427) = complementary conjugate of X(206)<br>
X(427) = X(112)-Ceva conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(427) = cevapoint of X(39) and X(1843)<br>
X(427) = X(39)-cross conjugate of X(141)<br>
X(427) = crosspoint of X(4) and X(264)<br>
X(427) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,184), (6,206)<br>
X(427) = X(4)-Hirst inverse of X(420)<br>
X(427) = X(55) of orthic triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(427) = exsimilicenter of nine-point circle and incircle of orthic triangle if ABC is acute; the insimilicenter is X(235)<br>
X(427) = intersection of tangents to nine-point circle at PU(4)<br>
X(427) = pole of orthic axis wrt the nine-point circle<br>
X(427) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(83) (line X(23)X(385))<br>
X(427) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(83)<br>
X(427) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(23)<br>
X(427) = inverse-in-orthosymmedial-circle of X(1112)<br>
X(427) = perspector of orthic and 5th Euler triangles<br>
X(427) = radical trace of anticomplementary circle and tangential circle<br>
X(427) = homothetic center of the medial triangle and the 2nd pedal triangle of X(4)<br>
X(427) = perspector of 4th Brocard triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 4th Brocard triangle<br>
X(427) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and 5th Euler triangle<br>
X(427) = harmonic center of nine-point circle and circle O(PU(4))<br>
X(427) = orthic-isogonal conjugate of X(1843)<br>
X(427) = intersection of tangents to Hatzipolakis-Lozada hyperbola at X(4) and X(6)<br>
X(427) = crosspoint, wrt orthic triangle, of X(4) and X(6)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X428">X(428) = EULER X(38)-5th-SUBSTITUTION POINT</h3>
Trilinears 3 sec A - csc A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears csc A - 3 sec A cot &omega; : :
</p><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(428) has Shinagawa coefficients (F,-3E - 3F).
</p><p>
Let V = P(4)-Ceva conjugate of U(4)) and W = U(4)-Ceva conjugate of P(4); then V and W lie on the orthocentroidal circle, and with with PU(4) they are the vertices of a cyclic trapezoid. The midpoint of V and W is X(428). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let H = X(4) and let A'B'C' be the pedal triangle of H in the plane of a triangle ABC. Let<br>
Bc = reflection of B' in HC', and define Ca and Ab cyclically;<br>
Cb = reflection of C' in HB', and define Ac and Ba cyclically;<br>
Ha = orthogonal projecton of A on BcCb, and define Hb and Hc cyclically.<br>
Then X(428) = centroid of triangle HaHbHc. See Antreas Hatzipolakis and Peter Moses, <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/27169"> <b>Hyacinthos 27169</b></a>
</p><p>
X(428) lies on these lines: 2,3 132,137
</p><p>
X(428) = X(354)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(428) = X(2) of 3rd pedal triangle of X(4)<br>
X(428) = {X(2),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5064)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

: v : w = X(58); e.g., u = u(a,b,c) = a/(b + c)
<p>Barycentrics (v + w)tan A : (w + u)tan B : (u + v)tan C
</p><p>

12,37 108,961 119,136 495,1068</p>

<h3 id="X442">X(442) COMPLEMENT OF SCHIFFLER POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc(v + w) : ca(w + u) : ab(u + v), where<br> u : v : w = X(284); e.g., u(A,B,C) = (sin A)/(cos B + cos C)<br>Barycentrics v + w : w + u : u + v
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(442) has Shinagawa coefficients
($aS<sub>A</sub>$ + abc,$aS<sub>A</sub>$ - abc)
</p><p>
Let I<sub>A</sub>, I<sub>B</sub>, I<sub>C</sub> be the excenters,
let A<sub>B</sub>, A<sub>C</sub> be the projections of A onto
I<sub>A</sub>I<sub>B</sub> and I<sub>A</sub>I<sub>C</sub>,
respectively, and define B<sub>C</sub>, B<sub>A</sub> and
C<sub>A</sub>, C<sub>B</sub> cyclically. The Euler lines of the four
triangles ABC, AA<sub>B</sub>A<sub>C</sub>,
BB<sub>C</sub>B<sub>A</sub>, CC<sub>A</sub>C<sub>B</sub> concur in
X(442). (Jean-Pierre Ehrmann, 11/24/01)</p>
<p>In the plane of triangle ABC, let DEF denote the intouch triangle of
ABC, and let<br>H<sub>A</sub> = orthocenter of IBC<br>M<sub>A</sub> = midpoint of segment BC<br>N<sub>A</sub> = midpoint of the arc BC which does not include A<br>S<sub>A</sub> = reflection of I in line DE,<br>and define cyclically the points H<sub>B</sub>, H<sub>C</sub>,
M<sub>B</sub>, M<sub>C</sub>, N<sub>B</sub>, N<sub>C</sub>, and
S<sub>B</sub>, S<sub>C</sub>. The lines S<sub>A</sub>M<sub>A</sub>,
S<sub>B</sub>M<sub>B</sub>, S<sub>CA</sub>M<sub>C</sub> concur in
X(442), and X(442) is the pole, with respect to the incircle, of the
perspectrix of the triangles H<sub>A</sub>H<sub>B</sub>H<sub>C</sub>
and N<sub>A</sub>&cap;<sub>B</sub>&cap;<sub>C</sub>. (Dominik Burek, January 18
2012)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle. X(442) is the radical center of the nine-point circles of A'BC, B'CA, C'AB. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016) </p><p>
Let (Ja) be the A-excircle of the A-altimedial triangle, and define (Jb) and (Jc) cyclically. X(442) is the radical center of (Ja), (Jb), (Jc). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(442) lies on these lines: 2,3 8,495
9,46 10,12 11,214
100,943 115,120 119,125
274,325 388,956 392,946
</p><p>
X(442) = midpoint of X(79) and X(191)<br>
X(442) = isogonal conjugate of X(1175)<br>
X(442) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(405)<br>
X(442) = complement of X(21)<br>
X(442) = complementary conjugate of X(960)<br>
X(442) = X(100)-Ceva conjugate of X(523)<br>
X(442) = crosspoint of X(264) and X(321)<br>
X(442) = crosssum of X(184) and X(1333)<br>
X(442) = perspector of Feuerbach triangle and 2nd extouch triangle<br>
X(442) = homothetic center of 4th Euler triangle and 2nd extouch triangle<br>
X(442) = X(54)-of-2nd-extouch-triangle<br>
X(442) = X(973)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X447">X(447) = X(2)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(27)</h3>
Trilinears bc(u<sup>2</sup>
- vw) : ca(v<sup>2</sup> - wu) : ab(w<sup>2</sup> - uv), where<br> u
: v : w = X(28); e.g., u(a,b,c) = (tan A)/(b + c)
<p>Barycentrics u<sup>2</sup> - vw : v<sup>2</sup> - wu :
w<sup>2</sup> - uv
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(447) has Shinagawa coefficients
(2(E+F)<sup>3</sup>FS<sup>2</sup>-2$abS<sub>C</sub>$(E+F)F
+$ab$[4(E+F)<sup>2</sup>-S<sup>2</sup>]F, -(E+F)(2E-F)S<sup>2</sup>-S<sup>4</sup>
+ 2($abS<sub>C</sub>$S<sup>2</sup>-$ab$(4E+F)S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(447) lies on this line: 2,3 340,540
350,811 519,648</p>
<p>X(447) = X(2)-Hirst inverse of X(27)</p>

<h3 id="X459">X(459) = X(253)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears (sec A)/(tan B + tan C - tan A) : :

<p>

<h3 id="X468">X(468) = X(2)-LINE CONJUGATE OF X(3)</h3>
Trilinears (sec A)(cot B + cot C - 2 cot A) : :
<br>
Trilinears sec A - 3 csc A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears 3 csc A - sec A cot &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b^2 + c^2 - 2a^2)/(b^2 + c^2 - a^2) : :
<br><b>
X(468) = 3X(2) + X(23)
</p> </b>
As a point on the Euler line, X(468) has Shinagawa coefficients (3F,-E - F).
</p><p>
Let (Pa) be the A-power circle of the A-altimedial triangle, and define (Pb) and (Pc) cyclically. The radical center of (Pa), (Pb), (Pc) is X(4), and the harmonic traces of (Pa), (Pb), (Pc) are X(2) and X(468). (Randy Hutson, November 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(468) lies on the Darboux quintic (Q071), the cubics K043, K164 ,K209, K217, K418, K452, K478, K533, K535, K600, K608, K698, K824, K869,K954, the GEOS circle, and on these lines: 2, 3}, {6, 5486}, <h3 id="X469">X(469) = EULER LINE INTERCEPT OF LINE X(92)X(264)</h3>
Trilinears u csc 2A : v csc 2B : w csc 2C, where<br>
u : v : w = X(386); e.g., u(a,b,c) = a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc + ca + ab)
<p>Barycentrics u sec A : v sec B : w sec C
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(469) has Shinagawa coefficients (F,E + F + $bc$).
</p><p>
X(469) lies on these lines: 2,3 92,264
226,273</p>
<p>X(469) is the {X(2),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(27). For a list of
other harmonic conjugates of X(469), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of
this page.</p>
<p>X(469) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(27)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X476">X(476) = TIXIER POINT</h3>
<a id="TixierPoint" name="TixierPoint"></a>
Trilinears 1/[(1 + 2 cos 2A) sin(B - C)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/{(b^2 - c^2)[(a^2 - b^2 - c^2)^2 - b^2c^2]} : :
<p>
The reflection of X(110) in the Euler line; X(476) is on the circumcircle. (Michel Tixier, 5/9/98). Also, X(476) is the center of the polar conic of X(30) with respect to the Neuberg cubic; this conic is a rectangular hyperbola passing through the incenter, the excenters, and X(30). (Peter Yff, 5/23/99)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, respectively parallel to the Euler line. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, respectively. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(476); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, respectively parallel to the orthic axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, respectively. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(476); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(476) is the center of the polar conic of X(30) with respect to the Neuberg cubic, which passes through the following points: incenter, excenters, X(30), X(5), X(523), and the excentral-isogonal conjugates of X(5663) and X(7724). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(476).gsp">X(476)</a>.
</p><p>
X(476) lies on the Hutson-Parry circle and these lines: 2, 842}, {3, 477}, {4, 16221}, {5, 14979}, {13, 2379}, {14, 2378}, {20, 2693}, {21, 2687}, {22, 2697}, {23, 94}, {24, 15112}, {30, 74}, {99, 850}, {100, 4036}, {101, 4024}, {102, 7424}, {103, 5196}, {104, 1325}, {105, 7469}, {106, 7478}, {107, 7480}, {109, 13486}, {110, 523}, {111, 230}, {112, 2501}, {125, 17511}, {143, 15907}, {146, 1553}, {183, 2857}, {186, 1300}, {250, 933}, {328, 2373}, {376, 841}, {403, 1299}, {468, 3563}, {511, 9161}, {512, 9160}, {524, 9184}, {526, 16170}, {549, 11749}, {655, 15439}, {691, 4226}, {729, 11060}, {755, 14902}, {759, 2166}, {804, 20404}, {843, 6792}, {858, 1297}, {915, 2074}, {917, 2073}, {930, 23181}, {935, 4230}, {953, 3109}, {1141, 2070}, {1290, 3658}, {1292, 7475}, {1294, 2071}, {1296, 7472}, {1298, 19167}, {1302, 1632}, {1304, 4240}, {1316, 2698}, {1379, 13722}, {1380, 13636}, {1494, 9141}, {1637, 23588}, {1648, 14846}, {1789, 2716}, {1995, 2453}, {2367, 20573}, {2395, 2715}, {2407, 10420}, {2409, 10423}, {2410, 9060}, {2452, 11422}, {2688, 4184}, {2689, 7450}, {2690, 4243}, {2691, 4236}, {2694, 16049}, {2695, 4225}, {2696, 11634}, {2706, 2979}, {2752, 4228}, {2758, 7419}, {2766, 4246}, {2799, 17708}, {2858, 23342}, {2966, 9979}, {3060, 16978}, {3153, 18401}, {3154, 15059}, {3260, 15295}, {3448, 6070}, {4235, 10098}, {4238, 10101}, {4608, 6578}, {5468, 10425}, {5663, 16169}, {5897, 16386}, {5899, 13597}, {5994, 20579}, {5995, 20578}, {6032, 9831}, {6325, 11594}, {6644, 15111}, {6757, 11101}, {6795, 15080}, {7575, 13530}, {8599, 11636}, {8705, 11593}, {9033, 15395}, {9070, 15455}, {9202, 14185}, {9203, 14187}, {10296, 18300}, {10412, 15329}, {10989, 14388}, {12077, 23357}, {12113, 18318}, {14934, 15035}, {15061, 16340}, {15168, 18359}, {15646, 20480}, {16089, 18817}, {18323, 18576}, {18403, 22751}.

X(476) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (146,1553), (477,3)<br>
X(476) = isogonal conjugate of X(526)<br>
X(476) = isotomic conjugate of X(3268)<br>

<h3 id="X477">X(477) = TIXIER ANTIPODE</h3>
Trilinears 1/[4 cos A + cos(A - 2B) + cos(A - 2C) - 3 cos(B - C)] : :
<br>
Barycentrics (a^8 + a^6*b^2 - 4*a^4*b^4 + a^2*b^6 + b^8 - 3*a^6*c^2 + 2*a^4*b^2*c^2 + 2*a^2*b^4*c^2 - 3*b^6*c^2 + 3*a^4*c^4 - 2*a^2*b^2*c^4 + 3*b^4*c^4 - a^2*c^6 - b^2*c^6)*(a^8 - 3*a^6*b^2 +
3*a^4*b^4 - a^2*b^6 + a^6*c^2 + 2*a^4*b^2*c^2 - 2*a^2*b^4*c^2 - b^6*c^2 - 4*a^4*c^4 + 2*a^2*b^2*c^4 + 3*b^4*c^4 + a^2*c^6 - 3*b^2*c^6 + c^8)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(a^6 (b^2 + c^2) - a^4 (3 b^4 - 2 b^2 c^2 + 3 c^4) + a^2 (3 b^6 - 2 b^4 c^2 - 2 b^2 c^4 + 3 c^6) - (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^4 + 3 b^2 c^2 + c^4)) : :
<p>
X(477) lies on these lines: {2, 9060}, {3, 476}, {4, 1304}, {5, 16166}, {20, 10420}, {22, 16167}, {23, 1302}, {24, 22239}, {30, 110}, {50, 112}, {74, 523}, {99, 3260}, {107, 186}, {109, 15228}, {111, 5915}, {125, 5627}, {140, 18319}, {265, 14851}, {376, 691}, {378, 935}, {403, 1301}, {468, 9064}, {511, 9160}, {512, 9161}, {526, 16169}, {550, 1291}, {631, 22104}, {759, 23226}, {842, 2411}, {925, 2071}, {930, 18859}, {933, 13619}, {1138, 12244}, {1141, 23286}, {1290, 3651}, {1300, 15470}, {1499, 9184}, {2222, 22342}, {2452, 2713}, {2549, 2715}, {2687, 7429}, {2688, 7440}, {2689, 7421}, {2690, 7430}, {2695, 7454}, {2752, 7425}, {2758, 7444}, {2766, 7414}, {2770, 7418}, {2782, 20404}, {3154, 14644}, {3233, 15034}, {5473, 9203}, {5474, 9202}, {5663, 14480}, {5994, 15743}, {5995, 11586}, {6080, 12290}, {6236, 11594}, {7417, 10102}, {7471, 15035}, {9781, 12052}, {10423, 18533}, {10990, 14536}, {12030, 14127}, {12084, 15112}, {13398, 16386}, {14094, 14611}, {15396, 17511}
</p><p>
X(477) = reflection of X(476) in X(3)<br>
X(477) = &Lambda;(X(3), X(74))<br>
X(477) = &Lambda;(X(40), X(2940))<br>
X(477) = isogonal conjugate of X(5663)<br>
X(477) = reflection of X(74) in the Euler line<br>
X(477) = Thomson-isogonal conjugate of X(526)<br>
X(477) = Lucas-isogonal conjugate of X(526)<br>
X(477) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(14254)<br>
X(477) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(14385)<br>
X(477) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(1637)<br>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X478">X(478) = CENTER OF YIU CONIC</h3>
<a id="CenterOfYiuConic" name="CenterOfYiuConic"></a>
Trilinears a[a<sup>4</sup> - 2abc(b + c - a) - (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>]/(b + c - a) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2*(a + b - c)*(a - b + c)*(a^4 - b^4 + 2*a^2*b*c - 2*a*b^2*c - 2*a*b*c^2 + 2*b^2*c^2 - c^4)
<p>
Center of the Yiu conic, which passes through the points outside the circumcircle at which the excircles of ABC are tangent to the sidelines of ABC. See Paul Yiu's
</p><p> <a href="http://www.math.fau.edu/yiu/clawson.pdf">The Clawson point and excircles</a>.
</p><p>
X(478) lies on these lines: {2, 8048}, {6, 19}, {9, 1038}, {12, 20029}, {37, 1455}, {56, 5019}, {69, 651}, {73, 2268}, {109, 573}, {154, 3195}, {198, 577}, {219, 4559}, {222, 226}, {223, 10319}, {388, 2298}, {572, 10571}, {603, 1400}, {604, 1457}, {1035, 18591}, {1122, 1407}, {1211, 5783}, {1413, 1903}, {1470, 2277}, {1766, 21147}, {2092, 11509}, {2122, 5750}, {2183, 2199}, {3142, 3330}, {3157, 10441}, {3596, 6648}, {3713, 9370}, {8231, 13388}, {8750, 18621}, {11496, 14749}.
</p><p.
X(478) = complement of X(8048)<br>
X(478) = center of the perspeconic of every pair of these triangles: ABC, 2nd extouch, 3rd extouch<br>
X(478) = complement of X(8048)<br>
X(478) = crosssum of circumcircle intercepts of excircles radical circle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X479">X(479) = X(269)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(279)</h3>
Trilinears (tan A/2 sec A/2)<sup>2</sup> : : <br>
Barycentrics tan<sup>3</sup>(A/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b + c - a)<sup>3</sup> : :
<p>
Let A' be the point in which the incircle is tangent to a circle that passes through vertices B and C, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(479). For an excircle version, see X(5423).
</p><p><b>
Clark Kimberling and Peter Yff,</b> Problem 10678, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 105 (1998) 666.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(479).gsp"><b>X(479)</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(479) lies on these lines: <br>
{2,5574}, {7,354}, {8,7182}, {55,3160}, {57,279}, {165,1323}, {269,614}, {348,5273}, {658,5435}, {934,1617}, {1014,5324}, {1119,1851}, {1407,1462}, {1996,5226}, {3188,6060}, {4554,8055}
</p><p>
X(479) = isogonal conjugate of X(480)<br>
X(479) = isotomic conjugate of X(5423)<br>
X(479) = X(269)-cross conjugate of X(279)<br>
X(479) = anticomplement of X(5574)<br>
X(479) = crosssum of X(3022) and X(4105)<br>
X(479) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {269,738}, {3271,3669}<br>
X(479) = {X(i),X(j)}-harmonic conjugate of X(k) for these (i,j,k): (1088,7056,7), (3160,3599,55)<br>
X(479) = X(i)-cross conguate of X(j) for these (i,j): (269,279), (3271,3669), (5573,2), (7195,7)<br>
X(479) = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of X(30682)<br>
X(479) = X(i)-isoconjugate of X(j) for these {i,j}: {1,480}, {2,6602}, {6,728}, {8,1253}, {9,220}, {31,5423}, {33,1260}, {41,346}, {55,200}, {78,7071}, {100,4105}, {101,4130}, {210,2328}, {212,7046}, {219,7079}, {281,1802}, {282,7368}, {284,4515}, {341,2175}, {607,3692}, {643,4524}, {644,657}, {663,4578}, {692,4163}, {756,6061}, {765,3022}, {1098,7064}, {1110,4081}, {1252,3119}, {1265,2212}, {1334,2287}, {2194,4082}, {2310,6065}, {2318,4183}, {2324,7367}, {2332,3694}, {3063,6558}, {3699,8641}, {3709,7259}, {3900,3939}, {4012,7084}, {4171,5546}, {6605,8012}
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X480">X(480) = X(200)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(220)</h3>
Trilinears (cot A/2 cos A/2)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Trilinears a(b + c - a)<sup>3</sup> : b(c + a - b)<sup>3</sup> : c(a + b - c)<sup>3</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(cot A/2 cos A/2)<sup>2</sup> : :
<p>
X(480) = radical center of the three circles used to construct X(57). (Peter Yff, 5/6/98)
</p><p>
X(480) lies on these lines: 8,344 9,55 10,954 56,78 100,144
</p><p>
X(480) = isogonal conjugate of X(479)<br>
X(480) = X(200)-Ceva conjugate of X(220)<br>
X(480) = crosssum of X(269) and X(738)<br>
X(480) = trilinear square of X(6726)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X481">X(481) = 1st EPPSTEIN POINT</h3>
<a id= "FirstEppsteinPoint" name="FirstEppsteinPoint"></a>
Trilinears 1 - 2 sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 - 4(area)/[a(b + c - a)] : : (E. Brisse, 3/20/01)
<br><b>
X(481) = s*X(1) - (r + 4R)*X(7)<br>
X(481) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc - X(1)/r, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles<br>
X(481) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc + X(175)/Rs', where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles, and Rs' = radius of outer Soddy circle
</b><p>
Let S be the inner Soddy circle and S<sub>A</sub>, S<sub>B</sub>,
S<sub>C</sub> the Soddy circles tangent to S. Let Ia =
S&cap;S<sub>A</sub>, Ea = S<sub>B</sub>&cap;S<sub>C</sub>, and
determine Ib, Ic, Eb, Ec cyclically. Then X(481) is the point of
concurrence of lines I<sub>A</sub>-to-E<sub>A</sub>,
I<sub>B</sub>-to-E<sub>B</sub>, I<sub>C</sub>-to-E<sub>C</sub>.
</p><p>
<b>David Eppstein,</b> "Tangent spheres and triangle centers,"<i>American Mathematical Monthly,</i> 108 (2001) 63-66.
</p><p>
Let S' be the outer Soddy center, X(175). X(481) is the point of concurrence of the Soddy lines of BS'C, CS'A, and AS'B. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La be the line tangent to the outer Soddy circle at the touchpoint with the A-Soddy circle. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc and define B' and C'cyclically. Triangle A'B'C', here introduced as the outer Soddy tangential triangle, is perspective to ABC, and the perspector is X(481). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p> X(481) lies on these lines: 1,7 174,1127 226,485
</p><p>
X(481) = X(79)-Ceva conjugate of X(482)<br>
X(481) = Kosnita(X(175),X(1)) point; see X(54)<br>
X(481) = Kosnita(X(175),X(7)) point<br>
X(481) = Kosnita(X(176),X(175)) point<br>
X(481) = {X(7),X(176)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1373)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X482">X(482) = 2nd EPPSTEIN POINT</h3>
<a id="SecondEppsteinPoint" name="SecondEppsteinPoint"></a>
Trilinears 1 + 2 sec A/2 cos B/2 cos C/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 + 4(area)/[a(b + c - a)] : : (E. Brisse, 3/20/01)
<br>
Barycentrics a + (a + b + c) tan(A/2) : :
<br><b>
X(482) = s*X(1) + (r + 4R)*X(7)<br>
X(482) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc + X(1)/r, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles<br>
X(482) = [A]/Ra + [B]/Rb + [C]/Rc + X(176)/Rs, where Ra, Rb, Rc = radii of Soddy circles, and Rs = radius of inner Soddy circle
</b><p>
Let S' be the outer Soddy circle and S<sub>A</sub>, S<sub>B</sub>,
S<sub>C</sub> the Soddy circles tangent to S. Let J<sub>A</sub> =
S'&cap;S<sub>A</sub>, E<sub>A</sub> = S<sub>B</sub>&cap;S<sub>C</sub>,
and determine J<sub>B</sub>, J<sub>C</sub>, E<sub>B</sub>,
E<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Then X(482) is the point of concurrence of
lines J<sub>A</sub>-to-E<sub>A</sub>, J<sub>B</sub>-to-E<sub>B</sub>,
J<sub>C</sub>-to-E<sub>C</sub>.</p>
<p><b>David Eppstein,</b> "Tangent spheres and triangle centers,"
<i>American Mathematical Monthly,</i> 108 (2001) 63-66.
</p><p>
Let S be the inner Soddy center, X(176). X(482) is the point of concurrence of the Soddy lines of BSC, CSA, and ASB. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ia, Ib, Ic be the centers of the Elkies companion incircles. Let A' be the trilinear product Ib*Ic, and define B' and C'cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(482). The lines IaA', IbB', IcC' concur in X(176). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La be the line tangent to the inner Soddy circle at the touchpoint with the A-Soddy circle. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C', here introduced as the <b>inner Soddy tangential triangle</b>, is perspective to ABC, and the perspector is X(482). (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
X(482) lies on these lines: 1,7 226,486
</p><p>
X(482) = X(79)-Ceva conjugate of X(481)<br>
X(482) = trilinear product of centers of Elkies companion incircles<br>
X(482) = Kosnita(X(176),X(7)) point<br>
X(482) = Kosnita(X(176),X(176)) point<br>
X(482) = perspector of ABC and the intangents triangle of the three Elkies companion incircles; see X(176)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X483">X(483) = RADICAL CENTER OF AJIMA-MALFATTI CIRCLES</h3>
<a id="RadicalCenterOfAjimaMalfattiCircles" name= "RadicalCenterOfAjimaMalfattiCircles"></a>
Trilinears sec<sup>2</sup>A/4 : sec<sup>2</sup>B/4 : sec<sup>2</sup>C/4
<br>
Trilinears 1/(1 + cos A/2) : 1/(1 + cos B/2) : 1/(1 + cos C/2)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec<sup>2</sup>A/4 : sin B sec<sup>2</sup>B/4 : sin C sec<sup>2</sup>C/4
</p><p>
The Ajima-Malfatti circles are described at X(179). (Peter Yff, 6/1/98)
</p><p>
Let (Ia) be the incircle of BCI, where I=X(1), and define (Ib) and (Ic) cyclically. Let Ea be the touchpoint of (Ia) and BC, and define Eb and Ec cyclically. Let Sa be the insimilicenter of (Ib) and (Ic), and define Sb and Sc cyclically. The lines EaSa, EbSb, EcSc concur in X(483). Let La be the internal tangent, other than AI, of (Ib) and (Ic). Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Then La, Lb, Lc concur in X(483). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(483).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(483)</a>.
<p>
X(483) lies on these lines: 8,178 173,180 174,175
</p><p>
X(483) = X(372)-of-BCI-triangle<br>
X(483) = BCI-isogonal conjugate of X(1)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X484">X(484) = 1st EVANS PERSPECTOR</h3>
<a name=
"1st EvansPerspector"></a>Trilinears 1 + 2(cos A - cos B
- cos C) : 1 + 2(cos B - cos C - cos A) : 1 + 2(cos C - cos A - cos
B)<br>Barycentrics a[1 + 2(cos A - cos B - cos C)] : b[1 + 2(cos B
- cos C - cos A)] : c[1 + 2(cos C - cos A - cos B)]
<p>X(484) is the perspector of the excentral triangle and the triangle
A'B'C', where A' is the reflection of vertex A in sideline BC and B',
C' are determined cyclically. (Lawrence Evans, 10/22/98)</p>
<p>X(484) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines: 1,3
4,3483 10,191 12,79
13,1277 14,1276 30,80
63,535 74,3465 100,758
499,962 759,901 1046,1048
1138,3464 3466,3484</p>
<p>
X(484) = midpoint of X(36) and X(3245)<br>
X(484) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,36), (36,1155)<br>
X(484) = isogonal conjugate of X(3065)<br>
X(484) = inverse-in-circumcircle of X(35)<br>
X(484) = inverse-in-Bevan-circle of X(1)<br>
X(484) = X(80)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(484) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(650)X(1100)<br>
X(484) = {X(1)X(46)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3336)<br>
X(484) = inverse-in-incircle of X(5045)<br>
X(484) = perspector of ABC and the reflection of the incentral triangle in the antiorthic axis (the reflection of the cevian triangle of X(1) in the trilinear polar of X(1))<br>
X(484) = reflection of X(36) in the antiorthic axis<br>
X(484) = X(30)-Ceva conjugate of X(3465)<br>
X(484) = X(186)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(484) = endo-homothetic center of Ehrmann vertex-triangle and dual of orthic triangle; the homothetic center of is X(3153)<br>
</p><br> <br><br>
<center><p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 485- 495,
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>371, and 372: Vierkanen in een driehoek - triangle centers associated
with squares.</b><br><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"><br>
</center>
<h3 id="X485">X(485) = VECTEN POINT</h3> <a name="Vecten Point"></a>
Trilinears sec(A - &pi;/4) : sec(B - &pi;/4) : sec(C -&pi;/4)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(sin A + cos A) : 1/(sin B + cos B) : 1/(sin C + cos C)
<br>
Trilinears sin A + cos(B - C) : sin B + cos(C - A) : sin C + cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec(A - &pi;/4) : sin B sec(B - &pi;/4) : sin C sec(C - &pi;/4)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(SA + S) : :<br>
</p><p>
Erect a square outwardly from each side of triangle ABC. Let A'B'C'
be the triangle formed by the respective centers of the squares. The
lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(485). For details, visit Floor van
Lamoen's site, <a href="http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant.html" style=
"font-style: italic">Vierkanten in een driehoek: 1. Omgeschreven
vierkanten</a> (van Lamoen, 4/26/98) and his article "Friendship Among
Triangle Centers," <i>Forum Geometricorum,</i> 1 (2001) 1-6. See also
Paul Yiu's papers, <a href="http://www.math.fau.edu/yiu/bottema38.pdf">"Squares Erected on the
Sides of a Triangle"</a>, and <a href="http://www.math.fau.edu/yiu/square.pdf">"On the Squares Erected
Externally on the Sides of a Triangle"</a>.
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(485).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Vecten Point</a>.
<p>X(485) lies on these lines: 2,372 3,590
4,371 5,6 69,639 76,491
226,481 489,671
</p><p>
X(485) = reflection of X(488) in X(641)<br>
X(485) = isogonal conjugate of X(371)<br>
X(485) = isotomic conjugate of X(492)<br>
X(485) = complement of X(488)<br>
X(485) = anticomplement of X(641)<br>
X(485) = X(3)-cross conjugate of X(486)<br>
X(485) = internal center of similitude of nine-point circle and 2nd Lemoine circle<br>
X(485) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1585)<br>
X(485) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(1585)<br>
X(485) = trilinear product of vertices of outer Vecten triangle<br>
X(485) = X(4)-of-outer-Vecten-triangle<br>
X(485) = X(4)-of-X(2)-quadsquares-triangle<br>
X(485) = perspector of ABC and inner-squares triangle<br>
X(485) = perspector of 3rd tri-squares triangle and 3rd tri-squares central triangle<br>
X(485) = Kosnita(X(485),X(485)) point<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X486">X(486) = INNER VECTEN POINT</h3>
<a name="Vecten Point"></a>
Trilinears sec(A + &pi;/4) : sec(B + &pi;/4) : sec(C + &pi;/4)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(sin A - cos A) : 1/(sin B - cos B) : 1/(sin C - cos C) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A - cos(B - C) : sin B - cos(C - A) : sin C - cos(A - B) (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec(A + &pi;/4) : sin B sec(B + &pi;/4) : sin C sec(C + &pi;/4)
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(SA - S) : :
</p><p>
X(486) is a perspector of triangles associated with squares that
circumscribe ABC. For details and references,<br>see X(485). (Floor van Lamoen, 4/26/98)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(486).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">Inner Vecten Point</a>.
</p><p>X(486) lies on these lines: 2,371 3,615
4,372 5,6 76,492
226,482 490,671
</p><p>
X(486) = reflection of X(487) in X(642)<br>
X(486) = isogonal conjugate of X(372)<br>
X(486) = isotomic conjugate of X(491)<br>
X(486) = complement of X(487)<br>
X(486) = anticomplement of X(642)<br>
X(486) = X(3)-cross conjugate of X(485)<br>
X(486) = external center of similitude of nine-point circle and 2nd Lemoine circle<br>
X(486) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1586)<br>
X(486) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(1586)<br>
X(486) = Kosnita(X(486),X(486)) point<br>
X(486) = trilinear product of vertices of inner Vecten triangle<br>
X(486) = X(4) of inner Vecten triangle<br>
X(486) = perspector of ABC and outer-squares triangle<br>
X(486) = perspector of 4th tri-squares triangle and 4th tri-squares central triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X487">X(487) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(486)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos A)(1 - csc A sin B sin
C)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)<br>Barycentrics (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)(a<sup>2</sup> - 2&sigma;) : (c<sup>2</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> - 2&sigma;) :
(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(c<sup>2</sup> -
2&sigma;) (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<p>X(487) is a perspector of triangles associated with squares that
circumscribe ABC. (Floor van Lamoen, 4/29/98)</p>
<p>X(487) lies on these lines: 2,371 3,69
4,489 20,638 193,372
376,490 492,631</p>
<p>
X(487) = reflection of X(486) in X(642)<br>
X(487) = anticomplement of X(486)<br>
X(487) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(638)<br>
X(487) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (4,488), (489,20), (491,2)<br>
X(487) = isogonal conjugate of X(8946)<br>
X(487) = X(20)-of-inner-Vecten-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X488">X(488) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(485)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos A)(1 + csc A sin B sin
C)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C) : (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)
<p>Barycentrics (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
a<sup>2</sup>)(a<sup>2</sup> + 2&sigma;) : (c<sup>2</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + 2&sigma;) :
(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(c<sup>2</sup> +
2&sigma;) (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)</p>

circumscribe ABC. For details, see <a href= "http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant2.html" style=

omgeschreven vierkanten</a> (Floor van Lamoen, 4/29/98)

4,490 193,371 376,489 491,631
591,3071
</p><p>

X(488) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(637)<br>

<h3 id="X491">X(491) = CEVAPOINT OF X(2) AND X(487)</h3>

</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X493">X(493) = 1st VAN LAMOEN HOMOTHETIC CENTER</h3>
Trilinears 1/(sin A + sin B sin C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)/(sin A + sin B sin C) : :
<p>
X(493) is a homothetic center of triangles associated with squares that circumscribe ABC. For details, see <a href= "http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant4.html" style="font-style: italic">Vierkanten in een driehoek: 4. Ingeschreven vierkanten</a> (Floor van Lamoen, 4/27/98)
</p><p>
X(493) is the homothetic center of triangle ABC and the Lucas homothetic triangle; see X(371). Writing t for the ratio L:W at X(371), let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through the intersections, other than A, of the A-Lucas(t) circle and sides CA and AB. Define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. Then the triangle A'B'C', here introduced as the Lucas(t) homothetic triangle, is homothetic to triangle ABC. If t = 1, the center of homothety is X(493); for t = -1, it is X(494); for t = 2, it is X(588); and for t = -2, it is X(589). (Randy Hutson, February 9, 2013)
</p><p>
Let A" be the intersection of line BC and the common tangent to the B- and C-Lucas circles (at their touchpoint). Define B" and C" cyclically. Then A"B"C" is the cevian triangle of X(493). Also, X(493) is the point of intersection of the tangents at X(371) and X(485) to the orthocubic K006. (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
X(493) lies on these lines: 25,371 39,494 394,1504
</p><p>
X(493) = isogonal conjugate of X(3068)<br>
X(493) = X(394)-cross conjugate of X(494)<br>
X(493) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of outer Vecten triangle<br>
X(493) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of Lucas(-1) antipodal triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X494">X(494) = 2nd VAN LAMOEN HOMOTHETIC CENTER</h3>
Trilinears 1/(sin A - sin B sin C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(sin A - sin B sin C) : :
<p>
X(494) is a homothetic center of triangles associated with squares that circumscribe ABC. For details and reference, see X(493). (Floor van Lamoen, 4/27/98)
</p><p>
X(494) is the homothetic center of triangle ABC and the Lucas(-1) homothetic triangle; see X(371).
</p><p>
Let A" be the intersection of line BC and the common tangent to the B- and C-Lucas(-1) circles (at their touchpoint). Define B" and C" cyclically. Then A"B"C" is the cevian triangle of X(494). Also, X(494) is the point of intersection of the tangents at X(372) and X(486) to the orthocubic K006. (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
X(494) lies on these lines: 25,372 39,493 394,1505
</p>
<p>
X(494) = isogonal conjugate of X(3069)<br>
X(494) = X(394)-cross conjugate of X(493)<br>
X(494) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of inner Vecten triangle<br>
X(494) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of Lucas antipodal triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X495">X(495) = JOHNSON MIDPOINT</h3> <a id="JohnsonMidpoint" name="JohnsonMidpoint"></a>
Trilinears 2 + cos(B - C) : 2 + cos(C - A) : 2 + cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)[2 + cos(B - C)] : (sin B)[2 + cos(C - A)] : (sin C)[2 + cos(A - B)]
<br><b>
X(495) = 2(R/r)*X(1) + 3X(2) - X(3)
</b><p>
X(495) is the midpoint of segments C1-to-P1, C2-to-P2, C3-to-P3 in the Johnson four-circle configuration.
</p><p>
<b>Roger A. Johnson,</b> <i>Advanced Euclidean Geometry,</i> Dover, New York, 1960, page 75.
</p><p>
<b>Peter Yff,</b> "Three concurrent congruent circles 'inscribed' in a triangle," manuscript, 1998; X(495) is the point R on page 5. (See also X(496)-X(499) and X(1478), X(1479).)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="Johnson%20Yff%20Circles%20Internal.gsp"><b>Johnson-Yff Circles
Internal</b> and <a href="Johnson%20Yff%20Circles%20External.gsp"
style="font-weight: bold">Johnson-Yff Circles External</a>.
</p><p>
X(495) lies on these lines:<br>1,5 2,956 3,388 4,390
8,442 10,141 30,55
35,550 36,549 56,140
202,395 203,396 226,517
381,497 392,908 429,1068
529,993 612,1060
</p><p>
X(495) = complement of X(956)<br>
X(495) = X(427)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X496">X(496) = {X(1),X(5)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(495)</h3>
Trilinears 2 - cos(B - C) : 2 - cos(C - A) : 2 - cos(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)[2 - cos(B - C)] : (sin B)[2 - cos(C - A)] : (sin C)[2 - cos(A - B)]
<br><b>
X(496) = 2(R/r)*X(1) - 3X(2) + X(3)
</b><p>
<b>Peter Yff,</b> "Three concurrent congruent circles 'inscribed' in a triangle," manuscript, 1998; X(496) is the point R' on page 5.</p>
<p>X(496) lies on these lines: 1,5 2,1058
3,497 4,999 30,56
35,549 36,550 55,140
149,404 202,397 203,398
381,388 390,631 613,1069
614,1062 942,946

X(496) = X(235)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>
X(496) = center of inverse-in-incircle-of-nine-point-circle<br>
X(496) = Ursa-major-to-Ursa-minor similarity image of X(5)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X497">X(497) CROSSPOINT OF GERGONNE POINT AND NAGEL POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1 - cos B cos C : 1 - cos C cos A : 1 - cos A cos B
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(1 - cos B cos C) : (sin B)(1 - cos C cos A) : (sin C)(1 - cos A cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics (SW - bc)(s - a) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (a - b - c)(a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - 2bc) : :
<br><b>
X(497) = 2(R/r)*X(1) - 3X(2) + 2X(3)
</b><p>
Let A'B'C' be the extangents-to-intangents similarity image of ABC. A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC at X(55) and to the medial triangle at X(497). (Randy Hutson, March 21, 2019)
<p>X(497) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,11 3,496 7,354
8,210 20,56 29,1036
30,999 35,499 36,376
57,516 65,938 69,350
80,1000 212,238 329,518
381,495 452,958 614,1040
1057,1065
</p><p>
X(497) = isogonal conjugate of X(1037)<br>
X(497) = isotomic conjugate of X(8817)<br>
X(497) = anticomplement of X(1376)<br>
X(497) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (7,8), (29,314)<br>
X(497) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (55,56), (73,1402)<br>
X(497) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(652)X(665)<br>
X(497) = homothetic center of Mandart-incircle triangle and anticomplementary triangle<br>
X(497) = inverse-in-Feuerbach-hyperbola of X(2550)<br>
X(497) = homothetic center of anticomplementary triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Johnson-Yff triangle<br>
X(497) = homothetic center of 2nd Johnson-Yff triangle triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd Johnson-Yff triangle<br>
X(497) = {X(1),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(388)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X498">X(498) = YFF CONCURRENT CONGRUENT CIRCLES POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1 + 2 sin B sin C : 1 + 2 sin C sin A : 1 + 2 sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears bc + 2R^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(1 + 2 sin B sin C) : (sin B)(1 + 2 sin C sin A) : (sin C)(1 + 2 sin A sin B)
<br><b>
X(498) = R*X(1) + r*X(3) + 2r*X(5)
</b><p>
X(498) and X(499) are harmonic conjugate points with respect to X(1)
and X(2), in analogy with such pairs with respect to X(1), X(4) and
with respect to X(1), X(5).</p>
<p><b>Peter Yff,</b> "Three concurrent congruent circles 'inscribed' in
a triangle," manuscript, 1998; X(498) is the point S on page 6.</p>
<p>X(498) lies on these lines: 1,2 3,12
4,35 5,55 9,920 36,388
37,91 46,226 47,171
56,140 141,611 191,329
255,750 345,1089</p>
<p></p>
X(498) = homothetic center of anti-Euler triangle and (cross-triangle of ABC and 2nd isogonal triangle of X(1))
<br><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X499">X(499) = {X(1),X(2)}-HARMONIC CONJUGATE OF X(498)</h3>
Trilinears 1 - 2 sin B sin C : 1 - 2 sin C sin A : 1 - 2 sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears bc - 2R^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(1 - 2 sin B sin C) : (sin B)(1 - 2 sin C sin A) : (sin C)(1 - 2 sin A sin B)
<br><b>
X(499) = R*X(1) - r*X(3) - 2r*X(5)
</b><p>
X(499) is the harmonic conjugate of X(498) with respect to X(1) and X(2).</p>
<p><b>Peter Yff,</b> "Three concurrent congruent circles 'inscribed' in
a triangle," manuscript, 1998; X(498) is the point S' on page 6.</p>
<p>X(499) lies on these lines: 1,2 3,11
4,36 5,56 12,999 17,202
18,203 35,497 46,946
47,238 55,140 57,920
80,944 141,613 255,748
348,1111 484,962</p>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X500">X(500) = ORTHOCENTER OF THE INCENTRAL TRIANGLE</h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> +c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc)[2abc + (b +
c)(a<sup>2</sup> - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<p>X(500) lies on these lines: 1,30 3,6
651,943</p>
<p>
X(500) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(582)<br>
X(500) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(35)<br>
X(500) = crosssum of X(1) and X(79)<br>
X(500) = X(1)-Ceva conjugate of X(942)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X501">X(501) = MIQUEL ASSOCIATE OF INCENTER</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= a[a<sup>3</sup> - b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup> - bc(a + b + c) +
ab(a - b) + ac(a - c)]/(b + c)
<p>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)</p>
<p>Miquel's theorem states that if A', B', C' are points (other than A,
B, C) on sidelines BC, CA, AB, respectively, then the circles AB'C',
BC'A', CA'B' meet at a point. Suppose P is a point and A' = P&cap;BC,
B' = P&cap;CA, C' = P&cap;AB; the point in which the three circles is
the <i>Miquel associate</i> of P. (Paul Yiu, 7/6/99)</p>
<p>X(501) lies on these lines: 1,229 10,662
21,214 35,110 36,58
215,1364 284,942 572,992
595,1326 759,1385</p>
<p>X(501) = isogonal conjugate of X(502)<br></p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X502">X(502) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(501)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc(b + c)/[a<sup>3</sup> -
b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup> - bc(a + b + c) + ab(a - b) + ac(a -
c)]<br>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle. Let BCA'' be the triangle
similar to A'B'C' such that the segment AA'' crosses the line BC.
Define B'' and C'' cyclically. The lines AA'', BB'', CC'' concur in
X(502). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)</p>
<p>X(502) lies on this line: 10,191</p>
<p>
X(502) = isogonal conjugate of X(501)<br>
X(502) = X(1)-cross conjugate of X(10)<br>
<br><br><br>
<center>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 503- 510,
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>173, 174, 258, and 351- 364 are associated with isoscelizers.</b>
<p>A line L<sub>A</sub> perpendicular to the internal bisector
line of A is an <i>A-isoscelizer.</i>. Suppose X is a point not on a
sideline of ABC, and let</p>
<p></p>
<table border="2">
<tr><td>L(A,X) =</td><td>the A-isoscelizer passing through X;</td>
</tr>
<tr><td>E(A,X) =</td><td>L(A,X)&cap;AC;</td></tr>
<tr><td>F(A,X) =</td><td>L(A,X)&cap;AB;</td></tr>
<tr><td>T(A,X) =</td><td>the triangle wth vertices A, E(A,X), F(A,X);</td></tr>
<tr><td>H(A,X) =</td><td>A-altitude of T(A,X);</td></tr>
<tr><td>D(A,X) =</td><td>distance between E(A,X) and F(A,X);</td></tr>
<tr><td>X(A) =</td><td>distance between E(A,X) and F(A,X);</td></tr>
</table><br>
<p>Cyclically define L(B,X), E(B,X), . . . , X(B) and L(C,X), E(C,X), .
. . , X(C).</p>
<p>Each center, X(503) to X(510), is defined by Peter Yff as the point
X of concurrence of isoscelers satisfying certain conditions.</p>
<p>Geometer's Sketchpad sketches for centers X(503)-X(510) were
contributed by Peter Moses, May 7, 2005.</p>
<p><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"></p>
</center>
<h3 id="X503">X(503) = 1st ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = sec B/2 + sec C/2 - sec A/2<br>Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>
The isoscelizer equations aH(A,X) = bH(B,X) = cH(C,X) have solution X = X(503). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(503).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(503)</a>.
<p>
X(503) lies on these lines: 1,167 164,361 173,844
</p><p>
X(503) = X(259)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(503) = X(92)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(503) = excentral-isogonal conjugate of X(504)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X504">X(504) = 2nd ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = b sin B/2 + c sin C/2 - a sin A/2<br>
Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>
The isoscelizer equations [H(A,X)]/a = [H(B,X)]/b = [H(C,X)]/c have solution X = X(504). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(504).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(504)</a>.
<p>
X(504) lies on this line: 164,173
</p><p>
X(504) = X(48)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(504) = excentral-isogonal conjugate of X(503)<br>
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X505">X(505) = 3rd ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = 1/(sin B/2 + sin C/2 - sin A/2)<br>
Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>
The isoscelizer equations H(A,X)D(A,X) = H(B,X)D(B,X) = H(C,X)D(C,X) have solution X = X(505). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)
</p><p>
X(505) is the perspector of ABC and the excentral triangle of the excentral triangle of ABC. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p> <p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(505).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(505)</a>.
<p>
X(505) lies on these lines: 40, 164 173,1130
</p><p>
X(505) = isogonal conjugate of X(164)<br>
X(505) = X(266)-cross conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(505) = X(46)-of-excentral-triangle
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X506">X(506) = 4th ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos A/2)<sup>-2/3</sup><br>Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>The isoscelizer equations</p>
<p></p>
X(A)[area of T(A,X)] = X(B)[area of T(B,X)] = X(C)[area of T(C,X)]<br>
<p>have solution X = X(506). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href="X(506).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(506)</a>.
</p><p>
X(506) = trilinear cube root of X(7)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X507">X(507) = 5th ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (cos A/2)<sup>-1/2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics af(A,B,C) : bf(B,C,A) : cf(C,A,B)
<p>
The isoscelizer equations
</p>

<p>have solution X = X(507). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)

<h3 id="X510">X(510) = 8th ISOSCELIZER POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = b<sup>3/2</sup> +
c<sup>3/2</sup> - a<sup>3/2</sup><br>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)
<p>The isoscelizer equations</p>
<p></p>
[area of T(A,X)]/a<sup>2</sup> = [area of T(B,X)]/b<sup>2</sup>
= [area of T(C,X)]/c<sup>2</sup><br>
<p>have solution X = X(510). (Peter Yff, 4/9/99)</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(510).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(510)</a>.

<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>30, and others, lie on the line at infinity.</b><br>Thus, a collection of collinearities reported for each of these centers
comprises a family of parallel lines.<br>

<h3 id="X511">X(511) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(98)</h3>
Trilinears cos(A + &omega;) : cos(B + &omega;) : cos(C + &omega;)
<br>
Trilinears sin A - sin(A + 2&omega;) : sin B - sin(B + 2&omega;) : sin C - sin(C + 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos(A + 2&omega;) : cos B + cos(B + 2&omega;) : cos C + cos(C + 2&omega;)
<br>
Trilinears a(a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup>) : : (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin A tan &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>cos B cos C - bc cos<sup>2</sup>A : : (R. Hutson, 1/29,15)
<br>
Trilinears cos A + cos 2A cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a - 2R cos A cot &omega; : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(A + &omega;) : sin B cos(B + &omega;) : sin C cos(C + &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics (cot A + cot B + cot C) tan A - (tan A + tan B + tan C) cot A : :
</p> <p style="font-weight: bold">X(511) = X(3) - X(6)
</p><p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(511) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let L denote the line having trilinears of X(511) as coefficients. Then L is the line passing through X(6) perpendicular to the Euler line.
</p><p>
X(511) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle of the hyperbola {{A, B, C, X(2), and X(110)}}.
</p><p>

<h3 id="X512">X(512) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(99)</h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>

<br>

<br>
Barycentrics SB^2 - SC^2 : :
<br><b>
X(512) = P(1) - U(1)
</b><p>
X(512) is the point in which the line of the 1st and 2nd Brocard points meets the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let La be the reflection of B'C' in the internal angle bisector of vertex angle A, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Then the lines La, Lb, Lc are parallel, and they concur in X(512). (Randy Hutson, September 5, 2015)
</p><p>
X(512) lies on these (parallel) lines: 1,875

<h3 id="X514">X(514) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(101)</h3>
Trilinears (b - c)/a : :
<br>
Trilinears |AP(1)| - |AU(1)| : :
<br>
Trilinears directed distance from A to line X(1)X(6) : :
<br>
Barycentrics b - c : :
<p>
Let A<sub>7</sub>B<sub>7</sub>C<sub>7</sub> and A<sub>8</sub>B<sub>8</sub>C<sub>8</sub> be Gemini triangles 7 and 8, resp. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the tangent at A to conic {{A,B<sub>7</sub>,C<sub>7</sub>,B<sub>8</sub>,C<sub>8</sub>}}, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(514). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(514) lies on these (parallel) lines: 1,663

<h3 id="X519">X(519) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(106)</h3>
Trilinears (2a - b - c)/a : (2b - c - a)/b : (2c - a - b)/c
<br>
Trilinears 1 - 2 csc A/2 sin B/2 sin C/2 : :
<br>
Trilinears 3 r - 2 R sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2a - b - c : 2b - c - a : 2c - a - b
<br><b>
X(519) = X(1) - X(2)
</b><p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(519) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in A', and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* be the cevapoint of B" and C", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(519). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be triangle T(-2,1). Let A" be the trilinear product B'*C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(519). The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(8). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)

<h3 id="X523">X(523) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(110)</h3>
Trilinears sin(B -C) : sin(C - A) : sin(A - B)
<br>
Barycentrics b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> : a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics cot B cos 2C - cot C cos 2B : :
<br>
Barycentrics SB - SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot B - cot C : :
<p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(523) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A"B"C" be the 2nd Brocard triangle. Let A* be the trilinear pole of line A'A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* are parallel and meet the line at infinity at X(523). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Feuerbach triangle. Let La be the tangent to conic {{A,B,C,B',C'}} at A, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(523); see also X(1109).
</p><p>
Let L be the line X(115)X(125); then X(523) = trilinear pole of L. The line L is also PU(40), the tangent to Steiner inellipse at X(115), the Lemoine axis of the 4th Brocard triangle, the Fermat axis of the 2nd Parry triangle, and the isogonal conjugate of hyperbola {A,B,C,PU(2)}) (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(523) lies on the Kiepert parabola and these (parallel) lines: 1,2605
2,1649 4,1552 6,879
11,1090 12,2599 23,385
30,511 59,655 66,2435
74,477 75,876 98,842

1297,2697 2525,2526 2594,2616
</p><p>

Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= (2ax - by - cz)/a, x = x(A,B,C) = tan A, y = x(B,C,A), z = x(C,A,B)
<p>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)</p>
<p>X(534) lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(534) lies on these (parallel) lines: 2,19
30,511 553,1407 1441,1839</p>

<h3 id="X546">X(546) = MIDPOINT OF X(4) AND X(5)</h3>
Trilinears 3 cos(B - C) - 2 cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A + 6 cos B cos C : cos B + 6 cos C cos A : cos C + 6 cos A cos B
<br>
Barycentrics 2 a^4 + a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - 3 (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<b><br>
X(546) = X(3) - 3*X(5) = X(4) + X(5) = X(3) + 3*X(4)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(546) has Shinagawa coefficients (1,5).
</p><p>
Let A'B'C', A"B"C" be the outer and inner Vecten triangles, resp. Let (Oa) be the circle inscribed in square A'BA"C, and define (Ob) and (Oc) cyclically. X(546) is the radical center of circles (Oa), (Ob), (Oc). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
Let M<sub>A</sub> denote the point in which the A-median meets side
BC. On 11/05/03, Andrew Crane noted that X(546) is the radical center
of circles (A), (B), (C), where (A) denotes the circle centered at A
and passing through M<sub>A</sub>, and (B) and (C) are defined
cyclically.
</p><p>
X(546) lies on these lines: 2,3 13,398
14,397 113,137 156,578 946,952
</p><p>
X(546) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (4,5), (382,550)<br>
X(546) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (140,5), (548,140)<br>
X(546) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(382)<br>
X(546) = complement of X(550)<br>
X(546) = anticomplement of X(3530)<br>
X(546) = X(1385)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(546) = X(5)-of-Euler-triangle<br>
X(546) = {X(3),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3628)<br>
X(546) = X(5)-of-Ehrmann-mid-triangle<br>
X(546) = Ehrmann-side-to-orthic similarity image of X(5)<br>
X(546) = Johnson-to-Ehrmann-mid similarity image of X(5)<br>
X(546) = homothetic center of Ehrmann mid-triangle and Euler triangle<br>
X(546) = radical center of de Longchamps circles of ABC and 1st and 2nd Ehrmann inscribed triangles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X547">X(547) = MIDPOINT OF X(2) AND X(5)</h3>
Trilinears 5 cos(B - C) + 2 cosA : :
<br>
Trilinears 7 cos A + 10 cos B cos C : 7 cos B + 10 cos C cos A : 7 cos C + 10 cos A cos B
<b><br>
X(547) = X(3) + 3*X(4)
</b><p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(547) has Shinagawa coefficients (7,3).
</p><p>
X(547) lies on the Euler line. (Antreas Hatzipolakis, 1/20/00, Hyacinthos #201)
</p><p>
X(547) lies on these lines: 2,3 551,952
</p><p>
X(547) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,5), (381,549)<br>
X(547) = reflection of X(140) in X(2)<br>
X(547) = complement of X(549)<br>
X(547) = {X(3),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3627)<br>
</p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X548">X(548) = MIDPOINT OF X(5) AND X(20)</h3>
Trilinears - cos(B - C) + 6 cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears 5 cos A - 2 cos B cos C : 5 cos B - 2 cos C cos A : 5 cos C - 2 cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A - 5 sec B sec C : 2 sec B - 5 sec C sec A : 2 sec C - 5 sec A sec B
<b><br>
X(548) = 3 X(2) - 7 X(3) = 3X(3) - X(5)
</b> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(548) has Shinagawa coefficients (5,-7).
</p><p>
X(548) lies on the Euler line. (Antreas Hatzipolakis, 1/20/00, Hyacinthos #201)
</p><p>
X(548) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,550), (5,20)<br>
X(548) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (140,3), (546,140)<br>
X(548) = {X(2),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(15712)<br>
X(548) = {X(3),X(5)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3530)<br>
X(548) = radical center of circles centered at vertices of ABC with diameter equal to opposite side<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X549">X(549) = MIDPOINT OF X(2) AND X(3)</h3>
Trilinears cos(B - C) + 4 cosA : :
<br>
Trilinears 5 cos A + 2 cos B cos C : 5 cos B + 2 cos C cos A : 5 cos C + 2 cos A cos B<br>
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A + 2 sin B sin C : 3 cos B + 2 sin C sin A : 3 cos C + 2 sin A sin B
<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A + 5 sec B sec C : 2 sec B + 5 sec C sec A : 2 sec C + 5 sec A sec B
<br>
Barycentrics 4a^4 - 5a^2(b^2 + c^2) + (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2 S^2 + 3 SA (SB + SC) : :
</p> <p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(549) has Shinagawa coefficients (5,-3).
</p><p>
Let Pa be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC. Let La be the polar of X(3) wrt Pa. Define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, B' = Lc&cap;La, C' = La&cap;Lb. X(141) of triangle A'B'C' is X(549). X(549) is also the centroid of the six points of tangency of lines from X(3) to Pa, Pb, and Pc. (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
In the construction of the Dao 6-point circle (see X(5569)), X(549) is the centroid of AbAcBcBaCaCb. (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
X(549) lies on these lines: 2,3 15,395
16,396 35,496 36,495
141,542 182,524 230,574
302,617 303,616 511,597 517,551 543,1153
</p><p>
X(549) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,140), (5,2), (381,547)<br>
X(549) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (14,619), (148,13), (616,99), (622,299)<br>
X(549) = complement of X(381)<br>
X(549) = anticomplement of X(547)<br>
X(549) = X(3)-of-X(2)-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(549) = intersection of tangents to Evans conic at X(13) and X(14)<br>
X(549) = inverse-in-circle-O(PU(5)) of X(140)<br>
X(549) = center of inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of de Longchamps line<br>
X(549) = QA-P39 (Midpoint of QA-P12 and QA-P20) of quadrangle ABCX(2) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/encyclopedia-of-quadri-figures/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/204-qa-p39.html)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X550">X(550) = MIDPOINT OF X(3) AND X(20)</h3>
Trilinears - cos(B - C) + 4 cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears 2 sec A - 3 sec B sec C : 2 sec B - 3 sec C sec A : 2 sec C - 3 sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears 6 cos A + cos B cos C - 3 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A - 4 cos B cos C + 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears 6 cos B cos C - 2 sin B sin C - cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears 5 cos A + cos(B - C) - cos B cos C - 3 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Barycentrics 4 a^4 - 3 a^2 (b^2 + c^2) - (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<br><b>
X(550) = 3*X(3) - X(4)
</b><br>
As a point on the Euler line, X(550) has Shinagawa coefficients (3,-5).
</p><p>
X(550) lies on the Euler line. (Antreas Hatzipolakis, 1/20/00, Hyacinthos #201)
</p> <p>
X(550) lies on these lines: 2,3 15,397 16,398 35,495 36,496 40,952 74,930 156,1092 165,355
</p> <p>
X(550) = midpoint of X(3) and X(20)<br>
X(550) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,548), (4,140), (5,3), (382,546)<br>
X(550) = isogonal conjugate of X(16835)<br>
X(550) = trisector nearest X(20) of segment X(5)X(20)<br>
X(550) = complement of X(382)<br>
X(550) = anticomplement of X(546)<br>

X(550) = X(143)-of-hexyl-triangle<br>
X(550) = intersection of tangents to Evans conic at X(17) and X(18)<br>

X(550) = radical center of reflections of nine-point circle in A, B, C<br>
X(550) = antipedal isogonal conjugate of X(5)<br>
X(550) = radical trace of circumcircle and Trinh circle<br>
X(550) = {X(2),X(3529)}-harmonic conjugate of X(382)<br>
X(550) = {X(3),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(140)<br>

<h3 id="X551">X(551) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(2)</h3>
Trilinears (4a + b + c)/a : (4b + c + a)/b : (4c + a + b)/c
<br>
Trilinears 3 r + 2 R sin B sin C :
<br>
Barycentrics 4a + b + c : 4b + c + a : 4c + a + b
<b><br>

</b><p>

37,537 56,553 86,99

<h3 id="X552">X(552) = POINT MAIA I</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a(b + c - a)(b + c)<sup>2</sup>] : 1/[b(c +a - b)(c + a)<sup>2</sup>] : 1/[c(a + b - c)(a + b)<sup>2</sup>]
<br>
Barycentrics 1/[(b + c - a)(b + c)<sup>2</sup>] : 1/[(c + a - b)(c + a)<sup>2</sup>] : 1/[(a + b - c)(a + b)<sup>2</sup>]
<p>
X(552) lies on this line: 261,873
</p><p>
X(552) = X(757)-cross conjugate of X(1509)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X553">X(553) = POINT MAIA II</h3>
Trilinears bc(2a + b + c)/(b + c - a) : ca(2b + c + a)/(c + a - b) : ab(2c + a + b)/(a + b - c)
<br>
Barycentrics (2a + b + c)/(b + c - a) : (2b + c + a)/(c + a - b) : (2c + a + b)/(a + b - c)
<p>
X(553) lies on these lines: 1,376 2,7
30,942 56,551 65,519 354,516
</p><p>
X(553) = crosssum of X(55) and X(1334)<br>
X(553) = X(51)-of-intouch-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X554">X(554) = (X(1),X(13))-ANSWER TO QUESTION A</h3>
Trilinears sec(A/2) csc(A/2 + &pi;/3) : sec(B/2) csc(B/2 + &pi;/3) : sec(C/2) csc(C/2 + &pi;/3)<br>Barycentrics sin A sec(A/2) csc(A/2 + &pi;/3) : sin B sec(B/2) csc(B/2 + &pi;/3) : sin C sec(C/2) csc(C/2 + &pi;/3)
<p>Suppose that X and Y are triangle centers. Let</p>
<p>Y<sub>A</sub> = (Y of the triangle XBC),<br>Y<sub>B</sub> = (Y of the triangle XCA),<br>Y<sub>C</sub> = (Y of the triangle XAB).</p>
<p>Let A' = (XY<sub>A</sub> intersect BC), and define B' and C'
cyclically. In</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling,</b> "Major Centers of Triangles," <i>Amer.
Math. Monthly</i> 104 (1997) 431-438,</p>
<p>Question A is this: <i>for what choices of X and Y do the lines AA',
BB', CC' concur?</i> A solution (X,Y) will here be called the
<i>(X,Y)-answer to Question A.</i> X(554) is the (X(1),X(13))-answer to
Question A. (In the reference, see (9) on page 435, with Y =
X(13).)</p>
<p>X(554) lies on these lines: 1,30 7,1082
14,226 75,299</p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X555">X(555) = (X(1),X(158))-ANSWER TO QUESTION A</h3>
Trilinears sec<sup>3</sup>(A/2) : sec<sup>3</sup>(B/2) : sec<sup>3</sup>(C/2)
<br>
Trilinears |AJa| : :, where Ja = A-mixtilinear excenter
<br>
Barycentrics sin A sec<sup>3</sup>(A/2) : sin B sec<sup>3</sup>(B/2) : sin C sec<sup>3</sup>(C/2)
<p>
X(555) lies on these lines: 7,177 234,1088
</p><p>
X(555) = X(234)-cross conjugate of X(7)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X559">X(559) = (X(1),X(15))-ANSWER TO QUESTION A</h3>

sin(A/2 + &pi;/3) : (sec B/2) sin(B/2 + &pi;/3) : (sec C/2) sin(C/2 +
&pi;/3)<br>Barycentrics (sin A/2) sin(A/2 + &pi;/3) : (sin B/2) sin(B/2
+ &pi;/3) : (sin C/2) sin(C/2 + &pi;/3)

299,319</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X560">X(560) 4th POWER POINT</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>4</sup> : b<sup>4</sup> : c<sup>4</sup>
<br>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>(S<sub>A</sub> - S<sub>&omega;</sub>) : :
<br>
Trilinears (cot B + cot C)^2 : :
<br>
Trilinears (SB + SC)^2 : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = (distance from A to de Longchamps line)<sup>2</sup>
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>5</sup> : b<sup>5</sup> : c<sup>5</sup>
<p>
X(560) is the vertex conjugate of the foci of the inellipse that is the trilinear square of the Lemoine axis. The center of the inellipse is X(16584) and its Brianchon point (perspector) is X(31). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(560) lies on these lines: 1,82 31,48
41,872 42,584 100,697
101,713 110,715 717,825 719,827
</p><p>
X(560) = isogonal conjugate of X(561)<br>
X(560) = isotomic conjugate of X(1928)<br>
X(560) = crosssum of X(75) and X(304)<br>
X(560) = barycentric product of PU(9)<br>
X(560) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(304)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X561">X(561) ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF 4th POWER POINT</h3>
Trilinears a <sup>- 4</sup> : b <sup>- 4</sup> : c <sup>- 4</sup>
<br>
Trilinears [sec^2(A/2) + csc^2(A/2)]^2 : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = (distance from A to Lemoine axis)<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics a <sup>-3</sup> : b <sup>-3</sup> : c<sup>-3</sup>
<p>
X(561) is the vertex conjugate of the foci of the inellipse that is the trilinear square of the de Longchamps line (with center X(21235) and perspector X(1928)). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the obverse triangle of X(1). Let A"B"C" be the N-obverse triangle of X(1). Let A* be the trilinear product A'*A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(561). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(561) lies on these lines: 1,718 2,716
6,720 31,722 32,724
38,75 63,799 76,321
92,304 313,696 305,1441
</p><p>
X(561) = isogonal conjugate of X(560)<br>
X(561) = isotomic conjugate of X(31)<br>
X(561) = cevapoint of X(75) and X(304)<br>
X(561) = complement of X(17486)<br>
X(561) = X(313)-cross conjugate of X(76)</p>
X(561) = trilinear square of X(75)<br>
X(561) = trilinear product of PU(11)<br>
X(561) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(1973)<br>
X(561) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(1973)<br>
X(561) = trilinear product of vertices of Gemini triangle 21<br>
X(561) = trilinear product of vertices of Gemini triangle 22<br>
X(561) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of Gemini triangles 31 and 32<br>
X(561) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 31<br>
X(561) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 32<br>
X(561) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 31<br>
X(561) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 32<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X562">X(562) = TRILINEAR QUOTIENT X(2)*X(50)/X(49)</h3>
Trilinears csc A tan 3A : csc B tan 3B : csc C tan 3C
<br>
Barycentrics tan 3A : tan 3B : tan 3C
<br><b>
= (3S<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup><sub>A</sub>)(3S<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup><sub>B</sub>)(3S<sup>2</sup> - S<sup>2</sup><sub>C</sub>)*X(3) - 16S<sub>A</sub>S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>(5S<sub>A</sub>S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 3S<sup>2</sup>S<sub>&omega;</sub>S)*X(3519) (Peter Moses, January 29, 2015)
</b><p>
X(562) lies on these lines: {4,93}, {252,6143}
</p> <p>
<b>Clark Kimberling and Cyril Parry,</b> "Products, Square Roots, and Layers in Triangle Geometry," <i>Mathematics and Informatics Quarterly</i> 10 (2000) 9-22; on page 21, section 8.
</p><p>
X(562) = polar conjugate of X(30529)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X564">X(564) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(1048) AND X(47,91)</h3>
Trilinears cos(2B - 2C) : cos(2C - 2A) : cos(2A - 2B)
<br>
Trilinears b^2 c^2 (a^4 (b^4 + c^4) - 2 a^2 (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^2 + c^2) + (b^2 - c^2)^4) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(2B - 2C) : sin B cos(2C - 2A) : sin C cos(2A - 2B)
<p>
X(564) lies on these lines: 1,1048 47,91</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling and Cyril Parry,</b> "Products, Square Roots,
and Layers in Triangle Geometry," <i>Mathematics and Informatics
Quarterly</i> 10 (2000) 9-22; on page 21, section 8.
</p><p>
X(564) = {X(91),X(92)}-harmonic conjugate of X(47)<br> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X565">X(565) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(49)X(93) AND X(143,324)</h3>
Trilinears cos(3B - 3C) : cos(3C - 3A) : cos(3A - 3B)
<br>
Barycentrics sin A cos(3B - 3C) : sin B cos(3C - 3A) : sin C cos(3A - 3B)
<p>
X(565) lies on these lines: 49,93 143,324</p>
<p><b>Clark Kimberling and Cyril Parry,</b> "Products, Square Roots,
and Layers in Triangle Geometry," <i>Mathematics and Informatics
Quarterly</i> 10 (2000) 9-22; on page 21, section 8.</p>
<br><br><br>
<center><p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 566 - 584
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>are on the Brocard axis, L(3,6). Each is the center X of a circle<br>meeting the sides of triangle ABC with three equal angles at X.<br>
</b>Let A<sub>B</sub>, A<sub>C</sub>, B<sub>C</sub>, B<sub>A</sub>,
C<sub>A</sub>, C<sub>B</sub> denote the meeting-points; e.g.,
A<sub>B</sub> and C<sub>B</sub><br>are on side CA. The equal angles are given by
<p>D = angle(A<sub>B</sub>XA<sub>C</sub>) =
angle(B<sub>C</sub>XB<sub>A</sub>) =
angle(C<sub>A</sub>XC<sub>B)</sub></p>
<p>Then trilinears for X are given by</p>
<p>X = sin A + cot D/2 cos A : sin B + cot D/2 cos B : sin C + cot D/2
cos C.</p>
<p>Definitions: Y is the <b>orthogonal</b> of X if D(X) + D(Y) =
&pi;/2;<br>Y is the <b>harmonic</b> of X if X and Y are harmonic conjugates with
respect to X(3) and X(6);<br>Y is the <b>orthoharmonic</b> if Y is the harmonic of the orthogonal of
X. The centers in this section were contributed by Edward Brisse,
December, 2000.</p>
<p><img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"></p>
</center>
<br>
<h3 id="X566">X(566) = HARMONIC OF X(50)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = sin A + cos A cot D/2, where
cot D/2 = 4*area/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
6R<sup>2</sup>), where R = abc/(4*area)<br>Trilinears f(a,b,c) :
f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where fa,b,c) = a[16(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>)&sigma;<sup>2</sup> -
3a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>]
(M.Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^4 (b^2 + c^2) - a^2 (2 b^4 + b^2 c^2 + 2 c^4) + (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^2 + c^2)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (SB + SC) (3 R^2 - SA - SW) : :
<br>
<p>X(566) lies on these lines: 2,94 3,6
53,1594 233,1879 2165,2963</p>
<p>
X(566) = isogonal conjugate of X(7578)<br>
X(566) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(50)<br>
X(566) = crosssum of X(6) and X(381)<br>
X(566) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(523)X(5926)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X567">X(567) = ORTHOGONAL OF X(50)</h3>
Trilinears cos(B - C) + 2 cos(C - A)cos(A - B) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A + cos A cot D/2 : : , where
where cot D/2 = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -
6R<sup>2</sup>)/(4*area), where R = abc/(4*area)
<p>
X(567) lies on these lines: 3,6 5,49
51,2070 140,3580 156,309
184,381 546,1614 1092,3526
1147,1656 1154,1994 1658, 3567
1986,3520
</p><p>
X(567) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(568)<br>
X(567) = crosssum of PU(5)<br>
X(567) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(523)X(2081)<br>
X(567) = crosspoint of isogonal conjugates of PU(5)<br>

<h3 id="X568">X(568) = ORTHOHARMONIC OF X(50)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cos A cot D/2, where where cot D/2 = (6R<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/(4*area) and R = abc/(4*area)
<br>
Trilinears a[3*R<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) + a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup>], where R =
abc/(4*area) (Wimalasiri Perera, August 29, 2011)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - 2 cos 2A cos(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^6 (b^2 + c^2) - a^4 (3 b^4 + b^2 c^2 + 3 c^4) + a^2 (3 b^6 - 2 b^4 c^2 - 2 b^2 c^4 + 3 c^6) - (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^4 + c^4)) : :
<p>
Let (A) be the circle centered at A that cuts off a segment of line BC equal to the radius of (A). Define (B) and (C) cyclically. Then X(568) is the radical center of circles (A), (B), (C). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(568) lies on these lines: 2,1154 3,6
4,94 5,3567 24,49
30,3060 51,381 54,1658
68,973 156,3518 184,2070
185,382 186,1994 195,1147
373,1656 549,2979 1216,3526
</p><p>
X(568) = reflection of X(381) in X(51)<br>
X(568) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(567)</p>
X(568) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(50)<br>
X(568) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(94)<br>
X(568) = homothetic center of Ehrmann side-triangle and 2nd anti-Conway triangle <p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X569">X(569) = HARMONIC OF X(52)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cot D/2 cos A : :,
<br>
Trilinears cot D/2 = (2e<sub>3</sub> + e<sub>2</sub> - e<sub>1</sub>)/[64*(area)<sup>3</sup>], where
<br>
e<sub>1</sub> = a<sup>6</sup> + b<sup>6</sup> + c<sup>6</sup>
<br>
e<sub>2</sub> = a<sup>4</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) + b<sup>4</sup>(c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>) + c<sup>4</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
e<sub>3</sub> = a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>
