<h3 id="X572">X(572) = ORTHOGONAL OF X(58)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = cos(A - U), where cot U =
cot(A/2) cot(B/2) cot(C/2) (Joe Goggins,
11/26/08)<br>Trilinears g(A,B,C) :
g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = sin A + cot D/2 cos A,
<br>
cot D/2 = (a + b + c)<sup>2</sup>/(4*area)
<br>
Trilinears s cos A + r sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears a (a^3 - a (b^2 - b c + c^2) - b c (b + c)) : :<br>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(572) = s*X(3) + r*cot(&omega;)*X(6)
</p>
X(572) is the intersection of the Brocard axes of ABC, the Feuerbach triangle, and the Apollonius triangle. (Randy Hutson, March 21, 2019) <p>
X(572) lies on these lines: 1,604 3,6
9,48 51,199 54,71
103,825 165,1051 169,610
184,1011 219,947 261,662
517,1100 594,952 631,966</p>
<p>
X(572) = isogonal conjugate of X(2051)<br>
X(572) = {X(1687),X(1688)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4279)<br>
X(572) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(573)<br>
X(572) = crosssum of X(11) and X(661)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X573">X(573) = ORTHOHARMONIC OF X(58)</h3>
Trilinears cos(A + U) : : , where cot U = cot(A/2) cot(B/2) cot(C/2) (Joe Goggins, 11/26/08)
<br>
Trilinears (c - a)cos B sin(A - B) - (a - b)cos C sin(C - A) : :
<br>
Trilinears a[a^2(b + c) - abc - b^3 - c^3] : :
<br>
Trilinears s cos A - r sin A, s = semiperimeter, r = inradius
<b><br>
X(573) = s*X(3) - r*cot(&omega;)*X(6)
</b><p>
X(573) is the internal center of similitude of the circumcircle and Apollonius circle. The external center is X(386). (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)
</p><p>
Let A' be the inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of the midpoint of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inscribed in the Apollonius circle and homothetic to the 1st circumperp triangle at X(573). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p>
X(573) lies on these lines: 1,941 3,6
4,9 10,5179 20,391 36,604
37,517 43,165 51,1011
55,181 101,102 109,478
184,199 256,981 346,1018
347,1020
</p><p>
X(573) = reflection of X(991) in X(3)<br>
X(573) = isogonal conjugate of X(13478)<br>
X(573) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(572)<br>
X(573) = X(333)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(573) = crosspoint of X(59) and X(190)<br>
X(573) = crosssum of X(11) and X(649)<br>
X(573) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(523)X(1459)<br>
X(573) = X(216)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(573) = perspector, wrt excentral triangle, of the excentral-hexyl ellipse<br>
X(573) = inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of X(5179)<br>
X(573) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(58)<br>
X(573) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(10)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X574">X(574) = HARMONIC OF X(187)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cot D/2 cos A, where cot(D/2) = 12*area/(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Trilinears a(a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A + 3 cos A tan &omega; : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)
<br>
Trilinears 2 sin(A + 2&omega;) - sin(A - 2&omega;) + sin A : :
<br>
Trilinears 3 cos A + sin A cot &omega; : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - &omega;) sin 2&omega; - e^2 sin(A + &omega;) : :
<p>
Let A', B', C' be the inverse-in-Brocard-circle of A, B, C. Let A", B", C" be the inverse-in-circumcircle of the vertices of 1st Brocard triangle. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(574). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(574) lies on these lines: 2,99 3,6
55,1015 110,353 183,538
230,549 232,378 805,843
</p><p>
X(574) = isogonal conjugate of X(598)<br>
X(574) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(187)<br>
X(574) = internal center of similitude of circumcircle and Moses circle<br>
X(574) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(351)X(523)<br>
X(574) = X(6)-of-2nd-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(574) = perspector of Lucas Brocard and Lucas(-1) Brocard triangles<br>
X(574) = {X(15),X(16)}-harmonic conjugate of X(182)<br>
X(574) = {X(1340),X(1341)}-harmonic conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(574) = perspector of ABC and inverse-in-Brocard-circle of vertices of circumsymmedial triangle<br>
X(574) = perspector of circumsymmedial triangle and inverse-in-Brocard-circle of A,B,C<br>
X(574) = pole, wrt Brocard circle, of Lemoine axis<br>
X(574) = inverse-in-Ehrmann-circle of X(5107)<br>
X(574) = harmonic center of Gallatly circle and Ehrmann circle<br>
X(574) = homothetic center of circumtangential triangle and unary cofactor triangle of Stammler triangle<br>
X(574) = perspector of ABC and unary cofactor triangle of Lemoine triangle<br>
X(574) = X(6)-of-X(3)PU(1)<br>
X(574) = homothetic center of Kosnita triangle and mid-triangle of inner and outer tri-equilateral triangles<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X575">X(575) = ORTHOGONAL OF X(187)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cot D/2 cos A, where cot(D/2) = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/(12*area)
<br>
Trilinears 3 sin A + cos A cot &omega; : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 7/20/03)</p>
<br> Trilinears cos A + 3 sin A tan &omega; : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)</p>
<br>
Trilinears 2 cos(A - 2&omega;) - cos(A + 2&omega;) + cos A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(2a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 3a^2b^2 - 3a^2c^2 - 4b^2c^2) : :
<br><b> X(575) = X(3) + 3X(6)
</b><p>
X(575) lies on these lines: 3,6 4,598
5,542 23,51 54,895
110,373 140,524 141,629
</p><p>
X(575) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,576), (6,182)<br>

X(575) = isogonal conjugate of X(7608)<br>

<h3 id="X576">X(576) = ORTHOHARMONIC OF X(187)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cot(D/2) cos A, where cot(D/2) = - (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/(12*area)
<br>
Trilinears 3 sin A - cos A cot &omega; : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 7/20/03)
<br>
Trilinears cos A - 3 sin A tan &omega; : : (Peter J. C. Moses, 8/22/03)
<br>
Trilinears 2 cos(A + 2&omega;) - cos(A - 2&omega;) + cos A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2(a^4 + 2b^4 + 2c^4 - 3a^2b^2 - 3a^2c^2 - 2b^2c^2) : :
<br><b>
X(576) = X(3) - 3X(6)
</b><p>
X(576) lies on these lines: 3,6 4,542 5,524 23,184 140,597 262,385
</p><p>
X(576) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,575), (182,6)<br>
X(576) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(575)<br>
X(576) = inverse-in-2nd-Lemoine-circle of X(1691)<br>
X(576) = isogonal conjugate of X(7607)<br>
X(576) = {X(61),X(62)}-harmonic conjugate of X(32)<br>

X(576) = center of Ehrmann circle<br>
X(576) = X(1) of 2nd Ehrmann triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(576) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(187)<br>
X(576) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(671)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X577">X(577) = HARMONIC OF X(216)</h3>

<br>

<br>
Trilinears cos A - sin A (cot A cot B cot C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A sin 2A : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - T) : :, T as at X(389)
<br>
Trilinears sec B sec C - csc B csc C : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^4(b^2 + c^2 - a^2)^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin^2 2A : :
<p>
X(577) lies on these lines: 2,95 3,6
20,393 22,232 30,53

<h3 id="X578">X(578) = ORTHOHARMONIC OF X(216)</h3>
Trilinears sin A + cot D/2 cos A, where cot(D/2) = (a<sup>2</sup>b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> cos A cos B cos C)/[8*(area)<sup>3</sup>]
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin A (tan A + tan B + tan C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A (cot A cot B cot C) + sin A : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2[a^8 - 3a^6(b^2 + c^2) + a^4(3b^4 + 4b^2c^2 + 3c^4) - a^2(b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2) - 2b^2c^2(b^2 - c^2)^2] : :
<p>
Joe Goggins notes (10/1/2008), in connection with the note at X(389), that trilinears for X(578) are sin(A-T) : sin(B-T) : sin(C-T), where tan(T) = - cot A cot B cot C.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the triangle described in ADGEOM #2697 (8/26/2015, Tran Quang Hung). A'B'C' is homothetic to the Euler triangle at X(578). (Randy Hutson, March 14, 2018)
</p><p>
X(578) lies on these lines: 2,1092 3,6
4,54 24,51 49,381
156,546 185,378 436,1093
</p><p>
X(578) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(389)</p>
X(578) = X(12514)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br> </p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X579">X(579) = HARMONIC OF X(284)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a(a<sup>2</sup>b +
a<sup>2</sup>c + abc - b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup>)
(M.Iliev, 5/13/07)
<p>Barycentrics af(a,b,c) : bf(b,c,a) : cf(c,a,b)</p>
<p style="font-weight: bold">X(579) = s*X(3) - (r +
2R)*cot(&omega;)*X(6) </p>
<p>X(579) lies on these lines: 1,71 2,7
3,6 19,46 36,48 37,942
40,387 56,219 109,608
165,380 198,218 443,966
474,965 517,1108</p>
<p>
X(579) = isogonal conjugate of X(1751)<br>

X(579) = crosssum of X(11) and X(652)<br>
X(579) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(523)X(663)<br>
X(579) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(284)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X580">X(580) = ORTHOGONAL OF X(284)</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = sin A + cot D/2 cos
A,<br> cot
D/2 = (e<sub>1</sub> - e<sub>2</sub> - 2abc)/[4*area*(a + b + c)],
where e<sub>1</sub>, e<sub>2</sub> are as for X(579)
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C): (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>
<p>X(580) lies on these lines: 1,201 2,283
3,6 31,40 34,46 36,54
57,255 162,412 165,601
223,603 238,946 517,595</p>

<h3 id="X581">X(581) = ORTHOHARMONIC OF X(284)</h3>

A,<br> cot
D/2 = (2abc - e<sub>1</sub> + e<sub>2</sub>)/[4*area*(a + b + c)],
where e<sub>1</sub>, e<sub>2</sub> are as for X(579)

<h3 id="X582">X(582) = HARMONIC OF X(500)</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = sin A + cot D/2 cos
A,<br> cot
D/2 = (e<sub>1</sub> - e<sub>2</sub> - 4abc)/[4*area*(a + b + c)],
where<br> e<sub>1</sub>
= a<sup>3</sup> + b<sup>3</sup> + c<sup>3</sup><br> e<sub>2</sub>
= a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + b<sup>2</sup>(c + a) + c<sup>2</sup>(a + b)
<p>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C): (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)</p>
<p>X(582) lies on these lines: 3,6 212,942
283,474 517,602</p>
<p>X(582) = inverse-in-Brocard-circle of X(500)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a(a<sup>2</sup>b +
a<sup>2</sup>c + 2abc - b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup>)

<h3 id="X585">X(585) = 1st CONGRUENT SHRUNK INSQUARES POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [2*area*(1/b + 1/c - 1/a) + b +
c - a]/a<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= 2*area*(1/b + 1/c - 1/a) + b + c - a
<p>X(585) lies on this line: 8,192</p>
<p>For a discussion, see <a href="http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant5.html"
style="font-weight: bold">Floor van Lamoen, "Vierkanten in een
driehoek: 5. Gekrompen ingeschreven vierkanten"</a>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X586">X(586) = 2nd CONGRUENT SHRUNK INSQUARES POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [2*area*(1/b + 1/c - 1/a) + a -
b - c]/a<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= 2*area*(1/b + 1/c - 1/a) + a - b - c
<p>X(586) lies on this line: 8,192</p>
<p>For a discussion, see <a href="http://home.wxs.nl/~lamoen/wiskunde/vierkant5.html"
style="font-weight: bold">Floor van Lamoen, "Vierkanten in een
driehoek: 5. Gekrompen ingeschreven vierkanten"</a>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X587">X(587) = POINT ARCTURUS</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = bc[2(a + b + c) + (a -
b - c) tan A]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= 2(a + b + c) + (a - b - c) tan A
<p>X(587) lies on this line: 2,92</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X588">X(588) = 1st KENMOTU-VAN LAMOEN POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a/(a<sup>2</sup> + 4*area(ABC))<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)
<p>
X(588) is the perspector of triangles ABC and A'B'C', where A' is the circumcenter of X(371) and the points where the squares in the Kenmotu configuration with center X(371) meet sideline BC, and B' and
C' are defined cyclically. See <p style="font-weight: bold">Floor van Lamoen, <a href=
"http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2002volume2/FG200202index.html">Some
concurrences from Tucker hexagons,</a> <i>Forum Geometricorum</i> 2
(2002) 5-13.
</p> <p>
X(588) is the homothetic center of triangle ABC and the Lucas(2:1) homothetic triangle; see X(371) and X(589). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p> <p>
Let A'B'C' be the Lucas central triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C'; define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* be the trilinear pole of line B"C"; define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(588). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p> <p>
X(588) lies on this line: 39,589
</p> <p>
X(588) = isogonal conjugate of X(590)<br>
X(588) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(371)<br>
X(588) = X(1994)-cross conjugate of X(589)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X589">X(589) = 2nd KENMOTU-VAN LAMOEN POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a/(a<sup>2</sup> - 4*area(ABC))<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)
<p>
X(589) is the perspector of triangles ABC and A'B'C', where A' is the circumcenter of X(372) and the points where the squares in the Kenmotu configuration with center X(372) meet sideline BC, and B' and
C' are defined cyclically. See the reference at X(588).
</p> <p>
X(588) is the homothetic center of triangle ABC and the Lucas(-2:1) homothetic triangle; see X(371) and X(588). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p> <p>
Let A'B'C' be the Lucas(-1) central triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C'; define B" and C" cyclically. Let A* be the trilinear pole of line B"C"; define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(589). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2015)
</p> <p>
X(589) lies on this line: 39,588
</p> <p>
X(589) = isogonal conjugate of X(615)<br>
X(589) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(372)<br>
X(589) = X(1994)-cross conjugate of X(588)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X590">X(590) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(588)</h3>
Trilinears (a<sup>2</sup> + 4*area(ABC))/a : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A + 2 sin B sin C : :
<br>
Trilinears aR + bc : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> + 2S : :
</p></p>
X(590) lies on these lines: 1,3302 2,6
3,485 4,1151 5,371
11,2066 12,2067 17,3389
32,640 39,642 53,1585
140,372 157,3155 393,3535
397,2045 398,2046 486,1656
493,2165 498,1335 499,1124
588,2963 605,748 606,750
631,1152 639,1504 1131,3522
1327,3534 1578,3546 1579,3547
1583,1609 1588,3090 1834,2047
3085,3298 3086,3297 3087,3536
3092,3542 3093,3541 3312,3526
3525,3594
</p><p>
X(590) = isogonal conjugate of X(588)<br>
X(590) = complement of X(492)<br>
X(590) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(485)<br>
X(590) = crosssum of X(6) and X(371)<br>
X(590) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(641)<br>
X(590) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(641)<br>
X(590) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(641)<br>
X(590) = homothetic center of outer Vecten and 3rd tri-squares triangles<br>
X(590) = homothetic center of [outer Vecten of outer Vecten triangle] and pedal triangle of X(1151)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X591">X(591) = 1st VAN LAMOEN PERPENDICULAR BISECTORS POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc[b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup> + 4*area(ABC)]
<p>
Erect squares outwardly on the sides of triangle ABC. Two edges emanate from A; let P and Q be their endpoints. Let a' be the perpendicular bisector of PQ, and define b' and c' cyclically. Then a', b', c' concur in X(591). See also X(1991). (Floor van Lamoen, 1/4/2001, Hyacinthos #2123)
</p><p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(591).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">1st Van Lamoen Perpendicular Bisectors Point</a>.
<p>X(591) lies on these lines: 2,6 372,754
488,3071 637,1152</p>
<p>
X(591) = reflection of X(1991) in X(2)<br>
X(591) = perspector of inner Vecten triangle and outer Vecten of outer Vecten triangle<br>
X(591) = centroid of {Ab, Ac, Bc, Ba, Ca, Cb} used in construction of 4th Lozada circle
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X592">X(592) = VAN LAMOEN CIRCUMCENTERS POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = 1/[cos A + 2 cos(B - &omega;)
cos(C - &omega;)]<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= (sin A)f(A,B,C)
<p>Let P be the point where the line through X(6) parallel to line CA
meets line BC, and let Q be the point where the line through X(6)
parallel to line AB meets line BC. Let X = X(182), and let A' be the
circumcenter of the triangle PQX. Define B' and C' cyclically. The
lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(592). (Floor van Lamoen, 1/4/01)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X593">X(593) = 1st HATZIPOLAKIS-YIU POINT</h3>
Trilinears a/(b +
c)<sup>2</sup> : b/(c + a)<sup>2</sup> : c/(a + b)<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics [a/(b + c)]<sup>2</sup> : [b/(c +
a)]<sup>2</sup> : [c/(a + b)]<sup>2</sup>
<p>Let O(A) be the circle tangent to line BC and to the circumcircle of
triangle ABC at vertex A. Let A<sub>B</sub> and A<sub>C</sub> be where
O(A) meets lines AB and AC, respectively. Let L(A) be the line joining
A<sub>B</sub> and A<sub>C</sub>, and define L(B) and L(C) cyclically.
Let A' be where L(B) and L(C) meet, and define B' and C' cyclically.
Then triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to triangle ABC, and the center of
homothety is X(593). See Antreas Hatzipolakis, Paul Yiu, Hyacinthos #2070.
</p><p>
X(593) lies on these lines: 2,261 31,110
36,58 81,757 115,1029 229,1104</p>
<p>
X(593) = isogonal conjugate of X(594)<br>
X(593) = isotomic conjugate of X(28654)<br>
X(593) = barycentric square of X(81)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X594">X(594) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(593)</h3>
Trilinears (b +
c)<sup>2</sup>/a : (c + a)<sup>2</sup>/b : (a + b)<sup>2</sup>/c<br>Barycentrics (b + c)<sup>2</sup> : (c + a)<sup>2</sup> : (a
+ b)<sup>2</sup>
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the Feuerbach triangle. Let La be the tangent to the nine-point circle at A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. La, Lb, Lc are also tangent to the Steiner inellipse. Let A", B", C" be the respective touchpoints. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(594). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(594) lies on these lines: 6,8 7,599
9,80 10,37 45,346
53,318 75,141 100,1030
210,430 220,281 313,321
319,524 519,1100 572,952
762,1089</p>
<p>
X(594) = midpoint of X(319) and X(894)<br>
X(594) = isogonal conjugate of X(593)<br>
X(594) = isotomic conjugate of X(1509)<br>
X(594) = anticomplement of X(17045)<br>
X(594) = crosspoint of X(10) and X(321)<br>
X(594) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (6,595), (58,1333)<br>
X(594) = barycentric square of X(10)<br>
X(594) = perspector of ABC and cross-triangle of ABC and Gemini triangle 19<br>
X(594) = barycentric product of vertices of Gemini triangle 26<br>
X(594) = {X(3661),X(3662)}-harmonic conjugate of X(17228)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X595">X(595) = 2nd HATZIPOLAKIS-YIU POINT</h3>
Trilinears r + R*(cos 2A - 1) : :
<br>
Trilinears a(a<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac - bc) : :
<br>
Trilinears sa<sup>2</sup> - SR : sb<sup>2</sup> - SR sc<sup>2</sup> - SR : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac - bc) : :
<p>
Let O(A) be the circle tangent to line BC and to the circumcircle of
triangle ABC at vertex A, and define O(B) and O(C) cyclically. X(595)
is the radical center of O(A), O(B), O(C).
<p>
See Antreas Hatzipolakis, Paul Yiu, Hyacinthos #2070
</p><p>
See Antreas Hatzipolakis and Paul Yiu, <a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/2070"> <b>Hyacinthos 2070</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(595) lies on these lines: 1,21 3,995
10,82 32,101 35,902
40,602 46,614 55,386
56,106 110,849 171,1125
387,390 517,580
</p><p>
X(595) = isogonal conjugate of X(596)<br>
X(595) = crosssum of X(244) and X(523)<br>
X(595) = {X(1),X(31)}-harmonic conjugate of X(58)<br> </p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X596">X(596) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(595)</h3>
Trilinears
1/[a(a<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac - bc)] : 1/[b(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + ba -
ca)] : 1/[c(c<sup>2</sup> + ca + cb - ab)]<br>Barycentrics 1/(a<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac - bc) :
1/(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + ba - ca) : 1/(c<sup>2</sup> + ca + cb - ab)
<p>X(596) lies on these lines: 10,38 37,39
58,82 65,519 244,1089
</p><p>

X(596) = anticomplement of X(4075)<br>

<h3 id="X597">X(597) = MIDPOINT OF X(2) AND X(6)</h3>
Trilinears
(4a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/a : (4b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>)/b : (4c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> +
b<sup>2</sup>)/c<br>Barycentrics 4a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>
: 4b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> : 4c<sup>2</sup> +
a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>
<p>X(597) lies on these lines: 2,6 5,542
30,182 39,1084 83,671
140,576 373,2854 511,549 518,551</p>
<p>X(597) = midpoint of X(2) and X(6)<br>
X(597) = reflection of X(141) in X(2)<br>
X(597) = complement of X(599)<br>
X(597) = crosssum of X(6) and X(574)<br>
X(597) = circumcenter of the pedal triangle of X(2)<br>
X(597) = circumcenter of the pedal triangle of X(6)<br>
X(597) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(598)<br>
X(597) = centroid of pedal triangle of X(182)<br>
X(597) = centroid of set consisting of the interiors (with or without boundaries) of the power circles<br>
X(597) = {X(395),X(396)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3815)<br>
X(597) = harmonic center of circles O(13,15) and O(14,16)<br>
X(597) = center of Lemoine ellipse<br>
X(597) = X(5)-of-anti-Artzt-triangle<br><p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X598">X(598) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(574)</h3>
Trilinears
bc/(a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup>) :
ca/(b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>) :
ab/(c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics 1/(a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup> -
2c<sup>2</sup>) : 1/(b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>) :
1/(c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup>)
<p>The Lemoine ellipse is the ellipse inscribed in triangle ABC having
X(2) and X(6) as foci. Let A' be where this ellipse meets sideline BC,
and define B' and C' cyclically. Then triangles ABC and A'B'C' are
perspective, and their perspector is X(598). (Bernard Gibert, 1/5/01,
Hyacinthos #2334)</p>
<p>X(598) lies on these lines: 2,187 4,575
6,671 30,262 76,524 98,381</p>
<p>
X(598) = isogonal conjugate of X(574)<br>
X(598) = isotomic conjugate of X(599)<br>
X(598) = trilinear pole of line X(351)X(523) (the Euler line of the 1st and 2nd Parry triangles)<br>
X(598) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(5094)<br>
X(598) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(5094)<br>
X(598) = perspector of ABC and anti-Artzt triangle<br>
X(598) = X(262)-of-anti-Artzt-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X599">X(599) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(598)</h3>

bc(a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup>) : ca(b<sup>2</sup>
- 2c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>) : ab(c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>
- 2b<sup>2</sup>)
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup>
: b<sup>2</sup> - 2c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup> : c<sup>2</sup> -
2a<sup>2</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup>

7,594 8,1086 76,338
340,458 381,511
</p><p>
X(599) = midpoint of X(2) and X(69)<br>

X(599) = isogonal conjugate of X(1383)<br>
X(599) = isotomic conjugate of X(598)<br>
X(599) = complement of X(1992)<br>
X(599) = anticomplement of X(597)<br>

<h3 id="X600">X(600) = 3rd HATZIPOLAKIS-YIU POINT</h3>
Barycentrics f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),
where f(a,b,c) = a<sup>2</sup>(bc + 2S)[abc(b + c - a) +
2(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)S]
<p>Let O<sub>A</sub> be the circle with center A and radius R, the
circumradius of triangle ABC. Let B<sub>A</sub> be the point where
O<sub>A</sub> meets line AB farthest from B. Define C<sub>B</sub> and
A<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let C<sub>A</sub> be the point where
O<sub>A</sub> meets line AC farthest from C. Define A<sub>B</sub> and
B<sub>C</sub> cyclically. X(600) is the radical center of the circles
AB<sub>A</sub>C<sub>A</sub>, BC<sub>B</sub>A<sub>B</sub>,
CA<sub>C</sub>B<sub>C</sub>. If "farthest from" is changed to "nearest
to" in the construction, the resulting point is X(5507). (Antreas
Hatzipolakis, Paul Yiu, 1/5/01, Hyacinthos #2344, #2346-8; for a
correction in coordinates, see Paul Yiu, Adgeom #202.)</p>
<p>If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view
<a href=
"X(600).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(600)</a>.
<p></p>
X(600) lies on this line: 4640,5507.
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

X(55)X(255)</h3>

sin<sup>2</sup>A + cos A : sin<sup>2</sup>B + cos B : sin<sup>2</sup>C
+ cos C<br>Barycentrics (sin A)(sin<sup>2</sup>A + cos A) : (sin
B)(sin<sup>2</sup>B + cos B) : (sin C)(sin<sup>2</sup>C + cos C)

<h3 id="X610">X(610) = X(63)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>

<h3 id="X611">X(611) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(55)X(511)</h3>

<h3 id="X612">X(612) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(2) AND X(9)X(31)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + 2bc (M. Iliev, 5/13/2007)
<br>
Trilinears bc + S<sub>&omega;</sub> : ca + S<sub>&omega;</sub> : ab + S<sub>&omega;</sub> (C. Lozada, 9/07/2013)
<br>
Trilinears (1 + cos A)(1 + cos B cos C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 + sec A)(1 + sec B sec C) : :
<p>
X(612) is the homothetic center of the incentral triangle and the Ayme triangle; see X(3610).</p>
<p>X(612) lies on these lines: 1,2 6,210
9,31 12,34 19,25 21,989
22,35 38,57 63,171
165,990 394,611 404,988
495,1060 518,940</p>
<p>
X(612) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(649)X(905)<br>
X(612) = trilinear product X(33)*X(1038)<br>
X(612) = trilinear product X(55)*X(388)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X613">X(613) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(56)X(511)</h3>
Trilinears W - sin A : W - sin B : W - sin C, where W = (a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)/(4*area)
<br>
Trilinears: a(S^2 - bc SW) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a(W - sin A) : b(W - sin B) : c(W - sin C)
<p>X(613) lies on these lines: 1,6 55,182
56,511 141,499 222,982
240,608 394,614 496,1069</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X614">X(614) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(2) AND X(11)X(33)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - 2bc (M. Iliev, 5/13/07)
<br>
Trilinears bc - S<sub>&omega;</sub> : ca - S<sub>&omega;</sub> : ab - S<sub>&omega;</sub> (C. Lozada, 9/07/2013)
<br>
Trilinears cot^2(B/2) + cot^2(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - cos A)(1 - cos B cos C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (1 - sec A)(1 - sec B sec C) : :
<p>
X(614) lies on these lines: 1,2 6,354
9,38 11,33 21,988 22,36
25,34 31,57 46,595
63,238 106,998 165,902
251,609 269,479 278,1096
305,350 394,613 496,1062
497,1040 968,1001 1616,3057
</p><p>
X(614) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,269), (28,86)<br>
X(614) = crosssum of X(42) and X(72)<br>
X(614) = trilinear product X(34)*X(1040)<br>
X(614) = trilinear product X(56)*X(497)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X615">X(615) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(589)</h3>
Trilinears (a<sup>2</sup> - 4*area)/a : :
<br>
Trilinears sin A - 2 sin B sin : :
<br>
Trilinears aR- bc : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> - 4*area : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup> - 2S : :
<p>X(615) lies on these lines: 1,3300 2,6 3,486
4,1152 5,372 32,639 39,641
140,371 605,750 606,748
</p><p>
X(615) = isogonal conjugate of X(589)<br>
X(615) = complement of X(491)<br>
X(615) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(486)<br>
X(615) = crosssum of X(6) and X(372)<br>
X(615) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(642)<br>
X(615) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(642)<br>
X(615) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(642)<br>
X(615) = homothetic center of inner Vecten and 4th tri-squares triangles<br>
X(615) = homothetic center of [outer Vecten of inner Vecten triangle] and pedal triangle of X(1152)<br>
</p><br><br>
<center><p></p>
<img alt="leftri" src="leftri.gif"> <b>Centers 616- 642
<img alt="rightri" src="rightri.gif"><br>were contributed by Bernard Gibert, March 2, 2001. Notation:</b>
<p style="font-weight: bold">S<sub>A</sub> = (b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)/2
S<sub>B</sub> = (c<sup>2</sup> + a<sup>2</sup> -
b<sup>2</sup>)/2 S<sub>C</sub> =
(a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/2</p>
<br>Joe Goggins (Oct. 19, 2005) found trilinears for points in this
section, using the following notation. Let
<p>F(13) = a csc(A + &pi;/3) + b csc(B + &pi;/3) + c csc(C +
&pi;/3)<br>F(14) = a csc(A - &pi;/3) + b csc(B - &pi;/3) + c csc(C - &pi;/3)<br>These are based on trilinears for the isogonic centers, X(13) and
X(14). In like manner, F(I) is defined for I = 15, 16, 17, 18, 61,
62.</p>
<p>Using this notation, we have, for example,<br>X(616) = F(13)/a - 2 csc(A + &pi;/3) : F(13)/b - 2 csc(B + &pi;/3) :
F(13)/c - 2 csc(C + &pi;/3)<br>X(617) = F(14)/a - 2 csc(A - &pi;/3) : F(14)/b - 2 csc(B - &pi;/3) :
F(14)/c - 2 csc(C - &pi;/3)</p>
<p>Trilinears of this sort are given below at X(i) for these I:
616-619, 621-624, 627-630, and 633-636.<br>
<img alt="underbar" src="underbar.gif"></p>
</center>
<h3 id="X616">X(616) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(13)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> -
2S<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + sqr(3) area)]/a
<p>Trilinears F(13)/a - 2
csc(A + &pi;/3) : F(13)/b - 2 csc(B + &pi;/3) : F(13)/c - 2 csc(C +
&pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)
</p><p>
The midpoint of X(616) and X(617) is the Steiner point, X(99).</p>
<p>X(616) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines: 2,13
3,299 4,627 14,148
15,532 20,633 30,298
69,74 302,381 303,549
489,2043 490,2044</p>
<p>
X(616) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (13,618), (148,14), (617,99), (621,298)<br>
X(616) = isogonal conjugate of X(3440)<br>
X(616) = anticomplement of X(13)<br>
X(616) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(621)<br>
X(616) = X(13)-of-anticomplementary-triangle<br>
X(616) = X(30)-Ceva conjugate of X(617)<br>
X(616) = X(298)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X617">X(617) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(14)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> -
2S<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> - sqr(3) area)]/a
<p>Trilinears F(14)/a - 2
csc(A - &pi;/3) : F(14)/b - 2 csc(B - &pi;/3) : F(14)/c - 2 csc(C -
&pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>
<p>X(617) lies on the Neuberg cubic and these lines: 2,14
3,298 4,628 13,148
16,533 20,634 30,299
69,74 302,549 303,381</p>
<p>
X(617) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (14,619), (148,13), (616,99), (622,299)<br>
X(617) = isogonal conjugate of X(3441)<br>
X(617) = anticomplement of X(14)<br>
X(617) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(622)<br>
X(617) = X(30)-Ceva conjugate of X(616)<br>
X(617) = X(299)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X618">X(618) = COMPLEMENT OF X(13)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= [2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 5S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> + 2
sqr(3)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area]/a
<p>Trilinears F(13)/a - csc(A
+ &pi;/3) : F(13)/b - csc(B + &pi;/3) : F(13)/c - csc(C + &pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>

5,629 14,99 15,298
30,623 39,395 61,627
140,630 141,542 396,532
</p><p>

X(618) = reflection of X(619) in X(620)<br>
X(618) = complementary conjugate of X(623)<br>
X(618) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(396)<br>
X(618) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(298)<br>
X(618) = X(13)-of-medial-triangle<br>
X(618) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(396)<br>
X(618) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(396)<br>
X(618) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(396)<br>

X(618) = outer Napoleon isogonal conjugate of X(17)<br>

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= [2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 5S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> - 2 sqr(3)
(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area]/a
<p>Trilinears F(14)/a - csc(A
- &pi;/3) : F(14)/b - csc(B - &pi;/3) : F(14)/c - csc(C - &pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>

16,299 30,624 39,396
62,628 140,629 141,542 395,533
</p><p>

X(619) = complementary conjugate of X(624)<br>
X(619) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(395)<br>
X(619) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(299)<br>

X(619) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(395)<br>
X(619) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(395)<br>

</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X620">X(620) = MIDPOINT OF X(618) AND X(619)</h3>
Trilinears [4S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> - (b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>)]/a : :
<b><br>
X(620) = 3*X(2) + X(99)
<p></b>
Let S = X(99). Let A' be the centroid of the triangle BCS, and define B' and C' cyclically. Let D' be the centroid of ABC. The four centroids form a quadrilateral homothetic to the quadrilateral ABCS. The center of homothety is X(620), which is the centroid of ABCS. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' and A"B"C" be the (equilateral) antipedal triangles of X(13) and X(14), resp. Let A* be the midpoint of A' and A", and define B* and C* cyclically. The triangle A*B*C* is homothetic to ABC, and the center of homothety is X(620). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(620) = center of the hyperbola H that is the locus of perspectors of circumconics centered at a point on line X(2)X(6), which is the locus of the X(2)-Ceva conjugate of P as P moves on line X(2)X(6). Also, H is the Kiepert hyperbola of the medial triangle; H is tangent to line X(2)X(6) at X(2), and H passes X(3), X(39) and X(114). H is also the bicevian conic of X(2) and X(99) (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
<p>
X(620) is the center of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of line X(2)X(6). The Brianchon point (perspector) of the inellipse is X(4590). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(620) lies on these lines:<br>2,99 3,114 30,625
98,631 141,542 187,325 230,538</p>
<p>
X(620) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,114), (99,115), (187,325), (618,619)<br>
X(620) = complement of X(115)<br>
X(620) = X(187)-of-X(2)-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(620) = X(230)-of-1st-Brocard-triangle<br>
X(620) = centroid of X(2)X(3)X(114)X(2482)<br>
X(620) = Kosnita(X(99),X(2)) point<br>
X(620) = crosssum of intersections of 1st and 2nd Lemoine circles (and the circle {{X(1687),X(1688),PU(1),PU(2)}})<br>
X(620) = QA-P29 center (Complement of QA-P2 wrt the Diagonal triangle) of quadrangle ABCX(2) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/57-qa-p29.html)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [sqr(3)
S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 2S<sub>A</sub> area]/a
<p>Trilinears F(15)/a - 2
sin(A + &pi;/3) : F(15)/b - 2 sin(B + &pi;/3) : F(15)/c - 2 sin(C +
&pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>

4,69 5,303 13,533
20,627 30,298 183,383

<h3 id="X623">X(623) = COMPLEMENT OF X(15)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where<br> f(a,b,c)
= [2(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area + sqr(3)
(S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> + 2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>)]/a
<p>Trilinears F(15)/a - sin(A
+ &pi;/3) : F(15)/b - sin(B + &pi;/3) : F(15)/c - sin(C + &pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>
<p>X(623) lies on these lines: 2,14 3,629
5,141 13,298 16,302
17,633 18,83 30,618 396,533
</p><p>

X(623) = reflection of X(624) in X(625)<br>
X(623) = inverse-in-nine-point-circle of X(624)<br>
X(623) = complement of X(15)<br>
X(623) = complementary conjugate of X(618)<br>
X(623) = crosspoint of X(2) and X(300)<br>
X(623) = intersection of diagonals of trapezoid PU(5)PU(11); i.e., the lines P(5)P(11) and U(5)U(11))<br>

<h3 id="X624">X(624) = COMPLEMENT OF X(16)</h3>

<h3 id="X625">X(625) = MIDPOINT OF X(623) AND X(624)</h3>
Trilinears [2(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)]/a : :

A construction of X(625) is given at <a href="https://beta.groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/27519"> Hyacinthos 27519</a>.
(Antreas Hatzipolakis and Peter Moses, April 16, 2018)
</p><p>
X(625) lies on these lines: 2,187 5,141 30,620 115,325 126,858 230,754
</p><p>

<h3 id="X626">X(626) = COMPLEMENT OF X(32)</h3>
Trilinears
(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>)/a : (c<sup>4</sup> + a<sup>4</sup>)/b:
(a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>4</sup>)/c
<br>Barycentrics b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup> : c<sup>4</sup> +
a<sup>4</sup> : a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>4</sup>
<p>
X(626) is the center of the inellipse that is the barycentric square of the de Longchamps line. The Brianchon point (perspector) of the inellipse is X(1502). (Randy Hutson, October 15, 2018)
</p><p>
X(626) lies on these lines: 2,32 3,114
5,141 10,760 37,746
39,325 76,115 316,384
</p><p>
X(626) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (32,315), (639,640)<br>
X(626) = complement of X(32)<br>
X(626) = complementary conjugate of X(39)<br>
X(626) = X(301)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X627">X(627) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(17)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> +
2S<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> + sqr(3) area)]/a
<p>Trilinears F(17)/a - 2
sec(A - &pi;/3) : F(17)/b - 2 sec(B - &pi;/3) : F(17)/c - 2 sec(C -
&pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>
<p>Erect equilateral triangles outwards on the sides of triangle ABC;
the circumcenter of the apices is X(627). (Peter Moses, 7/16,2003)
</p><p>
Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of the A-vertex of the inner Napoleon triangle, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the inner Napoleon triangle at X(5), and to the outer Napoleon triangle at X(627). (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(627) lies on the Napoleon cubic and these lines: 2,17
3,298 4,616 5,302
16,635 20,621 54,69
61,618 140,299
</p><p>
X(627) = reflection of X(17) in X(629)<br>
X(627) = isogonal conjugate of X(3489)<br>
X(627) = anticomplement of X(17)<br>
X(627) = anticomplementary conjugate of X(633)<br>
X(627) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (5,628), (302,2)<br>
X(627) = {X(54),X(1273)}-harmonic conjugate of X(628)<br>
X(627) = {X(69),X(631)}-harmonic conjugate of X(628)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X628">X(628) = ANTICOMPLEMENT OF X(18)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = [S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> +
2S<sub>A</sub>(a<sup>2</sup> - sqr(3) area)]/a
<p>Trilinears F(18)/a + 2
sec(A + &pi;/3) : F(18)/b + 2 sec(B + &pi;/3) : F(18)/c + 2 sec(C +
&pi;/3)</p>
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>

the circumcenter of the apices is X(628). (Peter Moses, 7/16,2003)
</p><p>

<h3 id="X631">X(631) = 3/5*OG</h3>
Trilinears 2 cos A + cos B cos C : 2 cos B + cos C cos A : 2 cos C + cos A cos B
<br>
Trilinears cos A + sin B sin C : cos B + sin C sin A : cos C + sin A sin B : :
<br>
Trilinears sec A + 2 sec B sec C : sec B + 2 sec C sec A : sec C + 2 sec A sec B
<br>
Trilinears a/(b sec B + c sec C) + 2 cos A : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)(2 cos A + cos B cos C) : (sin B)(2 cos B + cos C cos A) : (sin C)(2 cos C + cos A cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics 3a^4 - 4a^2(b^2 + c^2) + (b^2 - c^2)^2 : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2 SA a^2 + SB SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics 2 S^2 - SB SC : :
<br>
Barycentrics cot B cot C - 2 : :
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(631) has Shinagawa coefficients (2,-1).
</p><p>
Let AeBeCe and AiBiCi be the Ae and Ai triangles (aka K798e and K798i triangles). X(631) is the radical center of the circumcircles of triangles AAeAi, BBeBi, CCeCi. (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)

2(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area]/a
<p>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where
g(A,B,C) = 2 + sin 2B + sin 2C - cos 2B - cos 2C<br> h(a,b,c)
: h(b,c,a) : h(c,a,b), where h(a,b,c) = (a<sup>2</sup> + 4
area(ABC))(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - (b<sup>2</sup> -
c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup></p>
<p>X(639) lies on these lines: 2,371 3,641
5,141 32,615 69,485 315,372</p>
<p>X(639) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (315,372),
(371,637)<br>X(639) = reflection of X(640) in X(626)<br>X(639) = complement of X(371)<br>X(639) = complementary conjugate of X(641)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X640">X(640) = COMPLEMENT OF X(372)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) =
[2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> -
2(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area]/a<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(640) lies on these lines: 2,372 3,642
5,141 69,486 315,371</p>

(372,638)<br>X(640) = reflection of X(639) in X(626)<br>X(640) = complement of X(372)<br>X(640) = complementary conjugate of X(642)</p>

<h3 id="X641">X(641) = COMPLEMENT OF X(485)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) =
[2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 3S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> +
2(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) area]/a<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>Erect squares outwards on the sides of triangle ABC; the
circumcenter of the centers of the squares is X(641). (Peter Moses,
7/16,2003)</p>
<p>X(641) lies on these lines: 2,372 3,639
39,615 140,141 371,492</p>

X(641) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(590)<br>
X(641) = perspector of medial triangle and outer Vecten of outer Vecten triangle (note: the medial triangle is the inner Vecten of outer Vecten triangle.)<br>

f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) =
[2S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub> + 3S<sub>A</sub>a<sup>2</sup> -

<h3 id="X643">X(643) = TRILINEAR MULTIPLIER FOR KIEPERT PARABOLA</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c -
a)/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(643) satisfies the equation X*(incircle) = Kiepert parabola, where
* denotes trilinear multiplication, defined by<br>(u : v : w) * (x : y : z) = ux : vy : wz.</p>
<p>X(643) lies on these lines: 8,1098 99,109
100,110 101,931 162,190
163,1018 212,312 283,1043</p>
<p></p>

X(643) = trilinear pole of line X(9)X(21)<br>

<h3 id="X644">X(644) = TRILINEAR MULTIPLIER FOR YFF PARABOLA</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c - a)/(b -
c)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(644) satisfies the equation X*(incircle) = Yff parabola, where *
denotes trilinear multiplication, defined by<br>(u : v : w) * (x : y : z) = ux : vy : wz.</p>
</p><p>
X(644) is the perspector of the anticevian triangle of X(100) and the unary cofactor triangle of the intangents triangle. (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>

78,728 100,101 105,1083

934,1025

X(644) = X(650)-cross conjugate of X(9)<br>
X(644) = eigencenter of Caelum triangle<br>
X(644) = eigencenter of 5th mixtilinear triangle<br>
X(644) = perspector of unary cofactor triangles of 3rd and 5th mixtilinear triangles<br>
X(644) = perspector of 5th mixtilinear triangle and unary cofactor triangle of 3rd mixtilinear triangle<br>

<h3 id="X645">X(645) = BARYCENTRIC MULTIPLIER FOR KIEPERT PARABOLA</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c -
a)/[a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= (b + c - a)/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)
<p>X(645) satisfies the equation X*(incircle) = Kiepert parabola, where
* denotes barycentric multiplication, defined by<br>(u : v : w) * (x : y : z) = ux : vy : wz (barycentric coordinates; see
note at X(2)).</p>
<p>X(645) lies on these lines: 9,261 99,101
100,931 294,314 644,646
648,668 651,799 666,670

<h3 id="X646">X(646) = BARYCENTRIC MULTIPLIER FOR YFF PARABOLA</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c -
a)/[a<sup>2</sup>(b - c)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= (b + c - a)/[a(b - c)]
<p>X(646) satisfies the equation X*(incircle) = Yff parabola, where *
denotes barycentric multiplication, defined by<br>(u : v : w) * (x : y : z) = ux : vy : wz (barycentric coordinates, see
note at X(2)).</p>

<h3 id="X647">X(647) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(2) AND X(3)</h3>
Trilinears a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin 2A sin(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (sin A)(tan B - tan C) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos(A - 2B) - cos(A - 2C) : :
<p>
X(647) is the point whose trilinears are coefficients for the Euler line. <br>
X(647) = radical center of the circumcircle, nine-point center, and Brocard circle (Wilson Stothers, 3/13/2003)<br>
X(647) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle of the Jerabek hyperbola. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let L be the line at infinity. X(647) = X(230)X(231)&cap;X(441)X(525); that is, the polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of L and the isotomic conjugate of polar conjugate of L. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
The circumcircle of the anti-orthocentroidal triangle is here named the <b>anti-orthocentroidal circle.</b> The point X(647) is the radical center of these three circles: circumcircle, orthocentroidal circle, anti-orthocentroidal circle. (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(647) lies on these lines: 1,1021 2,850 50,654 111,842 112,1304 184,878 187,237 230,231 441,525 520,652
</p><p>
X(647) = isogonal conjugate of X(648)<br>
X(647) = isotomic conjugate of X(6331)<br>
X(647) = complement of X(850)<br>
X(647) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,125), (107,51), (110,184), (112,6), (1304,1495)<br>
X(647) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,110), (6,112), (107,275)<br>
X(647) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,1021), (2,525), (6,523), (110,112), (185,647), (216,520), (512,1196), (651,653), (850,1235)<br>
X(647) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(2)X(3)<br>
X(647) = perspector of the Jerabek hyperbola<br>
X(647) = orthojoin of X(125)<br>
X(647) = perspector of ABC and the side-triangle of the cevian triangles of X(3) and X(6)<br>
X(647) = PU(4)-harmonic conjugate of X(232)<br>
X(647) = bicentric difference of PU(i) for these i: 17, 145, 157<br>
X(647) = PU(17)-harmonic conjugate of X(185)<br>
X(647) = crossdifference of PU(30)<br>
X(647) = barycentric product of PU(75)<br>
X(647) = trilinear pole of PU(109) (line X(3269)X(9409))<br>
X(647) = isotomic conjugate of the trilinear pole of line X(4)X(69)<br>
X(647) = isotomic conjugate of isogonal conjugate of X(3049)<br>
X(647) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(125)<br>
X(647) = intersection of trilinear polars of any 2 points on the Jerabek hyperbola<br>
X(647) = X(187)-of-2nd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(647) = X(187)-of-3rd-Parry-triangle<br>
X(647) = intersection of the Lemoine axes of ABC and the 5th Euler triangle<br>
X(647) = X(92)-isoconjugate of X(110)<br>
X(647) = inverse-in-Parry-circle of X(3569)<br>
X(647) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(6528)<br>
X(647) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(6528)<br>
X(647) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(5191); see X(2)<br>
X(647) = midpoint of PU(145)<br>
X(647) = PU(157)-harmonic conjugate of X(51)<br>
X(647) = X(649)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
X(648) = barycentric product X(4)*X(99)<br>
X(657) = perspector of ciurcumconic through vertices of intangents triangle<br>
X(657) = X(2)-Ceva conjugate of X(14714)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X648">X(648) = TRILINEAR POLE OF EULER LINE</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>)]
<br>
Trilinears csc 2A csc(B - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears (csc A)/(tan B - tan C) : :
<p>
X(648) is constructed as the pole of the Euler line L as follows: let A", B", C" be the points where L meets the sidelines BC, CA, AB of ABC. Let A', B', C' be the harmonic conjugates of A", B", C" with respect to {B,C}, {C,A}, {A,B}, respectively, The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(648).
</p><p>
Let T be the anticevian triangle of X(4), and let U be the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(4). Let TT be the tangential triangle of U with respect to T. Then ABC and TT are perspective, and X(648) is their perspector. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(648) lies on the Steiner circumellipse, the MacBeath circumconic, these lines:<br>4,452 6,264 27,903
94,275 95,216 99,112
107,110 108,931 132,147
155,1093 162,190 185,1105
193,317 232,385 249,687
250,523 297,340 447,519
645,668 651,823 653,662
925,933 1020,1021 1075,1092
</p><p>
X(648) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (287,6), (340,297), (1494,2)<br>
X(648) = isogonal conjugate of X(647)<br>
X(648) = isotomic conjugate of X(525)<br>
X(648) = cevapoint of X(110) and X(112)<br>
X(648) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (6,250), (110,99), (112,107), (520,95), (523,264)<br>
X(648) = trilinear pole of PU(30)<br>
X(648) = crossdifference of PU(109)<br>
X(648) = MacBeath circumconic antipode of X(287)<br>
X(648) = cevapoint of X(185) and X(647)<br>
X(648) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(523) (line X(115)X(125))<br>
X(648) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(523)<br>
X(648) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(656)<br>
X(648) = Feuerbach image of X(4) if ABC is acute<br>
X(648) = Brianchon point (perspector) of inscribed parabola with focus X(112)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X649">X(649) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(1) and X(2)</h3>
Trilinears a(b - c) : b(c - a) : c(a - b)
<br>
Trilinears csc^2 (B/2) - csc^2 (C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cot^2 (B/2) - cot^2 (C/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b - c) : b<sup>2</sup>(c - a) : c<sup>2</sup>(a - b)
<p>
X(649) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle of the conic {{A, B, C, X(1), X(6)}}. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
A'B'C' be the excentral triangle and H the hyperbola {{A',B',C',X(1),X(9}}, so that H is the Jerabek hyperbola of A'B'C'. Let TT be the tangential triangle, wrt A'B'C', of H. Then T and TT are perspective, and their perspector is X(649). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(649) lies on these lines:<br>31,884 42,788 44,513
57,1024 89,1022 100,660
101,901 109,919 187,237
190,889 239,514 693,812

X(649) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (512,513), (649,665)<br>
X(649) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,190), (6,101), (57,109), (81,100)<br>
<p>X(649) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,649), (2,514), (9,522), (37,513), (100,644), (101,1331), (440,525), (523,1213)<br>

<h3 id="X650">X(650) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(1) AND X(3)</h3>
Trilinears cos B - cos C : cos C - cos A : cos A - cos B
<br>
Trilinears (b - c)(b + c - a) : (c - a)(c + a - b) : (a - b)(a + b - c)
<br>
Trilinears cos(A/2) sin(B/2 - C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears sin^2(B/2) - sin^2(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos^2(B/2) - cos^2(C/2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin A (cos B - cos C) : sin B (cos C - cos A) : sin C (cos A - cos B)
<br>
Barycentrics a(b - c)(b + c - a) : b(c - a)(c + a - b) : c(a - b)(a + b - c)
<p>
X(650) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle of the Feuerbach hyperbola. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let T1, T2, T3 denote the intouch, extouch,and incentral triangles. Let T4 be the side triangle of T2 and T3; T5 that of T3 and T1, and T6 that of T1 and T2. Then X(650) is the perspector of triangle ABC and T4, of ABC and T5, and of ABC and T6. (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
X(650) is the point of intersection of orthic axis, antiorthic axis and Gergonne line, these being the trilinear polars of X(4), X(1) and X(7), respectively. More generally, X(650) is the intersection of the trilinear polars of every pair of points on the Feuerbach hyperbola.
(Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(650) lies on these lines:<br>
2,693 44,513 55,884 100,919 230,231 241,514 521,1021 663,861
</p><p>
X(650) = midpoint of X(649) and X(661)<br>
X(650) = isogonal conjugate of X(651)<br>
X(650) = complement of X(693)<br>
X(650) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (2,11), (100,55), (101,37), (108,33)<br>
X(650) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,100), (57, 108), (101,284), (514,522)<br>
X(650) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,650), (6,513), (9,521), (73,652), (101,109), (222,905), (226,514), (525,1211), (649,1201), (663,1200), (665,1362)<br>
X(650) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(650) = orthojoin of X(1521)<br>
X(650) = isotomic conjugate of X(4554)<br>
X(650) = trilinear pole of line X(926)X(2170) (the tangent to the incircle at X(3022))<br>
X(650) = anticomplement of X(4885)<br>
X(650) = perspector of the Feuerbach hyperbola<br>
X(650) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(11)<br>
X(650) = bicentric difference of PU(i) for i in (15, 57, 59, 60, 80, 94, 125)<br>
X(650) = PU(15)-harmonic conjugate of X(65)<br>
X(650) = PU(57)-harmonic conjugate of X(1155)<br>
X(650) = PU(59)-harmonic conjugate of X(3057)<br>
X(650) = PU(60)-harmonic conjugate of X(56)<br>
X(650) = PU(80)-harmonic conjugate of X(2646)<br>
X(650) = PU(94)-harmonic conjugate of X(354)<br>
X(650) = PU(125)-harmonic conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(650) = orthic isogonal conjugate of X(3270)<br>
X(650) = X(1)-Ceva conjugate of X(2310)<br>
X(650) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(664)<br>
X(650) = crosspoint of X(1) and X(651)<br>
X(650) = radical center of {circumcircle, nine-point circle, Bevan circle}<br>

X(650) = bicentric difference of PU(112)<br>
X(650) = PU(112)-harmonic conjugate of X(55)<br>

<h3 id="X662">X(662) = TRILINEAR POLE OF LINE X(1)X(21)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(cot B - cot C) : 1/(cot C - cot A) : 1/(cot A - cot B)
<br>
Trilinears 1/(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(cos 2B - cos 2C) : :
<br>
Trilinears d(a,b,c) : : , where d(a,b,c) = directed distance of A to line X(115)X(125)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)/(cot B - cot C) : (sin B)/(cot C - cot A) : (sin C)/(cot A - cot B)
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the excentral triangle and H the Stammler hyperbola. Let T be the tangential triangle, with respect to A'B'C', of H. Then T and ABC are perspective, and their perspector is X(662). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A2B2C2 and A3B3C3 be the 2nd and 3rd Parry triangles. Let A' be the trilinear product A2*A3, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(1)X(21), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(7)X(21), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(8)X(21), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(10)X(21), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(21)X(36), and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(662). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(662) lies on these lines:<br>1,897 3,1098 6,757
27,913 48,75 60,404

<h3 id="X671">X(671) = TRILINEAR POLE OF LINE X(2)X(523)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the 4th Brocard triangle. Let A" be the pole, wrt the polar circle, of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(671). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the X(2)-Fuhrmann triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A in B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(671). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
Let Pa be the perspector of the A-Neuberg circle, and define Pb and Pc cyclically. The lines APa, BPb, CPc concur in X(671). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the reflection in BC of the A-vertex of the antipedal triangle of X(2), and define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcircles of A'BC, B'CA, and C'AB concur at X(671). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
If you have The Geometer's Sketchpad, you can view <a href="X(671).gsp" style="font-weight: bold">X(671)</a>.
</p><p>
X(671) lies on the Steiner circumellipse, the Darboux septic, and these lines:<br>2,99 4,542 6,598 10,190 13,531 14,530 30,98 76,338 83,597 226,664 262,381 316,524 321,668 485,489 486,490
</p><p>
X(671) = midpoint of X(2) and X(148)<br>
X(671) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (2,115), (99,2)<br>
X(671) = isogonal conjugate of X(187)<br>
X(671) = isotomic conjugate of X(524)<br>
X(671) = cevapoint of X(6) and X(23)<br>
X(671) = X(316)-cross conjugate of X(83)<br>
X(671) = anticomplement of X(2482)<br>
X(671) = the point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the Steiner circumellipse and the Kiepert hyperbola<br>
X(671) = Kiepert hyperbola antipode of X(2)<br>
X(671) = Steiner circumellipse antipode of X(99)<br>
X(671) = projection from Steiner inellipse to Steiner circumellipse of X(115)<br>
X(671) = antigonal image of X(2)<br>
X(671) = syngonal conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(671) = inverse-in-polar-circle of X(5095)<br>
X(671) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(468)<br>
X(671) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(468)<br>
X(671) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(896)<br>
X(671) = Kirikami concurrent circles image of X(13)<br>
X(671) = Kirikami concurrent circles image of X(14)<br>
X(671) = X(3) of anti-McCay triangle<br>
X(671) = crossdifference of PU(107)<br>
X(671) = McCay-to-Artzt similarity image of X(6)<br>
X(671) = perspector of ABC and 1st Brocard triangle of anti-McCay triangle<br>
X(671) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(7607)<br>
X(671) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(576)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X680">X(680) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(6) AND X(158)</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C): f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = cos<sup>2</sup>A (sin B
cos<sup>2</sup>B - sin C cos<sup>2</sup>C)<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = sin A f(A,B,C)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(680)
lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(680) lies on this line: 30,511 </p>
<p>X(680) = isogonal conjugate of X(681)<br>X(680) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(158)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X681">X(681) = TRILINEAR POLE OF LINE X(6)X(158)</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C): f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = (sec<sup>2</sup>A)/(sin
B cos<sup>2</sup>B - sin C cos<sup>2</sup>C)<br>Barycentrics (sin A)f(A,B,C): (sin B)f(B,C,A) : (sin
C)f(C,A,B)
<p>X(681) lies on the circumcircle.</p>
<p>X(681) lies on this line: 110,823</p>
<p>X(681) = isogonal conjugate of X(680)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X682">X(682) = POINT ARNEB</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = sec B csc<sup>3</sup>C + sec C
csc<sup>3</sup>B<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= sin A f(A,B,C)
<p>X(682) lies on these lines: 3,69 154,237
248,695</p>
<p>X(682) = isogonal conjugate of X(683)<br>X(682) = crosspoint of X(3) and X(32)<br>X(682) = crosssum of X(4) and X(76)</p>
<p></p>

<h3 id="X683">X(683) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(682)</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C): f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = 1/[sec B
csc<sup>3</sup>C + sec C csc<sup>3</sup>B]<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = sin A f(A,B,C)
<p>
X(683) lies on this line: 25,305
</p><p>
X(683) = isogonal conjugate of X(682)<br>
X(683) = isotomic conjugate of X(6467)<br>
X(683) = cevapoint of X(4) and X(76)<br>

<h3 id="X690">X(690) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF LINE X(6) AND X(110)</h3>
Trilinears bc(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)(2a<sup>2</sup> - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (cot B - cot C) (2 cot A - cot B - cot C) : :
</p><p>
Let NaNbNc and Na'Nb'Nc' be the outer and inner Napoleon triangles, respectively. Let A' be the isogonal conjugate of Na wrt Na'Nb'Nc', and define B' and C' cyclically. Let A" be the isogonal conjugate of Na' wrt NaNbNc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(690). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2015)
</p><p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(690) lies on the line at infinity.

<h3 id="X691">X(691) = TRILINEAR POLE OF LINE X(6)X(110)</h3>

<p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line of reflection of the line X(6)X(13) in line BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(691). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)

<br>

<p>
X(693): Let A<sub>29</sub>B<sub>29</sub>C<sub>29</sub> and A<sub>30</sub>B<sub>30</sub>C<sub>30</sub> be Gemini triangles 29 and 30, resp. Let E<sub>29</sub> and E<sub>30</sub> be the {ABC, Gemini 29}-circumconic and {ABC, Gemini 30}-circumconic, resp. Let A' be the intersection of the tangent to E<sub>29</sub> at A<sub>29</sub> and the tangent to E<sub>30</sub> at A<sub>30</sub>. Define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC" concur in X(693). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)

X(693) = cevapoint of X(2) and X(149)<br>

<h3 id="X694">X(694) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(385)</h3>
Trilinears a/(a<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B", C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(694). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let La be the trilinear polar, wrt A'B'C', of A, and define Lb, Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B", C" cyclically. A'A", B'B", C'C" concur in X(694). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the 1st Brocard triangle. Let A" be the trilinear pole of line B'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(385). Let A* be the trilinear pole of line B"C", and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(694). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
Let DEF and D'E'F' be the 1st and 2nd Sharygin triangles. Let A' be the barycentric product D*D', and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(694). (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)
</p><p>
X(694) lies on these lines:<br>6,1084 37,256 42,893
110,251 111,805 141,308
172,904 257,335 351,881
384,695 882,888
</p><p>

X(694) = isogonal conjugate of X(385)<br>
X(694) = isotomic conjugate of X(3978)<br>
X(694) = cevapoint of X(384) and X(385)<br>
X(694) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (446,232), (511,6)<br>
X(694) = trilinear pole of PU(1) (line X(39)X(512))<br>
X(694) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of line PU(11), alias X(141)X(523))<br>
X(694) = antipode of X(6) in hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(2),X(6)}}<br>
X(694) = perspector of circumconic centered at X(1567)<br>
X(694) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(1567)<br>

<h3 id="X695">X(695) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(384)</h3>
Trilinears a/(a<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the cross-triangle of the 1st and 2nd Neuberg triangles. Let A" be the crossdifference of B' and C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(695). Let La be the trilinear polar of A', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A* = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(695). Also, X(695) is the orthologic center of ABC to A'B'C'. The reciprocal orthologic center is X(4). (Randy Hutson, July 31 2018)
</p><p>
X(695) lies on these lines: 69,194 99,711 248,682 384,694
</p><p>
X(695) = isogonal conjugate of X(384)<br>
X(695) = isotomic conjugate of crosspoint of PU(11)<br>
X(695) = cevapoint of PU(1)<br>
X(695) = trilinear pole of line X(647)X(3221)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X696">X(696) = EVEN (- 4, - 3) INFINITY POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a <sup>-5</sup>(b <sup>-3</sup>
+ c <sup>-3</sup>) - a <sup>-4</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> + c
<sup>-4</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(696)
lies on the line at infinity. The first trilinear coordinate has the
form</p>
<p>a<sup>m-1</sup>(b<sup>n</sup> + c<sup>n</sup>) -
a<sup>n-1</sup>(b<sup>m</sup> + c<sup>m</sup>).</p>
<p>If m and n are distinct integers, this form fits the definition of
<b>even</b> polynomial center as in Clark Kimberling, "Functional
equations associated with triangle geometry," <i>Aequationes
Mathematicae</i> 45 (1993) 127-152. This form, perhaps appearing
initially here (July 7, 2001) defines a triangle center for arbitrary
distinct real numbers m and n. Selected even infinity and circumcircle
points begin at X(696); odd ones begin at X(768).</p>
<p>Certain points of this type occur prior to this section. They are as
follows:</p>
<p> X(538) = even (- 2, 0) infinity
point<br> X(536) = even (- 1, 0) infinity point<br> X(519) = even (0, 1) infinity point<br> X(106) = even (0, 1) circumcircle
point<br> X(524) = even (0, 2) infinity point<br> X(111) = even (0, 2) circumcircle
point<br> X(518) = even (1, 2) infinity point<br> X(105) = even (1, 2) circumcircle
point<br> X(674) = even (2, 3) infinity point<br> X(675) = even (2, 3) circumcircle
point<br> X(511) = even (2, 4) infinity point<br> X(98) = even (2, 4) circumcircle
point</p>
<p>X(696) lies on these lines: 30,511 313,561</p>
<p>X(696) = isogonal conjugate of X(697)\
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X697">X(697) = EVEN (- 4, - 3) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a <sup>-5</sup>(b
<sup>-3</sup> + c <sup>-3</sup>) - a <sup>-4</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> + c
<sup>-4</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(697) lies on the circumcircle. This is one of several points of
the form given by first trilinear</p>
<p>1/[a<sup>m-1</sup>(b<sup>n</sup> + c<sup>n</sup>) -
a<sup>n-1</sup>(b<sup>m</sup> + c<sup>m</sup>)],</p>
<p>hence the name "(m, n)-circumcircle point".</p>
<p>X(697) lies on this line: 100,560</p>
<p>X(697) = isogonal conjugate of X(696)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X698">X(698) = EVEN (- 4, - 2) INFINITY
POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a <sup>-5</sup>(b <sup>-2</sup>
+ c <sup>-2</sup>) - a <sup>-3</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> + c
<sup>-4</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(698)
lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(698) lies on these (parallel) lines:
6,194 30,511 75,257 76,141</p>
<p>X(698) = isogonal conjugate of X(699)<br>X(698) = isotomic conjugate of X(3225)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X699">X(699) = EVEN (- 4, - 2) CIRCUMCIRCLE
POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a <sup>-5</sup>(b
<sup>-2</sup> + c <sup>-2</sup>) - a <sup>-3</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> + c
<sup>-4</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(699) lies on the circumcircle.</p>
<p>X(699) lies on these lines: 32,99 172,932
251,689</p>

<h3 id="X728">X(728) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(8)X(9) AND
X(57)X(345)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = (b + c -
a)<sup>3</sup><br>Trilinears
cot<sup>3</sup>(A/2) : cot<sup>3</sup>(B/2) : cot<sup>3</sup>(C/2)
(M. Iliev, 4/12/07)
<p>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where
g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)</p>
<p>X(728) lies on these lines: 8,9 40,1018
57,345 78,644 200,220</p>
<p>
X(728) = isogonal conjugate of X(738)<br>
X(728) = isotomic conjugate of X(23062)<br>
X(728) = X(346)-Ceva conjugate of X(200)<br>
X(728) = X(480)-cross conjugate of X(200)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X729">X(729) = EVEN (- 2, 0) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a<sup>-3</sup>(b<sup>0</sup> + c<sup>0</sup>) - a <sup>-1</sup>(b<sup>-2</sup> + c <sup>-2</sup>)]
<br>
Trilinears a/(2b^2c^2 - a^2b^2 - a^2c^2) : :
<p>
X(729) lies on the circumcircle and these lines: 6,99 32,110
83,689 100,213 187,805</p>
<p>
X(729) = isogonal conjugate of X(538)<br>
X(729) = isotomic conjugate of X(30736)<br>
X(729) = &Lambda;(X(2), X(39))<br>
X(729) = &Psi;(X(6), X(669))<br>
X(729) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(669)<br>
X(729) = trilinear pole, wrt circumsymmedial triangle, of line X(2)X(6)<br>
X(729) = eigencenter of dual of orthic triangle<br>
X(729) = X(11636)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X730">X(730) = EVEN (- 2, 1) INFINITY POINT</h3>

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a <sup>-3</sup>(b<sup>1</sup> +
c<sup>1</sup>) - a<sup>0</sup>(b <sup>-2</sup> + c <sup>-2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)

lies on the line at infinity.</p>

8,194 10,39 30,511 </p>

(M. Iliev, 4/12/07)

<h3 id="X739">X(739) = EVEN (- 1, 0) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>

<sup>-1</sup> + c <sup>-1</sup>)] : :
<br>

<p>
X(739) lies on the circumcircle and these lines: 6,100 31,101 81,99
108,608 109,604 813,902
</p><p>

<h3 id="X740">X(740) = EVEN (- 1, 1) INFINITY POINT</h3>
Trilinears a <sup>-2</sup>(b<sup>1</sup> + c<sup>1</sup>) - a<sup>0</sup>(b <sup>-1</sup> + c <sup>-1</sup>) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (a^2 - b c) (b + c) : :
<p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(740) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the outer Garcia triangle and A"B"C" the inner Garcia triangle. X(740) is the radical center of the circumcircles of AA'A", BB'B", CC'C". (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
<p>
X(740) lies on these (parallel) lines:<br>
1,75 8,192 10,37 30,511
42,321 43,312 238,239 872,1089
</p><p>
X(740) = isogonal conjugate of X(741)<br>
X(740) = isotomic conjugate of X(18827)<br>
X(740) = crosspoint of X(239) and X(350)<br>
X(740) = crosssum of X(58) and X(1326)<br>
X(740) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(798)<br>
X(740) = X(10)-Hirst inverse of X(37)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

Trilinears

- bcS :: b<sup>2</sup> + rs - caS : c<sup>2</sup> + rs - abS<br>Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup> - 2abc : b<sup>3</sup> - 2abc :
c<sup>3</sup> - 2abc

2ab)<br>Trilinears a<sup>2</sup> + rs

<h3 id="X756">X(756) = CROSSPOINT OF X(10) AND X(37)</h3>
Trilinears (b +
c)<sup>2</sup> : (c + a)<sup>2</sup> : (a + b)<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics a(b + c)<sup>2</sup> : b(c + a)<sup>2</sup> :
c(a + b)<sup>2</sup>
<p>X(756) lies on these lines: 1,748 2,38
9,31 10,321 12,201
37,42 45,55 63,750
100,846 171,896 200,968 405,976</p>
<p>
X(756) = isogonal conjugate of X(757)<br>
X(756) = isotomic conjugate of X(873)<br>
X(756) = X(37)-Ceva conjugate of (1500)<br>
X(756) = crosspoint of X(10) and X(37)<br>
X(756) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (58,81), (60,593), (244,1019)<br>
X(756) = trilinear square of X(37)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X758">X(758) = EVEN (1, 3) INFINITY POINT</h3>

<br>

</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X768">X(768) = ODD (- 4, - 3) INFINITY POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a <sup>-5</sup>(b <sup>-3</sup>
- c <sup>-3</sup>) + a <sup>-4</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> - c
<sup>-4</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(768)
lies on the line at infinity. The first trilinear coordinate has the
form</p>
<p>a<sup>m-1</sup>(b<sup>n</sup> - c<sup>n</sup>) +
a<sup>n-1</sup>(b<sup>m</sup> - c<sup>m</sup>),</p>
<p>corresponding to an <b>odd</b> polynomial center in case m and n are
distinct integers. See the note accompanying X(696), where even (m,n)
infinity points and even (m,n) circumcircle points are introduced. [For
nonzero n, "odd (m,n) circumcircle point" would be a misnomer (as the
point is an even polynomial center); consequently, the prefix o- is
used to distinguish this point from "even (m,n) circumcircle point"
defined at X(696).] Certain points of these classes occur prior to this
section. They are as follows:
</p><p>
X(523) = odd (- 4, - 2) infinity point<br>
X(688) = odd (- 4, 0) infinity point<br>
X(689) = o-(- 4, 0) circumcircle point<br>
X(514) = odd (- 2, - 1) infinity point<br>
X(101) = o-(- 2, - 1) circumcircle point<br>
X(512) = odd (- 2, 0) infinity point<br>
X(99) = o-(- 2, 0) circumcircle point<br>
X(513) = odd (- 1, 0) infinity point<br>
X(100) = o-(- 1, 0) circumcircle point<br>
X(514) = odd (0, 1) infinity point<br>
X(101) = o-(0, 1) circumcircle point<br>
X(523) = odd (0, 2) infinity point<br>
X(110) = o-(0, 2) circumcircle point<br>
X(513) = odd (1, 2) infinity point<br>
X(100) = o-(1, 2) circumcircle point<br>
X(512) = odd (2, 4) infinity point<br>
X(99) = o-(2, 4) circumcircle point<br></p>
<p>X(768) lies on this line: 30,511</p>
<p>X(768) = isogonal conjugate of X(769)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X769">X(769) = o-(- 4, - 3) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a <sup>-5</sup>(b
<sup>-3</sup> - c <sup>-3</sup>) + a <sup>-4</sup>(b <sup>-4</sup> - c
<sup>-4</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(769) lies on the circumcircle. This is one of several points of
the form given by first trilinear</p>
<p>1/[a<sup>m-1</sup>(b<sup>n</sup> - c<sup>n</sup>) +
a<sup>n-1</sup>(b<sup>m</sup> - c<sup>m</sup>)],</p>
<p>hence the name "(m, n)-circumcircle point".</p>
<p>X(769) = isogonal conjugate of X(768)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X770">X(770) = POINT
ACAMAR</h3>
Trilinears
f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = cos<sup>3</sup>B -
cos<sup>3</sup>C<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= (sin A)f(A,B,C)
<p>X(770) lies on this line: 44,513</p>
<p>X(770) = isogonal conjugate of X(771)<br>X(770) = crosssum of X(1) and X(770)<br>X(770) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line
X(1)X(1092)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

Trilinears
f(A,B,C) : f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B), where f(A,B,C) = 1/(cos<sup>3</sup>B -
cos<sup>3</sup>C)<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= (sin A)f(A,B,C)

<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X783">X(783) = o-(- 4, 4) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a
<sup>-5</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> - c<sup>4</sup>) + a<sup>3</sup>(b
<sup>-4</sup> - c <sup>-4</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)

<h3 id="X798">X(798) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(1) AND X(75)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<br>
Trilinears S<sub>B</sub>S<sub>B</sub> - S<sub>C</sub>S<sub>C</sub> : :
<br>
Trilinears Area(BCP(1)) - Area(BCU(1)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>3</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) : :
<p>
X(798) lies on these lines: 44,513 163,1101
667,788 688,872 765,813
</p><p>
X(798) = isogonal conjugate of X(799)<br>
X(798) = X(163)-Ceva conjugate of X(31)<br>
X(798) = crosspoint of X(31) and X(163)<br>
X(798) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,798), (38,661), (86,1019), (99,645), (190,668), (513,1107)<br>
X(798) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1)X(75)<br>
X(798) = bicentric difference of PU(i) for i in (36, 85)<br>
X(798) = PU(36)-harmonic conjugate of X(1964)<br>
X(798) = PU(85)-harmonic conjugate of X(2667)<br>
X(798) = perspector wrt excentral triangle of the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(2)<br>
X(798) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(670)<br>
X(798) = trilinear product of PU(105)<br>
X(798) = trilinear pole of line X(3121)X(4117) (the tangent to the inellipse that is the trilinear square of the Lemoine axis, at the trilinear square of X(512))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X799">X(799) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(798)</h3>
Trilinears csc<sup>2</sup>A/(cos<sup>2</sup>B - cos<sup>2</sup>C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (csc A)/(cos<sup>2</sup>B - cos<sup>2</sup>C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics bc/(b^2 - c^2) : :
<p>
Let La be the A-extraversion of line X(1)X(75), and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(799). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
<p></p>
X(799) lies on these lines:<br>2,873 63,561 75,897
88,274 99,100 110,789
162,811 190,670 310,333
645,651 689,813
</p><p>
X(799) = isogonal conjugate of X(798)<br>
X(799) = X(190)-cross conjugate of X(99)<br>
X(799) = trilinear pole of line X(1)X(75)<br>
X(799) = isotomic conjugate of X(661)<br>
X(799) = perspector of ABC and the tangential triangle, wrt the excentral triangle, of the bianticevian conic of X(1) and X(2) (see X(99))<br>
X(799) = X(6)-isoconjugate of X(512)<br>
X(799) = trilinear product X(6189)*X(6190) (the intercepts of Steiner circumellipse and line X(2)X(6))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X800">X(800) = CROSSPOINT OF X(2) AND X(64)</h3>
Trilinears sin A (cos<sup>2</sup>B + cos<sup>2</sup>C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin<sup>2</sup>A (cos<sup>2</sup>B + cos<sup>2</sup>C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (a^4 (b^2 + c^2) - 2 a^2 (b^2 - c^2)^2 + (b^2 - c^2)^2 (b^2 + c^2)) : :
<br>
Barycentrics (sin^2 A) (-2 + sin^2 B + sin^2 C) : :
<p>
X(800) lies on these lines:<br>{3,6}, {19,1945}, {41,2197}, {53,115}, {232,1196}, {393,1093},
{1015,3554}, {1033,2207}, {1194,5304}, {1195,1409}, {1500,3553},

X(800) = center of circumconic that is locus of trilinear poles of lines passing through X(2883)<br>

<h3 id="X804">X(804) = ODD (- 2, 2) INFINITY POINT</h3>

<p>
