<p>X(804) lies on these (parallel) lines: 2,351
30,511 98,878 99,670
115,1084 147,684 669,850</p>
<p>
X(804) = isogonal conjugate of X(805)<br>
X(804) = crosspoint of X(98) and X(99)<br>
X(804) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (511,512), (694,882), (741,875)<br>
X(804) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(694)<br>
X(804) = X(512)-Hirst inverse of X(523)<br>
X(804) = X(512) of 1st Brocard triangle<br>
X(804) = ideal point of PU(133)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X805">X(805) = o-(- 2, 2) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a
<sup>-3</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>) + a<sup>1</sup>(b
<sup>-2</sup> - c <sup>-2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the vertex-triangle of the 2nd and 3rd Brocard triangles. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(805). (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Brocard axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(805); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Lemoine axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(805); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(805) lies on the circumcircle and these lines: 98,385 99,512
110,669 111,694 187,729
249,827 574,843 691,882 888,892</p>
<p>
X(805) = isogonal conjugate of X(804)<br>
X(805) = isotomic conjugate of X(14295)<br>
X(805) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(694)<br>
X(805) = &Psi;(X(6), X(694))<br>
X(805) = cevapoint of X(511) and X(512)<br>
X(805) = reflection of X(99) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(805) = X(9831)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(805) = intersection of antipedal lines of X(98) and X(99)<br>
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X806">X(806) = ODD (- 2, 3) INFINITY POINT</h3>

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a <sup>-3</sup>(b<sup>3</sup> -
c<sup>3</sup>) + a<sup>2</sup>(b <sup>-2</sup> - c <sup>-2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(806)
lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(806) lies on this line: 30,511</p>
<p>X(806) = isogonal conjugate of X(807)<br></p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X807">X(807) = o-(- 2, 3) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a
<sup>-3</sup>(b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup>) + a<sup>2</sup>(b
<sup>-2</sup> - c <sup>-2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(807) lies on the circumcircle.</p>
<p>X(807) = isogonal conjugate of X(806)<br></p>

<br>
Trilinears sin 2A (sin^2 B - sin^2 C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a^2(b^2 - c^2)(b^2 + c^2 - a^2) : :
<br>
Trilinears tan B cot C - tan C cot B : :
<br>
Barycentrics sin<sup>2</sup>A cos A (cos<sup>2</sup>B - cos<sup>2</sup>C) : :
<p>
Let V = X(521)X(656) = isotomic conjugate of polar conjugate of antiorthic axis and let W = X(514)X(661) = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of antiorthic axis; then X(810 = V&cap;W. (Randy Hutson, December 26, 2015)

Let Q be a point on line X(2)X(31) other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A'; equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'/ Define B" and C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(825). (Randy Hutson, December 29, 2015)

<h3 id="X831">X(831) = o-(1, 3) CIRCUMCIRCLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>0</sup>(b<sup>3</sup>
- c<sup>3</sup>) + a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>1</sup> - c<sup>1</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(831) lies on the circumcircle.</p>
<p>X(831) lies on this line: 662,827</p>
<p>
X(831) = isogonal conjugate of X(830)<br>
X(831) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(38)<br>
X(831) = &Psi;(X(6), X(38))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X842">X(842) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(542)</h3>
Trilinears a/(2ax - by - cz) : :, where x = x(A,B,C) = sec(A + &omega;)
<br>
Barycentrics a^2/[2a^6 - 2a^4(b^2 + c^2) + a^2(b^4 + c^4) - (b^2 - c^2)^2(b^2 + c^2)] : :
<p>
Let L = X(74)X(98) or any line parallel to X(74)X(98). Let La be the line of reflection of L in line BC, and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb&cap;Lc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Then the lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(842). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the Artzt triangle. Let A" be the reflection of A' in BC, and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A"' be the reflection of A in B'C', and define B"' and C"' cyclically. Let A* = B"B"'&cap;C"C"', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines AA*, BB*, CC* concur in X(842). (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(842) is the antipode of X(691) on the circumcircle.
</p><p>
X(842) lies on these lines: 2,476 3,691
4,935 23,110 30,99
74,512 98,523 107,468
111,647 112,186 858,925
</p><p>
X(842) = reflection of X(691) in X(3)<br>
X(842) = isogonal conjugate of X(542)<br>
X(842) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(526)<br>
X(842) = &Lambda;(X(6), X(13))<br>
X(842) = &Psi;(X(6), X(526))<br>
X(842) = intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),X(23)}}<br>
X(842) = reflection of X(98) in the Euler line<br>
X(842) = reflection of X(74) in the Brocard axis<br>
X(842) = inverse-in-circle-O(15,16) of X(112)<br>
X(842) = inverse-in-{circumcircle, nine-point circle}-inverter of X(3258)<br>
X(842) = inverse-in-Moses-radical-circle of X(111)<br>
X(842) = SR(P,U), where P and U are the circumcircle intercepts of the Fermat axis<br>
X(842) = 2nd-Parry-to-ABC similarity image of X(23)<br>
X(842) = 3rd-Parry-to-circumsymmedial similarity image of X(110)<br>
X(842) = X(10787)-of-McCay-triangle<br>
X(842) = X(2709)-of-circumsymmedial-triangle<br>
X(842) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(14246)<br>
X(842) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(14357)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X844">X(844) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(166)X(167) AND X(173)X(503)</h3>

<h3 id="X845">X(845) = X(165)X(166)&cap;X(173)X(503)</h3>
Trilinears - x + y + z : : , where x = x(A,B,C) = sin<sup>2</sup>(A/2) sec(A/2)
<p>
This point solves a problem posed by Antreas Hatzipolakis in Hyacinthos #2768, May 3, 2001.
</p><p>
Let Ia, Ib, Ic be the excenters of a triangle ABC. Let A' be the Clawson point of IaBC, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(845). (Angel Montesdeoca, August 12, 2018)

<h3 id="X846">X(846) = 4th SHARYGIN POINT</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = - a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>
+ c<sup>2</sup> + bc + ca + ab<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= a f(a,b,c)
<p>This point solves a problem posed by Antreas Hatzipolakis in
Hyacinthos #3001, June 11, 2001. For the construction as a Sharygin
point, see the description at X(1281).</p>
<p></p>
<p>X(846) lies on these lines: 1,21 2,1054
6,1051 9,43 35,228
37,171 55,984 100,756
333,740 405,986 982,1001</p>
<p>
X(846) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (37,1), (171,43)<br>
X(846) = homothetic center of the excentral triangle and the antipedal triangle, wrt the incentral triangle, of X(1)<br>
X(846) = X(275)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(846) = excentral polar conjugate of X(3)<br>
X(846) = perspector of 1st Sharygin triangle and unary cofactor triangle of 2nd Sharygin triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X847">X(847) = X(5)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(4)</h3>
Trilinears sec A sec 2A : sec B sec 2B : sec C sec 2C
<br>
Barycentrics tan A sec 2A : tan B sec 2B : tan C sec 2C
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(a^2 (a^2 - b^2 - c^2) (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2)) : :<br>
<p>
This point solves a problem posed by Antreas Hatzipolakis in
Hyacinthos #3130, June 25, 2001; see also Jean-Pierre Ehrmann, #3135,
June 26, 2001. The problem and solution may be stated as follows. Let
ABC be a triangle, L<sub>A</sub>, L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> the
perpendicular bisectors of sides BC, CA, AB, and AA', BB', CC' the
altitudes of ABC, respectively. Let A<sub>B</sub> be the point of
intersection of AA' and L<sub>B</sub>, and let A<sub>C</sub> be the
point of intersection of AA' and L<sub>C</sub>. Let A" be the point of
intersection of BA<sub>B</sub> and CA<sub>C</sub>. Define B" and C"
cyclically. Then triangle A"B"C" is perspective to triangle ABC, with
perspector X(847).
<p>X(847) lies on the McCay orthic cubic; see <a href=
"http://perso.wanadoo.fr/bernard.gibert/Exemples/mccayorthic.html">McCay
orthic cubic</a>.
<p>Let A'B'C' be the X(3)-cevian triangle of the orthic triangle of
triangle ABC. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(847). (Randy Hutson,
9/23/2011)</p>
<p>X(847) lies on these lines: 2,254 3,925
4,52 24,96 91,225
378,1105 403,1093</p>
<p>
X(847) = isogonal conjugate of X(1147)<br>
X(847) = isotomic conjugate of X(9723)<br>
X(847) = polar conjugate of X(1993)<br>
X(847) = barycentric product X(91)*X(92)<br>
X(847) = X(5)-cross conjugate of X(4)<br>
X(847) = cevapoint of X(485) and X(486)</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X848">X(848) = YIU ANGLE POINT</h3>
Trilinears (csc A)/(cot A - cot A') : : , where A' = 2&pi;a/(a + b + c)
<br>
Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C) = 1/(cot A - cot A'), A' = 2&pi;a/(a + b + c)
<p>
X(848) point is introduced by Paul Yiu in Hyacinthos #2704, April 7,
2001 (see also #2708, April 10, 2001) as the solution X of the
equation</p>
<p>angle BXC : angle CXA : angle AXB = a : b : c.
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X849">X(849) = 4th HATZIPOLAKIS-YIU POINT</h3>
Trilinears [a/(b +
c)]<sup>2</sup> : [b/(c + a)]<sup>2</sup> : [c/(a + b)]<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics a[a/(b + c)]<sup>2</sup> : b[b/(c +
a)]<sup>2</sup> : c[c/(a + b)]<sup>2</sup>
<p>Let D denote the circumcircle of triangle ABC. Let D<sub>A</sub> be
the circle tangent to sideline BC and tangent to D at A. Let
B<sub>A</sub> = AC&cap;D<sub>A</sub> and C<sub>A</sub> =
AB&cap;D<sub>A</sub>, and define C<sub>B</sub>, C<sub>B</sub> and
A<sub>C</sub>, A<sub>B</sub> cyclically. Define A' =
C<sub>B</sub>A<sub>B</sub>&cap;A<sub>C</sub>B<sub>C</sub>, and define
B' and C' cyclically. Then triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC, and
X(849) is the center of homothety. See A. Hatzipolakis and P. Yiu,
Hyacinthos #2056-2070, December, 2000.</p>
<p>X(849) lies on these lines: 32,163 36,58
110,595 249,1110 741,827
757,763</p>
<p>
X(849) = isogonal conjugate of X(1089)<br>
X(849) = X(249)-Ceva conjugate of X(163)<br>
X(849) = crosspoint of X(58) and X(501)<br>
X(849) = crosssum of X(10) and X(502)<br>
X(849) = trilinear square of X(58)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X850">X(850) = BARYCENTRIC MULTIPLIER FOR KIEPERT HYPERBOLA</h3>
Trilinears (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/a<sup>3</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)/a<sup>2</sup> : :
<br>
Barycentrics csc A sin(B - C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics |AP(1)|^2 - |AU(1)|^2 : :
<p>
The barycentric product of X(850) and the circumcircle is the Kiepert hyperbola.
</p><p>
Let P1 and P2 be the two points on the de Longchamps line whose trilinear polars are parallel to the de Longchamps line. P1 and P2 lie on the Kiepert hyperbola and circle {{X(2), X(98), X(99)}}. X(850) is the barycentric product P1*P2. (Randy Hutson, June 7, 2019)
</p><p>
X(850) lies on these lines: 2,647 99,476
110,685 297,525 316,512
325,523 340,520 669,804 670,892
</p><p>
X(850) = isotomic conjugate of X(110)<br>
X(850) = anticomplement of X(647)<br>
X(850) = X(i)-Ceva conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (76,338), (99,311), (264,339)<br>
X(850) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (115,1502), (125,2), (338,76), (339,264)<br>
X(850) = crosspoint of X(95) and X(99)<br>
X(850) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (32,669), (39,647), (51,512)<br>
X(850) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(32)X(184)<br>
X(850) = isogonal conjugate of X(1576)<br>
X(850) = trilinear pole of line X(115)X(127) (polar of X(112) wrt polar circle)<br>
X(850) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(112) (line X(6)X(25))<br>
X(850) = polar conjugate of X(112)<br>
X(850) = intersection of trilinear polars of X(300) and X(301)<br>
X(850) = barycentric product X(76)*X(523)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X851">X(851) = X(65)-HIRST INVERSE OF X(73)</h3>
Trilinears sin 2B sin(C - A) + sin 2C sin(B - A) : :
<br>
Trilinears (cos A + cos B + cos C) csc A - (csc A + csc B + csc C) cos A : :
<br>
Trilinears (sec A + sec B + sec C) csc A - (csc A + csc B + csc C) sec A : :
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(851) has Shinagawa coefficients ($bcS<sub>B</sub>S<sub>C</sub>$,-$bc$S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(851) lies on these lines: 2,3 42,65
43,46 44,513 226,228</p>
<p>

X(851) = inverse-in-orthocentroidal-circle of X(1985)<br>
X(851) = crosssum of X(1) and X(851)<br>

<h3 id="X869">X(869) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(2) AND X(31)X(32)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where

= af(a,b,c)

55,893 100,731 101,743
192,1045 210,1107</p>

<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X870">X(870) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(869)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc)] : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the trilinear obverse triangle of X(2). Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line through A' parallel to BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A" = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B" and C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC at X(870). (Randy Hutson, November 30, 2018)
</p><p>
X(870) lies on these lines:<br>1,76 2,292 6,75 34,331
56,85 58,274 86,871
106,789 767,825
</p><p>
X(870) = isogonal conjugate of X(869)<br>
X(870) = isotomic conjugate of X(984)<br>
X(870) = trilinear pole of line X(649)X(693)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X871">X(871) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(869)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>4</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(871) lies on these lines:<br>2,561 75,700 76,335
86,870 310,982 675,789</p>
<p>X(871) = isotomic conjugate of X(869)</p>

<h3 id="X895">X(895) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(468)</h3>

<p>

<h3 id="X897">X(897) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(896)</h3>

<p>
Let A1B1C1 and A3B3C3 be the 1st and 3rd Parry triangles. Let A' be the trilinear product A1*A3, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(897). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>

840,1083

X(898) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(100)<br>

X(898) = &Psi;(X(650), X(8))<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X899">X(899) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(2) AND X(6)X(750)</h3>
Trilinears 1/b + 1/c - 2/a : 1/c + 1/a - 2/b : 1/a + 1/b - 2/c (Joe Goggins, 2002)
<br>
Barycentrics a(1/b + 1/c - 2/a) : b(1/c + 1/a - 2/b) : c(1/a + 1/b - 2/c)
<p>
X(899) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 6,750 38,210 44,513 55,748 88,291 100,238 244,518
</p><p>
X(899) = anticomplement of X(4871)<br>
X(899) = crosssum of X(1) and X(899)<br>
X(899) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1)X(649)<br>
X(899) = bicentric sum of PU(58)<br>
X(899) = PU(58)-harmonic conjugate of X(649)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X900">X(900) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(6) AND X(101)</h3>
Trilinears (b - c)(b + c - 2a)/a : :
<br>
Barycentrics (b - c)(b + c - 2a) : (c - a)(c + a - 2b) : (a - b)(a + b - 2c)
<p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point that lies on the circumcircle, X(900) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let I<sub>a</sub> be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define I<sub>b</sub> and I<sub>c</sub> cyclically; then X(900) = X(513) of I<sub>a</sub>I<sub>b</sub>I<sub>c</sub>. (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let Ua be the line through X(80) perpendicular to the line AX(80), and define Ub and Uc cyclically. Let Va be the reflection of BC in Ua, and define Vb and Vc cyclically. The lines Va, Vb, Vc are parallel, and they concur in X(900).
(Angel Montesdeoca, June 30, 2017)
</p><p>
X(900) lies on these (parallel) lines: 11,244 30,511 37,665 100,190 335,876 673,885 1635,1644
</p><p>
X(900) = isogonal conjugate of X(901)<br>
X(900) = complementary conjugate of X(3259)<br>
X(900) = X(80)-Ceva conjugate of X(11)<br>
X(900) = crosspoint of X(100) and X(104)<br>
X(900) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (55,654), (513,517), (649,902)<br>
X(900) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(101)<br>
X(900) = isotomic conjugate of X(4555)<br>
X(900) = X(523)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>
X(900) = trilinear pole of line X(1647)X(2087)<br>
X(900) = ideal point of PU(i) for these i: 121, 123<br>
X(900) = bicentric difference of PU(i) for these i: 121, 123<br>
X(900) = barycentric product X(514)*X(519)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X901">X(901) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(900)</h3>
Trilinears a/[(b - c)(b + c - 2a)] : :
<p>
Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line of reflection of line X(1)X(5) in line BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(901). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
</p><p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the antiorthic axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(901); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of the Nagel line and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(901). (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(901) lies on the circumcircle and these lines:<br>3,953 6,2384 36,106 55,840
59,109 88,105 100,513
101,649 104,517 484,759 675,903
</p><p>
X(901) = reflection of X(953) in X(3)<br>
X(901) = isogonal conjugate of X(900)<br>
X(901) = anticomplement of X(3259)<br>
X(901) = X(36)-cross conjugate of X(59)<br>
X(901) = &Psi;(X(2),X(45))<br>
X(901) = &Psi;(X(6),X(101))<br>
X(901) = reflection of X(100) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
X(901) = trilinear pole of line X(6)x(101)<br>
X(901) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1647)X(2087)<br>
X(901) = intersection of antipedal lines of X(100) and X(104)<br>
X(901) = trilinear product X(100)*X(106) (circumcircle-X(1) antipodes)<br>
X(901) = &Psi;(X(650),X(9))<br>
X(901) = barycentric product of circumcircle intercepts of line X(2)X(45)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X902">X(902) = CROSSPOINT OF X(6) AND X(106)</h3>
Trilinears a(b + c - 2a) : b(c + a - 2b) : c(a + b - 2c) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 - cos 2A - (1 + cos A)(cos B + cos C) : :
<br>
Barycentrics a<sup>2</sup>(b + c - 2a) : b<sup>2</sup>(c + a - 2b) : c<sup>2</sup>(a + b - 2c)
<p>
X(902) lies on these lines:<br>1,89 6,31 35,595 36,106
44,678 100,238 109,840
165,614 187,237 518,896
739,813 750,1001
</p><p>
X(902) = isogonal conjugate of X(903)<br>
X(902) = X(106)-Ceva conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(902) = crosspoint of X(6) and X(106)<br>
X(902) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,519), (88,1320), (900,1086)<br>
X(902) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(2)X(514)<br>
X(902) = trilinear pole of PU(99) (line X(1017)X(1960))<br>
X(902) = inverse-in-Parry-isodynamic-circle of X(5029); see X(2)<br>
X(902) = {X(31),X(42)}-harmonic conjugate of X(2308)<br>
X(902) = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of X(22356)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X903">X(903) = X(1)-BLAIKIE TRANSFORM OF X(2)</h3>
Trilinears bc/(b + c - 2a) : ca/(c + a - 2b) : ab/(a + b - 2c) : :
<br>
Barycentrics 1/(b + c - 2a) : 1/(c + a - 2b) : 1/(a + b - 2c) (Darij Grinberg, 12/28/02)
<p>
James Blaikie (1847-1929) proposed the following problem. Let O be any point in the plane of triangle ABC, and let any straight line g through O meet BC in P, CA in Q, AB in R; then, if points P', Q', R' be taken on the line so that
PO = OP', QO = OQ', RO = OR'. Prove that AP', BQ', CR' concur.
</p><p>
Darij Grinberg introduces the term <i>Blaikie point of O and g</i> for the point Z of concurrence. If
</p><p>
O
= x : y : z and g = [k : l : m] (barycentric coordinates),
</p><p>
then Z has first barycentric 1/[k(y-z) - (ly-mz)]. Given a point S = u : v : w, Grinberg then defines the <i>S-Blaikie transform of O</i> as the Blaikie point of O and OS. The first barycentric of Z can be written as
</p><p>
1/[yw(y+x) + zv(z+x) - yz(2u+v+w)].
</p><p>Seet <a href="http://mathforum.org/epigone/geometry-college/glexzhuntwyr">Blaikie theorem in barycentrics.</a> (Darij Grinberg, 12/28/02)
<p>
X(903) lies on the Steiner circumellipse and these lines:<br>2,45 7,528 27,648 75,537 86,99 310,670 320,519 335,536 350,889 527,666 675,901 812,1022
</p><p>
X(903) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (2,1086), (190,2)<br>
X(903) = isogonal conjugate of X(902)<br>
X(903) = isotomic conjugate of X(519)<br>
X(903) = X(i)-cross conjugate of X(j) for these (i,j): (320,86), (519,2)<br>
X(903) = Steiner-circumellipse-antipode of X(190)<br>
X(903) = anticomplement of X(4370)<br>
X(903) = projection from Steiner inellipse to Steiner circumellipse of X(1086)<br>
X(903) = antipode of X(2) in hyperbola {A,B,C,X(2),X(7)}<br>
X(903) = trilinear pole of line X(2)X(514)<br>
X(903) = pole wrt polar circle of trilinear polar of X(8756) (line X(4120)X(4895))<br>
X(903) = X(48)-isoconjugate (polar conjugate) of X(8756)<br>
X(903) = crossdifference of PU(99)<br>
X(903) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(1017)X(1960)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where

b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)

b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)]

<h3 id="X908">X(908) = POINT ACUBENS</h3>
Trilinears [(wb + vc)/a - v - w]/a, where u : v : w = X(3)
<br>
Barycentrics cos B + cos C - 1 : :
<br>
Barycentrics a^2 (b + c) - 2 a b c - (b - c)^2 (b + c) : :
<p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the antiorthic axis. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. Let A"B"C" be the reflection of A'B'C' in the antiorthic axis. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, with center of homothety X(908); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(908) lies on these lines:<br>1,998 2,7 4,78 5,72
8,946 10,994 11,518
12,960 80,519 92,264
100,516 119,517 153,515
214,535 224,1079 377,936
392,495 514,661
</p><p>
X(908) = reflection of X(1512) in X(119)<br>
X(908) = isogonal conjugate of X(909)<br>
X(908) = complement of X(3218)<br>
X(908) = crosssum of X(41) and X(902)<br>
X(908) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(31)X(663)<br>
X(908) = inverse-in-circumconic-centered-at-X(9) of X(63)<br>
X(908) = {X(2),X(7)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3306)<br>
X(908) = polar conjugate of isogonal conjugate of X(22350)<br>
X(908) = homothetic center of the complement of the excentral triangle and the anticomplement of the intouch triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

= af(a,b,c)

<h3 id="X918">X(918) = ISOTOMIC CONJUGATE OF X(666)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = (w/b - v/c)/a<sup>2</sup>, u : v : w = X(100)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= (b - c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> -ab - ac)
<p>As the isogonal conjugate of a point of the circumcircle, X(918)
lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(918) lies on these (parallel) lines: 30,511
63,654 190,644 1086,1111</p>
<p>

</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X919">X(919) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(918)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>/(w/b - v/c) : : , where u : v : w = X(100)
<p>
Let Q be a point on line X(2)X(11) other than X(2). Let A'B'C' be the cevian triangle of Q. Let A" be the {B,C}-harmonic conjugate of A' (or equivalently, A" = BC&cap;B'C'), and define B", C" cyclically. The circumcircles of AB"C", BC"A", CA"B" concur in X(919). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of line X(1)X(6) and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(919). (Randy Hutson, February 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(919) lies on the circumcircle and these lines:<br>6,840 99,666 100,650
101,663 103,672 104,294
105,910 106,1055 109,649
673,675 885,929
</p><p>
X(919) = isogonal conjugate of X(918)<br>
X(919) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(692)<br>
X(919) = &Psi;(X(i), X(j)) for these (i,j): (1,41), (2,11), (6,692), (76,8)<br>
X(919) = isogonal conjugate of isotomic conjugate of trilinear pole of line X(2)X(11)<br>
X(919) = circumcircle intercept, other than A, B, C, of conic {{A,B,C,PU(95)}}<br>
X(919) = trilinear product X(101)*X(105) (circumcircle-X(1) antipodes)<br>
X(919) = barycentric product X(100)*X(105) (circumcircle-X(2) antipodes)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X920">X(920) = X(158)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears f(A,B,C)
: f(B,C,A) : f(C,A,B),<br> where
f(A,B,C) = cos<sup>2</sup>B + cos<sup>2</sup>C - cos<sup>2</sup>A<br>Barycentrics g(A,B,C) : g(B,C,A) : g(C,A,B), where g(A,B,C)
= f(A,B,C) sin A
<p>X(920) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 4,46 4,78 9,498
19,91 57,499 158,921
201,601 243,1075</p>
<p>
X(920) = isogonal conjugate of X(921)<br>
X(920) = X(158)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<p>

<h3 id="X924">X(924) = CROSSDIFFERENCE OF X(5) AND X(6)</h3>
Trilinears b cos(A - B) - c cos(A - C) : :
<br>
Trilinears a (b^2 - c^2) (a^4 + b^4 + c^4 - 2 a^2 b^2 - 2 a^2 c^2) : :
<br>
Barycentrics sec 2B - sec 2C : :
<p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(924)
lies on the line at infinity.</p>
<p>X(924) lies on these (parallel) lines: 30,511
50,647 66,879 669,684</p>

X(924) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (3,523), (216,512)<br>

<h3 id="X927">X(927) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(926)</h3>
Trilinears 1/(bw - cv) : : , where u : v : w = X(7)
<p>
Let La, Lb, Lc be the lines through A, B, C, resp. parallel to the Gergonne line. Let Ma, Mb, Mc be the reflections of BC, CA, AB in La, Lb, Lc, resp. Let A' = Mb&cap;Mc, and define B' and C' cyclically. Triangle A'B'C' is inversely similar to, and 3 times the size of, ABC. The centroid of A'B'C' is X(927); see Hyacinthos #16741/16782, Sep 2008. (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A', B', C' be the intersections of line X(7)X(8) and lines BC, CA, AB, resp. The circumcircles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B' concur in X(927). (Randy Hutson, March 25, 2016)
</p><p>
X(927) lies on the circumcircle and these lines:<br>7,840 100,693 101,514
103,516 109,658 813,1025
</p><p>
X(927) = isogonal conjugate of X(926)<br>
X(927) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(7)<br>
X(927) = &Psi;(X(6), X(7))<br>
X(927) = &Psi;(X(41), X(1))<br>
X(927) = circumcircle-intercept, other than A, B, C, of conic {{A,B,C,PU(57)}<br>
X(927) = circumcircle-intercept, other than A, B, C, of conic {{A,B,C,PU(96)}}<br>
X(927) = intersection of antipedal lines of X(101) and X(103)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X940">X(940) = POINT ALDEBARAN</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b), where f(a,b,c) = a<sup>2</sup> + a(b +
c) + 2bc<br>Trilinears as + bc : bs + ca
: cs + ab<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
</p><p>
Let A' be the center of the conic through the contact points of the incircle and the A- excircle with the sidelines of ABC.
Define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the 4th extouch triangle at X(940). See also X(6), X(25), X(218), X(222), X(1743). (Randy Hutson, July 23, 2015)
</p><p>
X(940) lies on these lines:<br>
1,3 2,6 31,1001 37,63
42,750 58,405 72,975
222,226 312,894 386,474
387,443 518,612
</p><p>
X(940) = isogonal conjugate of X(941)<br>
X(940) = crosssum of X(11) and X(784)<br>
X(940) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(512)X(650)
</p> <p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X941">X(941) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(940)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>2</sup> + a(b + c) + 2bc]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(941) lies on these lines:<br>1,573 2,314 6,21 8,37
9,42 81,967 84,581 111,931</p>
<p>X(941) = isogonal conjugate of X(940)</p>
<p></p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X942">X(942) = INCIRCLE-INVERSE OF X(36)</h3>
Trilinears 2abc + (b + c)(a - b + c)(a + b -c) : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 + cos B + cos C : :
<br>
Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the incentral triangle of triangle ABC. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the line of reflection of line BC in line B'C', and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The lines AA'', BB'', CC'' concur in X(942). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
Let I be the incenter of ABC. Let N<sub>A</sub> be the nine-point center of the triangle IBC, and define N<sub>B</sub> and N<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of N<sub>A</sub> in the line AI, Let A<sub>B</sub> be the reflection of N<sub>A</sub> in the line BI, let Let A<sub>C</sub> be the reflection of N<sub>A</sub> in the line CI, and define B<sub>A</sub>, B<sub>B</sub>, and B<sub>C</sub> cyclically, and define C<sub>A</sub>, C<sub>B</sub>, and C<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let O<sub>A</sub> be the nine-point center of the triangle A<sub>A</sub>A<sub>B</sub>A<sub>C</sub>, let O<sub>B</sub> be the nine-point center of the triangle B<sub>A</sub>B<sub>B</sub>B<sub>C</sub>, and let O<sub>C</sub> be the nine-point center of the triangle C<sub>A</sub>C<sub>B</sub>C<sub>C</sub>. The circles O<sub>A</sub>, O<sub>B</sub>, O<sub>C</sub> concur in X(942). (Antreas Hatzipolakis and Cï¿½sar Lozada, January 28, 2015,
<a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/23074">Hyacinthos 23074)</a>
</p><p>
X(942) is the center of the conic which is the locus of poles, wrt the incircle, of tangents to the circumcircle. This conic has foci at X(1) and X(65). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the intouch triangle. Let A" be the orthocenter of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to A'B'C', and the center of homothety is X(942). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let A" be the incenter of AB'C', and define B" and C" cyclically. The triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to the intouch triangle, and the center of homothety is X(942). (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A' be the homothetic center of the orthic triangles of the intouch and A-extouch triangles, and define B' and C' cyclically. The triangle A'B'C' is perspective to the half-altitude triangle at X(942). In fact, A'B'C' is the cevian triangle of X(942), wrt the half-altitude triangle. (Randy Hutson, July 20, 2016)
</p><p>
A construction of X(942) is given at <a href="https://beta.groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/24090"> 24080</a>.
(Antreas Hatzipolakis, August 29, 2016)
</p><p>
X(942) lies on these lines:<br>
1,3 2,72 4,7 5,226 6,169 8,443 10,141 11,113 28,60 30,553 34,222 37,579 42,1066 58,1104 63,405 78,474 212,582 238,1046 277,1002 279,955 284,501 355,388 496,946 750,976 758,960 962,1058 1042,1064
</p><p>
X(942) = midpoint of X(1) and X(65)<br>
X(942) = reflection of X(960) in X(1125)<br>
X(942) = isogonal conjugate of X(943)<br>
X(942) = inverse-in-incircle of X(36)<br>
X(942) = complement of X(72)<br>
X(942) = X(1)-Ceva conjugate of X(500)<br>
X(942) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,79), (2,286), (7,81)<br>
X(942) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,35), (6,228), (37,55)<br>
X(942) = X(5)-of-the-intouch-triangle<br>
X(942) = anticomplement of X(5044)<br>
X(942) = X(1112) of Fuhrmann triangle<br>
X(942) = {X(1),X(40)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3295)<br>
X(942) = X(3)-of-inverse-in-incircle-triangle<br>
X(942) = X(4)-of-incircle-circles-triangle<br>
X(942) = X(6756)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(942) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(55)<br>
X(942) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(7)<br>
X(942) = QA-P23 (Inscribed Square Axes Crosspoint) of quadrangle ABCX(1) (see http://www.chrisvantienhoven.nl/quadrangle-objects/15-mathematics/quadrangle-objects/artikelen-qa/51-qa-p23.html)
</p> <hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X943">X(943) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(942)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br>
where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[2abc + (b + c)(a - b + c)(a + b - c)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(943) lies on these lines:<br>1,201 3,7 4,12 8,405
21,72 28,228 35,79
80,950 100,442 500,651
968,1039 1001,1058</p>
<p>
X(943) = isogonal conjugate of X(942)<br>
X(943) = cevapoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,35), (6,228), (37,55)<br>
X(943) = X(523)-cross conjugate of X(100)</p>
X(943) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(7)<br>
X(943) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(55)<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X944">X(944) = HOFSTADTER TRAPEZOID POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc[3a<sup>4</sup> - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(2ab + 2ac - 2bc - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - 2a<sup>2</sup>)]
<br>
Trilinears 1 - cos A - cos B - cos C + cos B cos C
<br>
Trilinears r - R cos B cos C : :
<b><br>
X(944) = 2 X(1) - X(4)
</b><p>
X(944) is the point in which the extended legs X(4)X(1) and X(3)X(8) of the trapezoid X(4)X(1)X(3)X(8) meet. The point is introduced in
</p><p>
<b>Hofstadter, Douglas. R.,</b> "Discovery and dissection of a geometric gem," in <i>Geometry Turned On!</i> editors J. R. King and D. Schattschneider, Mathematical Association of America, Washington, D. C., 1997, 3-14.
</p><p>
The centroid of ABC is also the centroid of triangle X(4)X(8)X(944). (Darij Grinberg, August 22, 2002)
</p><p>
Let Ha be the hyperbola passing through A, and with foci at B and C. This is called the A-Soddy hyperbola in (Paul Yiu, Introduction to the Geometry of the Triangle, 2002; 12.4 The Soddy hyperbolas, p. 143). Let La be the polar of X(3) with respect to Ha. Define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A' = Lb &cap; Lc, B' = Lc &cap; La, C' = La &cap; Lb. Triangle A'B'C' is homothetic to ABC, and its orthocenter is X(944). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
Let Ma be the polar of X(4) wrt the circle centered at A and passing through X(1), and define Mb, Mc cyclically. (Note: X(4) is the perspector of any circle centered at a vertex of ABC.) Let A" = Mb &cap; Mc, and define B" and C" cyclically. Triangle A"B"C" is homothetic to ABC, and its orthocenter is X(944). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(944) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,355 3,8 5,3616 10,631
20,145 30,962 40,376
48,281 80,499 84,1000
150,348 390,971 392,452
938,999 958,1006
</p><p>
X(944) = midpoint of X(20) and X(145)<br>
X(944) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (4,1), (8,3), (355,1385), (962,1482)<br>
X(944) = isogonal conjugate of X(945)<br>
X(944) = anticomplement of X(355)<br>
X(944) = crosspoint, wrt hexyl triangle, of X(1) and X(40)<br>
X(944) = X(185)-of-hexyl-triangle<br>
X(944) = outer-Garcia-to-inner-Garcia similarity image of X(4)<br>
X(944) = {X(1),X(4)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5603)<br>
X(944) = Ehrmann-mid-to-Johnson similarity image of X(1)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X945">X(945) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(944)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a/[3a<sup>4</sup> - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) + (b -
c)<sup>2</sup>(2ab + 2ac - 2bc - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> -
2a<sup>2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(945) lies on these lines: 78,517 283,859</p>
<p>X(945) = isogonal conjugate of X(944)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X946">X(946) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(4)</h3>
Trilinears bc[a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup> - ab - ac - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - 2bc)] : :
<br>
Trilinears r + 2 R cos B cos C : :
<br>
Trilinears 2 tan A + tan B + tan C + (sec A)(sin B + sin C) : :
<b><br>
X(946) = X(1) + X(4)
</b><p>
Let A' be the midpoint of BC, and define B' and C' cyclically. A" be the midpoint of AX(1), and define B" and C" cyclically. Let A"'B"'C"' be the incentral triangle. Let A* be the orthocenter of A'A"A"', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A"A*, B"B*, C"C* concur in X(946). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the intersection of these three lines: the perpendicular from midpoint of segment CA to line BX(1), the perpendicular from midpoint of segment AB to line CX(1), and the perpendicular from midpoint of segment AX(1) to line BC. Define B' and C' cyclically. The circumcenter of A'B'C' is X(946). Note that A'B'C' is the complement of the excentral triangle; also A'B'C' is the extraversion triangle of X(10). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
Let A' be the midpoint of A and X(1), and define B' and C' cyclically. The orthocenter of A'B'C' is X(946). (Randy Hutson, November 18, 2015)
</p><p>
X(946) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,40 3,142 5,10
7,84 8,908 11,65 29,102
30,551 46,499 56,1012
79,104 165,631 238,580
355,381 392,442 496,942
546,952 951,1067
</p><p>
X(946) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,4), (40,962)<br>
X(946) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (3,1125), (10,5)<br>
X(946) = inverse-in-incircle of X(1785)<br>
X(946) = isogonal conjugate of X(947)<br>
X(946) = complement of X(40)<br>
X(946) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (2,309), (7,92)<br>
X(946) = crosssum of X(48) and X(55)
X(946) = incenter-of-Euler-triangle</p>
X(946) = X(4)-of-3rd-Euler-triangle<br>
X(946) = X(20)-of-4th-Euler-triangle<br>
X(946) = X(113)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>
X(946) = center of conic that is the locus of orthopoles of lines passing through X(1)<br>
X(946) = radical center of circles centered at excenters and internally tangent to nine-point circle<br>
X(946) = harmonic center of 1st & 2nd Johnson-Yff circles<br>
X(946) = X(5446)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(946) = Johnson-to-Ehrmann-mid similarity image of X(1)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X947">X(947) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(946)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a/[a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(a<sup>2</sup>
- ab - ac - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup> - 2bc)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(947) lies on these lines:<br>29,515 40,77 48,282
73,102 219,572 581,1036
950,1067 951,1066</p>
<p>X(947) = isogonal conjugate of X(946)<br>X(947) = cevapoint of X(48) and X(55)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X948">X(948) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(4) AND X(6)X(7)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = bcvw[a<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + a(b +
c)<sup>2</sup> - (b - c)(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)],<br> where
u : v : w = X(9)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(948) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 2,85 6,7 37,347
57,169 142,269 220,329
307,966 342,393</p>
<p>X(948) = isogonal conjugate of X(949)<br>X(948) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line
X(652)X(926)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X949">X(949) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(948)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = au/[a<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + a(b +
c)<sup>2</sup> - (b - c)(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)],<br> where
u : v : w = X(9)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(949) lies on these lines:<br>1,607 2,294 3,41 6,77
48,1037 78,220</p>
<p>
X(949) = isogonal conjugate of X(948)</p>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X950">X(950) = CROSSPOINT OF X(8) AND X(29)</h3>
Trilinears bc(b + c - a)[2a<sup>3</sup> + (b + c)(a<sup>2</sup> + (b - c)<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<p>
Let A'B'C' be the Gergonne line extraversion triangle, as defined at X(10180). Let La be the reflection of line BC in line B'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb &cap; Lc, and define B" and C" cyclically. The lines AA", BB", CC" concur in X(950). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(950) lies on these lines:<br>1,4 8,9 10,55 11,214
20,57 29,284 30,553
35,1006 65,516 72,519
80,943 142,377 145,329
281,380 389,517 440,1104
947,1067</p>
<p>
X(950) = isogonal conjugate of X(951)<br>
X(950) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (7,333), (8,29)<br>
X(950) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (55,1400), (56,73)<br>
X(950) = X(185)-of-2nd-extouch-triangle<br>
X(950) = X(10)-of-Mandart-incircle-triangle<br>
X(950) = homothetic center of intangents triangle and reflection of extangents triangle in X(10)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X951">X(951) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(950)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a/[(b + c - a)[2a<sup>3</sup> + (b + c)(a<sup>2</sup> + (b -
c)<sup>2</sup>)]]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(951) lies on these lines:<br>29,226 56,219 57,78
73,284 77,738 946,1067 947,1066</p>
<p>X(951) = isogonal conjugate of X(950)<br>X(951) = cevapoint of X(56) and X(73)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X952">X(952) = INTERSECTION OF X(1)X(5) AND X(3)X(8)</h3>
Trilinears bc[2a<sup>4</sup> - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - 4bc + c<sup>2</sup>) + (2a - b - c)(b - c)(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(952) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
Let Ia be the reflection of X(1) in the perpendicular bisector of BC, and define Ib and Ic cyclically. X(952) = X(517) of IaIbIc, which is the inner Garcia triangle.. (Randy Hutson, September 14, 2016)
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the outer Garcia triangle and A"B"C" the inner Garcia triangle. Let A* be the isogonal conjugate, wrt A"B"C", of A', and define B* and C* cyclically. The lines A"A*, B"B*, C"C* concur in X(952); see also X(355). (Randy Hutson, December 2, 2017)
</p><p> X(952) lies on these (parallel) lines:<br>1,5 3,8 4,145 10,140 30,511 40,550 150,664 182,996 390,1000 546,946 547,551 572,594
</p><p>
X(952) = isogonal conjugate of X(953)<br>
X(952) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(6)X(654)<br>
X(952) = X(30)-of-Fuhrmann-triangle<br>
X(952) = inner-Garcia-isogonal conjugate of X(40)<br>
X(952) = X(5663)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X953">X(953) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(952)</h3>
Trilinears a/[2a<sup>4</sup> - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - 4bc + c<sup>2</sup>) + (2a - b - c)(b - c)(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Let L be the line tangent to the incircle and the nine-point circle; i.e., the line X(11)X(244), called the Feuerbach tangent line. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the reflection of L in BC, and define L<sub>B</sub> and L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A'' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B'' and C'' cyclically. The lines AA'', BB'', CC'' concur in X(953). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
For a construction of X(953) involving the Euler line and X(110), see Antreas Hatzipolakis and Cï¿½sar Lozada,
<a href="https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/Hyacinthos/conversations/messages/26959"> <b>Hyacinthos 26050</b></a>.
</p><p>
X(953) lies on the circumcircle and these lines: 3,901 36,109 100,517 104,513 110,859
</p><p>
X(953) = reflection of X(901) in X(3)<br>
X(953) = isogonal conjugate of X(952)<br>
X(953) = anticomplement of X(31841)<br>
X(953) = trilinear pole of line X(6)X(654)<br>
X(953) = &Psi;(X(6), X(654))<br>
X(953) = trilinear pole wrt 2nd circumperp triangle of line X(1001)X(2801)<br>
X(953) = X(476)-of-2nd-circumperp-triangle<br>
X(953) = reflection of X(104) in line X(1)X(3)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X954">X(954) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(3)X(7)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>5</sup> + (b + c)[2a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc) - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(2bc + ab + ac)] : :
<p>X(954) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 3,7 4,390 10,480
21,144 55,226 142,474
971,1012 999,1006</p>
<p>X(954) = isogonal conjugate of X(955)</p>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X955">X(955) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(954)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>5</sup> + (b + c)[2a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup> - a<sup>2</sup> + bc) - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(2bc + ab +
ac)]]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(955) lies on these lines: 57,991 278,354
279,942</p>
<p>X(955) = isogonal conjugate of X(954)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X956">X(956) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(3)X(8)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> - a(b - c)<sup>2</sup> - 2bc(b + c)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)<br><b>X(956) = 2X(1) - 3X(2) - (r/R)X(3) </b>
<p>X(956) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 2,495 3,8 10,56
21,145 55,519 63,517
183,668 210,997 333,859
388,442 452,1058</p>
<p>
X(956) = reflection of X(55) in X(993)<br>
X(956) = isogonal conjugate of X(957)<br>
X(956) = {X(1),X(9)}-harmonic conjugate of X(392)<br>
X(956) = X(55)-of-inner-Garcia-triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X957">X(957) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(956)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>3</sup> - a(b - c)<sup>2</sup> - 2bc(b + c)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)

81,859</p>

<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X958">X(958) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(2)X(12)</h3>
Trilinears (b + c - a)(a<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac + 2bc) : :
<br>
Barycentrics b + c + a cos A : :
<br><b>
X(958) = X(1) - 3X(2) - (r/R)X(3)<br>X(958) = r*X(3) + 2R*X(10)<br>X(958) = X(1) + X(8) + (r/R)*X(3)

452,497 944,1006</p>

</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

<h3 id="X960">X(960) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(6) AND X(5)X(10)</h3>

f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = (b + c - a)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + ab + ac)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)

<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X962">X(962) = LONGUET-HIGGINS POINT</h3>
Trilinears bc[a<sup>4</sup> + 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) - 4a<sup>2</sup>bc - (b + c)(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(2a + b + c)] : :
<br>
Trilinears sin B sin C + cos B + cos C - cos A - 1 : :
<br>
Trilinears cos B + cos C + cos B cos C - 1 : :
<br>
Trilinears 1 - 2 cos<sup>2</sup>(B/2) cos<sup>2</sup>(C/2) : :
<br>
Trilinears cos A' : :, where A' is the angle formed by the tangents from X(1) to the A-excircle
<p>
X(962) is shown in <b>Michael S. Longuet-Higgins,</b> "On the principal centers of a triangle," <i>Elemente der Mathematik</i> 56 (2001) 122-129, to complete a simple pattern of collinearities.
</p><p>
X(962) lies on these lines:<br>1,7 2,40 4,8 30,944
55,411 65,497 145,515
149,151 165,1125 278,412
382,952 392,443 484,499
942,1058
</p><p>
X(962) is the radical center of the circles centered at A, B, C, with respective<br>radii |CA| + |AB|, |AB| + |BC|, |BC| + |CA|. See
</p><p>
<b>Floor van Lamoen,</b> Problem 10734, <i>American Mathematical Monthly</i> 107 (2000) 658-659.
</p><p>
X(962) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (8,4), (20,1), (40,946), (944,1482)<br>
X(962) = isogonal conjugate of X(963)<br>
X(962) = anticomplement of X(40)<br>
X(962) = X(309)-Ceva conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(962) = {X(175),X(176)}-harmonic conjugate of X(77)<br>
X(962) = X(3)-of-2nd-Conway-triangle<br>
X(962) = perspector of 2nd Conway triangle and Gemini triangle 29<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X963">X(963) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(962)</h3>
Trilinears a/[a<sup>4</sup> + 2a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) - 4a<sup>2</sup>bc - (b + c)(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(2a + b + c)] : :
<br>
Trilinears sec A' : :, where A' is the angle formed by the tangents from X(1) to the A-excircle
<p>
X(963) lies on these lines: 3,200 33,56
48,220 55,603</p>
<p>X(963) = isogonal conjugate of X(962)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X964">X(964) = INTERCEPT OF EULER LINE AND LINE X(6)X(8)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = bc[a<sup>4</sup> + (b + c)(a<sup>3</sup> + ab<sup>2</sup> +
ac<sup>2</sup> + abc + (b + c)(a<sup>2</sup> + bc))]
<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>
As a point on the Euler line, X(964) has Shinagawa coefficients
(2(E + F)<sup>2</sup> + 2(E + F)*$bc$ + abc*$a$, 2S<sup>2</sup>).
</p><p>
X(964) lies on these lines: 1,321 2,3 6,8 10,31</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X965">X(965) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(2)X(6) AND X(3)X(9)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>4</sup> - a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) -
a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) + a(b + c)<sup>3</sup> +
2bc(b + c)<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(965) lies on these lines:<br>2,6 3,9 10,219 19,960
37,78 48,958 284,405 474,579</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X966">X(966) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(2)X(6) AND X(4)X(9)</h3>

<br>
Barycentrics a^2 - 2s^2 : :\
<p>

<br>

<h3 id="X969">X(969) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(10)X(69) AND X(19)X(81)</h3>

<h3 id="X970">X(970) CENTER OF THE APOLLONIUS CIRCLE</h3>
Trilinears a[a<sup>3</sup>(b + c)<sup>2</sup> + a(ab + ac - 2bc)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - bc(b<sup>3</sup> + c<sup>3</sup>) - a(b<sup>4</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>) - (b<sup>5</sup> + c<sup>5</sup>)] : :
<br>
Trilinears (r<sup>2</sup> - s<sup>2</sup>) cos A + 2rs sin A
<p>
The Apollonius circle is described at X(181) as the circle tangent
to the three excircles and encompassing them. That X(970) is its center
was noted on New Year's Day, 2002, by Paul Yiu. (Hyacinthos
#4619-4623)
</p><p>
The Apollonius circle is the inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of the nine-point circle. (Randy Hutson, December 10, 2016)
</p><p>
X(970) lies on these lines: 1,181 3,6 5,10 21,51 40,43 185,411
</p><p>
X(970) = complement of X(10441)<br>
X(970) = {X(181),X(1682)}-harmonic conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(970) = {X(371),X(372)}-harmonic conjugate of X(5019)<br>
X(970) = inverse-in-excircles-radical-circle of X(3814)<br>
X(970) = perspector of Apollonius triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and Apollonius triangle<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X971">X(971) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(3)X(9) AND X(4)X(7)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>4</sup>(b + c) - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - bc) + 2a(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc) - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b + c)<sup>3</sup> : :
<p>
X(971) is the perspector of triangle ABC and the tangential triangle of the conic that passes through the points A, B, C, X(2), and X(9). (Randy Hutson, 9/23/2011)
</p><p>
As the isogonal conjugate of a point on the circumcircle, X(971) lies on the line at infinity.
</p><p>
X(971) lies on these (parallel) lines:<br>1,1419 3,9 4,7 5,142 6,990
20,72 30,511 33,222
37,991 103,910 165,210
390,944 954,1012</p>
<p>
X(971) = isogonal conjugate of X(972)<br>
X(971) = crosssum of X(55) and X(910)<br>
X(971) = crosssum of X(32622) and X(32623)<br>
X(971) = intersection of trilinear polars of X(2) and X(9)<br>
X(971) = X(3564)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(971) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(7367)<br>
X(971) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(14256)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X972">X(972) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(971)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a<sup>4</sup>(b + c) - 2a<sup>3</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> - bc) + 2a(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup> + bc) - (b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b + c)<sup>3</sup>] : :
<p>
X(972) lies on the circumcircle and these lines:<br>3,934 40,101 55,108
100,329 109,165
</p><p>
X(972) = reflection of X(934) in X(3)<br>
X(972) = isogonal conjugate of X(971)<br>
X(972) = cevapoint of X(32622) and X(32623)<br>
X(972) = the point of intersection, other than A, B, and C, of the circumcircle and hyperbola {{A,B,C,X(4),X(40),X(57)}}<br>
X(972) = Cundy-Parry Phi transform of X(14256)<br>
X(972) = Cundy-Parry Psi transform of X(7367)<br>
</p><p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X973">X(973) = 1st EHRMANN POINT</h3>
<a id="FirstEhrmannPoint" name="FirstEhrmannPoint"></a>
Trilinears u[a<sup>10</sup> - 3a<sup>8</sup>s + a<sup>6</sup>(2b<sup>4</sup> + 3b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 2c<sup>4</sup>) + a<sup>4</sup>s(2b<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 2c<sup>4</sup>) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(3b<sup>4</sup> + 5b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + s(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> - b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>)] : : ,
<br>
where
u : v : w = X(51) and s = b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>
<p>
For constructions of X(973) and X(974), see Hyacinthos message 3695, Sept. 1, 2001, and related messages.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. X(973) is the radical center of the nine-point circles of AB'C', BC'A', CA'B'. (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(973) lies on these lines: 5,51 6,24 68,568
</p><p>
X(973) = midpoint of X(52) and X(1209)<br>
X(973) = crosssum of X(3) and X(1209)<br>
X(973) = X(442)-of-orthic-triangle if ABC is acute<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X974">X(974) = 2nd EHRMANN POINT</h3>
<a id="SecondEhrmannPoint" name="SecondEhrmannPoint"></a>
Trilinears [sa<sup>10</sup> - a<sup>8</sup>(3b<sup>4</sup> - 2b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 3c<sup>4</sup>) + a<sup>6</sup>s(2b<sup>4</sup> - 3b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 2c<sup>4</sup>) + a<sup>4</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(2b<sup>4</sup> - 7b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + 2c<sup>4</sup>) - 3a<sup>2</sup>s(b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> - 3b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>) + (b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)<sup>4</sup>(b<sup>4</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>c<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>4</sup>)] cos A, where s = b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>
<p>
For constructions of X(973) and X(974), see Hyacinthos message 3695, Sept. 1, 2001, and related messages.
</p><p>
Let A'B'C' be the orthic triangle. Let La be the orthic axis of AB'C', and define Lb and Lc cyclically. Let A" = Lb&cap;Lc. B" = Lc&cap;La, C" = La&cap;Lb. Triangle A"B"C" is inversely similar to ABC, with similitude center X(6). The orthocenter of triangle A"B"C" is X(974). (Randy Hutson, January 29, 2018)
</p><p>
X(974) lies on these lines: 5,113 6,74
</p><p>
X(974) = midpoint of X(125) and X(185)<br>
X(974) = reflection of X(1112) in X(389)<br>
X(974) = crosssum of X(3) and X(113)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X975">X(975) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(2) AND X(3)X(37)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> + a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + a(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup> + 4bc) + (b + c)<sup>3</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(975) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,37 9,58 28,33
35,968 46,750 57,201
72,940 226,1038 312,1010</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">

f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> + (b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)

<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X978">X(978) = X(56)-CEVA CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + a(b<sup>2</sup> - bc + c<sup>2</sup>) - bc(b + c) : :
<br>
Trilinears csc^2(B/2) + csc^2(C/2) - csc^2(A/2) : :
<p>
X(978) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,238 9,39 21,748
31,404 40,1050 46,1054
56,979 57,1046 58,87
72,982 171,474 266,361
631,1064 651,1106 960,986
</p><p>
X(978) = isogonal conjugate of X(979)<br>
X(978) = X(56)-Ceva conjugate of X(1)<br>
X(978) = X(1093)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X979">X(979) = X(8)-CROSS CONJUGATE OF X(1)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) + a(b<sup>2</sup> - bc +
c<sup>2</sup>) - bc(b + c)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(979) lies on these lines: 10,87 43,58
56,978</p>
<p>X(979) = isogonal conjugate of X(978)<br>X(979) = X(8)-cross conjugate of X(1)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X980">X(980) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(3) AND
X(2)X(39)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup>) +
(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)(bc + ca + ab)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(980) lies on these lines: 1,3 2,39
32,81 38,869 63,213</p>
<p>X(980) = isogonal conjugate of X(981)<br>X(980) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line
X(650)X(669)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X981">X(981) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(980)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup>) + (b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)(bc + ca + ab)] : :
<p>X(981) lies on these lines: 6,314 8,213
21,32 256,573
</p><p>
X(981) = isogonal conjugate of X(980)<br>
X(981) = trilinear pole of line X(650)X(669)<br> </p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X982">X(982) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(3) AND X(2)X(38)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = b<sup>2</sup> - bc + c<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>
X(982) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 2,38 7,256 43,518
58,977 63,238 72,978
81,985 222,613 226,262
240,278 257,330 310,871
312,726 404,976 758,995
846,1001</p>
<p>
X(982) = isogonal conjugate of X(983)<br>
X(982) = isotomic conjugate of X(7033)<br>
X(982) = crosspoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (7,330), (81,310)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X983">X(983) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(982)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[b<sup>2</sup> - bc + c<sup>2</sup>]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)

8,238 21,976 55,256</p>

<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X984">X(984) = MIDPOINT OF X(8) AND X(192)</h3>
Trilinears b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup> : :
<p>
Let A<sub>15</sub>B<sub>15</sub>C<sub>15</sub> and A<sub>16</sub>B<sub>16</sub>C<sub>16</sub> be Gemini triangles 15 and 16, resp. Let L<sub>A</sub> be the tangent at A to conic {{A,B<sub>15</sub>,C<sub>15</sub>,B<sub>16</sub>,C<sub>16</sub>}}, and define L<sub>B</sub>, L<sub>C</sub> cyclically. Let A' = L<sub>B</sub>&cap;L<sub>C</sub>, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(984). (Randy Hutson, January 15, 2019)
</p><p>
X(984) lies on these lines:<br>1,6 2,38 8,192 10,75
21,976 43,210 55,846
63,171 100,753 101,761
201,388 240,281 386,872
519,751 936,988
</p><p>
X(984) = midpoint of X(8) and X(192)<br>
X(984) = reflection of X(i) in X(j) for these (i,j): (1,37), (75,10)<br>
X(984) = isogonal conjugate of X(985)<br>
X(984) = isotomic conjugate of X(870)<br>
X(984) = complement of polar conjugate of isogonal conjugate of X(22163)<br>
X(984) = {X(1),X(9)}-harmonic conjugate of X(238)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X985">X(985) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(984)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup>]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(985) lies on these lines:<br>1,32 2,31 6,291 58,274
81,982 105,825 279,1106 727,789</p>
<p>X(985) = isogonal conjugate of X(984)</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X986">X(986) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(3) AND X(8)X(38)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup>) + b<sup>3</sup> +
c<sup>3</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(986) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 4,240 6,1046 8,38
10,75 43,72 100,976
194,257 291,337 386,758
405,846 474,1054 774,938
960,978</p>

<p></p>

f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a(b<sup>2</sup> + bc + c<sup>2</sup>) + b<sup>3</sup> +

<h3 id="X988">X(988) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(3) AND X(9)X(39)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) - (3a + b +
c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(988) lies on these lines:<br>1,3 9,39 21,614 38,78

<h3 id="X989">X(989) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(988)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = 1/[a<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) - (3a + b +
c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)]<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(989) lies on these lines: 21,612 40,256
84,171</p>

<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X990">X(990) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(7) AND X(3)X(37)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>5</sup> - a<sup>4</sup>(b + c) - 2a<sup>3</sup>bc -
a(b - c)<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) + (b -
c)<sup>2</sup>(b + c)<sup>3</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(990) lies on these lines:<br>1,7 3,37 6,971 33,57
58,84 165,612 226,1040
</p><p>
X(990) = complement, wrt hexyl triangle, of X(12717)<br> <p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X991">X(991) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(1)X(7) AND X(3)X(6)</h3>
Trilinears a[a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) - a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> - bc + c<sup>2</sup>) - a(b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) + (b - c)(b<sup>3</sup> - c<sup>3</sup>)] : :
<br>
Trilinears sin(A + U) : : , where tan U = tan(A/2) tan(B/2) tan(C/2) (Joe Goggins,11/26/08)
<br>
Barycentrics (sin A)[cos(A - arccot(p))] : : , where p = (r + 4R)/s
<b><br>
X(991) = X(3) + ((cot &omega;)/p)X(6) = 3 X[3576] - X[6210]
</b><p>
The function p = (r + 4R)/s is the Tucker parameter for X(991); see the preamble to X(13323.)
</p><p>
X(991) lies on the cubic K382 and these lines:<br>
{1,7}, {2,5400}, {3,6}, {4,4648}, {9,1818}, {22,1790}, {35,255}, {36,1471}, {37,971}, {42,165}, {43,10164}, {45,5779}, {48,3220}, {51,4191}, {55,103}, {57,955}, {63,3190}, {73,1394}, {78,4416}, {81,1754}, {84,2335}, {212,2003}, {223,10383}, {241,5728}, {394,2328}, {550,5453}, {601,10902}, {741,6011}, {940,7580}, {942,1418}, {954,6180}, {968,1709}, {975,1490}, {984,2801}, {993,6518}, {995,1064}, {999,8147}, {1011,3917}, {1012,4653}, {1038,10393}, {1062,8555}, {1193,7987}, {1214,10391}, {1279,1385}, {1283,5197}, {1308,12032}, {1396,4219}, {1427,11018}, {1456,2646}, {1469,2223}, {1699,3720}, {1724,6986}, {1736,10394}, {1768,4414}, {1779,2979}, {2177,5537}, {2195,7295}, {2318,3929}, {2340,5223}, {2594,5217}, {2635,5219}, {2700,2701}, {2999,10857}, {3060,4210}, {3214,9588}, {3216,3523}, {3666,10167}, {3730,3781}, {3752,11227}, {3912,12618}, {3931,9943}, {4551,5218}, {4644,5759}, {4649,9441}, {4658,5706}, {4675,5805}, {5292,6908}, {5713,6851}, {6051,12688}
</p><p>
X(991) = reflection of X(573) in X(3)<br>
X(991) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(523)X(657)<br>
X(991) = crosssum of X(i) and X(j) for these {i,j}: {1,4312}, {11,4724}<br>
X(991) = inverse-in-Schoute-circle of X(4262)<br>
X(991) = X(264)-of-2nd-circumperp-triangle<br>
X(991) = perspector of excentral-hexyl ellipse wrt hexyl triangle<br>
X(991) = intersection of Brocard axes of ABC and hexyl triangle<br>
X(991) = {X(371),X(372)}-harmonic conjugate of X(4251)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X992">X(992) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(2)X(6) AND X(9)X(39)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup>(b + c) + a<sup>2</sup>(b<sup>2</sup> +
c<sup>2</sup>) - abc(b + c) - bc(b + c)<sup>2</sup><br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(992) lies on these lines: 2,6 9,39
44,583 238,1009</p>
<p></p>
<hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X993">X(993) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(63)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> - a(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>) - bc(b +
c)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)<br><b>X(993) = X(1) - 3X(2) - 2(r/R)X(3) </b>
<p>X(993) lies on these lines:<br>1,21 2,36 3,10 8,35
9,48 32,1107 55,519
56,226 75,99 87,106
238,995 495,529 516,1012
527,551 912,960</p>
<p>X(993) = midpoint of X(i) and X(j) for these (i,j): (1,63),
(55,956), (1012,3428)<br>X(993) = reflection of X(226) in X(1125)<br>X(993) = isogonal conjugate of X(994)<br>X(993) = complement of X(1478)</p>

f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where

<h3 id="X995">X(995) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(43)</h3>
Trilinears f(a,b,c)
: f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a(ab + ac - bc + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c)
= af(a,b,c)
<p>X(995) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,595 6,101 31,36
56,58 57,957 238,993
581,1104 609,1055 758,982
991,1064</p>
<p>X(995) = midpoint of X(1) and X(43)<br>X(995) = isogonal conjugate of X(996)<br>X(995) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line
X(649)X(900)
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X996">X(996) = INTERSECTION OF LINES X(8)X(58) AND X(10)X(56)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a(ab + ac - bc + b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<p>
X(996) lies on these lines: 2,106 6,519
8,58 10,56 182,952
</p><p>

</p>hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X997">X(997) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(200)</h3>
Trilinears
f(a,b,c) : f(b,c,a) : f(c,a,b),<br> where
f(a,b,c) = a<sup>3</sup> - a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) - a(b - c)<sup>2</sup>
+ (b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> + c<sup>2</sup>)<br>Barycentrics g(a,b,c) : g(b,c,a) : g(c,a,b), where g(a,b,c) = af(a,b,c)
<p>X(997) lies on these lines:<br>1,2 3,960 9,48 21,90

55,392 56,72 57,758

X(997) = isogonal conjugate of X(998)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X998">X(998) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(997)</h3>

a<sup>2</sup>(b + c) - a(b - c)<sup>2</sup> + (b + c)(b<sup>2</sup> +

= af(a,b,c)

46,58 106,614</p>
<p>
X(998) = isogonal conjugate of X(997)</p>
<p></p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X999">X(999) = MIDPOINT OF X(1) AND X(57)</h3>
Trilinears 2 - cos A : 2 - cos B : 2 - cos C (Joe Goggins, 2002)
<br>
Trilinears a(a^2 + 4bc - b^2 - c^2) : :
<p>
X(999) is the radical center of the mixtilinear incircles.
</p><p>
X(999) lies on these lines: 1,3 2,495
4,496 5,388 6,101 7,104
8,474 11,381 12,499
20,1058 30,497 63,392
77,1057 78,1059 81,859
145,404 329,405 376,390
518,997 527,551 601,1106
938,944 954,1006
</p><p>
X(999) is the {X(1),X(56)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3). For a list of other harmonic conjugates of X(999), click <b>Tables</b> at the top of this page.
</p><p>
X(999) = midpoint of X(1) and X(57)<br>
X(999) = isogonal conjugate of X(1000)<br>
X(999) = complement of X(3421)<br>
X(999) = X(89)-Ceva conjugate of X(6)<br>
X(999) = crossdifference of every pair of points on line X(650)X(900)<br>
X(999) = {X(1),X(3)}-harmonic conjugate of X(3295)<br>
X(999) = {X(55),X(56)}-harmonic conjugate of X(36)<br>
X(999) = X(25)-of-incircle-circles-triangle<br>
X(999) = X(1596)-of-excentral-triangle<br>
X(999) = homothetic center of outer Yff triangle and cross-triangle of ABC and 1st Johnson-Yff triangle<br>
X(999) = homothetic center of anti-incircle-circles triangle and anti-tangential midarc triangle<br>
X(999) = polar conjugate of isotomic conjugate of X(22129)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
<h3 id="X1000">X(1000) = ISOGONAL CONJUGATE OF X(999)</h3>
Trilinears 1/[a(a<sup>2</sup> + 4bc - b<sup>2</sup> - c<sup>2</sup>)] : :
<br>
Trilinears 1/(2 - cos A) : :
<p>
Let A* be the parabola with focus A and directrix BC, and let A** be the polar of X(1) with respect to A*. Define B** and C** cyclically, and let A' = B**&cap;C**, and define B' and C' cyclically. The lines AA', BB', CC' concur in X(1000); the centroid of A'B'C' is X(5657). (Randy Hutson, July 7, 2014)
</p><p>
X(1000) lies on these lines:<br>1,631 7,517 8,392 9,519 21,145 55,104 65,3296 79,388 80,497 84,944 390,952
</p><p>
X(1000) = isogonal conjugate of X(999)<br>
X(1000) = X(45)-cross conjugate of X(2)<br>
X(1000) = perspector of ABC and mid-triangle of excentral and extouch triangles<br>
X(1000) = trilinear pole of line X(650)X(900)<br>
</p><hr noshade size="4" width="50%">
